HEADLINE: YELTSIN, ADMITTING ECONOMIC DISTRESS, ASKS FOR PATIENCE

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 1

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin, opening a session of the Russian Congress, acknowledged today that his economic changes were shriveling the living standards of most Russians. But he insisted that a change in course was not the answer.
In a speech to 1,041 deputies in the glittering Grand Kremlin Palace, Mr. Yeltsin asked for "a respite of a year to a year and a half" from the disputes over his program, but preliminary skirmishes suggested that the session would not pass peacefully. 
 Mr. Yeltsin also proposed a nationwide referendum on a new Constitution that would finally define the powers of the executive and the legislature.
 
Murmurs, Not Cheers
 "The transformations in Russia have lately become a subject of controversy and fierce struggle," he said. "Colossal political overloads and confrontations among various political forces have become an evil plaguing Russia's economy. The inability and the unwillingness to look for compromise is turning into a serious factor impeding the reform."
The President's appeals drew only a skeptical murmur, as did a proposal to have the state replenish savings accounts wasted away by inflation, an idea that seemed intended to attract waning public support for the Government's drive to create a free-market economy.
The two other main speakers at the opening session of the highest legislative body in Russia -- the Speaker, Ruslan Khasbulatov, and the president of the Constitutional Court, Valery Zorkin -- also spoke in alarmed terms of the crisis enveloping the nation and called for joint efforts to resolve it.
 
A Different Remedy
 But their prescriptions clashed sharply with those of Mr. Yeltsin, and it was a measure of the mood in the hall that Mr. Yeltsin drew by far the weakest ovation.
Mr. Khasbulatov, a leader of the opposition, was fervently applauded when he declared that there had been a "complete collapse of Government economic policy." He accused the Government of trying to impose an "American model" on Russia instead of a "socially oriented market economy" for which it was more suited.
Mr. Zorkin, making the first appearance before the Congress by a representative from Russia's highest court, delivered an emotional appeal to the deputies to halt the disintegration. "We have slid into poverty, and impoverished people have never formed a basis for a law-based state," he said to a hushed assembly. "Save Russia! Russia is in your hands!"
How the Congress might proceed was the subject of animated and widely differing speculation in the ornate halls and nooks of the Kremlin. The session is likely to last at least a week.
But the strong statements by Mr. Yeltsin's two antagonists and the early jousting indicated that the main battles will be less over this Government than over how future governments would be formed.
The President's basic appeal was for a period of stabilization during which Congress would give him considerable leeway in economic and administrative matters. He asked also that a law on government be postponed until a new constitution is adopted.
In exchange, Mr. Yeltsin would agree not to seek an extension of his special power to impose edicts and would agree to have his candidate for Prime Minister approved by the Congress.
The issue is especially focused on future governments because the extraordinary powers to govern by decree, which Congress gave Mr. Yeltsin a year ago, expired today.
 
Balancing Vetoes
 Last month Mr. Yeltsin vetoed a measure adopted by the smaller sitting Parliament that would require the legislature's approval of a Prime Minister. It was this discussion that Mr. Yeltsin especially wanted to postpone.
But Mr. Khasbulatov has indicated that he will bring the bill requiring such approval before the full Congress, and foes of the current Cabinet won a vote today on adding to the agenda a separate discussion on the Prime Minister. Unlike the sitting Parliament, the Congress cannot be overruled by the President.
The procedural skirmishes that mark the opening day of Russian Congresses confirmed that neither the die-hard foes of the Government nor its supporters have enough votes on their own to have their way.
The hard-liners failed in attempts to raise the issue of Mr. Yeltsin's impeachment and to prevent the Acting Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar, from speaking on Wednesday; they argued that it is the President who must take responsibility for economic policy.
The disposition of the forces also confirmed that the deciding vote belonged to the center and its new coalition, Civic Union. Many of the coalition's primary positions were laid out today by Mr. Khasbulatov, the powerful Speaker, suggesting that he would ally himself with the centrists.
Most deputies agreed that the President's speech was somewhat more muted than those of the past. Though his delivery was as vigorous as ever, the confessions of hardships and the calls for compromise reflected a leader in trouble.
"We must say directly that for the majority of the population, the reforms are for the moment only increasing the problems and difficulties," Mr. Yeltsin said. And again later: "Against the background of considerable deterioration of living standards of most of the population, a rapid and in many aspects unjustified social differentiation is making itself acutely felt."
 
Placing the Blame
 Mr. Yeltsin argued that the deputies were much to blame for the laggard pace of change through their constant opposition to the Government.
"How many contradictions could have been removed, how many mistakes avoided, if the Supreme Soviet had abandoned its attitude to the Government as to a junior?" he asked.
At the same time, Mr. Yeltsin insisted that he had no intention of trying to dissolve the Congress, which was elected in 1990 under the old Soviet Union, as some of his supporters have demanded.
"Let me make known my stand on this," he said. "Starting the stabilization period by destroying any of the supreme institutions of power is absurd."
Mr. Yeltsin also extended an olive branch to Civic Union, whose core is the Union of State Industrial Managers, by inviting cooperation from "business people and industrialists."
The Yeltsin proposals drew skeptical comments. Vasily Lipitsky, a leader of Civic Union, said the deputies would not likely support a proposal that "narrows the scope of the Parliament and deprives deputies of any levers of influence over Government activities."
Mr. Khasbulatov did not directly reject Mr. Yeltsin's request for a respite from criticism or opposition. A stabilization period was needed, he said in his speech, "but it would hardly be correct to allow a deviation from the constitution and the laws during this period."
He also joined in the call for civil concord, but in a formulation that was hardly enthusiastic: "We are doomed to be united by the current situation."
Such comments contributed to speculation that a compromise was in the making. But Mr. Khasbulatov's speech, and the enthusiasm it generated in the hall, made clear that the struggle for the fundamental shape of the reforms was well under way.
 
Defining the Problem
 Following the arguments of the Civic Union, Mr. Khasbulatov declared that the fall in economic production was the "No. 1 problem." Mr. Yeltsin, in contrast, had declared the main problem to be inflation.
The difference was central to the debate. Civic Union, and Mr. Khasbulatov, have argued that the state should intervene to brake the fall in production by propping up state industries and reimposing some controls on prices. Mr. Gaidar, the Acting Prime Minister, recently declared that there would be no revival of extensive Government interference or controls on the economy.
Which way the Congress leaned was clear. But whether it was prepared to change the orientation of reform was far less clear. The betting in the hallways was that Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gaidar would prevail, but at what cost and with what wounds, nobody was prepared to predict.

HEADLINE: Transition Team Stalled on Ethics Rules

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 1

 BODY:
Nearly three weeks after President-elect Bill Clinton said tighter ethics rules for Administration appointees would be forthcoming, transition officials acknowledged today that they were having trouble producing the restrictions.
The timing is important because aides said Mr. Clinton is on the verge of making his first round of appointments, with announcements for major economic posts tentatively planned for late next week, after he returns from a two-day trip to Washington. Before accepting a position in the new Administration, candidates would presumably want to know how their lobbying would be restricted after they left Government, one of the issues to be addressed by the rules. 
 George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director, said at a news briefing today that the delay was simply because officials had "to get all the lawyers working on it." He said he hoped the restrictions, intended to slow the pace of Administration officials' leaving Government and lobbying the Administration, would be completed by Christmas.
 
Complicated Rule-Making
 Other transition officials, speaking on the condition that they not be identified, said developing the rules was far more complicated than expected.
The only elements of the rules that were certain, the officials said, are what Mr. Clinton promised in the campaign: that some appointees would sign a pledge not to lobby agencies within their responsibilities for five years after leaving office (the current ban is for one year), and that the officials would have to agree never to become registered agents on behalf of any foreign government.
But the officials, who said a draft of the rules has yet to be completed, explained that questions still needed to be resolved over critical issues like what level of appointees should be subjected to the rules. As many as all of the 3,000 political jobs in the Administration could be covered by the rules, they said, or only the top 700 posts that are mostly at the Cabinet or sub-Cabinet levels. Another important unresolved issue, they said, is defining what constitutes lobbying an administration.
"There's not a big internal fight about pulling back," said one official. "But it's very complicated stuff. Unlike the transition ethics rules, this is going to bind everyone."
 
Appointments Before Christmas
 Mr. Stephanopoulos said, "Hopefully, we'll have a fair amount of the Cabinet positions done before Christmas."
Other aides to Mr. Clinton said that before Thanksgiving he submitted a short list of initial appointments for background checks and that in most cases more than one name was given so there would be alternate choices. The officials said separate background checks of the same individuals were being conducted by lawyers hired by the transition office and by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Mr. Clinton's decision-making has been so closely held that only a handful of his advisers know whom he is selecting for important positions, aides said.
So far, the Clinton camp has asked the F.B.I. to screen dozens of potential appointees but has only requested full investigations on fewer than a half-dozen candidates for high-level jobs, including some Cabinet posts, law-enforcement officials said today.
The transition officials said the economy policy cluster of announcements would likely include the heads of the Treasury Department, the Office of Management and Budget, the Commerce Department, the Council of Economic Advisers and Mr. Clinton's economic security counsel.
 
Perot Invitation Questionable
 In addition to underscoring that the economy is his top priority, the officials said Mr. Clinton wanted to announce the economic appointments first so the names would be out before the economic conference economy that he has called here for Dec. 14 and 15. Invitations to more than 100 people will be sent later this week, the officials said.
Organizers of the event said they had made a preliminary decision not to invite Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who made the deficit his priority in his run for President. With Mr. Perot on hand, as one Clinton adviser said: "It would become a huge political event. We wouldn't accomplish anything and it would be an impossible situation."
The organizers also said they would not invite the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who said last week that he expected to be included.
Mr. Clinton spent most of his first full day back from his California holiday in the Governor's mansion. He met with Vice President-elect Al Gore and other close advisers and also with Donna Shalala of the University of Wisconsin, a possible candidate for Education Secretary.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Federal Reserve Board chairman told a key Congressman that the central bank was considering whether to reduce its targets for money supply growth next year. Such a move could upset politicians who have criticized the Fed for falling below its monetary growth targets, saying that this was an important reason the economic recovery has been so weak. [Page D1.]
The index of leading indicators, the Government's main forecasting index, advanced four-tenths of 1 percent for October after two straight monthly declines. [D1.] 
 Higher spending on new single-family homes helped push total construction outlays up 1 percent in October to the highest level in more than two years. [D2.]
In an indication of the state of the manufacturing economy, the nation's purchasing managers said their index of economic activity increased to 55 percent in November, the highest since May. [D2.]
 
Companies
Disney's chairman and its president sold more than $200 million of their company's stock, citing "the strong likelihood of impending tax legislation" under a Clinton Administration. [D1.]
Investigations of unusual stock activity in Comptronix focuses on an Alabama businessman who may have profited before the company said that senior management inflated earnings. [D1.]
Texas Instruments named Clayton K. Yeutter to its board. The former Agriculture Secretary and trade official once led semiconductor talks with Japan that helped Texas Instruments. [D4.]
Dell Computer introduced an upgraded line of personal computers it expects to produce $1 billion in sales next year. [D4.]
McDonnell Douglas's move to curtail medical coverage for retirees has been challenged in court by former employees. [D4.]
Northwest Airlines is said to be close to a $250 million cash infusion from suppliers, an equity holder and its banks. [D4]
Lehman Brothers named a veteran trader from Smith Barney as a managing director and head of equity trading. [D5.]
 
International
A new trade war is breaking out in dog breeding. Canada, responding to public unease about the health of puppies imported from the United States, is preparing new regulations that would severely curb the dog trade. [D1.]
More Japanese are looking for jobs than there are jobs to be had, the first such condition in four and a half years. [D20.]
 
Business Technology
A new system to help computers recognize pictures was announced by the David Sarnoff Research Center, which has set up a new company to market the products. [D4.]
Amtrak is testing a high-speed electric train developed in Sweden to speed passenger service in the Northeast Corridor. [D6.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks were hurt by profit taking. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.80 points, to 3,294.36. [D8.]
A forecast of bond market economists for interest rates next year depends on whether the Clinton Administration will produce a credible deficit-reduction program. [D16.]
Grain prices fell sharply and oil prices and natural gas prices declined. [D17.] The dollar fell against most currencies and gold rose slightly in New York. [D17.]
 
Today's Columns
Tokos Medical was criticized by the American Medical Association for paying physicians to use its controversial home treatments for pregnant women. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D8.]
Dr Pepper is faring better in the intensely competitive soft-drink industry after shifting its image from a niche-market product to one with wider appeal. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Hostility Greets Students at Black School in White Area of Detroit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 1

 BODY:
When the virtually all-black Malcolm X Academy moved into a virtually all-white pocket of Detroit this fall, the reception was so hostile it reminded many people of Little Rock in 1957, not Detroit in 1992.
About 30 police officers patrolled the school and a police helicopter circled overhead. 
 "It made me feel unwelcome," said 10-year-old Matthew Weaver, who is now unlikely to ever forget his first day of fifth grade.
Malcolm X Academy is one of three public elementary schools in Detroit created last year as educational alternatives for urban black boys, who have historically been at risk of academic failure. The academy, like similar schools in Baltimore, Milwaukee and Portland, Ore., teaches an African-centered curriculum that emphasizes black achievements.
 
Raising Self-Esteem
 Educators say the curriculum raises the self-esteem of black children, and that in the long run will help keep those children interested in school. But school officials also contend that all children can benefit from such a curriculum. So far, however, only one of Malcolm X Academy's 470 students is white.
"I don't think it is any place for a white kid to go to school," said Wayne Earhart, 29, a leader of the opposition to Malcolm X Academy. "They teach the kids that blackness is the center of the universe."
Deborah McGriff, the Detroit superintendent of schools, said, "As a school district we are committed to African-centered education, not only in the acadamies, but to infuse African-centered concepts across the entire curriculum."
The district has started three more academies since the first three opened and, because of a Federal judge's order, all six are open to girls as well as boys. They are public "schools of choice," to which parents from across the city apply. Students are selected through a lottery, although one-fourth of the spaces are reserved for neighborhood children.
 
Attendance Put at 98%
 Parents and educators say the schools have been successful so far; as evidence Clifford Watson, the principal of Malcolm X, pointed to a 98 percent attendance rate at his school.
Last year Malcolm X Academy shared space with another elementary school in a different part of Detroit. The school district decided to give the academy its own building and selected a closed elementary school in Warrendale, a white working-class neighborhood, because it would cost less to renovate than other sites.
But many Warrendale residents opposed the move. At a chaotic meeting of neighborhood residents and school officials last August some shouted, "I don't want niggers in my neighborhood!" and "Go home!"
Some residents complained at the meeting that black children bused to the academy would make their neighborhood unsafe, diminish property values and scare away whites. They demanded that children coming to class be frisked.
"We don't feel a need to do security checks on 5- to 11-year-olds," said Ms. McGriff, who is black. Her response was met by boos from residents.
After the meeting vandals spray-painted white swastikas on Malcolm X Academy's new building. Bomb threats were made against the school. On several occasions, Warrendale residents picketed the school before classes began in September.
"I heard people say, 'If you open that school we will burn it down,' " said Malaika Kenyatta, whose son is a fourth grader at Malcolm X. "I took those threats very seriously."
Despite their fears Malcolm X parents voted overwhelmingly to stay, saying that to back down would set a bad example for the children.
Since the school opened the animosity has continued. Parents patrol the school daily along with round-the-clock guards. They have reported several incidents: Eggs and rocks have been thrown at school buses. The words "white power" were spray-painted on a school wall.
"Even now, they ride by and hurl threats and racial slurs at the security guards," said Tandrea Black, whose son is in fourth grade. "They holler, 'Niggers go home!' "
 
Bottom Line Is Racism
 Mrs. Black said she had tried to explain all this to her 8-year-old son Ellis. "I told him they don't want you out there simply because you are black," she said. "I told him: 'You hear Mommy talk about racism. This is it.' "
Yvonne Hicks, president of the Warrendale Community Organization, which is trying to repair the rift with the school, said the bottom line is racism.
"The kids are in, and people have seen that their worst fears are completly unfounded," said Ms. Hicks, who is white. "You are going to find racist people no matter where you go. It is inbred."
Some Warrendale residents are trying another approach. They recently asked the Michigan Board of Education to investigate the academy and its African-centered curriculum. They have also hired a lawyer and plan to file a lawsuit charging that the academy violates the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution by teaching religion and by creating separate and unequal schools.
 
Focus on Curriculum Change
 These neighborhood residents insist their actions are not racist. They say they are not seeking to close the academy, but rather, to change its curriculum. They contend that the students meditate every day and observe a religious holiday called Kwanzaa.
Dr. Watson, the principal, said there is no meditation. Students do recite the Malcolm X Academy pledge daily, instead of the Pledge of Allegiance, which one parent said "wasn't written for us."
The Malcolm X pledge goes: "We at the Malcolm X Academy will strive for excellence in our quest to be the best. We'll rise above every challenge with our heads held high. We'll always keep the faith when others say die. March on till victory is ours: Amandla!"
The last word means "power."
Instead of Halloween, students celebrate Heritage Day, dressing up like black historical figures and giving speeches about them. The academy also honors the birthdays of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the abolitionists Sojourner Truth, Harriet Tubman and Frederick Douglass, the singer and actor Paul Robeson and the black nationalist Marcus Garvey, as well as Malcolm X.
This month the students will celebrate the seven days of Kwanzaa, which means "first fruits of the harvest" in Swahili. The holiday, cultural rather than religious, focuses on seven principles: unity, self-determination, collective work and responsibility, co-operative economics, purpose, creativity and faith.
But beyond the issue of "religion," the Warrendale residents' broader concern is that the African-centered curriculum excludes whites. That the school is named after a man who once called white people "devils" also bothers some residents.
"They are placing so much emphasis on the needs of the African-American kid in this city," said Terri Zyskowski, a 28-year-old Warrendale parent. "They have needs, but so do all the other kids. They say they had to learn a Eurocentric way and now it's their turn. As I see it, their curriculum is distorted."
Parents and educators say the academy's main thrust is to educate students in mathematics, reading and writing. But beyond that, teachers supplement conventional textbooks, which rarely mention the accomplishments of blacks, with lessons that stress black achievements and try to correct the practice of overlooking African history.
"Science books talk about the work of Thomas Edison or Sir Isaac Newton," said Dr. Watson, holding up a fifth-grade science text. "But you won't find a black scientist named in this book. Why couldn't you have a Lewis Latimer or a Mae Jemison?" Mr. Latimer was an inventor and engineer who worked with Alexander Graham Bell in developing the telephone; Ms. Jemison is the first black female astronaut.
Discipline is strict at Malcolm X Academy. Students wear uniforms, and Dr. Watson routinely reminds boys to tuck in their shirts.
Behind all this is the goal of raising the students' awareness of their cultural heritage to encourage them that they can succeed in school.
"In my old school they didn't teach us hardly anything about African-Americans, except in February during Black History Month," said Matthew Weaver, the fifth grader at Malcolm X. "Here, they do it every day. And that's important to me."

HEADLINE: YUGOSLAV PREMIER TO CHALLENGE SERB

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1

 BODY:
The Prime Minister of Yugoslavia announced today that he would attempt to unseat the Serbian republic's hard-line nationalist President, Slobodan Milosevic, in elections set for Dec. 20.
Mr. Milosevic is widely held to be the person most responsible for the bloody aftermath of the breakup of Yugoslavia, and the candidacy of the federal Prime Minister, Milan Panic, is the strongest challenge to Mr. Milosevic's grip on power here since he took over as Serbia's Communist Party chairman in 1987. 
 "All that he offers is fear, division and confrontation," Mr. Panic said at a news conference here this afternoon. "Our economy is in a shambles. Unemployment is skyrocketing. Inflation is out of control. Our children have no future."
"War rages out of control, yet Milosevic has done nothing," Mr. Panic said. "Milosevic is doing everything to keep it going."
 
Move to Block Candidacy
 The 62-year-old Mr. Panic was born in Serbia but emigrated to the United States and made a fortune in the pharmaceuticals industry. He was appointed Prime Minister in July by the Yugoslav Parliament, which is controlled by Mr. Milosevic's party, even though Mr. Panic has consistently expressed opposition to the aggressive Serbian nationalism that has been the cause of most of the bloodshed in neighboring Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
It is widely believed that Mr. Milosevic calculated that Mr. Panic would serve as a fig leaf for the Serbian nationalists, and even persuade the United Nations Security Council to end trade sanctions imposed on the Serbian-dominated rump Yugoslavia at the end of May, without threatening Mr. Milosevic's control. But opinion polls taken by local newspapers indicate that Mr. Panic is now more popular than the Serbian President.
Mr. Panic promised again that he would work to end the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which has brought this country international isolation.
In an attempt to block Mr. Panic's candidacy, Serbian election officials announced today that the Yugoslav Prime Minister would not be able to stand in the Serbian presidential election unless he can show by Wednesday afternoon that he has been a resident of Serbia for one year. The residency law was passed Nov. 3.
 
Milosevic and Defeat
 Before taking leave from his pharmaceuticals company in July, Mr. Panic was a resident of California.
"I was born a Serb," Mr. Panic said. "I am a Serb. I live in Belgrade, and I am the Yugoslav Prime Minister. Of course I am eligible."
Despite his popularity, Mr. Panic has no party affiliation or solid political base. But the leading opposition coalition, whose candidate for Serbian President is Vuk Draskovic, announced today that it would throw its support to Mr. Panic if he is ruled eligible.
Western diplomats expressed concern that Mr. Milosevic, who maintains control of the governing Serbian Socialist Party as well as Serbia's television network, major newspapers, major enterprises and secret police, will not accept an election defeat.
"Even if Panic wins, there are reasons to fear that Milosevic will not accept defeat by democratic means," a Western diplomat said. "His exercises in democratic politics are only a game."
Mr. Panic's announcement came as international condemnation of Yugoslavia grew and the war in Bosnia continued to rage despite a weekend cease-fire agreement between Serbian and Croatian commanders.
The United Nations today halted humanitarian aid flights to Sarajevo after a United States military aircraft was struck by small-arms fire. United Nations officials said that the aircraft, the second United States aid plane in three weeks to be struck by fire since the airlift operation began in June, was slightly damaged and that none of the crew was injured.
Sarajevo radio reported fierce fighting today between Serbian and Bosnian forces at the towns of Gradacac and Tesanj, asserting that 56 people had died in the battles. Clashes were also reported at Orasje, Maglaj, Bihac and Doboj.
Serbian shells also fell on the western suburbs of Sarajevo, local news reports said.
In Geneva today, the United Nations Human Rights Commission condemned Bosnia's Serbs as primarily responsible for the atrocities in the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The commission called on the international community to judge whether the Serbs' forced expulsions of hundreds of thousands of Bosnian Muslims from their homes amounted to "genocide."
Yugoslavia was the only country in the 53-member commission to vote against the resolution, calling it "one-sided and exclusive."

Call to Arm Bosnian Muslims
 JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- King Fahd of Saudi Arabia opened an Islamic conference today by calling on the United Nations to allow Bosnian Muslims to arm themselves against Serbs.
 The King told the foreign ministers of the 47-member Organization of the Islamic Conference that although Saudi Arabia continued to support United Nations resolutions, "we see that achieving justice dictates allowing Bosnia and Herzegovina to acquire weapons for its legitimate self-defense."

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Weighing Policy Shift

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, in a letter released today told a key Congressman that the central bank was seriously considering reducing its targets for money supply growth next year.
Such a move would underscore the Fed's seriousness about combating inflation, but would also probably upset politicians who fear that it could hurt economic growth. 
 For the last two years, the White House and Democrats in Congress alike have repeatedly battered the Fed over monetary growth that has fallen below its targets, saying this has been an important factor in the weakness of the nation's recovery from recession.
 
A Balancing Act
 Economists generally agree that slower growth in the money supply helps reduce inflation but also slows economic growth, while faster money supply growth aids economic expansion but can also fuel inflation.
One Fed governor insisted in an interview today that "our view of what the appropriate stance of monetary policy is has not changed one iota."
But in interviews before Mr. Greenspan's letter became public, other Fed officials suggested that reducing monetary targets could actually end up promoting economic growth. By reassuring the financial markets that it will persist in being tough on inflation for the long term, they indicated, the central bank might have more leeway not to raise interest rates to combat inflation.
 
An Alternative View
 Still, several economists said that the Fed might be more ready to raise interest rates if it adopted a lower monetary growth target. The reasoning is that if the money supply grows faster than expected and thus rises toward the top of the target range, the Fed might feel compelled to raise rates. This discourages lending and helps reduce money supply growth.
"I think the markets would view this as another reason for the Fed not to ease," said David M. Jones, chief economist for Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities firm. "If they lower the target and the economy starts to pick up, it might then feel it has to tighten monetary policy sooner rather than later."
Mr. Greenspan's statement about the possibility of lowering targets came in a letter to Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is the chairman of the House Banking Committee, responding to Mr. Gonzalez's complaints on monetary policy.
In his letter, Mr. Greenspan sought to explain why money supply growth had fallen below expectations. He also said that growth in economic output had been higher than Fed officials and most economists would have expected, considering how slow the growth in the money supply has been. This, he suggested, was causing the Fed to rethink how much growth in the money supply was needed to obtain a desired rate of growth.
Mr. Greenspan's letter said that any change in money supply targets "would be largely of a technical nature" to take account of the changing relationship between economic growth and growth in M-2, the most closely watched gauge of the money supply. He said such a move would not be "indicative of a change" in the Fed's "desired or expected outcomes for the performance of the economy."
Fed officials insisted such a move would be consistent with their desire to encourage sustained growth while keeping inflation in check.
In an interview today, David W. Mullins Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, said, "I think it would just confirm that we have a long-term strategy trying to make sure there is enough monetary accommodation and stimulus to allow the real economy to grow to its real potential but not allow inflationary pressures to develop."
 
Speculation on Motive
 But some economists suggested that any move to lower monetary growth targets might be aimed in part to deflect criticism: lowering the targets would make it easier for the Fed to hit them.
And in his response to Mr. Greenspan's reply to him, Representative Gonzalez complained that lowering the targets could "jeopardize the chances for a strong recovery."
Mr. Greenspan noted in his letter that M-2 grew at a 1.75 percent annual rate during the first nine months of this year, well below the target of 2.5 to 6.5 percent growth. Fed officials pointed out, however, that the money supply grew at a 2.5 percent rate during the first 11 months of the year.
Mr. Greenspan said one reason for the slow growth in M-2 was that many people were moving money from short-term deposits, which are considered part of M-2, into mutual funds, which are not part of M-2.
Although the Fed stressed that any move to lower targets would be technical in nature, several economists said such a move could upset the coming Clinton Administration and the Democrats in Congress.
"I'm puzzled why the Fed wants to take on this bear right now," said Lyle Gramley, a former Federal Reserve governor who is chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. "It seems impolitic. Why antagonize the Congress by even suggesting that you might follow a monetary policy that's more restrictive?"

HEADLINE: Thomas Gambino: It's All in the Name

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
The Apparel Industry Chapter of the American ORT Federation's cocktail party next week will have all the trappings of a typical $150-a-person fund-raiser: An elegant three-color invitation. An open bar. A buffet with smoked salmon and chefs carving away. But the guest of honor will not be so typical: Thomas Gambino.
Yes, the Thomas Gambino who pleaded guilty at his corruption and racketeering trial nine months ago, the Thomas Gambino who prosecutors say is an organized-crime captain and the Thomas Gambino who promised to get out of the short-haul trucking business in the garment industry after paying a $12 million fine. 
 The president of the Apparel Industry Chapter, Sidney Reiff, said Mr. Gambino and his wife, Frances, were chosen because Mr. Gambino was "instrumental in this industry." To hear Mr. Reiff tell it, it did not matter that Mr. Gambino was a reputed organized-crime captain. "What the Government does, the Government can go ahead and do."
"Look, he's not in jail," Mr. Reiff said. "He's been generous in other endeavors." Mr. Reiff said he could not recall that Mr. Gambino had ever given money to the Apparel Industry Chapter himself. But he said the Gambino trucking companies had made donations in the 25 years since the chapter was set up.
Mr. Reiff refused to talk about how the Apparel Industry Chapter had choosen Mr. Gambino, saying the details were "immaterial." But he said there was no quid pro quo: Mr. Gambino had not sought the award in return for the promise of a big gift.
As for the man who agreed to the Gambino plea bargain, his spokesman had only a one-sentence reaction to the idea of honoring Mr. Gambino at the cocktail party. "The guilty plea speaks for itself," said Gerald McKelvey, the spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.
Foundation officials point out that the Gambino family has given generously to charitable organizations like Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I., where the $2 million Gambino Medical and Science Foundation Bone Marrow Transplantation Unit was dedicated last year. It was New York State's first such unit for children.
The Apparel Industry Chapter is one of 50 that raises money for the 112-year-old federation, which says it supports vocational and technical schools with 220,000 students in 38 countries.
The federation began to train Eastern Europeans to be carpenters and seamstresses. Now about half of the students are in Israel, and the emphasis is on 20th-century careers like word processing and robotics.
With financial support from agencies like the World Bank and the United Nations Development Program, the federation has also helped with skill-building programs in Africa. The federation says that its team in Chad is helping farmers increase crop yields, and it is also running community health projects from Argentina to Uruguay to Zaire.
 
Fund-Raising Names
 The Apparel Industry Chapter turned to Mr. Gambino to help keep the money coming. "We attempt to find somebody who is willing to allow us to use his name to raise some funds," Mr. Reiff said. He said the group raised about $90,000 at a reception last year, when the guest of honor was John Pomerantz, the chairman of Leslie Fay, a women's clothing manufacturer. The year before, the guest of honor was Ted Schatzberg, the president of Party Formals After Five Inc.
"If it's a recognizable name, a name in the industry we can raise funds off of, fine," he said. Referring to Mr. Gambino, he added: "We're not delving any deeper. It's a worthwhile charity from our point of view and it must be a worthwhile charity from his point of view or he wouldn't have gotten involved."
The federation itself called the choice of Mr. Gambino and his wife as next week's honorees "an independent decision of that chapter."
"I don't know that the national organization has a feeling about that," said Avi Feinglass, the federation's spokesman.
The national organization was well aware that the Apparel Industry Chapter was honoring Mr. Gambino, though. "I'm a national officer" as well as the chapter president, Mr. Reiff said. "Nobody tried to dissuade me."
 
Disposing of Business
 But with the reservations trickling in -- Mr. Reiff said he was hoping for a crowd of 125 to 150 people -- the effort continues to get Mr. Gambino out of the short-haul trucking business for good.
After Mr. Gambino pleaded guilty to antitrust charges that stemmed from a sting operation begun by undercover state police officers, Robert W. McGuire, a former New York City Police Commissioner, was named to dispose of that part of what prosecutors said was an empire that gave the Gambinos a stranglehold on the garment business.
"We are looking at potential buyers," said Alice T. McGillion, speaking for Mr. McGuire.
Even when that happens -- Ms. McGillion said Mr. McGuire has until early next year to work out the details -- some Seventh Avenue hands say the Gambinos' presence will still be felt.
"On the street level, the same players are still there," said Alan Milstein, editor and publisher of Fashion Network Report, a publication that caters to the garment trade. "One could almost surmise that it's business as usual."
But not for Herman Bubendey, manager of the 500 Club, at 500 Seventh Avenue, where next week's reception is to be held. The Gambinos, he said, are not regular customers.
"It's possible they've come here before," he said. "When a member brings them in, what can you do?"

HEADLINE: In Searching for Scholarship Funds, the Advice Is: 'Do It Yourself'

 BODY:
Tough economic times and the rising cost of a college education, which can now top $20,000 annually, have produced a boom in computerized scholarship search operations.
For fees ranging from $50 to $250, these operations offer customized lists of corporate and foundation grants for which a student might qualify. The services scan electronic data banks of thousands of scholarships and match ethnic background, religion, intended career choice, or other criteria to the individual applicant. 
 But many educators believe that such services are a waste of money because similar financial aid information is accessible at public libraries, high school guidance offices and college financial aid offices. "At the very most, these firms save you a couple of hours of research in the library," said Madeline McLean, a spokeswoman for the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators.
Moreover, students are increasingly able to conduct their own computerized scholarship searches at no cost or at a minimal cost because more academic institutions and libraries are installing electronic financial aid data bases.
 
List of 45,938 Scholarships
 Charles Khoury, director of guidance at Ridgewood High School in Northern New Jersey, said his school purchases scholarship search computer software for $210 annually from Peterson's, a Princeton, N.J., publisher of college and career guides, and the program lists 45,938 private scholarships and grants.
"The level of specificity is pretty good," Mr. Khoury said. "We can't find a scholarship based on whether you're left-handed or right-handed, but if you're a white Catholic female and want to study nursing, we can find something for that."
The College Board, a higher education research group, has developed a computer program on comprehensive financial aid that should be available, for $395, this month. The program will enable a family to calculate how much of a child's education it will be expected to pay, based on Federal guidelines, as well as to search for state and private scholarships and loans from among 3,000 programs, said Maureen Matheson, executive director of the College Board's guidance publishing unit.
Last year, college financial aid totaled $30.8 billion, including government grants and loans, and helped about half of all college students pay for their education, according to the College Board.
Ms. Matheson said the board was prompted to computerize financial aid information partly in response to widespread complaints about scholarship search operations from educators, students and consumer groups.
 
'Information Questionable'
 "The quality of the information these services provide is questionable," said Carrie Getty, vice president of operations at the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York. Very few of those who paid the search companies' fees actually found scholarships, she said. In some cases, the scholarships the companies listed no longer existed or the deadlines had passed, Ms. Getty said.
Often, she said, the services did not make it clear to students that they would have to complete scholarship applications themselves. And Ms. Getty said the companies rarely made good on promises of cash refunds or savings bonds if scholarships were not obtained.
As a result, the Better Business Bureau issued unsatisfactory ratings in September to 20 of 21 scholarship search services that it had examined in New York City. The lone company that was not rated unsatisfactory was Data Search in Manhattan.
Nine other search operations about which the bureau had received calls had closed before the consumer group contacted them, pointing up what Ms. Getty said was the fly-by-night quality of the search operations.
 
Disappointed Student
 "It was a learning experience," Sylvia Alvarado said of her dealings with a now-defunct New York City scholarship search company. The 22-year-old Brooklyn resident, who studies accounting at La Guardia Community College in Queens, wrote a check for $89 to Money For School in August 1991 after calling the company and being assured that it had helped other students obtain financial aid.
Ms. Alvarado said that all she received was a booklet listing some corporate scholarships and general financial aid information. She also said she was unable to get the refund promised if she was not satisfied with the services provided.
Some of the search operations defended themselves by saying that it is impossible to tell how successful their services are because they do not know whether students follow through on applying for scholarships.
Students and parents are often lured by what college aid experts say are misleading advertisements sent through the mail or posted on campus bulletin boards. Typically, companies promise to help students tap vast amounts of scholarship money that supposedly goes begging every year because no one eligible applies.
The thousands of search companies that have sprung up nationwide are typically franchise-like businesses, which pay a parent company to conduct data searches. Most of the search businesses examined by the Better Business Bureau had such arrangements with one of three parent companies, all of which are under government investigation for either deceptive marketing practices or advertising claims.
 
Big Operation Shuts Down
 One of the most widely used, Academic Guidance Services of Mount Laurel, N.J., has been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with questionable marketing techniques, including overstating licensees' potential earnings. After the Federal District Court in Trenton temporarily froze the company's assets last July, it ceased operations, said a commission lawyer, John Cook.
The company had 17,000 to 18,000 licensees nationwide (each was charged an initial fee of $495), and 1991 pretax income of $5.8 million, Mr. Cook said. When it went out of business, he said, "most of the licensees I talked to refunded students' money" and shut down. Some stayed in business by switching to another parent processing company, he said.
Another parent company, called Money for College and based in Granada Hills, Calif., has been sued for fraud by the Wisconsin Attorney General. Jim Haney, a spokesman for the Wisconsin Attorney General, said the company had overstated earnings potential to licensees and provided scholarship lists that were outdated or inaccurate.
Money for College did not responded to several telephone messages seeking comment about the accusation.

HEADLINE: Revision Discussed for One-Day-Old Health Plan

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Ushered into law with marginal political support and faint praise from its creators, New Jersey's new health care system already has brought talk of major revisions and the threat of protracted legal fighting.
Gov. Jim Florio signed the sweeping overhaul of the state's health care system Monday night, only minutes after the Republican-controlled Legislature approved the package of bills, which includes a plan to pay for hospital care for the poor by diverting $1.6 billion from the state's unemployment insurance fund. 
 "We have averted a crisis that could have shut down New Jersey's health care system at midnight Dec. 1," Mr. Florio said. "At the same time, we have enacted far-reaching insurance reforms that will help make sure no one in our state has to lie awake at night wondering how they would pay the bills if someone in the family gets sick.
"The new method of paying for the care of those who can't afford it is far from perfect. But it was the only option that the legislative process made available."
 
Amendments Expected Soon
 Although the Governor had acquiesced, none of his Democratic colleagues in the Legislature did. They voted against the package, and the Republican leaders in the Senate were forced to cajole a freshman Republican, who at first had abstained, to supply the deciding vote.
The measure passed, 48 to 23 in the Assembly and 21 to 18, with one abstention, in the Senate.
The Democratic minority leader in the Assembly, Joseph V. Doria of Bayonne, predicted that the issue would be back before the Legislature within weeks, saying: "I think politically the Republicans will have to amend it immediately, before we have total chaos."
There are at least three amendments under consideration, according to Democrats in the Legislature. One is intended to help hospitals, especially those in urban areas, that are expected to suffer financially.
Provisions of the amendment would create a floor under which deregulated hospital rates could not fall. It would also establish a fund in the State Department of Health to help pay expenses for teaching hospitals and provide for state money to make up for anticipated Medicaid losses.
 
'Nice Try' Category
 A second amendment would give the Legislature more power to oversee the new system. As it stands, the new legislation diminishes the regulatory role of the Insurance Commissioner, the Public Advocate and the appropriations committees of the Legislature.
The third proposal would guarantee that people in inner cities and other areas that might not be served by insurance companies would still have access to medical care.
Faced with a Federal court ruling in May that outlawed the state's 12-year-old system of paying for charity health care, the Governor and the legislative leaders used the opportunity to revamp the entire system.
Pushing their own ideas on health care and borrowing ideas from other states, they produced a package unlike any other plan in the nation.
"This legislation places New Jersey in the 'nice try' category," said Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization.
He described some of the legislation as "noble sounding" but the overall plan as full of loopholes.
Under an "open enrollment" provision, for example, the package assigns every health insurer in New Jersey a quota of customers based on its market share. Up to that quota, the company must accept customers without regard to age, sex, health or geographic location. A company that fails to do so must pay a large subsidy to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey, which now insures most of the state's high-risk customers.
"It's easy to say in the Legislature that this will work," said Mr. Hunter. "It's a lot harder to make it work at the kitchen table with the insurance agent sitting across the way."
He said there were a number of ways insurance companies could circumvent the law. For example, he said, they can advertise only to low-risk groups, so that customers they do not want might not think of applying to them.
The changes agreed upon by Mr. Florio, the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, and the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, were influenced as much by politics as by the need for reform.
Finding a source of financing for charity hospital care was the major and most pressing issue, and with both gubernatorial and legislative elections less than a year away, the Governor and the Republican leaders avoided any direct tax increase. Instead, they settled on a Republican idea, tapping into the unemployment fund, an idea that has been criticized as a "back-door tax."
The financing source would be eliminated -- or in legislative terms, "sunset" -- after three years, to be replaced by state-subsidized or low-cost private health insurance or by a system in which hospitals would simply absorb more of their unpaid bills.
"The major shortcomings, as I see them, are structural, not philosophical," said Senator Richard J. LaRossa of Trenton, who abstained on the bill, citing problems with the funding mechanism. "The system sunsets, uses a highly questionable funding source and simply does not make genuine changes on a system that is hemorrhaging and bleeding businesses, patients, insurance companies, hospitals and consumers in New Jersey to death."
The state A.F.L.-C.I.O., which along with the state Chamber of Commerce had opposed the use of unemployment insurance money, said today that it would try to have the courts overturn the package.
The regional administrator for the Federal Department of Labor, Thomas E. Hill, had advised the state in October that it was "inadvisable" to divert money from the unemployment trust fund. But an official in the office said today that the new legislation did not violate Federal guidelines.
"Legally we cannot intervene," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The New Jersey Legislature is perfectly within its rights."

HEADLINE: Economic Indicators Rise by 0.4%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
More evidence of economic pickup emerged today as the Government's main forecasting index posted an advance of four-tenths of 1 percent for October after two straight monthly declines.
The broad-based, albeit modest, rise in the index of leading indicators came as the Commerce Department reported a 1 percent gain in spending on new construction for the month. And in a third report, this one covering November, an index of manufacturing activity by the nation's purchasing managers showed a sharp jump to 55 percent from 50.6 percent. [Page D2.] 
 Analysts were generally encouraged by today's statistics. The data came after last week's report on gross domestic product for the July-September quarter showed a hefty upward revision to a growth rate of 3.9 percent. In addition, there has been a steady reduction in recent weeks in first-time claims for jobless benefits.
Still, most economists remained skeptical to one degree or another about the prospects for vigorous expansion in the months ahead. Some cited the impending disappearance of special factors that have helped fuel the gains in the economy, while others pointed to such drags as the Federal budget deficit.
"Before you get too excited, you better at least wait for the employment numbers" for November, which are to be released Friday, cautioned Maury N. Harris, chief economist for Paine Webber Inc.
He said the current situation and its economic data reminded him of the period around Memorial Day, when there were similar gains. "Then, in early July, kerplunko," Mr. Harris said, referring in particular to unexpectedly poor labor-market results for June when payrolls shrank and the unemployment rate spurted three-tenths of a percentage point.
Lawrence A. Hunter, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in a statement that the rise in the leading indicators showed the economic growth in the third quarter to have been "no fluke" and predicted that the economy would grow at about a 3 percent pace for the first half of 1993. Stil, that rate is below par for the early stage of an expansion, and he questioned whether even that could be sustained.
 
Some Special Factors
 The economy in recent months has benefited from the spending related to cleaning up Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki and from a reduction in withholding of income taxes, but those stimuli will soon wear off. After that, Mr. Hunter said, "the economy will still be beset with policy problems that have plagued it the past three years -- increases in costly regulations, rapidly rising Federal spending and increased taxes on businesses and individuals."
Of the 11 components of the leading indicators, 8 expanded during October, although for 2 of them, consumer expectations and money supply, the rise was so small as to round to zero. And of the three that declined, the biggest factor by far was an easing of prices -- not entirely unwelcome -- of goods especially sensitive to the business cycle.
Another plus was the fact that the companion indexes of coincident and lagging indicators also advanced in October, the first time since March 1990 that all three composite indexes gained in the same month.
The rise in the coincident index, an approximation of current economic activity, was four-tenths of 1 percent. This followed two straight declines and matched its best performance since February.
The lagging index climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent, making two gains since July after falling for 18 straight months.
The chief contributor to the leading index's October gain was weekly jobless claims, which dropped sharply. Lesser improvement came from a longer workweek, a rise in unfilled factory orders, higher contracts and orders for plant and equipment, new factory orders for consumer goods and materials, and a rising volume of building permits.
Besides the decline in sensitive materials prices, the negative factors were faster deliveries by company suppliers and lower stock prices, subsequently reversed, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
In what was mainly a reflection of a longer workweek, a revision of September's decline put it at one-tenth of 1 percent instead of the drop of three-tenths originally reported.
All three available components of the coincident index -- nonfarm payrolls, personal income and industrial production -- rose in October, fueling speculation that the National Bureau of Economic Research will soon declare an official end to the recession that began in July 1990.
A private forecasting index compiled by Safian Investment Research posted a jump of nine-tenths of 1 percent in October as gains in monetary and consumer-attitude components continued to more than offset weakness in the labor market and in macroeconomic gauges, a reversal of earlier readings.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
1993: So-So Growth, Low Inflation

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
A consensus forecast of leading bond market economists released yesterday said the economy would grow moderately next year, inflation would remain low and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond could decline to around 7.25 percent.
The forecast for interest rates, however, depends on a big if: whether the new Clinton Administration will produce a credible deficit-reduction program along with its proposals to stimulate the economy. 
 "We need to believe the campaign promises on the deficit," said James Annable, an economist of the First National Bank of Chicago and co-chairman of the group of 11 economists who did the forecast for the Public Securities Association. "Without that we'll see trouble in the bond market."
 
The Deficit Factor
 Any visions of rising deficits, which are bad for bond traders, investors and speculators, would cause problems for the bond market. Higher deficits mean more government borrowing, which can push interest rates higher. Deficits also raise fears of rising inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments.
The importance of the deficit factor is easy to see in another forecast yesterday by an economist not on the association's panel. It calls for the yield on the 30-year bond to be 7.75 percent in the fall of next year. The forecaster, Paul W. Boltz of T. Rowe Price Associates, put his bond yield forecast a full half-percentage-point higher than the 7.25 percent seen by the 11-member panel in part because he has less confidence in the Government's ability to produce an effective deficit-reduction proposal.
Mr. Boltz said that Mr. Clinton's promise to stimulate the economy was not easily reconciled with cutting the deficit significantly. And this fact, he argued, has created "an unease in the financial markets."
Mr. Annable, who used to work for the Congressional Budget Office in Washington, is familiar with past attempts and failures at credible deficit reduction. Despite such efforts, Government red ink swelled to a record high in the 1992 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, and should set another record in the 1993 fiscal year.
 
Have Times Changed?
 But Mr. Annable, in response to a question, said he had more confidence in the new Administration and Congress because times had changed.
"It is now such a serious problem that the Administration realizes it," he told a group of reporters at the morning presentation of the consensus forecast. And when pressed on why past record deficit levels did not create the same urgency, he replied, "The deficit wasn't constraining choices as it is today."
These are among other points in the consensus forecast, which is the first produced by members of the Public Securities Association:
*Inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, will be 3 percent next year, the same as is forecast for this year.
*Economic growth will be 2.2 percent year over year, compared with a forecast of about 2 percent this year.
*The unemployment rate will be 7.3 percent for 1993, as economic growth will create some new jobs but not enough to bring the rate down significantly from this year. In October, the unemployment rate was 7.4 percent.
*The budget deficit for the 1993 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, will be a record $340 billion, compared with $290 billion for the 1992 fiscal year. Much of the increase will be from spending to bail out more savings and loan associations.
The group also urged that the Clinton Administration and Congress decide soon on the effective date for the investment tax credit the President-elect is expected to propose. Until that date is set, many companies are likely to delay any new investments in plants or equipment, the group said.
 
Treasury Market
 In another volatile day, the price of the 30-year bond rose while the prices of shorter-term notes fell as investors and traders focused on more news showing that the economy may be on a stable path of growth. The discount rates on Treasury bills also rose.
The price of the 30-year bond was up11/32 , to 10023/32 , to yield 7.56 percent, down from 7.59 percent Monday.
As as been happening for the last few weeks, economic data showing the economy a little stronger than is expected have hurt the shorter end of the bond market. This is because a stronger economy would mean there is no chance of a further cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve. In addition, the signs of growth indicate to some that the time when the Fed might raise short-term rates seems to be moving closer.
The 30-year bond has fared better because recent economic data still show that the inflation rate is low and there is little chance of any kind of surge in the near future.
The case for a stronger economy was supported yesterday by a rise of four-tenths of a percent in the index of leading economic indicators in October and a jump in the National Association of Purchasing Managers index of buying activity to 55 in November from 50.6 in October.
In addition, analysts interpreted comments from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as another signal that the Fed would not cut short-term interest rates any more. Mr. Greenspan said the Fed was considering lowering the growth range targets for a key money supply figure. If the Fed did this, money supply growth, which is now at the bottom of the range, would be comfortably within the range, erasing any need to cut interest rates.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction yesterday of 49-day cash management bills:

HEADLINE: Purchasers' Survey Finds an Upturn

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The manufacturing economy expanded robustly in November, led by sharp increases in new orders and industrial production, according to a monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers.
The report, along with other data released yesterday by the Commerce Department, provided additional signs of economic recovery, economists said. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of economic activity increased to 55 percent in November, from 50.6 percent in October. The November reading was the highest since May, when the index stood at 56.3 percent, and was the second highest this year. It was also the second consecutive monthly increase.
A reading above 50 percent indicates that the economy is expanding, while a reading below 50 percent is a sign of contraction.
The monthly index is compiled from a survey of more than 300 purchasing managers at a wide range of industrial companies. It is considered important because its release early in each month provides one of the first significant indicators of economy activity in the previous month.
This month the purchasing managers' report came on the day the Commerce Department reported that construction spending increased 1 percent in October. The department also said yesterday that the Government's major economic forecasting barometer posted its largest increase in five months, rising four-tenths of 1 percent in October.
"It seems that economic activity in the manufacturing sector is expanding somewhat more rapidly now," said Andrew F. Brimmer, a former governor of the Federal Reserve who is now president of Brimmer & Company, a consulting firm in Washington. "This is reinforced by the rise in the purchasing managers' index in new orders, which suggests that future economy activity will also be stronger than it is currently."
The association's index of new orders rose sharply, to 60.8 percent in November, from October's 55 percent. Economists said the increase would lead to higher production.
"The surge in new orders in November was sufficient to boost the overall growth in the economy to a level not seen since May," said Robert J. Bretz, the director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. and the chairman of the purchasing managers' survey committee. "The vigorous growth significantly slowed the decline in employment in the manufacturing sector, while inflation was kept at bay."
Indeed, production continued to grow with the association's production index rising sharply in November, to 60.1 percent, compared with 54.3 percent in October.
The association's price index dropped to 41 percent in November, from 44.9 percent in October. It was the lowest level for that index since July 1991, when it stood at 39.8 percent. The report said only three industries reported paying higher prices in November: furniture, apparel and transportation equipment.
The association said employment figures improved in the manufacturing sector with the employment index rising to 48.7 percent in November, from 44.8 in October.

HEADLINE: Rebecca Grand; Teacher, 84

 BODY:
Rebecca Grand, a former teacher and assistant principal in New York City public schools, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 84 years old.
Miss Grand fell last winter and grew progressively weaker afterward, said her lawyer, Hazel Schizer. 
 During a 35-year career from 1937 to 1972, Miss Grand was a history teacher, guidance department chairman and an assistant principal of Samuel J. Tilden High School in Brooklyn. Before that, she taught history and economics at Hunter College High School from 1929 to 1937. She retired in 1972.
Miss Grand, a native of Brooklyn, received a bachelor's degree at Hunter College in 1929 and a master's degree at Teachers College, Columbia University, in 1931.
There are no immediate survivors.

HEADLINE: Yields on Money Market Accounts and C.D.'s Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The average yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the seven days beginning today are mixed locally and flat to slightly higher outside the New York area, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
The likelihood that rates on deposits will rise significantly anytime soon is remote, said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. "There are those who believe that a rate rise will emanate from the incoming Administration's plans of increased spending, but already there are analyses from the Clinton camp that there will be no quick turnaround for the economy." 
 He added, "With credit restrictions hampering the consumer sector from spending, it may fall on government spending to add the spark."
 
Earlier Impact on Loans
 Analysts say any rise in interest rates will probably affect loan rates before deposits.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, the average discount rates were up for the eighth consecutive week. The auction is often viewed as a sign of how banks might adjust their rates on savings.
The average rate was up slightly for a three-month bill, to 3.31 percent, from 3.27 percent the previous week, while the six-month bill rose a single basis point, to 3.46 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
In the New York area, the combined yield averages for commercial and savings banks, show a money market account down 2 basis points, to 2.75 percent, while three-month and six-month C.D.'s are both 2 basis points higher, to 2.87 percent and 3.02 percent, respectively.
The largest changes this week are at Crossland Savings, which is lowering the average yield on its market account 30 basis points, to 2.75 percent, and at Chase Manhattan, which is raising the yield on its three-month C.D. 20 basis points, to 2.89 percent. At the Republic National Bank, the new yield on a six-month C.D. is 3.30 percent, up 25 basis points.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks are nearly the same as the previous week. The average money market account yield is unchanged at 2.68 percent, while the average six-month certificate of deposit is up a basis point, to 2.99 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ex-Official Is Named A Director

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 1

 BODY:
Clayton K. Yeutter, the one-time United States trade representative and Agriculture Secretary, today was named to the board of Texas Instruments Inc., the computer chip maker.
A spokeswoman said the Dallas-based company would pay Dr. Yeutter the yearly fee of $40,000 that each of its 14 other directors receives, plus other fees of at least $5,000 or $10,000 for each of various committees on which he might serve. 
 Dr. Yeutter, 61 years old, who was deputy chairman of the Bush-Quayle campaign, led trade talks with the Japanese Government in 1986 that produced an agreement to increase sales of foreign-made semiconductors in Japan, directly benefiting Texas Instruments.
 
Accord on Chip Trade
 Japanese companies dominated the market at the time, and American chip makers had accused them of illegal "dumping" of Japanese memory chips in the United States market, sapping sales and profits of American chip makers. Dumping refers to the practice of selling products in foreign countries at prices below manufacturing costs.
An agreement signed last year by representatives from Tokyo and Washington called for sales of foreign suppliers to reach at least 20 percent of Japan's chip market by the end of this year. Sales penetration by foreign suppliers was 16 percent at the end of June, according to the United States trade representative's office.
Texas Instruments was in 1986 and is still today the largest foreign chip supplier in Japan. "Certainly the dumping goal was achieved, and we did see some improvement in opening Japan's market," said Terri West, a spokeswoman for the company.
Jerry R. Junkins, the chairman and chief executive of Texas Instruments, said Dr. Yeutter's role in the 1986 trade talks had "absolutely nothing" to do with his selection to the Texas Instruments board. Mr. Junkins said Dr. Yeutter, whose other corporate directorships include Conagra Inc. and the Oppenheimer Funds, had been sought as a director because of his diverse background in government and industry.
 
'Value, Strength and Experience'
 Mr. Junkins added that he had worked with Dr. Yeutter on the board of Caterpillar Inc., where Dr. Yeutter once was a director. "I saw firsthand the value, strength and experience he adds," Mr. Junkins said. "His is the type of leadership counsel that we look for in directors."
Dr. Yeutter, who has a Ph.D. in agricultural economics and a law degree, both from the University of Nebraska, expects to rejoin the Caterpillar board next year as well as return to the board of the FMC Corporation.
In addition to being the nation's trade representative, a Cabinet-level post, from 1985 to 1989, Dr. Yeutter was Agriculture Secretary from 1989 to 1991. He was previously president and chief executive of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and a senior partner at a law firm in Lincoln, Neb.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Broad Retreat Despite Signs of Recovery

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday, even though two Government reports showed that the United States economy was picking up.
Gold prices rose. Gold for December delivery finished at $335.10 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, up 80 cents from Monday's close. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $334.90, up 30 cents from Monday. 
 In New York, the dollar fell to 124.15 Japanese yen late yesterday from 124.695 late Monday. Earlier, in London, the dollar closed at 124.40 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 124.72 yen, from 124.75 yen on Monday.
In New York, the British pound rose to $1.5475, from $1.5165 late Monday. In London, the pound rose to $1.5365, from $1.5140 late Monday.
 
Two Pieces of Good News
 The index of leading economic indicators, the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge, jumped four-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said. And The National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly index on manufacturing rose to 55 percent, a big jump from the 50.6 percent level of October.
Curtis Perkins, a currency trader at Chemical Bank, said that the good economic news showed short-term improvement, but that questions remained about future conditions. Traders are waiting for the monthly unemployment report on Friday before making significant moves based on the economy, he said.
Traders also said the dollar was somewhat affected by the German central bank president's renewed vow yesterday that his nation would not cave in to world pressure and ease interest rates until domestic conditions permitted such a move.
Late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late rates, included: 1.5735 German marks, down from 1.5915; 1.4045 Swiss francs, down from 1.4340; 5.3655 French francs, down from 5.4055; 1,393.00 Italian lire, down from 1,394.00, and 1.28225 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2872.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, were: 1.5805 German marks, down from 1.5940; 1.4135 Swiss francs, down from 1.4370; 5.3895 French francs, down from 5.4137; 1.7775 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7920; 1,398.50 Italian lire, down from 1,393.50, and 1.2848 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2859.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Seen Widening

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1

 BODY:
In parting shots on foreign trade, the Bush Administration today accused China and Taiwan of manipulating their currencies to gain unfair advantage and predicted that a sluggish world economy would send America's trade deficit rising rapidly this year and next.
The Administration's gloomy assessment was that the merchandise trade deficit, which shrank in 1991 to an eight-year low of $65.4 billion, would hit $75 billion this year and exceed $100 billion in 1993. 
 The forecast represented a reversal from a report just six months ago when the Administration was still confidently predicting that the trade deficit, which has been declining for the last three years, would show further improvement.
The new assessment blamed "weaker demand than previously foreseen in Europe and Japan" for the change
The new report said that the problems highlighted six months ago involving China and Taiwan had not been corrected. China's reported currency manipulation comes at a time when the United States trade deficit with that country is soaring rapidly.
Through September, the United States deficit with China was $13.4 billion, second only to America's deficit with Japan of $33.9 billion. The deficit with Taiwan ranked third at $7.6 billion.
Under a 1988 law, the Administration is required to provide Congress with a report on the country's trade prospects and name countries unfairly depressing the value of their currencies.
A weak currency promotes a country's trade performance by making foreign goods more expensive while lowering the price of that country's exports.
