HEADLINE: Twice Appreciated When Given Just Once

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
WHILE it has always been possible to give a gift by making a donation to charity, the knowledge that good has been done in one's name may be satisfying only to the truly generous or the materially sated.
Increasingly, though, businesses and organizations are selling products that benefit others by giving a percentage of sales to a political or social cause. A wine maker is contributing money to help save eagles; African elephants are the beneficiaries of some garlic farmers, and sales of chocolates are being used to help preserve the rain forests. 
 Pay heed, though. Some ambitious marketers are sure to exploit this nascent trend by professing to give generously to some worthy cause. Read labels carefully. A vague statement about the company's donations to anonymous environmental groups, for instance, should arouse suspicion. A label that specifies the amount of the donation or at least the name of the beneficiary is much more reassuring. But even then, amounts of donations vary greatly. Some companies give as much as 40 percent of their profits to causes; others give just 1 or 2 percent.
Many of the products sold to produce more than profits are food and personal-care items, and they are more often found in catalogues than in stores. But greater variety is beginning to appear, and non-profit groups are becoming more familiar with marketing.
Some of the groups that raise money for social change, like Oxfam and Cultural Survival, are trying to show that consumers need not benefit to the detriment of producers. They are trying to change the whole wage structure in countries that produce luxuries sent here. They pay producers higher-than-usual wages, or bypass importers and distributors, sending more profit back to those who did the work.
Most of the products sold partly to help produce social change are intended to reach a high level of perfection on several grounds: fair wages for the producer, environmentally safe packaging and materials, and value for the consumer. Some even manage to come close to those goals.
Greenpeace, the environmental group based in Washington, sells a line of clothing made from organically grown cotton without dyes. Profits from its catalogue and its stores in Provincetown, Mass.; Key West, Fla., and San Francisco go to support the group's environmental agenda.
Although ordinary cotton is promoted for its virtue as a natural fiber, half of the pesticides used worldwide are used in growing cotton, said David Leeson, manager of the Greenpeace store in Key West, which like the store in San Francisco carries a large selection of the cotton clothing.
Among his offerings are a one-piece striped outfit for a baby, $25; an adult tank top, $16, and a polo shirt, $37.50. The organic cotton clothes, which are more expensive than their chemically grown counterparts because organic cotton is double the price, can be ordered from his store by calling (305) 296-4442, or from the San Francisco store at (415) 474-1870. The Greenpeace catalogue can be obtained by calling (800)456-4029.
Oxfam, an international organization that tries to promote economic self-sufficiency around the world, has a holiday catalogue with food, clothing, jewelry and household items, many made by artisans in Central and South America. An alpaca cardigan, made in Bolivia of natural undyed wool, comes in one adult size and features a scoop in the front. It is $98.75. The catalogue or merchandise can be ordered at (800) 639-2141.
The Pride Company, a new clothing company in San Francisco, that says it plans to donate some of its profit to gay and lesbian groups, is offering a long white cotton terry robe, made by Martex, available with embroidered gay and lesbian symbols, like the rainbow flag or the pink triangle. It is $75, available from Pride at (800) 568-5880.
Food gifts that offer a dual reward are especially easy to find. Sherry-Lehmann, the wine store at 679 Madison Avenue, near 61st Street, has a line of moderately priced wines called Bald Eagle, made for the company by California winemakers. The 1991 sauvignon blanc is $5.29 a bottle; the 1991 chardonnay is $7.49; and the 1990 cabernet sauvignon is $6.45. A Save the Eagle Sampler of 12 bottles is $76.95. The company sells about 2,000 cases of Bald Eagle wine a year, and in the last two years has contributed "a significant bulk" of the more than $4,000 in a special Bald Eagle fund, said Ronald Dodson, president of the Audubon Society of New York State.
Toucan Chocolates, an assortment of milk and dark chocolate with cashews, brazil nuts and caramel, can be found at many stores nationwide, including Terra Verde Trading Company at 72 Spring Street in SoHo. Some of the proceeds go to Cultural Survival, a Cambridge, Mass., group that tries to help native people around the world remain self-sufficient. The chocolates can also be found in many catalogues, including Seventh Generation, at (800) 456-1177, and the National Wildlife Federation, at (800) 824-3553. A 12-ounce box is $18.95.
Oxfam's Mascao Chocolate, billed as "The Chocolate of Fair Trade," contains cocoa grown by small farmers in Bolivia, sweetened with sugar grown by small farmers in the Philippines, and turned into confections in Switzerland. A package of three four-ounce bars -- milk chocolate, praline and hazelnut -- is $10.50, available at (800) 639-2141.
Cloud Nine sells chocolate bars, and donates 10 percent of its profit to Cultural Survival. A gift set of six bars wrapped in corrugated packaging with a raffia tie is $12.50 and can be ordered from Cultural Survival at (617) 621-3818.
Enviromints are small chocolate squares embossed with the images of endangered animals. One and a half pounds are $14.95, from the National Wildlife Federation at (800) 824-3553. The federation raises 37 percent of its revenue from product sales.
The Harvest coffees from the Thanksgiving Coffee Company are organically grown in Mexico, Peru and Guatemala. For each package sold, the company contributes 15 cents to economic development efforts in those countries. The company also offers its organically grown Coffee for Peace pack: four pounds, either regular or decaffeinated, for $17.95. Orders can be placed at (800) 648-6491.
The Starbucks Coffee Company in Seattle donates $2 to Care on each sale of its Care coffee sampler. The money goes to children's programs in Kenya, Guatemala, Sumatra and Java. The four-pound sampler is $18.95 and is available from Starbucks stores, including those in Seattle; Portland, Ore.; Chicago; Los Angeles; San Francisco; San Diego, and Denver, and from the catalogue, (800) 445-3428.
Christopher Ranch in Gilroy, Calif., is giving 5 percent of the sales of its elephant garlic to Wildlife Conservation International's effort to publicize the plight of the endangered African elephant. Elephant garlic has larger, milder cloves than the more commonly available type. In the last six months, the ranch has raised $10,000 with its garlic sales. The garlic, which sells for $1.99 to $2.99 for a large bulb, can be found at many supermarkets nationwide, including A.& P., Lucky, Safeway and Pathmark.
The non-endangered animal in your life can chow down on Moon Over Vermont All Natural Dog Biscuits, made by Applebrook Farms of Westford, Vt., and available through Cultural Survival, which gets part of the proceeds, at (617) 621-3818. Also benefiting Cultural Survival, and available from the group, is a Rainforest fruit and nut mix for humans to munch, $8.95 for a 12-ounce can.
Community Products Inc. in Montpelier, Vt., a company started by Ben Cohen of Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream to help create social change, offers a line of snacks called Rainforest Crunch that are available in many catalogues and stores, packaged in colorful tins. Included in the line are chocolate chip cookies, popcorn, and nut crunch. The profits are used to help make the rain forests sustainable through activities like nut harvesting rather than cutting and burning for transformation into plantations and ranches. The products can be ordered at (800) 927-2695 or through many catalogues, including Seventh Generation, at (800) 456-1177.
Another rain-forest company focuses on the pleasures of the skin rather than the tastebuds. Rainforest Essentials Ltd., which contributes 40 percent of its profits to Cultural Survival, makes a line of soaps and personal-care products. A bar of green soap, made from aloe vera and from oils from the copaiba tree in the Amazon rain forest, has a subtle, fresh smell; three four-ounce bars are $11.95. The company, which also offers gift packs with shampoo and body lotion, sells its products at retailers like Macy's in New York and California, some Nordstrom stores, Terra Verde in New York and the Nature Company, and through catalogues like Seventh Generation.
Cookbooks have often been used to raise money for various groups. A good Hanukkah gift for anyone trying to update traditional cuisine would be "California Kosher," put out by the Women's League of Adat Ari El Synagogue in North Hollywood, Calif. It is $19.95, not including postage and handling, from the Women's League at 12020 Burbank Boulevard, North Hollywood, Calif. 91607.
Sales of the "Native Indian Wild Game Fish and Wild Foods Cookbook," published by Fox Chapel Publishing in Lancaster, Pa., benefit the Indian women who contributed to the book. The book, which includes recipes like Black Walnut Souffle, Indian Fry Bread and Clover Soup, is $19.95 from Fox Chapel at (800) 457-9112. The same publisher offers "Treasured Mennonite Recipes," and the royalties go to the Mennonite Central Committee's projects in third world countries. It is $11.95.
A calendar with the recipes of well-known American chefs is being offered by Share Our Strength, a hunger-relief organization in Washington, founded by people in the food business. The calendar, which benefits the group, costs $10 and is available in many bookstores and gift shops, or by calling Share Our Strength at (800) 222-1767.
For children, Share Our Strength is selling a book called "Home," a collaboration of 30 authors and illustrators of children's books who have produced short stories and poems that center on feelings about home. It is $16, in bookstores nationwide.
Children can get a variety of art supplies, and a way to organize them, with the Chock Full Color Box, $19.95, a colorful jungle-motif box filled with water colors, pastels, brushes, coloring pencils, markers, a sharpener and stickers. It is sold through the Company of Women catalogue, which was started both to promote businesses owned by women and to raise money for the Rockland Family Shelter, an agency in Rockland County, New York, that serves victims of domestic violence or rape, and the homeless. To order: (800) 937-1193.
For bird-watching or just careful inspection, the National Wildlife Federation offers binoculars for children, in two sizes: one, for children 3 years old and older, for $12.95, and another, for children 7 and older, for $13.95. They have unbreakable plastic lenses and bodies. The federation also sells a fabric globe that when turned inside out reveals a fuzzy little elephant. The globe elephant, $19.95, benefits the federation, and also comes with a pledge from its manufacturer that 25 square feet of endangered rain forest in Costa Rica will be preserved and protected. Available from the National Wildlife Federation at (800) 822-9919.
For around the house, lightweight, natural beeswax candles are made by homeless men and women at A Candle in the Window, an organization in New York that provides jobs for the homeless. The candles, $6.50 for two or $13 for four, are sold at Body Shop stores throughout the country, or through its catalogue at (800) 541-2535. From Oxfam is a basket made in Zambia, woven from a root, patterned in earth tones. Suited for holding anything from mail to dinner rolls, it is $63 from Oxfam, at (800) 639-2141.
The lives of women are captured in the 50 songs included in "Great Ladies of Song," a two-tape or compact disk collection from the Company of Women that includes original pop hits by Peggy Lee, Judy Garland, Billie Holiday and others. It's $29.95 on CD, or $18.95 on tape, at (800) 937-1193.
Finally, from the Company of Women, for $4.75, is a small refrigerator magnet with a big sentiment: a reproduction of the Rosie the Riveter poster used during World War II, and the message "We Can Do It!"

HEADLINE: Kentucky Chickens With Je Ne Sais Quoi

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, Ky.

 BODY:
FOR the last year or so, flocks of French chickens have been pecking and scratching their way from the gentle hills of southern Kentucky to some fine dinner tables. They are the only French chickens being raised commercially in this country.
It was the doggedness of David Wilson, a former squab farmer, that brought these chickens here. Mr. Wilson, whose easy bluegrass twang is peppered with phrases like "raison d'etre," became intrigued with French chickens nearly five years ago after some of the chefs who were buying his squabs kept telling him how good they were. 
 "I went to France and also to England to see what this was all about," he said. "I came back very impressed with what they were doing."
After a trip to Europe in 1988 he tried raising American chickens a la Francaise for about a year and a half but was not satisfied with the results. "American chickens are bred for their breast meat, so they look like small turkeys," he said. "They don't have the flavor and texture of French chickens."
So now he is importing French chickens, which are being raised with plenty of room to run around outdoors. They are not fed antibiotics or other chemicals, nor are their beaks and claws clipped. The day-old chicks land first in Quebec, where they spend four weeks in quarantine before they are allowed to cross the American border.
"You really have to want to do this," Mr. Wilson said. "Our poultry industry has wisely set up barriers to protect against disease and also for economic reasons. We were fortunate to find a quarantine facility in Canada that we could work with."
Wilson Fields, the company based in Louisville that Mr. Wilson organized with a group of investors, brings in 4,500 hybrid Breton chickens every 18 weeks. Mr. Wilson explained that livestock breeding must be very carefully controlled, which is why he continues to import the chicks instead of simply breeding his own.
"The breeding part is best left to the experts," he said. "We are bringing in the parent flocks and we sell the chickens we grow from their eggs." Each flock can breed for 40 weeks, producing up to 700,000 chickens, or about 17,000 chickens a week. Currently, 60 percent of the chickens are sold in Canada, with the rest going to restaurants and supermarkets, mainly in Kentucky.
These chickens require 66 days to reach market weight of about three-and-a-half pounds dressed, compared with 39 to 42 days for American chickens. The difference is due to the breed and their diet of corn and wheat, which contains no growth-inducing drugs.
The Wilson Fields flocks are distributed among 17 farmers in the southern part of the state near Bowling Green who had been raising industrial chickens. The Kentucky Department of Agriculture played matchmaker between the farmers and Wilson Fields.
It appears to be a very happy marriage, said Leon and Laverne Kessler of Exie, whose farm just happens to be off Fry Ridge Road.
"We've been in the chicken business for 30 years," Mrs. Kessler said. "I like doing this, with 2,000 birds in a barn and letting them run outside, much better than having 13,000 inside all the time with the ammonia odor. We used to have six fans running all the time, and now we only need two, so it uses less energy."
When the doors to the Quonset hut-style barn opened, the mostly white chickens milled around outside, some pecking at gravel, others venturing out into the carefully fenced green meadow beyond.
"There is enough room at each farm to give every chicken two square meters of space," said Missy Camp, vice president of the company. "That's the minimum standard the French allow for free range. There are very few farms in this country that comply with that."
The Kesslers also have a small flock of handsome black chickens called acco noir, also from France, and some purebred brown Breton chickens. These take 81 days to reach market weight and are being raised on a very limited basis.
Not only is Mr. Wilson breaking new ground when it comes to raising chickens in the United States; his new federally inspected processing plant here, about 50 miles east of Bowling Green, also operates differently from any other plant in the country.
The chickens are first anesthetized with carbon dioxide before killing, which Wilson Fields says relaxes them and improves their texture. The birds are briefly scalded three times in progressively cleaner water to facilitate the removal of the feathers. This process is said to minimize bacterial contamination, compared with the usual single scalding.
The United States Department of Agriculture requires that the internal temperature of chickens be cooled to 38 degrees in no more than 16 hours after slaughtering, to prevent deterioration. The quickest method is to plunge the birds into cold water, which reduces the temperature sufficiently in less than an hour. But there is the potential for bacterial contamination, even in cold water.
At Wilson Fields, the chickens are placed on V-shaped racks for two hours in a room with circulating chilled air. The racks prevent the chickens from resting in any fluids. As a result, there is almost no excess moisture when a package is opened.
What Mr. Wilson is doing seems to be worth the effort. The chicken is extremely flavorful, with a succulence unmatched by the typical American chicken. Tests at the University of Kentucky have shown that the chickens have thinner skins, less exterior fat and juicier flesh than standard American chickens.
The chickens, labeled Wilson Fields la Belle Rouge (brown chickens are called reds in the industry), are mostly sold whole, trussed for roasting and without giblets, and mostly to restaurants. The chickens are also sold at a few Kroger stores in the Louisville area for $2.69 a pound; typical commercial chickens are less than a dollar a pound.
Some chefs who are using the chickens include Kathy Cary, who owns La Peche and Lilly's in Louisville, Mark Militello of Mark's Place in Miami and Dean Fearing of the Mansion at Turtle Creek in Dallas. "You can even tell the difference in a chicken pot pie," Ms. Cary said.

HEADLINE: With New Food Marriages, People Who Hate Decisions Never Have to Make Them

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
AND now, for the generation that begs for choices but hates to choose, here's Mix-In Cuisine.
There is ice cream with candy mixed in. Cookies with ice cream sandwiched between them. Chocolate bars with cookies crumbled in them. A cheese spread with jalapenos and corn chips mixed in. At grocery stores in Columbus, Ohio, one of the nation's test-market capitals, familiar snacks, desserts and convenience products have been nudged aside by a new generation of packaged foods that combine several products or even well-known brand names, like Hershey's chocolate pudding with York Peppermint Patties mixed in. 
 Food purists may wring their hands as individual flavors are melded, blended and merged. But those stymied by choice can put aside the Prozac and let their local supermarket soothe at least one conflict of modern life: choosing between discrete forms of edible indulgence.
For those loath to commit even to something as simple as corn flakes or Rice Krispies, Kellogg's offers Cris pix, cereal puffs that have corn on one side and rice on the other.
Those torn between meat and cheese can make sandwiches with Hormel's pepperoni-flecked cheese slices.
In the brave new world of have-it-your-way packaged food, one need not suffer a moment's indecision between fruit juices. Not when Dole has created Pine-Passion-Banana juice, when Chiquita has blended kiwi, plum, strawberry and grape juices in its Calypso Blend, and when Ocean Spray has combined all manner of exotic fruits with its cranberry juice.
"Products like these make avoiding decisions a virtue," said Art Siemering, the publisher of the Food Channel, a newsletter that tracks trends in the food industry. "You don't have to choose. You don't have to worry about what you might be missing. You can have it all."
At least that's what food manufacturers hope.
"Whenever profits are down, companies scramble to expand the equity in their brand names," said Dr. Susan Strasser, the author of "Satisfaction Guaranteed" (Pantheon, 1987), a history of marketing in America. The classic example is Arm & Hammer baking soda's move from the pantry shelf to the back of the refrigerator when it was marketed as an odor absorber. And now Knox gelatin is being used to fortify Strong Nail Cutex, a nail-polish remover.
And the gelatin market has diversified in edible areas, too. In the custardy netherworld where the impulse to eat something healthful competes with the urge to indulge in something sweet, Jell-O puddings now compete with similarly packaged yogurts, as well as puddings made by Hershey (with flavors ranging from Kisses to Chocolate Almond, along with the York Peppermint Pattie).
Dr. Strasser said the current recession had fueled a frenzied brand-name parthenogenesis of late. In addition to its puddings, Hershey has introduced Hershey's Cookies 'n' Mint, the first permutation of its classic milk-chocolate bar since almonds were added nearly a century ago. The bar, which is mildly flavored with mint and riddled with crunchy bits of dark chocolate cookies, "is Hershey's way of making sure customers don't stray," Dr. Strasser added.
"If they can sate the cookie and candy impulse in one package, they insure that Hershey's makes the money, not Keebler," she said.
George Rosenbaum, the president of Leo J. Shapiro, a market-research group in Chicago, acknowledges the economic sense of broadening brand appeal but said that the mix-in phenomenon was the second stage of a response to a shifting psychosocial market. Initially, he said, "radical dietary changes were authenticated for health reasons, and that forced some brands to update the equity in their names."
In a fat-fearing world, is it any surprise then that Land O Lakes butter and Skippy peanut butter will lend their names to cookies?
Facing similarly lean times, the alcoholic-beverage industry has responded with shelves of premixed offerings that range from Seagram's Gin & Juice to Bacardi's rum-and-fruit-juice Breezers and Jack Daniel's Lynchburg Limeade and Downhome Punch.
"Facing the fact that they have well-known names whose original products are not necessarily popular with the current generation," Mr. Shapiro said, "these brands either expanded into a market where indulgence is a given, tried to take on the trappings of healthfulness or looked to supply convenience."
What's more, he said, profits from processed food products, including all the mix-ins, are up to 20 percent higher than they are for individual ingredients, because companies charge more for them.
Merging brand names and updating images, Mr. Shapiro said, have long been ways of protecting a given market. But the mix-in phenomenon is something new. And most marketers agree that the idea has generational appeal.
The indecisiveness and self-indulgence that have long characterized the baby-boom generation led to a "profound willingness to reinvent and recombine foods," Mr. Shapiro said. They became even more adventuresome, he added, when faced with the strictures of health concerns.
Dr. Strasser calls the same appetite "the insatiable urge for new." This appetite is driven by a sense of adventure and a taste for variety. But even more, the mix-in market craves individual attention, the accommodation of idiosyncratic or bizarre tastes.
The mix-in concept was pioneered two decades ago by Steve Herrell, who founded Steve's Homemade Ice Cream in Somerville, Mass. There, customers routinely waited in line for 30 minutes for custom-blended ice-cream toppings. One customer would order Heath bars crumbled into coffee ice cream. Another would ask that Oreo cookies be smushed into vanilla-bean ice cream. Another wanted M & M's and cookies worked in.
Like the $7 manicures that began appearing around the same time, the $3.50 customized ice-cream cone was an affordable indulgence. More important, as the servers at Steve's scooped and blended ice cream and mix-ins on their marble counters, the customer also had the sense of being mogul-for-the-moment or at least king-of-the-cone.
"As soon as Steve's and Ben & Jerry's started making inroads in supermarkets, we started to see mix-ins moving into candies, other desserts and salty snacks," said Lynn Dornblazer, the publisher of New Product News in Chicago, a magazine for the grocery industry. "Now we are seeing yogurt packaged with granola to mix in and mix-in entrees."
Mr. Siemering of the Food Channel predicts these offerings are just the beginning. Customers, he said, "are crazed for variety, but they don't want to choose." He predicted that mix-ins would be the driving force of new grocery products in the next few years.
Call it the succotashing of cuisine.
"Girl Scout cookies in candy!" gasped 17-year-old Rita O'Leary, a high school student in Columbus, when she spotted a six pack of Hershey's Cookies 'n' Mint on the shelves of a local Kroger supermarket.
Through its spokeswoman, Bonnie Hinkson, Hershey denied any such inspiration. "We were simply looking for a new taste and texture to put in the familiar bar form," she said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Pay Dips at Hot Corner, Second Base and Outfield

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Not everyone who plays major league baseball is making more money than ever. According to salary information given to the Players Association executive board at its meeting in Boca Raton, Fla., yesterday, the average salaries of shortstops, third basemen and outfielders decreased this year. Not since 1987 have so many positions lost money.
The overall 1992 major league average soared, rising 20.8 percent to $1,028,667, the first time the average reached $1 million. Fourteen clubs averaged more than $1 million compared with eight last year. 
 The union average, as usual, was higher than the average computed by the Player Relations Committee for the clubs. The two sides figure certain parts of players' salaries differently. The clubs' average is $1,012,424, a 19.8 percent increase.
 
Averages Are Slipping
 The P.R.C. computed the median salary at $392,500, meaning half of the 772 players on major league rosters or disabled lists Aug. 31 earned more than that figure and half earned less.
The 18 shortstops who played 100 or more games (the union's qualifying level) saw their average drop from $1,146,403 to $1,142,552; the average for 21 third basemen fell from $1,151,853 to $1,056,778 and 63 outfielders had their average slip from $1,523,408 to $1,517,606.
In the previous four seasons, only two position groups had their average salaries decrease, but in 1987, shortstops and third basemen were the only ones whose averages didn't drop.
The highest-paid position this year was designated hitter, $2,415,591; relief pitcher the lowest, $853,096, the only one not at $1 million.
Toronto, seventh last season, was No. 1 in the team salary standing, supplanting Oakland. Atlanta took the largest economic leap, rocketing from 19th ($686,340) to 6th ($1,280,689) in the players' computations, an 86.6 percent increase.
The Cleveland Indians produced the steepest plunge, 26.8 percent, from $446,250 to $326,537.

HEADLINE: George Bush's Unfinished Business

 BODY:
Though President Bush may be brooding about his defeat, rewarding work awaits him in his final weeks. One major priority is to complete a task nobly begun -- disarming the nuclear-armed republics of the former Soviet Union.
He will have powerful allies should he decide to finish that task. Senators Sam Nunn and Richard Lugar recently went to Moscow and Kiev to move the disarmament deal along. But the job can't be done without the President's help. And it ought not to wait until Bill Clinton takes office. 
 There are two objectives to meet. One is an agreement on deeper cuts in Russian and U.S. nuclear arms. The other is persuading Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus to sign the Nonproliferation Treaty and dismantle their weapons.
The original Start treaty would have reduced Russian and American warheads to about 7,000 apiece. But an agreement reached in June would lower the ceiling on warheads to 3,000 to 3,500 each, and ban multi-warhead missiles on land.
Russia has finally responded to a U.S. draft treaty codifying the June agreement. Moscow has said it will seek changes to allow it to reduce the number of warheads on its missiles, thus avoiding the costs of building new single-warhead missiles and silos to shelter them. Washington can afford to be accommodating if it can verify the changes Moscow is proposing.
Actual disarming could be held up by Ukraine, which has yet to ratify the Start treaty and sign the Nonproliferation Treaty, as it promised. It has also been threatening to hold onto its 176 multi-warhead missiles unless it gets adequate compensation and some form of security guarantee.
Mr. Nunn and Mr. Lugar suggested useful ways to meet Kiev's demands. Under their plan, the U.S. would foot the bill for dismantling Ukrainian missiles and pay its share for the uranium extracted from warheads now in Ukraine. The two Senators also want Russia and the U.S. to cooperate in extending reasonable security assurances to Ukraine.
But they rightly warn that Ukraine risks political and economic isolation if it fails to carry out its nuclear pledges.
Now it's up to Mr. Bush to close the deals with Russia and the other nuclear republics. He could leave no finer legacy than to complete the task he has begun -- diminishing the nuclear danger.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
ROBERT KOTLOWITZ, former senior vice president and director of programming and broadcasting at WNET, Channel 13 in New York, has been named to a senior fellowship at the Freedom Forum Media Studies Center at Columbia University. Mr. Kotlowitz, who is now an editorial adviser at WNET, will use the fellowship to work on a book analyzing the impact of public broadcasting and will join the program, an independent affiliate of Columbia University, in January.
"For me it is a chance after many years at the station to step aside and look at what has happened in two decades," he said. "There is a powerful feeling that it has a constituency that has grown over the years and that does not really share economic and cultural values but is spread throughout the population. The common denominator is curiosity. I want to see how true that is and what it means." 
 Other 1992-93 fellows at the center include TERRY ANDERSON, the former hostage and Associated Press Middle East correspondent, and JAMES HOGE, the former publisher of The Daily News in New York. The Freedom Forum Media Studies Center was established in 1984 as a center for the study of mass communication and technological change.

HEADLINE: Europe's Doldrums;
Disputes Are Stalling the Search for Union -- Will Talks Next Week Get It Restarted?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 30

 BODY:
A year after optimistically setting course for monetary union later in the decade, the 12-nation European Community is riven by economic, monetary and political divisions, raising doubts whether it will ever become anything more than the single trading market due to take effect Jan. 1.
Instead of crowning that achievement by starting to carry out the ambitious treaty on currency union and closer foreign policy cooperation they agreed to a year ago in the Dutch city of Maastricht, the Europeans find themselves being driven apart. 
 A spreading and deepening recession, and the resulting political strains, have made French, German, Italian and British leaders all deeply unpopular.
Cutbacks in the generous social and labor benefits that many Europeans came to expect during the sheltered years of the cold war are increasing their leaders' unpopularity even further.
[Not all developments affecting European cohesion are negative, though. In Berlin Wednesday, the lower house of the German Parliament voted to ratify the Maastricht treaty, a step that Chancellor Helmut Kohl hopes will make it easier for Denmark, a dissenter in its first treaty referendum in June, to reconsider and accept the accord in 1993. Page A12.]
The next opportunity to chart a course out of the morass will come when European leaders gather in Edinburgh on Dec. 11-12, but even on such a basic community issue as trade they have been at odds, with France threatening to veto an agreement to reduce agricultural subsidies that is the prerequisite for a new global trade accord.
"The mood in all of Central Europe is that the world is collapsing all around it," a senior Western official commented in Vienna the other day. "All the political leaders seem to be at the end of the cycle, and all the major countries are in a period of economic decline. The result has been a crucial collapse of political credibility in Western Europe."
 
Europe's Biggest Failure
 Many Europeans look eagerly to President-elect Bill Clinton's administration to provide American leadership in coping with the social and political chaos that took them by surprise after the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
The war in the Balkans is seen as the biggest European failure, with the European Community no more able to agree on effective measures to halt or deter Serbian aggression than the American-led NATO alliance. Instead of the common defense policy they aimed for in the Maastricht treaty, the European countries cannot even agree to send troops to trouble spots like Bosnia and Herzegovina or Somalia, with the Germans arguing that their Constitution forbids it.
European leaders say they remain committed to the treaty and to its principle of closer economic and political cooperation, but with a Danish rejection now standing, the treaty's future is unclear.
Even if it is finally ratified by all 12 countries and goes into effect, its major provisions for a common currency by 1999 and broader welfare and social benefits in most countries now seem destined to remain dead letters in the face of economic penury everywhere, officials from most of the major countries privately concede. All that seems certain now is the creation of a single European market on Jan. 1 that will allow the free flow of goods, services and capital.
Two weeks before the Edinburgh meeting, the 12 have not even been able to agree on a financial package for a modest redistribution of wealth among themselves that they agreed on a year ago, with richer Northern European countries like Germany and Britain now pleading that budget difficulties make it hard for them to make big sacrifices for poorer neighbors like Greece, Spain and Ireland.
Nor is the pessimism just over economic issues. At a thronged Thanksgiving Day service at St. Paul's Cathedral, the United States Ambassador to Britain, Raymond G. H. Seitz, said: "In these days of historic change, we should remember that peace is not the natural order of things. It is an act of political will."
The longest era of stability in Europe this century ended three years ago when the Berlin wall came down and Communism began to collapse in the rest of eastern Europe.
Until then, the Western Europeans, safely protected from the threat of Soviet aggression by the American security umbrella, built a community of rich and prosperous welfare states.
Now, with the cold war behind them and unity before them, many countries are acting as if nothing really needed to change. Even in Germany, which absorbed 16.5 million people from the formerly Communist eastern part of the country in the 1990 reunification, well-off burghers from the west do not see why they should help their eastern cousins by giving up any of the generous benefits they became used to during the cold war.
Eastern German politicians like Wolfgang Thierse, an opposition Social Democrat, keep saying that real sacrifice, not just belt-tightening, will be required to make unification work smoothly, but nobody has yet started to pay real attention.
 
Financial System in Chaos
 Heavy German borrowing unleashed inflation, and the German central bank jerked up interest rates, sending chaos through the European financial system just as most countries were sinking into recession.
With the Maastricht treaty, they tried to move closer to economic and political union anyway, agreeing to establish a common currency as early as 1997. The economic strains and uncertainty about whether the French would reject the treaty in a referendum in September became too much for the European monetary system to handle.
Italy and Britain were forced to pull out, and Spain has twice had to devalue, despite the narrow French approval of the treaty in the referendum. Now new political uncertainty caused by the threat of a French veto over a new global tariff and trade agreement is putting pressure on the French franc and causing some to have second thoughts about the viability of the whole European monetary system.
"Most of the Maastricht provisions will clearly never happen," a British official said. German central bankers agree that a single European currency is an unrealistic prospect as long as European economies are as far apart as they are now. Things are likely to get worse, they say, as Germany, too, enters recession.
The first six months of next year threaten to be even more chaotic, with the trade talks unlikely to have been completed and the presidency of the European Community going to the Danes on Jan. 1 before they have even decided whether to be part of the Maastricht process.
The community decided this year that negotiations on letting Austria, Sweden, Finland, Norway, and possibly Switzerland become members could begin only after the Maastricht treaty had been ratified by all 12 existing members. The Austrian Chancellor, Franz Vranitzky, said in Vienna last week that he hoped talks could begin anyway in January even though ratification will not be complete.
An aide to Prime Minister John Major of Britain said here, "We'd like to get agreement at Edinburgh to start negotiations on expansion in January, but we don't think we'll get it."
Delay on letting in these prosperous would-be members, in turn, puts off the day when new democracies will even be allowed to apply.
But giving the Eastern Europeans, the Russians, the Ukrainians and other former Soviet lands hope for the future is seen as a crucial challenge. Germany, which is closest to the social and economic turmoil and the first stop for refugees, is increasingly anxious and deeply unsettled, with a deadly neo-Nazi backlash against the arrival of about a million asylum-seekers over the last three years.
The Austrian Defense Minister, Werner Fasslabend, sounded the alarm in Vienna this month about a "zone of instability like nothing in the past hundred years" that extended from the Baltic to the Black Sea. Despite Austria's usual neutrality, he said, the country could join the defense arm of the European Community, the Western European Union, if it became a member.
This organization, foreseen as the nucleus of a common European defense, is now enforcing naval sanctions against Serbia in the Adriatic Sea and recently admitted Greece as its 10th member. NATO countries, most of whose European members also belong to the Western European Union, have also provided troops and military equipment to the United Nations peacekeeping mission in the Balkans.
But as Col. Andrew Duncan of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London said, "NATO has no desire to become a supranational peacekeeping force." And instability in Central Europe seems a lot less threatening and more distant from London than it does from Bonn or Berlin.
"It doesn't actually affect the lives of any country more than one country away from it," he said. As long as the turmoil seemed safely at arm's length from most Western countries, they would be unlikely to become any more involved in trying to halt it than they were in Yugoslavia.
"We have no deterrence to that sort of conflict because nobody's prepared to do anything about it," Colonel Duncan said.
The only way this would change is if the United States took the lead. Some American diplomats in Europe think it should. "We have a choice like the one we had in 1946 and 1947," one said. "That was a postwar situation; this is a postwar situation. If we just sit back and let them fight it out, Europe is going to turn into a big problem for us."
Others are not so sure. The only thing everybody agrees on is that Europe is not likely to provide the Clinton Administration with a foreign policy holiday.

HEADLINE: INSURERS, IN SHIFT, ASK U.S. TO REQUIRE COVERAGE FOR ALL

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
In a sharp break from past practice, the health insurance industry called today for a new Federal law that would require coverage for all Americans, define a basic set of benefits and try to contain health-care costs by limiting tax breaks for the purchase of insurance.
The board of directors of the Health Insurance Association of America, representing 270 commercial insurers, adopted a policy statement today declaring that "the insurance industry itself needs reform." 
 The industry has often been described as an obstacle to change in the nation's health-care system. But with the new proposal, to be announced Thursday, the industry signals its willingness to accept sweeping changes, many of them similar to those proposed by President-elect Bill Clinton.
 
Details to Be Worked Out
 Details of the insurers' proposal remain to be worked out. Many of the unresolved issues are contentious. But Democrats and Republicans as well as business executives and labor unions agree that the nation must do something to help the 35 million people who do not have health insurance.
In a separate action today, the association adopted a policy stating that the health insurance industry would treat AIDS like any other physical illness. Current practice varies; some insurers have tried to avoid paying claims for AIDS and related illnesses.
Carl J. Schramm, president of the association, said the health benefits proposal was in the long-term financial interest of insurance companies. For more than a year, the insurers have been denouncing proposals for a Government-run program of national health insurance that would minimize the role of private insurers.
 
'Enlightened Self-Interest'
 "This is probably the only way you preserve the private health insurance industry," Mr. Schramm said. "It's plain-out enlightened self-interest."
The insurers, like Mr. Clinton, endorsed the idea of universal coverage, mandated by Federal law, along with new measures to control costs, including a larger role for the Government in supervising fees charged by doctors and hospitals. But the insurers did not support Mr. Clinton's proposal for an annual limit on all health spending, public and private.
The Health Insurance Association is one of many business groups that have offered to cooperate with Mr. Clinton since his election. Many of these groups previously opposed overhauling the health-care system but now say they see major changes as inevitable and want to help shape the results to their liking.
Ian M. Rolland, chairman of the board of directors of the association and chief executive of the Lincoln National Corporation, in Fort Wayne, Ind., said the new proposal was "radically different from positions taken by the industry in the past."
In Little Rock, Ark., Judith Feder, health policy coordinator for the Clinton transition team, welcomed the new proposal and described it as "a major turnaround" for members of the health insurance industry.
"It suggests they are willing to participate in the process of health-care reform," she said. "They seem to be demonstrating a commitment to universal coverage and cost containment, which we've not seen before."
The insurers' proposal may help break a logjam that has blocked Congressional action on comprehensive health legislation for the last two years. Dozens of bills died earlier this year amid partisan squabbling in the election campaign.
In announcing his candidacy on Oct. 3, 1991, Mr. Clinton said he would "take on the big insurance companies" in an effort to control health costs. He repeated that vow hundreds of times in the campaign.
The insurers' new position, unlike the old one, would require health insurance coverage for all Americans and limit the amount of tax-free health benefits that employees could get from their employers.
The proposal would require employees to pay a tax on the value of health insurance exceeding the standard package of benefits. This proposal is noteworthy because companies rarely propose a new tax on their own goods and services. Revenue from the health insurance tax would be used to help finance additional coverage for poor people, fewer than half of whom are now covered by Medicaid.
 
Four Main Elements
 The industry's new proposal, set forth in a discussion paper adopted unanimously today by the board of the association, is incomplete. But the proposal has these four main elements:
*Through unspecified tax incentives for employers and tax penalties for consumers who do not purchase insurance, the Government would require all Americans to buy "an essential package" of health benefits. If the Government fails to achieve universal coverage in this way, then "it may become necessary to require employers to help finance such coverage," the insurance industry said. Most big companies already provide health benefits to employees, but 30 million workers and dependents have no coverage.
*The Government would help define the essential package of benefits. The package, though not described in detail, would go beyond minimum benefits and would meet "most of the needs of Americans" for doctors' services and hospital care. Private insurers would agree to provide the standard coverage, regardless of a person's medical history.
*The open-ended Federal subsidy for health insurance would be curtailed. If employers bought insurance covering more than the essential package of benefits for their employees, the premiums paid for that extra coverage would be treated as income to the employees, and they would have to pay income tax on it. The core benefits would still be tax-free. Under current law, none of the employer-provided health benefits are taxable. Economists say these tax breaks contribute to the costly overuse of health care, by encouraging companies to overinsure their employees.
*The Government would work with insurers and providers of care to reduce the immense variation in payments to doctors and hospitals. Private insurers and Government programs would eventually have to pay similar amounts for the same services in the same geographic area. Medicaid and Medicare, the programs for poor people and the elderly, now usually pay less than private insurers.
Mr. Schramm said this recommendation "represents a sea change because it implies that insurers are willing to consider a larger role for Government in overseeing the prices charged by doctors and hospitals."
 
Shift Costs
 The Health Insurance Association said the standard rates would help stabilize health-care prices and would prevent the Government from shifting costs to patients with private insurance.
The insurers are eager to promote competition in the health-care market, but recognize that a decade of competition has not restrained the growth in medical prices, now rising twice as fast as other consumer prices. The association has not decided on the proper balance between regulation and free-market competition, one of the most delicate issues in any plan to revamp the health-care system.
The Federal Government has already established fee schedules for doctors and hospitals under Medicare, and some private insurers have begun to use similar price lists.
In January, President Bush seriously considered taxing a portion of the health benefits received by some workers. But he abandoned the idea after Republican members of Congress warned him that such a tax would cause a political uproar on Capitol Hill. The commercial insurance industry is now offering a similar proposal.
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, chairman of the National Governors' Association, said Tuesday that governors wanted to limit the tax deductions that employers could take for the cost of providing health benefits to workers. At present, there is no limit on such deductions.
The new proposal, describing the insurers' vision for the next decade, was drafted by a committee of the Health Insurance Association headed by G. David Hurd, chief executive of the Principal Financial Group, in Des Moines. Mr. Hurd endorsed Mr. Clinton in September, saying the Democratic candidate "will take a progressive view of national health care reform" while preserving a big role for private insurance.
The association began developing the new policy in February. The board took straw votes on it in September, two months before the Presidential election.
"This policy has been in the works for a long time," Mr. Schramm said. "We would have taken these positions whether Bill Clinton won or not."
In an interview, Mr. Rolland, the chairman of the Health Insurance Association, said: "There is a general recognition within the industry that we had an image problem and needed to address it. The desire to be regarded more favorably by the public has led to a lot more receptivity to change. We recognize that there will be significant change and that defense of the status quo is just not a viable strategy."
Under its plan, the association said, "no one would have to worry about losing insurance coverage because of bad health or switching jobs."
The package of essential benefits would be the same for rich and poor alike. But people could buy additional coverage to supplement the package, just as many elderly people buy private insurance to fill gaps in Medicare.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Proposals"
 
Universal coverage. Through tax incentives and penalties, the Government would require that Americans have health insurance.
 
Essential benefits. The Government would help define "an essential package of benefits." Insurers would provide coverage, regardless of a person's medical history.
 
Insurance tax. To hold down costs, the Government would limit tax-free health benefits.
 
Cost control. Private insurers, Medicare and Medicaid would eventually pay similar amounts for the same services in the same geographic area.

HEADLINE: Resort (Not Too African) for Rich Tourists

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUN CITY, South Africa

 BODY:
You are in Africa, but in no particular place.
The drizzling rain forest says the latitude is tropical. But that grove of pendulous baobab trees, still adjusting to their new home just across the lagoon-sized swimming pool, implies savannah. The architecture is neither Luxor nor Marrakesh nor Kalahari game lodge, but something of each, only more so. You are a bit lost. 
 You are, in fact, in the Lost City, the most audacious and most deafeningly hyped theme resort in the Southern hemisphere, at least.
 
Crocodiles at the 13th Hole
 This is Africa as it might have been had Steven Spielberg and Donald Trump conspired to reinvent the continent for a clientele of wealthy sheiks: a drought-proof, disease-free, nonviolent and nondenominational, $210-a-night-and-up Africa with a three-story water slide, an ocean where a panic button stops the waves if a swimmer gets in trouble, a nightly volcanic eruption (featuring "non-allergenic smoke"), a golf course with live crocodiles in the 13th-hole water hazard.
And -- because history in Africa is so troublesome -- the resort has its own myth, involving a peaceloving, rich, environmentally correct and watersport-loving tribe of founders known as the Ancients.
 
Casino Impresario's Vision
 The Lost City, which opened this week, is the brainstorm of a son of immigrants from Russia who has made a fortune peddling high-priced fancies to South Africans, and who now, with the political awakening of the region, intends to peddle them to the globe.
It is a $300 million gamble that when white rule gives way to democracy in South Africa, tourists will storm the subcontinent in a spending frenzy, and that they will want to experience Africa, as long as it is not too -- African.
"I believe that people aren't going to travel all the way to visit us here in South Africa to see what they could see elsewhere in the world," said Sol Kerzner, the South African hotel and casino impresario, musing over his 62-acre fantasy from a veranda of its hotel, the Palace, a colossal, snicker-defying cathedral of blushing towers and blue domes, elephant tusks and kudu gargoyles and thousands of individually pre-cast concrete palm fronds.
"And consequently I began to visualize ----"
The developer clicked his silver worry beads, recalling his vision, now executed here with the aid of a California architect and a Texas design team.
 
Sun City's Neighbor
 "I saw a major African jungle with rivers, with waterfalls, with what you would expect in a jungle, and that the concept would revolve around that, and the animals of Africa," he said.
This white man's fantasy of Africa is 100 miles northwest of Johannesburg, within another white man's fantasy of Africa -- Bophuthatswana, one of four nominally independent tribal homelands invented by South Africa's racial scientists in the apartheid heyday as repositories for unwanted blacks.
Bophuthatswana's independence is not taken seriously by any country except South Africa, or, for that matter, by those of its citizens who are not on the payroll of its authoritarian ruler.
Thirteen years ago, when this homeland was still newly minted, Mr. Kerzner built here the Las Vegas-style Sun City complex as a place where South Africans could escape the Puritan constraints of their own society to enjoy gambling and bare-breasted chorus lines in an interracial setting. It, and Lost City, are two hours' drive from Johannesburg.
 
Politics Becomes Tricky
 The apartheid fiction of the independent black homelands has been an asset to Mr. Kerzner's casino empire, which also has resorts in the ostensible states of Ciskei and Transkei. Homeland law liberated Mr. Kerzner from the anti-gaming laws of the motherland, from the South African trade unions that are banned here, and from the tediously accountable ways of democracy.
Bophuthatswana's dictator, Lucas Mangope, for example, did not need to fret about protest from the drought-stricken farmers and one-pump villages of the region when he agreed to build the new water lines that deliver the 2.6 million gallons of water a day to water the Lost City's gardens, fill its artificial lakes, and flush the toilets in its 338-room hotel.
But Bophuthatswana is not the refuge it once was. First the anti-apartheid cultural boycott of the mid-1980's put Sun City off limits as a venue for world-class talent. Then a recession and a proliferation of unregulated mom-and-pop casinos in South Africa whittled Sun City's gambling revenues.
Now with South Africa on the verge of majority rule, homeland politics has become tricky in a way that must make Mr. Kerzner yearn for the simple, imaginary civilization of the Lost City's ancients.
 
Threat of Embarrassment
 Bophuthatswana and other homelands are expected to be reabsorbed into a South Africa governed, most likely, by the African National Congress. Until that happens, Mr. Kerzner must hedge his bets, keeping simultaneous peace with his present and future rulers, who despise each other.
Mr. Kerzner has befriended senior dignitaries in the African National Congress, but the congress's local representatives still accuse him of maintaining the Mangope regime with Sun City tax revenues and of bolstering the pretense that Bophuthatswana is a separate country.
The tensions between the homeland regime and its foes in South Africa present Mr. Kerzner with a constant threat of embarrassment.
The week Mr. Kerzner opened his resort to scores of freeloading journalists, Bophuthatswana planned to hang three convicted murderers, provoking an outcry from human-rights advocates in South Africa, where the death penalty is suspended. The hangings were stayed, reportedly after an appeal from a Sun City executive, for 90 days, until well after the opening of Lost City and the million-dollar golf tournament and Miss World pageant that are billed here in early December.
 
Betting on Tourist Dollars
 That is one woe postponed, but there are others. South African churchmen have harangued Bophuthatswana for its lack of political freedom. The African National Congress local has warned it might disrupt the Miss World pageant if it turns into a showcase for Bophuthatswana's "independence." Workers angry over layoffs at other hotels in Mr. Kerzner's Sun chain are contemplating a boycott of the Lost City.
Worse yet, Mr. Mangope has hinted he may resist giving up power to the new South Africa, creating the kind of political crisis that tends to give international tourists cold feet.
"The fact of the matter is we operate here," Mr. Kerzner said, irritably rejecting the notion that Sun City is "propping anybody up." "The de facto issue is that President Mangope is the president, he has a government, they have statutes, and we have to operate within those statutes.' '
Mr. Kerzner is betting that, whoever comes out on top, all will be forgiven in the craving for tourist dollars to underwrite an even grander reinvention, that of South Africa.
"At the end of the day," the mogul said, "whoever governs, you don't want to be governing a wasteland."

HEADLINE: Educators Seeking Common Ground Under Clinton

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Usually fractious education groups here have found education principles they can all support, hoping to capitalize on President-elect Bill Clinton's longtime interest in education.
Representatives of 21 major national education organizations have been working together since September to devise a list of education goals they could support. Today, 18 of the groups sent the document to Congress. 
 But gathering the signatures for it illustrated just how difficult it is for the educational community to work together. Some organizations declined to sign, saying their needs did not mesh with those of the other groups.
The American Federation of Teachers was one of the last signers, deciding only late today to support the principles outlined in the document. "They just really wanted to go through it and make sure it jibes with the A.F.T. interests," said Janet Bass, a spokeswoman for the teachers federation.
Michael Edwards, manager of Congressional relations for the National Education Association, the other major teachers' union along with the A.F.T., said his organization would submit its own document to the House and Senate education committees.
The Council of Great City Schools, representing the nation's major urban schools, also declined to sign the document.
 
Groups' Recommendations
 Still, according to Gordon M. Ambach, executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers and a leading force behind the document, this is the first time that the education community has got together on a legislative effort of this magnitude.
The groups' recommendations include better coordination between what students learn in school and their jobs after high school, more emphasis on helping students learn new technologies, and increased support for early childhood development programs.
One reason the education groups have tried to work more closely on this, Mr. Ambach said, is that they felt the new Administration would be more supportive of education interests than the previous two. He also said tough economic times had forced the groups to work together.
"For 12 years the education organizations have had to play defense against Reagan-Bush, and now there is an opening to move on a major agenda," Mr. Ambach said. "We must have the education team going in the same direction." His organization represents the top state officials responsible for education in each of the 50 states.
The main focus of all the education groups is the reauthorization next year of the elementary and secondary education acts, the principal Federal education legislation. This year it delivered $10.9 billion to the nation's school districts.
When the legislation was originally passed in 1965, the nation's education focus was on supporting disadvantaged students. Recent education research and analysis suggests that along with issues of equity between rich and poor districts, the whole educational system needs upgrading.
 
Main Disagreement
 The main area of disagreement among the education groups is on whether the legislation should simply be reauthorized, with only the spending levels to be debated, or whether it should be the vehicle for redefining the Federal role in education. Mr. Clinton supports national education standards and national testing, but that emphasis makes some groups nervous.
Mr. Ambach said the incoming Administration offered the usually divisive education community an "extraordinary, exciting" opportunity because Mr. Clinton, as Governor of Arkansas, was the leading Democrat in helping to write and establish the national education goals issued by the National Governors Association and the Bush Administration in September 1989.
Congressional aides say the shift to cooperation among the education groups could be helpful in drafting and passing education legislation with a minimum of conflict next year.

HEADLINE: World Events Force Clinton to Divert Attention to Foreign Affairs

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 2

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton, who had the luxury of running a political campaign that focused on the domestic issues he knew best, is now grappling with a transition period that has forced him to address the shifting grounds of foreign policy.
Today he talked to Caribbean leaders and to President Bush, who briefed him on the status of a United Nations resolution regarding military intervention in Somalia. 
 Aides to the President-elect insist he is still spending most of his time selecting a Cabinet, a process that he has kept secretive. But as political turmoil grows in Russia and international intervention becomes more likely in Somalia, the few public pronouncements that have emerged from the Clinton transition team have been about anything but the domestic economy.
 
Foreign Affairs Catch-Up
 "There are a series of challenges out there that a new team coming in would need to understand -- not only the nature and essence of the problem, but also understand the kind of urgency they would have to deal with," said a Bush Administration official involved in the transition.
Some of Mr. Clinton's advisers admit privately that events have caught the Clinton transition team somewhat off guard. While Mr. Clinton has sought to devote the interregnum to quiet deliberation about the shape of his new Government, the Bush Administration's actions abroad, especially asking the United Nations to send troops to Somalia, have forced much recent scrutiny of the new President to center on his weakest area of expertise.
But others involved in advising Mr. Clinton on foreign matters have said they expected much of the current activity and that the President-elect has spent relatively little time on it.
 
International Phone Calls
 "Foreign policy is not the type of issue you can always plan or manage like formulating a budget or putting together your Government," said Nancy Soderberg, a foreign policy adviser to Mr. Clinton.
Nonetheless, Mr. Clinton has taken time from his schedule to receive telephone calls from President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and a number of other world leaders including President Ibrahim Babangida of Nigeria, President F. W. de Klerk of South African and the the African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela, Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao of India, President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine, Georgian leader Eduard A. Shevardnadze, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea, President Francois Mitterand of France, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, Prime Ministers John Major of Great Britain, Constantine Mitsotakis of Greece and Kiichi Miyozawa of Japan.
 
'We Have Only One President'
 "We're in regular contact with the Administration, and it's fairly continuous right now," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director. "Again, we have only one President. It's President Bush's responsibility right now to work with the U.N. and to make that policy."
When Mr. Clinton has ventured to speak about foreign policy matters, he has been equally cautious.
He has said he generally supports the President's decision to send American troops to Somalia to insure the safe delivery of relief supplies. He sent a spare, one-paragraph letter of support to President Yeltsin in advance of his meeting with the Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow this week. He has stayed as far out of the fray as he can on the question of what the United States' continuing role should be in the internal conflicts in the Balkans.
And today, he said in a speech to a meeting of Caribbean leaders that he rejects "those who would use violence against democratically elected governments," presumably a reference to the leaders of Haiti, who came to power after ousting President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
He used the speech, delivered by satellite, to transform the discussion about foreign policy into one about the domestic economy, a tactic he used successfully during the campaign.
"We cannot hope to be fruitfully involved in the things which you are discussing today unless we are strong enough to be an economic leader," Mr. Clinton told the conference on trade, investment and development in the Caribbean.
But even in his statement today, he stopped short of using the harsh language he had employed in his campaign. A few months ago, he was often highly critical of the Bush Administration's refusal to allow Haitian refugees to stay in the United States as the victims of political persecution.
Samuel Berger, who is heading Mr. Clinton's foreign policy operation, speaks every day with Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser. The Central Intelligence Agency has set up an office in Little Rock from which to deliver a copy of the National Intelligence Daily to Mr. Clinton.
The President-elect also receives a daily 15-minute oral briefing on security matters that aides say is the same one Mr. Bush gets at the White House.
It is clear that Clinton aides are not entirely in the loop on the most delicate matters being decided in Washington. Earlier this week, when the United States was circulating a draft copy of a United Nations resolution concerning joint action on Somalia, top Clinton aides knew nothing about it.
But they may not be entirely unhappy with such circumstances.
"In many cases, there are instances where they would just as soon see this President go ahead and make the decision and relieve them of the need to do so," the Administration official said.

HEADLINE: Colorado Faces Boycott Over Its Gay-Bias Vote

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Furious that Colorado voters appeared to sanction bigotry against homosexuals, some tourists are canceling plans to come to the Rockies and a television production company picked another state to shoot a movie.
"This is too blatant an act to ignore," said Joyce Miller, president of the Coalition of Labor Union Women, referring to voters' approval of a binding referendum that repealed ordinances in Denver, Boulder and Aspen that barred discrimination against homosexuals and forbade any city in the state to pass similar ordinances. "This is a basic violation of civil rights." 
 The women's group has canceled its 1,500-member convention that had been scheduled for Denver in November 1993. In addition, the Atlanta City Council banned official travel to Colorado, and other cities, including San Francisco, are taking steps to follow suit.
Reaction to the November vote has already cost the state at least $10 million in lost tourism from four canceled conventions, said William Burford, an economist at Denver University.
 
$5 Billion From Tourists
 Tourism is to Colorado what corn is to Iowa. It generates about $5 billion in revenue a year here.
"If I were the tourist people, I would be very nervous right now," Mr. Burford said.
Although the resorts in Aspen say rooms and lodges are virtually all booked around Christmas, the glitzy ski community has taken out advertisements in newspapers, including Variety, to proclaim its opposition to the anti-gay-rights vote.
This is a state that has always enjoyed its image as a beautiful land where tolerant, progressive people live in a casual atmosphere. It has always been considered rather hip to be a Coloradoan.
Now suddenly the anti-gay-rights vote has cast an entirely different image: a backward state that wishes to discriminate.
"You hear people now say, I'm ashamed of being from Colorado," said Deborah Milo Cornelius, a spokeswoman for the Colorado Tourism Board. "A lot of people are still in denial. They just can't believe this has happened."
 
Family Values Group
 The push for the amendment was led by a conservative group called Colorado for Family Values, which contended anti-discrimination laws amounted to special rights that would lead to higher quotas in affirmative action programs.
Business and political leaders have been meeting to devise ways to avert the losses in Arizona because it did not have a holiday in recognition of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. That state lost an estimated $500 million before it finally voted last year to honor the civil rights leader.
The Colorado vote has provoked much debate among Hollywood people, many of whom own property in Aspen or spend a lot of time at the resort. Some celebrities say they will not set foot in Colorado, but others have balked at the idea of a boycott, arguing that Aspen is a beacon of progressive values.
Talk of a possible boycott of Colorado was raised last week by the singer Barbra Streisand, who later seemed to back away from it.
Denver's Mayor, Wellington Webb, who has acknowledged that results of the vote on Nov. 3 could seriously harm the state's $5 billion a year tourism industry, has been campaigning against any boycott wherever he can find an audience.
He arranged to be on the Arsenio Hall show tonight to make the case that a boycott would be unfair and counterproductive.
 
Boycott Seen as Unfair
 He noted that voters in Denver, Boulder and Aspen, places that would suffer most from any boycott, voted against the referendum. Those cities have filed suit in Federal court, saying the measure violates the equal protection clause of the Constitution.
"Before you're critical of us, ask yourself two questions," Mayor Webb said. "Does the state in which I live have a gay rights law? Could a similarly worded referendum have passed in my state?"
Only seven states have laws that ban discrimination in jobs or housing on the basis of sexual orientation.
The Mayor also warned that people resent being lectured by outsiders, so that a boycott would probably hamper efforts to overturn the anti-gay-rights measure, known here as Amendment 2.
 
Conferences Canceled
 In addition to the women's labor union group, others who have canceled conferences here include the American Association of Law Libraries, the National Center for the Social Studies and the National Organization for Women.
A television production company, Laurel Entertainment Inc., which had considered Colorado as a site for a new Stephen King movie, has decided to go elsewhere because of the referendum.
"Frankly, it was neck and neck between yourselves and another state until recently," Richard P. Rubinstein, Laurel's president, wrote to the Colorado Film Commission, "when a new factor surfaced and swung the decision away from Colorado, i.e. the passage of what we consider to be anti-gay legislation by the majority of Colorado voters."
In another protest, Armistead Maupin, a gay author, canceled a stop in Denver on his book tour.
Susan Anderson, the head of the Gay and Lesbian Community Center in Denver, said a boycott would "send a message to other states" that might be considering an anti-gay-rights measure. But she also expressed concern that "we're hurting the wrong people," by refusing to come to Denver, Boulder or Aspen, places where the measure was soundly defeated.
Rather than a boycott, the tennis star Martina Navratilova is considering another response. Ms. Navratilova, who is gay, has vowed to move from Aspen if the measure is not overturned.
"I will not pay taxes in a state that does not recognize me as an equal citizen," she wrote in a recent article in USA Today.

The Economy
Health insurers called for a Federal law requiring coverage for all Americans, asking the Government to define a basic set of benefits and limit tax breaks for the purchase of insurance. The move was a signal that the industry would accept sweeping changes like those proposed by President-elect Clinton. [Page A1.]
Standardized labels for all packaged food were announced by the Bush Administration, taking effect in 1994. [A1.] 
 Sales of new homes fell 10.3 percent in October, the first drop after five monthly increases. The drop, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 600,000, followed a huge upward revision in September's figures -- to a 7 percent increase, from the initial report of a 1 percent drop -- to the highest sales rate this year. Housing industry analysts pointed out that the Government has regularly revised its initial sales figures upward for more than a year, and they suggested that October's figure likely will be changed to show a smaller fall than the 10.3 percent plunge. [D1.]

Directors of Comptronix learned of wrongdoing in the executive suite at least 10 days before they disclosed that news to public investors, the company's interim chairman confirmed. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Kennebunkport Journal;
Bushes' Retreat Is in Transition, Too

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Dec. 1

 BODY:
The election returns had barely been tabulated before some shopkeepers on Dock Square began marking down the George Bush coffee mugs and T-shirts. Raymond Crepeau, a local car dealer, has been doing a brisk trade in used Secret Service minivans -- low mileage, discounted, and a story to pass on to the grandchildren.
After 12 years in the national spotlight, residents of this coastal community in southern Maine are preparing for life after Jan. 20, when its most famous summer resident becomes plain Citizen Bush. Some of the changes were already evident when Mr. Bush returned to Maine to spend the Thanksgiving holiday at his vacation home on Walker's Point. 
 Only a handful of reporters and photographers kept a vigil outside the Cape Arundel golf course, where the President slogged through 18 holes despite a chill fog and heavy drizzle.
The journalists will be missed, sort of. The townspeople have enjoyed the attention even while maintaining the requisite air of Yankee diffidence.
The sightseers will be missed, too, especially by the souvenir merchants and fast food purveyors. Shops like the Mountain Tops have turned a nice profit on T-shirts featuring the likenesses of President Bush, his wife, Barbara, and their dog, Millie. The Old Salt's Pantry has done well peddling a relish labeled Bush Sauce ("Excellent With Quail").
But nobody will miss the demonstrators, who turned up whenever the Bushes were in residence to clog the narrow streets, chant slogans, wave signs, blow whistles and otherwise inspire the locals to keep indoors or leave town.
"It's always been a resort, so we were used to the crowds," said Town Clerk Janet Winters. "But the demonstrations were the major change. We had Act-Up and pro-life and pro-choice and Lithuanian rights -- any reason that somebody could think of to come by, they did. We had the broccoli bunch for a week."
Even though the town is losing a President, residents seem confident about its commercial future.
"It's going to be fine," said Karen Arel, executive director of the Kennebunkport Chamber of Commerce. "The summer crowd was coming here long before Bush was President, since the 1800's. In 1988, before he was even elected, we had our best year."
Ms. Arel expects family vacationers and crowd-shunning regulars who avoided coming when the Bushes were in town to take up the slack next year in the big motels where the journalists and White House staff members have stayed. She said her office is receiving up to 50 calls a day from people out of state seeking lodging reservations for the 1993 season.
Sgt. Gary Ronan of the police department said that he and his colleagues would miss the overtime pay that came with Presidential visits but that otherwise he does not envision much of a dislocation after Mr. Bush leaves the White House.
The police force, which consists of 11 officers, was not expanded for the Summer White House years. Security for the Bush family is provided by the Federal Government, and state troopers are brought in to help with crowd control when necessary.
Kennebunkport has a year-round population of less than 3,500. Even in normal times, that can swell to about 25,000 in the summer, leaving traffic snarled in the tiny downtown area.
No one doubts that Mr. Bush will continue to spend summers here, as he has almost every year since he was a child, and the Secret Service will continue to provide protection for him once he leaves office.
But local residents, who seem genuinely fond of the Bushes (he carried the town with 50 percent of the vote while the state went for Bill Clinton), expect to see more of them. The President and his wife avoided the downtown area in recent years because of the disruptions their visits touched off.
"He'll be more accessible," Ms. Arel predicted. "Before, even as Vice President, he felt free to shop and eat in the village or visit the American Legion and speak on a Memorial Day. Barbara would go to the florist and into the dress shops. Then they stayed away."
