HEADLINE: A Study's Answer to the Costliest Drug: Economize

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
The annual cost of treatment with what is often called the world's most expensive drug can be cut by hundreds of thousands of dollars a person simply by giving smaller doses more frequently, a study concludes.
The drug, Ceredase, is the only treatment for Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited illness most common among descendants of Eastern European Jews that causes swelling of the liver and spleen. 
 The drug, approved by the Federal Government last year, is extremely expensive, in part because it is extracted in tiny quantities from human placentas. The first year of treatment costs about $380,000 for an adult who is administered the recommended dose.
But researchers from the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, Calif., found that by changing the schedule of doses, patients do as well on one-fourth the recommended amount of medicine.
 
One Maker Under the Law
 The treatment was discovered and initially tested by researchers at the National Institutes of Health. It was later developed and brought to market by Genzyme Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.
The company sells the medicine under the Federal Orphan Drug Act, which offers financial incentives and seven years of exclusive marketing rights for finding medicines for rare illnesses. The high cost of Ceredase is sometimes cited by critics of the law, who say it encourages unreasonably high prices.
The latest study, conducted by Dr. Michael L. Figueroa and others, is being published on Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine.
Gaucher's disease, which afflicts an estimated 20,000 Americans, results from a genetic defect that interferes with an enzyme needed to break down a kind of fat. As a result, these fats build up in the liver, spleen and bone marrow. The severity of the disease varies greatly. It can be fatal, especially when symptoms begin in childhood.
Ceredase replaces the missing enzyme. One unit of the medicine costs $3.50 and contains four-millionths of an ounce of liquid. A medication plan worked out by doctors at the National Institutes of Health recommends that people receive 60 units for every kilogram they weigh. The guidelines suggest the medicine be given every other week for most patients.
This adds up to $380,000 a year for an adult who weighs 70 kilograms, or about 150 pounds.
The Scripps researchers theorized that because the medicine disappears quickly from the bloodstream, it could be given far more efficiently if it was split into many small doses. They found that 2.3 units for every kilogram taken three times a week works as well.
"Cost was uppermost in our minds when we did this, because our patients could not afford the enzyme," said Dr. Ernest Beutler, the senior author of the study.
A spokeswoman for Genzyme, Donna LaVoie, said that new guidelines being developed by the National Institutes of Health suggest cutting the recommended high dose in half after the first year of treatment and cutting it further as time goes by.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Plummet 10.3%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell sharply in October, the first drop after five monthly increases, the Commerce Department said today.
The 10.3 percent drop in sales to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 600,000 came after a huge upward revision in September's figures to the highest sales rate this year. 
 Housing industry analysts pointed out that the Government has regularly revised its sales figures upward for more than a year, and they suggested that October's figure was likely to be changed to show a smaller fall.
The Commerce Department said September sales jumped 7 percent, to an annual rate of 669,000, surpassing January's 667,000 rate, for the strongest monthly sales this year. The department previously estimated that September sales fell 1 percent from the August rate. With the revised figure for September, sales of new homes had risen for five straight months until October's drop.
 
Firming Market
 "They've pushed these figures up every month now since August 1991," said David Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. "Our own monthly survey of builders in early November shows that after a second-quarter relapse there has been a firming of tone in the market and gradual increases in sales."
The 10.3 percent drop in October sales was the sharpest since an 11.5 percent decline in March. It was concentrated in the Northeast, where sales fell 43.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 55,000.
 In other regions, the monthly sales drop from September was much smaller -- down 6 percent in the South, 4.9 percent in the Midwest and 1.2 percent in the West.
 After a quick start at the beginning of the year, sales of new homes slackened in the second quarter to an average annual rate of 561,000. But in the third quarter, sales recovered to 637,000 a month on average.
 October's annual sales rate was 14 percent higher than the 526,000-unit annual rate in October 1991.
 Housing is a big part of the economy. The industry is a big employer, from construction to real estate sales and furnishings. The buying of homes also measures consumers' optimism.
 Builders are counting on total new home sales of 600,000 in 1992, after a depressed 1991, when sales were only 509,000. For 1993, builders estimate that sales will rise to 675,000.
 "Higher interest rates in October are a worry, particularly if the rise was based simply on an expectation of what a Clinton Administration might mean for rates," Mr. Seiders said.
Lower mortgage rates and stable prices have made houses more affordable. But sales of new homes have struggled, with interest remaining most intense in the market for lower-priced existing homes.
 The real estate industry said last week that sales of existing homes climbed 9.1 percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.6 million, the highest level in nearly four years.
Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, said mortgage rates would probably stay level for the rest of this year and rise modestly in 1993.
 The average price of a new home in October rose to $152,600 from $142,300 in September, while the median price was $125,000, up from $119,000.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Slightly Higher But Focus Is on Strong Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended slightly higher yesterday, with the focus of trading firmly on European currencies and the high-flying German mark. Gold prices rose, with the spot price on the New York Commodity Exchange up 80 cents, to $335.90 an ounce.
The mark surged against the French franc, Italian lira and Danish krone, prompting central banks to intervene to support the weaker currencies. 
 European central banks have been forced to raise interest rates and intervene to protect currencies that have come under speculative selling pressure. The aim is keep them in line with each other under the ranges set in the European monetary system. With German interest rates relatively high -- and other European nations in recession -- the mark has benefited at the expense of its neighbors' currencies.
 
10-Week Low for Franc
 While the interventions helped restore stability, dealers feared speculators would return with a vengeance to drive the franc, lira and crown down.
The French franc, viewed as key to the survival of the exchange-rate mechanism in the monetary system, fell to a 10-week low of around 3.415 to the mark. It recovered to 3.4072 in late New York trading.
Guy Pasquier, a dealer at Credit Lyonnais, said the French franc got an immediate lift from the German central bank's intervention. But many traders wondered about the depth of the Bundesbank's resolve to help the embattled French currency.
In New York, the dollar ended at 1.5740 marks, up from 1.5730 late Tuesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.17 Japanese yen, down from 124.72 on Tuesday. Later in London, it rose to 124.35 yen. In late trading in New York, the dollar climbed to 124.42 yen from Tuesday's close of 124.15.
In London, the British pound rallied to $1.5500, from $1.5465 Tuesday. It edged up further to close in New York at $1.5525, compared with Tuesday's close at $1.5485.
In New York, the dollar eased to $1.2810 (Canadian), from $1.2818 (Canadian) Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Clinton Option: Sit Out the Fever

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IN "Catch-22," Joseph Heller's surrealist novel about World War II, G.I.'s who went to the infirmary with fevers above 102 degrees were hospitalized. Those with temperatures below 100 were sent back to the barracks. And those in between were parked on a bench until their fevers went up or down.
Waiting to see which way the economy's temperature turns is no laughing matter for millions wondering whether they will have jobs next year. But one can still glimpse irony in Bill Clinton's fiscal choices. The candidate swept into office by voters demanding that something -- anything -- be done to cure the recession is discovering that a lot of economists think it would be prudent to sit on the bench. Indeed, the President-elect may end up with the task of deflecting enthusiasm for an instant fix into budget reforms with an enduring but very slow payoff. 
 To everyone's surprise -- and George Bush's post-election chagrin -- the economy grew at an annual rate of 3.9 percent from July through September. That is the best quarterly gain since 1988. And while it is not the big leagues compared with other recoveries, Charles Schultze of the Brookings Institution thinks it is about as much bounce as could be expected from a relatively shallow recession.
The catch is that healthy growth has yielded virtually no change in total employment. The jobless rate is stuck at 7.4 percent -- higher than it was in February, when more than a third of New Hampshire's Republican primary voters expressed their disgust with the economic policy-as-usual by rejecting George Bush in favor of Pat Buchanan.
Job creation always lags behind growth during recoveries, because employers initially respond by demanding more work from underemployed people already on the payroll. But the lag this time is exceptional.
If Bill Clinton's luck holds, the employment dam will soon burst as corporations become convinced that the recovery is not another false start. That explains why Mr. Clinton is apparently planning to wait until January to make up his mind about the need for fiscal stimulus.
For what it is worth, though, the consensus forecast is for growth at the high end of the 2 to 3 percent range -- enough to keep the recovery going, but not enough to ratchet down unemployment by more than a few tenths of a percentage point next year. In fact, Paul Krugman of M.I.T. estimates that it would take three years of 3 percent growth to push unemployment below 6 percent.
Is slow but steady good enough? Ed Yardeni of the investment firm C. J. Lawrence speaks for many business economists when he argues that under the circumstances budget-busting fiscal stimulus would be bad economics and problematic politics.
"It looks like we have self-sustaining growth," he commented. "Why risk overheating the economy," he asks, thereby setting the stage for another recession before the 1996 election?
One answer is that the voters expect Mr. Clinton to do better. But Mr. Yardeni is skeptical. The President-elect's real worry, he suggests, is not the people without jobs, but the far greater numbers who watched unemployment drift higher through the Bush years and feared they would be next. As long as the jobs trend turns clearly positive, Mr. Yardeni argues, the President is on safe political ground. And he might even be applauded if, as Mr. Yardeni predicts, more productive businesses start raising wages to keep up employee morale.
Mr. Schultze is reluctant to give up on short-term stimulus if the alternative is years of less-than-full employment. But he would use it only as the decoration to an otherwise unattractive package of long-term deficit-reduction measures -- an increase in income taxes at the high end, perhaps, plus an attack on entitlements that benefit the affluent. And he would offer only the sort of stimulus that served long-term productivity goals. A short list would include tax credits for investment, and higher spending for infrastructure or training.
 Such a linkage would please the Perot crowd -- or, at least, those who actually paid attention to Mr. Perot's message. But it is difficult to see how any President could pull it off in a reasonable time. It is one thing to ask for speedy passage of stimulus that simply put money in people's pockets. It is quite another to invite Congress to fine-tune the economy, even as legislators swing an ax at the great spending lobbies.
One plausible linkage strategy might be to start with a temporary tax credit for investment, and then make credible deficit reduction the price for extending this popular business tax break. At worst, the economy would end up with temporary kick when it still might do more good than harm. At best, it might be also serve as the catalyst for serious budget reforms.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Up on Money Funds But Level of Assets Is Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were up slightly in the latest week, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report's most recent survey.
After declining for three consecutive weeks, tax-exempt yields moved up, as assets slipped by $159 million, to a total of $98 billion. Analysts said a heavy supply of new short-term municipal paper that reached market in the last few days was more than likely to affect yields this week. 
 The average number of days left to maturity of securities being held in fund portfolios fell to 62, from 64.
The seven-day average compounded tax-exempt yield was up a basis point, to 2.21, with the simple yield up a like amount, to 2.18 percent. Donoghue's statisticians calculate that over the course of 30 days, the average compounded yield is 2.22 percent, with the simple yield at 2.20 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Making no assumption for state taxes, the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield this week for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket comes out to about 3.07 percent, and 3.20 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
From its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market fund distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management was still outperforming the others, yielding 2.84 percent this week, or about one basis point lower than its yield in the previous survey.
 
Taxable Yield: 2.81%
 Among taxable money market funds, the average seven-day compounded and simple yields were both up three basis points, to 2.81 percent and 2.77 percent, respectively.
Assets of taxable funds were off by $12.2 billion, to a total of $475.9 billion. Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, assessed the situation this way: "Market yields, because of rising interest rates in short-term Treasury securities, are outperforming money market fund yields. As a result, investors are being drawn to other short-term investments and I expect that money market rates soon have to raise their yields if they are to remain competitive."
Donoghue's analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios slipped to 62, from 63.
The Dreyfus Basic Money Market was the top-yielding fund for the week, at 3.72 percent. Among government-only funds, United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services in San Antonio, had the best yield, at 3.90 percent.
This week, bank money market accounts, which compete directly with the funds, were yielding an average 2.77 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Lumber Prices in Retreat On Weak Home Sales Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lumber futures prices plummeted yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after the Government reported that new home sales had fallen after five monthly gains.
Although many analysts consider the report an unreliable predictor of building activity, it was enough to bring on profit taking in a market that had risen sharply in recent days. 
 On other commodity markets, hog futures fell sharply and cattle were mostly lower.
 
Two-by-Fours Tumble
 Spruce two-by-fours for January delivery tumbled the permitted daily limit of 5 cents, to $248.90 a board foot, in Chicago, ending a four-day advance in the lightly traded market. The loss wiped out nearly half of the $10.80 gain posted in the previous week on signs of tightening supplies and economic recovery.
Analysts said yesterday's report from the Commerce and the Housing and Urban Development Departments of a 10.3 percent drop in October home sales was a shock.
"The expectation was for a bit of improvement, with the improvement in the general economy and the lower interest rates," said Curt Cunningham, president of the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. He said futures traders had also responded to increased availability of lumber from wholesalers at prices below those asked by sawmills.
The home sales data are often revised and are considered a less important indicator of future lumber demand than the monthly report on building permits. Nevertheless, "we didn't need much of an excuse to start taking profits after the last three or four days," Mr. Cunningham said.
Bud Merrill, lumber analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in Eugene, Ore., agreed that the report offered an excuse for profit taking. He said he did not believe that the market's recent upward trend had been broken.
Pork futures tumbled on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on signs of rising pork belly stocks and worries that a seasonal rise in pork loin prices had not developed. Moreover, traders expect increased hog production to result in record pork production in December, said Chuck Levitt, Shearson's senior livestock analyst.
Cattle futures ended mostly lower in a relatively quiet performance after strong gains last week. Live cattle for December delivery ended 0.10 cent lower at 76.42 cents a pound; January feeder cattle fell 0.08 cent, to 83.77 cents a pound; December live hogs dropped 0.88 cent, to 44.12 cents a pound; February frozen pork bellies fell 0.95 cent, to 38.62 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Prediction for Clinton Plan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's economic stimulus program will provide a small lift to the economy next year, enough to make only a tiny dent in the unemployment rate, the nation's top business economists predicted today.
While Mr. Clinton has promised to focus like a "laser beam" on the economy once in office, the survey by the National Association of Business Economists found that analysts at some of the country's largest companies held decidedly low-key expectations for what the incoming President will be able to accomplish. 
 The association said the median expectation of 41 professional forecasters surveyed in late November was that Mr. Clinton's program would result in a slight, two-tenths of 1 percent increase in economic growth next year when compared with what they would have expected had President Bush won re-election.
While Mr. Clinton is still formulating his short-term economic program, he has indicated that two key elements will be investment tax credits for businesses and a rise in spending on roads, bridges and other public works projects of around $20 billion next year.
In a $6 trillion economy, such a package would represent only a small dose of fiscal stimulus, analysts said.
But the business economists group said it hoped Mr. Clinton would not listen to advisers who are urging him to take a bolder approach in an effort to get the unemployment rate down more quickly.

HEADLINE: A Couple Builds a Home So Healthful It Passes the Sniff Test

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

DATELINE: KIRKLAND, Wash.

 BODY:
ON the shore of Lake Washington here, six miles from Seattle, is a nearly $2 million condominium with hand-painted wallpaper in the dining room, a coromandel screen in the living room, and a pure silk comforter on the bed. But what really makes this home different is that the three-bedroom apartment and all its contents were selected to create an environment that does not make one of the owners ill.
John Shimer is one of many Americans who have environmental illness or multiple chemical sensitivities. When he smells fumes from some paints, automobile exhaust or ammonia, for example, his vision blurs, his speech slurs and his head aches. 
 Dr. Richard Thomas, director of human toxicology and risk assessment at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, D.C., said there are "probably millions of Americans who suffer from environmental illness, and have varying degrees of this problem, but we cannot substantiate the figure."
Mr. Shimer became sick in the winter of 1989, when he was working as a fund-raising consultant in a client's office in a new building in Seattle. "I walked like a little old man," said Mr. Shimer, who is 49 years old. His client quickly moved him to another rented office, but he didn't feel better because he had already become sensitized, said his doctor, David Buscher.
Dr. Buscher, a specialist in environmental medicine in nearby Bellevue, first saw Mr. Shimer in March 1990. Within a month, he had diagnosed Mr. Shimer's condition as multiple chemical sensitivity. As part of his treatment, Mr. Shimer stopped working, detoxified his body through medication, exercise and therapeutic saunas, and tossed out his polyester comforter, pillows and cotton-poly sheets. "Anything petroleum-based is the kiss of death for me," he said.
Finally, he and his wife, Cay Fortune, an interior designer, sold their house in Medina and moved into the new apartment last March.
In designing a new home to be a safe shelter in a world otherwise poisonous to him, Mr. Shimer was lucky. He was unemployed, but Ms. Fortune was working, they had the proceeds from their Medina house, and he had disability insurance, he said.
In July 1990, they paid more than $1 million for the concrete shell that would enclose the lakefront 3,016-square-foot condominium in a new luxury development. The interior cost $700,000 more, of which $100,000 went to consultants and for many special elements to make the home free of irritants to Mr. Shimer: a furnace/ air-conditioning system with triple filters, special glues, nontoxic grout, custom paints, upholstery and cabinetry, and a double layer of vapor barriers to seal the apartment.
"You can do the same with less money," Mr. Shimer said. "If you plan a $100,000 home, you have to add in another 7 percent for the extra low-toxicity features."
James Olson, a Seattle architect whose firm, Olson/Sundberg, also designed the galleries of the new Seattle Art Museum, designed the apartment. It has wood doors in a Shoji-screen style, gleaming maple floors, and a dropped ceiling of wood-framed translucent plexiglass panels that also look like Shoji screens. "We wanted to keep materials in their natural state, in keeping with the Japanese philosophy, where wood is usually admired for its natural beauty," Mr. Olson said.
For the architect, the project was a lesson in which materials can be toxic and which are not. When Mr. Olson showed his clients the first drawings, the couple screamed, "Oh, no!" Mr. Olson thought they hated the design but "they were objecting to the smell of the ammonia from the blueprints," he said. From then on, the architect let the drawings air a day or two before presenting them to his clients.
Before building began, Mr. Shimer started sniff-testing, which was advised by Dan Morris, an environmental engineer in Clinton, Wash. "The reason I recommend the sniff test is that everybody's body is different," Mr. Morris said. Mr. Shimer sniff-tested more than 50 products -- paint, sealants, adhesives -- a process that continued until last January.
Mr. Shimer and Mr. Olson asked the developer, Skinner Development of Seattle, to coat the inside of the concrete shell with a nontoxic, water-based sealant to prevent the emission of gases by curing agents in the concrete. Mr. Shimer sniff-tested sealants after they were kept in a cookie tin for four days. He would inhale vapors, and Ms. Fortune would write down any symptoms. "Sometimes I got dizzy, sometimes I got headaches, sometimes my respiratory system closed up as if I was having a violent asthma attack," Mr. Shimer said.
Mr. Shimer said he is thriving among antiques, because the 18th-century Korean tansu chests, and the 17th-century English partner's desk, years ago emitted whatever gases they contained, long before anyone was aware of environmental illness.
New wood didn't bother him, either, but stains, varnishes and some other finishes caused problems. The finish he finally chose for the floors and cabinets is water-based. In the bathroom, the counter and walls are sheets of Corian, a synthetic material, rather than tile, which would have required grout and yet more sniff-testing. The floor is marble.
The walls are either painted or covered with paper. "Oil-based paints can have 30 to 40 chemicals," Mr. Morris said. "Most water-based paints have 12 to 15 chemicals, but the most problematic are those with biocides, which prevent mold."
The solution? To use custom paints without biocides, which cost $20 a gallon. "If the humidity in the home is kept under control, there should be no mold growth, even without the biocides," Mr. Morris said.
Mr. Shimer isn't sensitive to the hand-painted wallpaper in his dining room, but most wallpaste makes him sick. Ms. Fortune discovered clay-based adhesive. "It's an old-fashioned paste that wallpaperers used to use before they had all those so-called wonderful adhesives," she said.
For Mr. Shimer, who just finished writing a book on financial investment, the fabric of choice is cotton. He dresses in cotton, sleeps on cotton and sits on cotton. The sofas and chairs were stuffed first with cotton batting, then wrapped in a barrier cloth of organic cotton, which prevented any seepage of pesticides that might have been used on the batting when the fiber was still in the fields. Slipcovers are cotton, as are the sheets and pillowcases. The comforter, however, is silk, inside and out.
To keep out gases from the concrete shell and the insulation, there are two vapor barriers. Sheets of polyethylene were taped together on the studs, under the plasterboard. The second barrier was made by covering the plasterboard with a special paint that prevents vapors from penetrating the wall. "Neither of the barriers is perfect," Mr. Morris said, "so two barriers were needed." They cost $2,000.
The furnace/air-conditioner was put in a closet. It has a filter that looks like cotton batting and that filters out large particles of dust; an activated charcoal filter that absorbs chemicals like formaldehyde, and a third, which looks like a paper coffee filter, that traps fine dust particles. The filters cost $2,500 a year to replace.
For a household designed to be free of irritants, there is the surprising presence of Snowball, an American Eskimo dog, a new breed. He was Ms. Fortune's before the couple married two years ago, and his dander does not make Mr. Shimer suffer. Horses bother him, but Snowball, no.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:
Morality in all its interpretations is a volatile issue in video stores. This week, for example, The New York Daily News quoted the business publication Inside Media as saying that Blockbuster, the nation's largest video chain, had refused to stock Woody Allen's film "Shadows and Fog" and that the store "was offended by the whole Allen-Mia Farrow mess."
Blockbuster, which has more than 2,500 outlets, does not stock NC-17 films and promotes itself as a family video center. But the Inside Media article reported that Carol Feinberg, a senior vice president of the chain, denied that the absence of "Shadows and Fog" from its stores had anything to do with Mr. Allen. The article also said that Ms. Feinberg declined to explain why Blockbuster stores didn't stock the film. 
 In an interview yesterday, Ms. Feinberg said that Blockbuster makes hundreds of buying decisions every month and that "Shadows and Fog," a film rated PG-13 that was released by Orion in October and is No. 26 on Billboard's best-renter list, "just didn't make it" as a rental prospect and was rejected for business reasons.
Many distributors and other people in the business say that Blockbuster and other video stores are boycotting "Shadows and Fog" and another new Orion release, "Article 99," because of Orion's deal with McDonald's to sell the film "Dances With Wolves" only at McDonald's restaurants and not at Blockbuster or any other video store. Ms. Feinberg denied there was such a boycott.
Beyond the contentions about "Shadows and Fog," the case illustrates increased sensitivity about the content of films being offered in video stores. Dealers report that unrated versions of films with added sex scenes outsell the R-rated tapes by margins of eight to one. One example is "Love Crimes" starring Sean Young. Other groups say there is an equally strong demand for more family-oriented material.
One such group is the Dove Foundation of Grand Rapids, Mich., which identifies films it considers appropriate for family viewing. Dick Rolfe, Dove's managing director, said that of 15,000 films the foundation has reviewed, 720 are suitable for family viewing and that only 400 to 500 of these are commonly available in stores.
As examples of current Dove-approved films on tape, Mr. Rolfe mentioned "The Rocketeer," "Home Alone," "Father of the Bride," "Sister Act" and "Hook." Mr. Rolfe said that Dove advocated altering films to eliminate obscenities and other material it regards as offensive.
No studio has agreed to alter films as Dove suggests, but at least one company, Prime Cut Entertainment of Mission Viejo, Calif., plans to distribute what it considers the next best thing: so-called airline movies, or R-rated films that the studios have sanitized for viewing on flights and on network television.
John J. Lee Jr. of Prime Cut said that about three dozen such films are released each year. "My Cousin Vinny" is the perfect airline film, he said, because altering only a little dialogue makes the movie meet airline standards.
Mr. Lee said his interest was commercial, not ideological. He described the primary audience for airline movies as millions of 8- to 15-year-olds who can't use their parents' video store cards to rent R-rated material, as well as parents who like R-rated films but not to watch with their children.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
Lethal Weapon 3
1992. Warner. $99.99. Laser disk, $29.98. 1 hour 58 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
 Detective sergeants Riggs (Mel Gibson) and Murtaugh (Danny Glover) dig deep for the vigor that propelled them through the first two "Lethal Weapon" films. This time, though, the team seems tired. Murtaugh is on the verge of retirement and Riggs, the cutup and renegade, seems more bored than rambunctious. Buildings explode and bodies are blown apart, glass shatters, and bullying police antics seem particularly insensitive in the wake of the Rodney King case. In sum, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times, Richard Donner's film "celebrates a luxurious kind of destruction and disorder that can only appear mindless amid today's realities."
 
A Midnight Clear
1992. Columbia Tri-Star. $92.95. LD, $34.95. 1:47. CC. R.
 An American intelligence unit has encounters of a strange kind in the snowy Ardennes Forest during the last winter of World War II. Two bodies, one German and the other American, are found frozen together upright as if they'd been dancing. Skirmishes with the enemy never happen as the Americans withhold attack and the Germans turn away and withdraw. In his second film, Keith Gordon uses arresting images to turn William Wharton's novel of war as surreal muddle into a "very fine screen adaptation" (Canby).
 
Night on Earth
1992. New Line. $92.95. 2:08. R.
 Jim Jarmusch's film views life in exchanges between cab drivers and their passengers. In Los Angeles a driver named Corky (Winona Ryder) picks up a high-powered agent (Gena Rowlands) who might be Corky's ticket to stardom. In New York a loquacious passenger (Giancarlo Esposito) does the driving for an inept East European cabby (Armin Mueller-Stahl). In Paris a driver from the Ivory Coast (Isaach de Bankole) tangles with a blind passenger (Beatrice Dalle); in Rome a macho cabby (Roberto Benigni) gives his confession to a reluctant priest (Paolo Bonacelli). Viewing his characters from afar, Mr. Jarmusch "demonstrates his mastery of comedy of the oblique" (Canby).

HEADLINE: WHERE TO FIND IT

BYLINE: By Terry Trucco

 BODY:
UNLIKE most shopkeepers, Joanna Doniger expects her customers to return their purchases. And during the holidays, her busiest season, they bring back beaded bustiers, taffeta skirts and sequined evening gowns after wearing them just once.
One Night Stand, Ms. Doniger's five-year-old Manhattan dress shop, specializes in women's evening wear to rent, everything from billowy ball gowns to slinky cocktail dresses. And though she refuses to stock evening trousers ("too hard to fit," she said) and white debutante-style gowns ("too hard to keep snappy"), she has almost 800 dresses, sizes 2 to 14. 
 "Nobody ever sees everything, because things are always out on hire," she said, patting the flounce on a little black Terence Nolder number.
For decades, the garment-rental business, always bustling during the holidays, consisted mainly of men's tuxedos. But in recent years, new types of rental services have begun, offering everything from women's party dresses in velvet and chiffon, to Santa suits with optional padding, the ultimate holiday rental. Basic rules apply for most rented garments. Clothing is dry cleaned before each rental. A security deposit is required. And last-minute rentals, while not advised, are usually possible.
The women's evening-wear rental business grew with the grand-style entertaining of the 1980's. And the recession has kept it going. Rentals at One Night Stand average $200 to $250 for dresses that retail for $1,000 and up. Fees for gowns rented for a business occasion are tax deductible, Ms. Doniger said.
Women want "black, black and more black," she added. Customers are also starting to ask for long dresses again. Still, her most popular rental is a short, stretchy sequined sheath, in black, naturally, by Pamela Dennis.
"It's strapless and sexy, with no pronounced waist," Ms. Doniger said. "But you can add a black chiffon jacket to make it safe."
ONE NIGHT STAND 905 Madison Avenue near 72d Street, New York 10021; (212) 772-7720. By appointment.
 
Especially for the Bride
 Dresses for hire by Carolina Herrera and Victor Costa, among others, hang on the racks at Just Once in Manhattan, renters of women's evening wear for five years. But wedding gowns, the apex of formal attire, make up nearly half of the shop's stock of 400 dresses. "My customer is the bride who is 30 or older," said the shop manager, Debra Urban. "Instead of spending $8,000 for a wedding gown, she rents one for $700 and buys a dining-room table instead."
Ms. Urban rents regularly to the growing number of brides from Japan who want lavish dresses for weddings at the United Nations chapel.
Most of Ms. Urban's evening dresses are short, though a recent creation by Liberatto, the shop's own designer, features a quilted silk faille top and a long, narrow skirt. Evening-gown rentals range from $85 to $325, wedding-gown rentals from $250 to $700.
JUST ONCE 292 Fifth Avenue, near 31st Street, New York 10001; (212) 465-0960. Hours: Monday through Friday, 10:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M.; Saturdays by appointment.
 
In the Expectant Interim
 When she was pregnant with her first child, Loretta Chiavetta discovered it was both challenging and costly to find suitable evening wear. So her three-year-old company, Formal Expectations, based in Pleasantville, N.Y., specializes in dressy attire for mothers-to-be. "About 90 percent of my stock is black in sequins, velvet or chiffon," she said. Most of her dresses also display some leg. "When you're pregnant you still want to show something," she said.
She stocks over 250 pieces, including separates to mix and match. Rentals range from $75 to $95.
FORMAL EXPECTATIONS (914) 769-0883. By appointment.
 
For Those Jolly Old Elves
 There's only one true Santa Claus, of course, but would-be helpers, or imposters, can choose from five types of classic red-and-white suits at Allan Uniform Rental Service, a 32-year-old concern in Manhattan. The fully lined deluxe model ($125) comes in red velvet, while budget-minded Santas can opt for velour or corduroy ($75). Wig, beard, belt and boot coverings are included, with optional stomach padding ($20). Men's sizes range from 42 to 60.
ALLAN UNIFORM RENTAL SERVICE 152 East 23d Street, near Lexington Avenue, New York 10010; (212) 529-4655. Hours: Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Fund-Raiser Aiding Rematch For a Mayoral Bid,

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Keeping financial pace with the man he wants to replace, Rudolph W. Giuliani raised almost $1 million last night for his mayoral rematch against David N. Dinkins next year -- no small achievement for a Republican in New York City, where Democrats hold a 5 to 1 advantage in registered voters.
Altogether this year, Mr. Giuliani has raised nearly $2.5 million, roughly equal to Mr. Dinkins's total. At the same time, he has been busy soothing the rank-and-file party leaders who were irked by his standoffish approach in 1989. That means that he will almost certainly avoid the kind of costly primary challenge that set him back then, and that Mr. Dinkins faces from his fellow Democrat, City Council President Andrew J. Stein. 
 Mr. Giuliani's success in smoothing feathers was symbolized by the inclusion of the city's five county Republican organizations on the committee for his fund-raiser at the Sheraton New York last night. All five have agreed to lend their names, though only the Brooklyn organization has so far endorsed him. All that, the county leaders said, makes it highly improbable that Mr. Stein, who had wooed Republican support, could win the backing of the three counties' organizations he would need to get on the Republican ballot.
 
Call for Change
 "This election should not be about skin tone but moral tone," Mr. Giuliani said last night, in a challenge to Mr. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor. "We will argue that white and black New Yorkers should put race aside and support the candidate that offers the chance we need for better services, more economic progress, cleaner streets, more orderly public spaces and hope for our children. This administration offers the minority community, like the rest of the city, little more than symbolism."
But the symbolism of the recent tensions between blacks and Jews in Crown Heights stood out at the dinner where Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn was among the guests on the dais. At Mr. Dinkins's fund-raiser on Monday, Mr. Hikind was outside the hotel, leading a group protesting the Mayor's handling the Crown Heights unrest.
Labor Secretary Lynn M. Martin also spoke, telling the crowd: "You need a mayor. You just don't need change, you need a mayor."
Peter J. Powers, a lawyer and longtime friend who managed Mr. Giuliani's last campaign, in which the former United States Attorney lost to Mr. Dinkins by just 2 percentage points, said before the dinner that the campaign was pleased with its fund raising so far, especially coming just weeks after its party lost the White House. He said the dinner -- at which tickets sold for $500 or $1,000 a plate -- would take in $900,000, on top of the $1 million raised at a similar party last spring and $500,000 from smaller events.
"We're surprised at the numbers, because we figured we might raise $500,000 at this dinner, because it comes right after the election and it's hard to raise money at holiday time," he said.
Mr. Powers said he hoped the early fund raising would help the campaign avoid some of the problems of three years ago, when many Republicans criticized Mr. Giuliani for fielding an inexperienced staff and being unwilling to reach out to local Republican groups, preferring to stress his lone-wolf image as a crusader.
 
Courting Support
 Before taking on Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Giuliani had to stave off a bitter primary challenge from Ronald S. Lauder, the cosmetics heir, whose candidacy was backed by the party's conservative wing, led by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
This time, Mr. Giuliani has not only sought the advice of a wide range of New York political figures from both parties, but has been holding serious discussion about hiring David Garth, the media maven and political guru who was instrumental in electing two New York mayors, John V. Lindsay and Edward I. Koch, and last month helped another Republican, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, win a come-from-behind re-election.
"We've talked with David," Mr. Powers said. "We've not made any final decisions yet." Mr. Garth's aides said he had no comment.
This fall, Mr. Giuliani swallowed his earlier distaste for Mr. D'Amato and endorsed his re-election, and expects his support next year.

At a fund-raiser last night in Manhattan that raised nearly $1 million, Mr. Giuliani spoke with his wife, Donna Hanover, left, and Labor Secretary Lynn M. Martin. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cuomo Calls for New York and New Jersey to End Rivalry

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday appealed for peace in the economic war between New York and New Jersey and called for the two sides to meet. But he also said he was prepared to do battle if New Jersey continued to woo New York companies with financial incentives.
"They slug you. You slug them. That's primitive," Mr. Cuomo said. "Well, what should you do? You should sit down with New Jersey and say, 'Look, this is foolish. You're going to rip us and we're going to rip you. You're going to cost us money. We're going to cost you money. Let's get together. Let's make a region that's more attractive, which is what we've talked about for years.' " 
 Mr. Cuomo's comments at a news conference in Albany were the first he has publicly made about the fight that has erupted over New Jersey's increasing use of financial incentives to attract companies. Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey announced yet another incentive program on Monday.
 
States Choose Weapons
 In an interview last night, Vincent Tese, New York State's director of economic development, said New York was proceeding with plans to begin a marketing program aimed at persuading New Jersey companies to move to New York. "If we let them get away with this, it becomes an untenable situation for us," he said of the New Jersey incentives.
If New York begins the campaign by mid-December as vowed, it would kill the so-called nonaggression pact signed by New York State, New York City, Connecticut and New Jersey in October 1991. The pact was billed as the first step toward broader cooperation in regional economic development.
While calling for both sides to step back from the brink, Mr. Cuomo indicated that he thought New York needed a weapon to give it clout in any talks. "You can make all the fine speeches and all the calls for conciliation that you want," he said. "But if they get the impression that you're not going to do anything, they'll just keep taking your companies."
Reacting to Mr. Cuomo, Brooke Hern, a spokesman for Barbara W. McConnell, New Jersey's Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, said, "We're willing to talk." But he gave no sign that New Jersey was willing to make any concessions.
Mr. Tese said New Jersey officials had contacted his office yesterday, but he was out of the state and was not able to respond. To keep New York from starting its marketing campaign, he said, New Jersey must promise to stop offering New York companies incentives from its new $224 million Economic Recovery Fund.
Mr. Hern said, "That's not a possibility." New Jersey officials have repeatedly insisted that they are not targeting New York companies and that the Economic Recovery Fund is aimed mainly at helping businesses already in the state and at financing construction projects.
"What we're seeing here is a reaction to some very successful and creative positive economic-development programs and they're going to continue," Mr. Hern said. "But again, the commissioner conveyed that we are very interested in continuing to promote regional economic development and development efforts that don't rely on negative campaigning."

HEADLINE: A Ray of Hope From City Hall On Job Growth

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
New data on New York's employment and output of goods and services indicate that the worst of the recession -- which has caused the city to lose 10.7 percent of its jobs since April 1989 -- is over, government and private economists say.
But they caution that the city's economic recovery will lag behind the country's and that there will be no significant increase in jobs soon. Indeed, several economists expect another employment decline in 1993. 
 In interviews and at a City Hall hearing held yesterday by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, economists said the city would still be plagued by factors that have made New York's recession much more severe than the national slump.
These include cuts in industries like banking, airlines, telecommunications and manufacturing; the exodus of back-office operations, like processing securities transactions or insurance forms, and new technology that enables companies to avoid hiring new workers. Other problems cited included a surplus of office space that promises to stem construction and an inflation rate higher than the national average, which means that the city's cost-competitiveness is still eroding.
 
Data Offer Some Hope
 "We do not yet see a significant upturn," said Elinor B. Bachrach, New York State's deputy comptroller for New York City.
Economists agreed with Ms. Holtzman, however, that October employment data offered some hope.
The total nongovernment jobs in the city increased slightly, by 600 or 4,800, depending on how the figures were seasonally adjusted by two city agencies. John Tepper Marlin, Ms. Holtzman's chief economist, who produced the 4,800 estimate, called it the largest rise since February 1989.
But the number of government jobs fell in October. As a result, Mr. Marlin estimated that total employment rose by only 1,300 in October, which would be the first increase since May 1990, excluding temporary summer jobs. Using a different adjustment, James A. Parrott, chief economist of Mayor David N. Dinkins's Economic Policy and Marketing Group, estimates total employment fell by 200.
Calling the job figures "a ray of hope," Ms. Holtzman said her economists nonetheless predicted that the city would lose 130,000 jobs in 1992 and 50,000 more in 1993. Those figures are a bit higher than what other city and state agencies are forecasting.
 
Total Product Falling Slower
 Rae D. Rosen, former chief economist of the Federal Home Loan Bank, said that she did not expect employment to have a sustained rise until late 1993, and she doubted that the growth rate would even hit 1 percent in 1994.
Using a new method to calculate the gross city product -- the value of goods and services produced in New York -- Ms. Holtzman's economists said it was falling at a slower rate. Mr. Marlin predicted inflation-adjusted gross city product would shrink 1.5 percent this year and grow 1.4 percent in 1993. He calculated that it fell 5.3 percent in 1991, the largest annual decline since the 1960's.
The new calculation also showed that workers in the city are much more productive than those nationwide. Inflation-adjusted output per employee in the city has risen by an annual average of 2.1 percent since 1974 to a current $77,400. Output per worker grew an average of 0.5 percent in the country to $53,900.
But there is a dark side to the figures. "A big reason the output per worker in New York is so much higher is because many lower-paying, less-skilled jobs in the city have disappeared," Mr. Marlin said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Upturn Is Seen In Media Spending

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
A prediction for media spending in 1993 foresees noticeable upturns after two disappointing years.
Myers Reports in Parsippany, N.J., an advertising, marketing and media consulting company, made what it described as a bullish forecast in predicting that media spending next year will grow 2 to 3 percent after inflation, or 7 to 8 percent factoring in inflation. 
 Myers expects robust gains in media categories like network cable television, up 13 percent to 15 percent; broadcast network television, up 8 percent to 10 percent; consumer magazines, up 9 percent to 10 percent, and newspapers, up 6 percent to 7 percent.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Visions in Collision

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Looking down into the abyss of hyperinflation a condition that bred totalitarianism in Germany -- Russian leaders, old and new, are now deciding which economic model to follow.
One model is Western-style capitalism that couples political democracy with free markets. The Poles and Czechs, having accepted the hardship of such "shock therapy," are making this dual freedom work. 
 The other model is the sort of "capitalism with an inhuman face" practiced in China. This allows the old Communist elite to remain in political power while permitting certain free markets to flourish.
Boris Yeltsin and his reformist right-hand man, Yegor Gaidar, want both halves of the freedom enjoyed by Americans.
They are opposed in Moscow by the Civic Union industrialists, who position themselves between the Yeltsin reformers and the nutty nationalists and Communists. These men want authoritarian control of politics and the economy, but with some toleration of private enterprise: "The Chinese people feed themselves," says Arkady Volsky, a longtime Andropov-Brezhnev aide, "and 1.2 billion are living a life of which we can only dream." Some dream.
Those are the two visions in collision in Moscow this week. The anti-reformers are posing as pragmatists who only want to "go slow" in moving toward a free economy. They profess concern for the human hardships in the wrenching away from their old command economy.
Some Westerners -- mainly Gorbophiles who wanted merely restructuring of Communism, not its replacement -- are touting the Volsky faction as moderate, practical and centrist, almost Clintonian in its reasonableness. They delight in Yeltsin's concessions to this China-model crowd as evidence that seeking both halves of freedom's loaf is a mistake for Russians historically hooked on authoritarianism.
Let's not be taken in by the siren song of moderation. The anti-reformers want to stop the privatization of the huge enterprises that ought to be made competitive or shut down. They want to stop the sale of land to farmers and keep agriculture in the inefficient hands of the old collectives. Bring back price control, they say, and let bureaucrats rather than consumers dictate what is produced.
In the first half of this year, reform began to take hold; private plots tripled to 20 million, and today are the bulwark against starvation.
But since July, the Russian Parliament -- 87 percent Communists elected before the attempted coup -- has managed to turn back the reformist clock. Old-timers gained control of the central bank, which promptly decreed that inefficient, state-owned heavy industries needed heavy infusions of cash. The result of this subsidy to hang onto the old elite's influence: Inflation rose from 8 percent a month to 30 percent.
What can the West do to help Russia avert a Tiananmen economy?
Our governments should reschedule the old Soviet debt, taking off a little repayment pressure, and come through on promises of visible humanitarian aid. But private investment, joint ventures, is the answer; that will happen only as Russian reformers win their battle to establish the primacy of private property.
Yeltsin, though he bobs and weaves to avert a coup, knows this. He stopped compromising with the Volsky elite on state control of the oil industry last week, decreeing privatization. The world's largest oil producer is the most inefficient; when Russia opens the profit potential to oil, world business will make it possible for Russia to get back on its feet.
We should know what to root for, and compromise is not it. "Shock therapy works and it works fast," says Anders Aslund, the Swedish economist advising the reformers. But it's not happening now.
We should root for the amalgam of political and economic freedom. That calls for a new constitution followed by elections, and a mandate for private farms and stock ownership of industry.
Maybe Boris Yeltsin, who retains more popular support than any Russian leader, can bring it off. From the sidelines, as we cheer for the success of their reach for freedom, we should at least let the Russian people know that the American model is far better than the Chinese.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Get Cracking on Bosnia

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
The people of Bosnia and the tinderboxes nearby might meditate on two realities: First, President Bush will not order U.S. forces to the rescue. Forget it. Second, President-elect Clinton won't either -- at least not for months. He shows little disposition to walk economics and chew foreign policy gum at the same time. He has barely begun to select his national security team.
Mr. Bush's decision to dispatch troops to Somalia has in no way altered his opposition to American intervention in Bosnia. His senior aides are absolutely clear about that. He just sees too many land mines in Bosnia and no way to get out. 
 Mr. Clinton is unlikely to set his course in Bosnia until weeks after inauguration at the earliest. Which means thousands more dead Bosnians and hundreds of thousands more Bosnian refugees pouring into an already floundering Germany. Which means little prospect of heading off wider Balkan wars in Kosovo and Macedonia. All this portends moral and strategic disaster.
Mr. Clinton should move now to put his senior foreign policy and defense team in place and get them cracking on Bosnia and other world crises. Focusing on the economy is right. But treading water on foreign affairs is dead wrong.
His transition staff for national security cannot do the job of creating policy. It contains few experienced, high-level pros. And these pros have to spend most of their time answering ridiculous press queries about Clinton policies that don't exist, playing footsie with anxious foreign diplomats, taking phone calls from panicky job-seekers and meeting with political allies to keep them from feeling excluded when the moment comes to exclude them.
Sandy Berger, the leader of the transition staff, has commissioned various policy papers from able, senior people. But these papers cannot substitute for the advisers who will form the Clinton National Security Council.
The first task of these senior advisers should be to flesh out Mr. Clinton's promising campaign rhetoric on Bosnia. He talked sensibly about providing arms to Muslims, now virtually defenseless against Serbian attacks. He hinted creatively at bombing attacks against military targets in Serbia to deter Serbs from further aggression. But good thoughts do not a policy make.
Before the Clinton team goes too far down the road on a Balkan policy, it should talk with key Bush aides. The President and his team have been far too cautious, unimaginative and shortsighted on Bosnia. But they have some telling arguments. Clinton advisers should listen and fashion convincing responses.
Mr. Clinton wisely rejects fighting a ground war in Bosnia. Instead, some of his advisers speak of establishing a safety zone there where Bosnians could go for food, shelter and security. Bush aides and Bosnian Muslims -- along with the international mediators Cyrus Vance and Lord David Owen -- reject this idea. They feel it would legitimize Serbian conquests of Bosnian Muslim territory. But surely a formula can be found to provide for immediate humanitarian needs without compromising long-term negotiating positions.
Bush advisers also fault the Clinton inclination to arm Muslims. They believe, again backed by Mr. Vance and Lord Owen, that this will only lead to greater violence and even more Muslim deaths. But there is a trade-off here: a heavy short-term price may be worthwhile to stabilize the battlefield and save lives thereafter.
Bush aides insist that if the U.S. bombs Serbia, as Mr. Clinton may propose, London and Paris will withdraw their humanitarian-relief forces from Bosnia. And so they will, unless Mr. Clinton successfully mounts a risky and ambitious campaign in private and public diplomacy.
Most compellingly, Bush advisers warn that getting into Bosnia will be far easier than getting out. Before taking any action, Mr. Clinton will have to fashion a persuasive plan of limited involvement, explaining what lines he will and will not cross -- then sell it to Americans and to Congress.
After looking at all this, Mr. Clinton may decide it's too late to help Bosnia. If so, he had better stop leading the Bosnian Muslims on, come up with a second line of defense against Serbia in Kosovo and Macedonia and sell that to Congress and the American people.

HEADLINE: With Jobs Scarce, the Neediest Helps the Unemployed

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Kathleen Nairne needs a job.
A conversation with her always returned to that point.
She recently separated from her husband and is trying to raise her two boys by herself after being laid off in June. She just learned that she is pregnant. The family's breakup has shaken her 13-year-old son, who is failing school. 
 But she could easily cope, she said in an interview, if only she had a job.
The recession has carved through the lives of Ms. Nairne and thousands of other New Yorkers out of work for the first time, leaving them dejected, frustrated and with little choice but to turn to charities like those aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Ms. Nairne, 34 years old, sought help from Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, to find a job as a bookkeeper and to pay the security on a cheaper apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn. With frustration etched across her face, she described her quest for employment in the months since she lost her job as an administrator with the New York City Department of Correction.
"I used to have a lot of spunk," she said. "I'm not losing it, but sometimes I get a little depressed. It's one letdown after another. I'm an isolated single person trying to maintain control. But I'm a strong woman, so I'll hold on."
 
A Harsh Toll
 She said she had visited dozens of offices across the city, filling out numerous applications and sitting through a seemingly endless series of interviews. With a degree from the John Jay College of Criminal Justice and recommendations from previous employers, she thought she would have little trouble landing a new position. She was wrong.
Msgr. James J. Murray, executive director of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, said the recession -- which has driven the unemployment rate in New York City to more than 10 percent -- has taken a harsh toll on people like Ms. Nairne.
"The person who is out of a job for the first time in their lives -- that we are seeing a lot of," he said. "They are not accustomed to seeking help. It's a tough thing for a person to face."
Emanuel Tobier, a professor at the Wagner School of Public Service at New York University, said the economic slump has particularly hurt New Yorkers who thought a college degree would prevent them from being unemployed for a lengthy period of time.
"In the early 1970's, if you were educated and lost your job, you could get another one pretty quickly," he said. "Now, you're out of work a lot longer. The apprehension is much greater, as is the pain."
In years of prosperity and in years of despair, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has assisted New Yorkers trying to turn their lives around in the face of adversity. The fund begins its 81st campaign this week as many people across the city go without food, shelter and health care. The Times pays for the fund's overhead so all contributions go directly to seven charities. This year's campaign ends on Feb. 28.
Ms. Nairne said that when she feels discouraged after she receives a rejection letter, she reminds herself that she has two sons who depend on her. But she added that she would have little enthusiasm for life until she could support her family.
"It all boils down to a job," she said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 277 words

HEADLINE: Economic Security Rates Higher Status

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a Nov. 15 editorial you joined the chorus of concern over Bill Clinton's proposed Economic Security Council, warning that "the parallel with national security invites . . . a quick descent into the worst protectionism." 
 In my experience, putting economic considerations on the same plane as national security is long overdue. Time and again, creative trade proposals that made waves diplomatically or geopolitically have failed even to make it to the President's table, because of the domination of the State Department and National Security Council. And I say this as a free-trader, who has taken considerable political heat at home for opposing protectionist trade measures.
A perfect model for the strategic role the Economic Security Council could play is found in the primary dealers amendment to the 1988 trade bill, which targeted Japan's closed market in government securities and threatened retaliation unless barriers came down. The amendment was opposed by N.S.C., State and the rest of the Reagan Administration, which heard only rumblings coming from Tokyo, but Congress prevailed. So far the provision has proved a smashing success, with American firms' share of this major Japanese market rising from zero to 11.3 percent and no need for United States retaliation.
While trade would only be part of the Economic Security Council mission, it is one area where the council could have a salutary effect by helping to make free trade a reality on both sides of the ocean, rather than serving as a stalking horse for protectionism.
 
CHARLES E. SCHUMER
Member of Congress, 10th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Nov. 18, 1992

HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
Expectations in Somalia

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Many Somalis welcome the imminent American military intervention in their country, but they view the narrowly focused goal of protecting the delivery of food to the destitute as a mere sideshow to what really interests them: an end to the clan violence, economic reconstruction and political reconciliation. And they expect the Americans to deliver on all counts.
This mismatch in expectations, with the Somalis seeing the Americans as the economic and political salvation for their destroyed country and the Americans planning a brief mission designed to avoid any long-term involvement, could turn the operation sour very quickly, Somalis and international aid workers say. 
 Educated Somalis, many of whom have been holed up in their houses in the capital for the last two years while the country was devastated by clan fighting, say the Americans must stay for at least a year to solve the problem of the starving, disarm the population and get political and economic reconstruction going.
They talk of schools being reopened, job training for the armed vagabonds, roads being paved, all under the auspices of the United States.
"The Americans are in for a surprise," said Ahmed Jama, a British- and American-educated former national police chief. "The expectations are very high. The Somalis think they will do a lot of things for them. And if they don't do these things -- deliver the humanitarian food, then disarm the people and then bring people together for political reconciliation -- it will revert to chaos."
It also became clear today that Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the most aggressive of the Somali clan leaders, had expectations other than food and medical aid for his people when he accepted Washington's proposal last week. General Aidid said he planned military action against a rival clan this weekend at Bardera, one of the worst hit towns in the famine zone.
Bardera, where more than 100 Somalis are dying of hunger and disease daily, is understood to be a chief target for the Americans: a place they would secure and then deliver food to. It is under the control of the forces of Gen. Mohammed Said Hersi Morgan, the son-in-law of the deposed president, Mohammed Siad Barre.
Armed attacks by General Morgan's forces on the warehouses stocking food for the International Committee of the Red Cross and CARE, the international aid agency, occur daily at Bardera.
General Aidid said on Somali radio on Wednesday night that he would attack Bardera, 220 miles west of here, unless General Morgan's forces left the town, which they took from General Aidid two months ago. All international aid workers were advised today by Mr. Aidid's office to leave Bardera.
 
Seeks Alliance With U.S.
 Several Somalis said that the ultimatum by General Aidid appeared to reflect a calculation by the Soviet-trained general, who has been weakened by a series of military setbacks, that he could forge an alliance on the ground with the American forces moving into Bardera and thus use them to regain control of the city.
But Somalis said it would not be enough even if the Americans secured Bardera against the predations of either General Morgan or General Aidid, and even if the Americans repeated this process around the country.
Mr. Jama said the long-term goals were even more vital than feeding the hungry. He said that if they were not addressed, the country, which is brimming with weapons and ammunition from the cold war superpowers, would continue "to fight over what is left."
"This coming and going out is not worth it," said the former police chief. "It's just a waste of time. They shouldn't come if that's what it is because when they leave things will spark up again. They should be here for about a year if they are serious about it."
 
Aura of Goodwill
 The aura of goodwill that has enveloped the United States plan and the overwhelming strength of the American military meant the armed clan fighters who roam Mogadishu and the countryside might at first submit, many Somalis said. Mr. Jama predicted only "isolated incidents" of clashes between the Americans and the clan fighters.
But this tolerance would evaporate if the Americans carried off an aggressive aid mission but left a power vacuum that a broader, weaker United Nations force could not replace. Fighters like port security guards would be back, extorting money as they are now, aid workers and Somalis said.
"There will be very negative feelings if the security people from the port are told to leave and offered no alternative," said Abukar Mohammed Dahiye, a CARE official. They would want job training to replace the income they now get through gangsterism, he said.
If the Americans deliver only to the most poorly off 1.5 or so million Somalis and forget the rest of the population, particularly the urban and displaced population of Mogadishu, resentment of the Americans could soon surface.
For now, the Americans wear a mantle of approval because they are deemed far preferable to the United Nations and more likely to improve the situation in Somalia. The United Nations is viewed with contempt for having failed to resolve the food crisis and the lack of security.
 
Enthusiasm May Be Superficial
 The day Mr. Aidid expressed his acceptance of the Americans, one of his supporters, Asli Ahmed Gutaale, the supervisor of a Red Cross kitchen, showed how superficial the enthusiasm for the Americans might be.
"I hope the American troops will not come," she said. "If they come, I will fight them with my mouth. Why don't they help build our own military? They are jobless right now."
And many Somalis bitterly recall that it was Washington, a cold war supporter of Somalia in the 1980's, who delivered planeloads of arms to the forces of Mr. Barre as late as 1988 when his tottering government was staving off a rebellion in Hargeisa, the major city in the northeast.
A former military attache at the United States Embassy, Col. Al Girardi, wrote an assessment not long after leaving Mogadishu in 1989 warning against the kind of American support that many Somalis are appealing for today but that Washington is obviously trying to circumvent.
"Sooner or later, the country will be thrown into prolonged and violent tribal conflict and no amount of U.S. assistance will change this," he wrote.

HEADLINE: U.S. Tried to Support Dollar, Federal Reserve Confirms

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve confirmed yesterday that it had tried to support the dollar against the German mark in the early stages of Europe's currency crisis, but its efforts were largely in vain.
In a quarterly report on its foreign-exchange operations through October, the Fed said that it had acted amid fears in the currency markets that the dollar's decline would accelerate after it hit new lows in response to high German interest rates. 
 The dollar did set a record low of 1.39 marks on Sept. 2, but has since rebounded, to 1.58 marks through yesterday.
The Fed's purchases in August of $1.1 billion in dollars for marks, coordinated with actions by about a dozen other central banks, came as the mark's appreciation began testing the ability of the European monetary system to maintain stable rates. Selling marks and buying dollars would tend to reduce the mark's value and relieve some of the strains.
Currently, renewed pressure against the French franc threatens to tear apart the core group of nations, including Germany, that are striving to preserve Europe's currency mechanism despite the withdrawal of Italy, Britain and Spain.
William J. McDonough, executive vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the manager of its foreign exchange operations, said the United States, in principle at least, remained a supporter of Europe's exchange rate mechanism.
The Fed bought $600 million in dollars for marks on Aug. 7 and Aug. 11, when the dollar declined after a weak employment report. An additional $500 million in purchases came on Aug. 21 and Aug. 24.
The earlier August moves relieved pressure against the dollar only somewhat, without arresting the decline, the Fed said. When the later intervention had no apparent effect, officials decided against further action.

HEADLINE: Gearing for Conference, Clinton Meets With Federal Reserve Chief

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 3

 BODY:
As he faces decisions about dealing with an economy that shows signs of improvement, President-elect Bill Clinton met today with the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and approved the initial guest list for a conference on the economy that has doubled to 215 participants.
Because the Federal Reserve controls interest rates, its chairman, Alan Greenspan, has as much influence over the economy as anyone in the Government. Mr. Clinton summoned him to the Governor's Mansion here for their first meeting since the election one month ago today. 
 "Governor Clinton wanted to meet with Chairman Greenspan to establish a sound working relationship, to talk about the state of the economy and to lay the groundwork for a productive relationship in the future," said George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's communications director.
The Federal Reserve and the Bush White House often clashed because the Administration wanted lower interest rates to stimulate the sagging economy. In the Clinton Administration, Mr. Stephanopoulos said, while it will be important "to preserve the independence of the Fed," it will also be crucial for both sides to have "a common understanding of the economic situation."
 
Some Tension Predicted
 Some analysts have predicted that despite Mr. Greenspan's preference for consensus, there will be tension between the Federal Reserve and the Clinton White House as he seeks to keep inflation in check and the new President proposes legislation intended to stimulate the economy. Mr. Greenspan was appointed chairman by President Ronald Reagan in 1987 and reappointed by President Bush. His term runs until 1995.
Officials said there were no indications that Mr. Clinton would ask Mr. Greenspan to step down as chairman. In the first Presidential debate Mr. Clinton basically endorsed the work of the Federal Reserve System, saying, "Their policies so far, it seems to me, are pretty sound."
In their talks today, Mr. Stephanopoulos said the President-elect and Mr. Greenspan discussed Mr. Clinton's goal of "economic growth without heightened inflation." He added, "I don't know if he'll get into specifics on the economic plan, but I think those basic principles will be in discussion."
As Mr. Clinton and Mr. Greenspan met for more than an hour, transition officials were making final decisions about the economic conference, which is growing into a far bigger event than originally contemplated.
Aides said they had juggled the agenda of the two-day conference to accommodate 215 participants instead of the 100 initially planned. They said that they were still crossing off and adding names to the guest list today, and that Mr. Clinton had reviewed the initial list of invitees, which includes ordinary citizens, academics and business executives. The first calls went out today.
 
'Cross Section' Sought
 "We're trying to get a cross section by industry, state, gender and economic approach," said one official involved in the event. "We'll get people who every day deal with the economy."
The conference is not expected to produce any policy statements on the economy, but it is expected to give Mr. Clinton a way to interact with a broad range of people on how to grapple with the economy. No elected officials will be invited, officials said, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the "shadow Senator" representing the District of Columbia, an elected post with no actual authority.
In another sign that the conference is turning into something resembling a mini political convention, officials from ABC and NBC said they were planning to base their major evening news broadcasts from Little Rock during the conference, which will be held on Dec. 14 and 15. CBS officials said they had not decided whether to broadcast from here. But the CNN program "Larry King Live" is planning to broadcast from here.
Tamara Haddad, a vice president of CNN and executive producer of the Larry King program, disputed critics who contend that the networks are helping turn the event into a media spectacle. "All anyone's talking about is how the Clinton Administration's going to handle the economy," she said. "This will be the first chance to see them in action."
 
'Some News to Chew On'Expected Soon
 Mr. Clinton spent the day at the Governor's Mansion, but as he began a morning jog he hinted that his first round of Cabinet appointees would be come soon. "We're getting close," he told reporters, adding that "we're making real progress" and "you all will have some news to chew on in the next few days."
Announcements on major economic posts are expected by the middle of next week, aides said.
In another sign that the election has not discouraged Mr. Clinton from campaigning, his aides announced that he would meet in Chicago on Monday with students at Wilbur Wright Community College, a vocational school. The visit will include a question-and-answer session with the students.
Later on Monday, Mr. Clinton plans to fly to Washington to confer with Congressional leaders and transition officials. There are no plans for him to meet again with President Bush. But Mr. Clinton will pay a courtesy call on William H. Rehnquist, the Chief Justice of the United States, who will swear him in on Jan. 20.
"He wants to pay his respects" to the Supreme Court, Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore also plan to have tea with the Supreme Court Justices while they are in Washington next week.
The encounter, initiated by the Clinton transition team, copies a November 1980 visit that Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush, then Vice President-elect, made to the Court.
The Reagan visit was the first by a President-elect to the Supreme Court since the 19th century.
