HEADLINE: Hire City Poor In the Suburbs, A Report Urges

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Going against the grain of the most familiar anti-poverty strategies, which focus on urban economies or low-income housing in the suburbs, proponents of a plan to transport inner-city workers to suburban jobs are now bidding for the attention of the incoming Clinton Administration.
The Urban Institute, a Washington research group, is holding a conference here to discuss creating or realigning transportation systems to get the poor out to the suburbs where the jobs are. 
 An Urban Institute consultant, Mark Alan Hughes, presented a report citing four current projects in the Philadelphia, Chicago and Milwaukee metropolitan areas. He said the Federal Government should consider spending $5 million to $10 million on such demonstration projects to see if they make a significant difference for inner-city workers. Unemployment figures in inner-city areas are consistently higher than those in suburbs.
 
'Engines of Employment'
 Using familiar labor-force and population data, Mr. Hughes said at a press briefing today that "the suburbs have become more than nice places to raise the kids; they have become engines of employment growth."
In an interview after the briefing, he said that using transportation initiatives to combat unemployment is an attractive solution, in part because the $150 billion in transportation spending authorized by Congress last year is available for domestic initiatives.
According to the report, The New Metropolitan Reality, written by Mr. Hughes and Julie E. Steinberg, a study of Newark and its suburbs between the years 1970 and 1988 showed thatthe farther from the center of Newark an area was the more job growth it generally had.
Central Newark lost nearly 80,000 jobs during that period, and the area within two miles lost 40,000 more. But areas six miles or more to the west, south and north of downtown gained jobs steadily, with the greatest increases recorded in areas about 16 miles out.
But the data indicate that more than half those jobs were inaccessible via New Jersey mass transit.
"The new metropolis is predicated on mobility, and private automobile travel is how this mobility is realized," the report said. "However, the transportation costs associated with all this mobility are regressive. Participation in work, shopping, schooling and so on requires travel in the modern metropolis. What for most people is a low-density life style becomes for the poor a set of costly barriers."
Whether such barriers can be overcome by making transportation more accessible to the inner-city poor has been a focus of debate for two decades. In his recent book, "The New Politics of Poverty," Lawrence Mead, a New York University political science professor, argues that earlier demonstrations of "reverse commuting" programs in the late 1960's had little or no effect on unemployment in the cities.
"I don't see strong evidence for lack of access to employment -- physical access or other barriers -- sheer lack of jobs, racial bias, or other things," Dr. Mead said in a telephone interview today. "To say this is a major solution is counter to the evidence we have."
But Dr. Hughes, a professor of public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, disagreed. "Some of the most persuasive post-L.A. riot rhetoric says give the poor a greater stake in their communities," he said. "That's the right incentive, but the wrong geography.
"Setting aside the issue of how possible it is to revitalize inner cities, if it works, it's separatist. Why, after a period of 30 years of massive infrastructure investment in the suburban labor market," he asked, should the Government try to replicate that success in the inner cities, where the jobs have been lost.

HEADLINE: Big Retailers Register Modest Sales Gains for November

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Most of the nation's large retailers posted only modest sales gains last month, according to figures released yesterday by big chain stores.
But most Wall Street analysts said the numbers were somewhat deceptive, and did not sound a somber note for the all-important Christmas season.
An index of comparable-store sales at 14 leading retailers compiled by Salomon Brothers rose by 3.8 percent in November, well below the 7.5 percent gain recorded during October. 
 "The first half of the month was sluggish, but things picked up by the third week," Jeff Feiner, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said. "And the weekend after Thanksgiving was good and indicative of what we think will be a slowly improving environment."
 Analysts said a number of factors contributed to the poor results early in November, including unusually warm weather in certain parts of the country, which hurt sales of fall and winter merchandise, and consumer preoccupation with the Presidential election.
"Anybody who spoke to these companies early in the month knew then that it was painfully weak," Edward A. Weller, a retail analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said. "But Thanksgiving was good, and we have a strengthening trend."
Even though some underlying economic trends continue to suggest a sputtering recovery -- employment and wage growth both continue to be moribund, for example -- conditions are markedly better now than they were a year ago. That, analysts said, is one reason they are upbeat about the Christmas selling season.
An index of same-store sales at 18 retailers compiled by Alex. Brown & Sons rose just 1.8 percent last December.
Because of the year-to-year comparison and because two extra selling days between Thanksgiving and Christmas fall in December, "I think December sales will look unusually good," Robert F. Buchanan, an Alex. Brown analyst, said.
Indeed, if sales "aren't up substantially, it's a bad sign," Mr. Buchanan added, noting that a gain of 5 percent or less would not be good news for retailers or the economy.
"The environment has picked up some," Mr. Buchanan said, "but it is still tough. It's not like shoppers are walking around with a lot of cash out there."
Among individual retailers, analysts said they were particularly impressed with results posted by Wal-Mart Stores Inc., whose same-store sales rose by 7 percent last month; by the J. C. Penney Company, whose sales rose by 5.1 percent, and the Limited Inc., where sales were up by 8 percent.
Chains whose results were poorer than expected were led by the Gap Inc., whose same-store sales were up just 1 percent in November.
 
 
Lower Prices
 "The Gap had a disappointing month," Mr. Weller at Montgomery Securities said. "Part of that is related to the fact that the merchandise they sold was moved at much lower prices than they had planned."
The Gap's results also disappointed investors, and the price of the company's stock slid by 75 cents a share, to $35.375, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
In addition to the Gap, some analysts said sales results posted by the Woolworth Corporation were unexpectedly bad.
Same-store sales at Woolworth fell by 1.1 percent in November from a year earlier.
The drop in sales may have surprised some outsiders, but Mr. Weller said the decline probably did not raise many eyebrows or concerns within the company.
"Some retailers had been expecting soft sales because they ran so many promotions a year ago," he said. "Woolworth is the best example of that."

HEADLINE: At Plant, Gray Skies and Pink Slips

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EWING, N.J., Dec. 3

 BODY:
Workers on the day shift streamed out of General Motors Inland Fisher Guide plant here today just as gray clouds and a cold wind were moving in from the west. Hours earlier, in a meeting in the plant cafeteria, they had been told that the plant's 2,200 employees would lose their jobs next year.
"G.M. says 'Merry Christmas,' " one worker yelled to waiting reporters. "We'll survive!" called another. Yet another carried a homemade sign that read, "Will work for food." 
 The news did not surprise some workers at the plant, which makes items like door handles, seat adjusters and decorative exterior moldings.
 
'A Hammer Over My Head'
 "I came here on Aug. 27, 1978, and I was told I would not get my 90 days in," said Everett Barber, 39 years old, of Hamilton Township, N.J., a quality operator who builds power-seat components. "So this was a hammer hanging over my head since then. I feel relief now it's over."
Mixed with the relief was bitterness.
"They've been badgering us about company loyalty," Mr. Barber said. "Where's the loyalty to us? I can promise you I own my last G.M. vehicle."
Mr. Barber said that when workers arrived at the plant this morning, they were told that a meeting would be held at 10 A.M. in the cafeteria. "Management came through and they looked like they had just gotten a major whupping," he said. "We knew."
What he did not know was what would happen next. "The questions we asked today, no one had answers to. We're always the last to know."
Across America, in towns like Sioux City, Iowa; Syracuse, and Kalamazoo, Mich., G.M. workers came to work today, only to learn that their jobs would be among 18,000 cuts, and their futures would be in doubt. Under the United Automobile Workers contract, workers might be offered a transfer to another G.M. plant, but with the nation's No. 1 auto maker paring 80,000 jobs over the next few years, actually getting a transfer may be difficult. To make matters worse, the union contract with the company expires next fall.
 
 
Closing Set for '93
 Patricia Molloy, a spokeswoman for Inland Fisher Guide, said the plant was scheduled to close in the third quarter of 1993 although an exact date had not been set. She said the workers were told what was happening before the closing was disclosed to reporters.
Another worker expressed concern about how many people would be hurt.
"I think it's not only sad our standard of living is going to go down, but the entire community is going to suffer from this," said Karen Restuccio, 37, of Roebling, N.J. "A big corporation like General Motors won't be around to pump money into the economy."
When asked if this would make her Christmas difficult, Ms. Restuccio said, "We were prepared for it." She added: "I live alone, but I'm a homeowner, so I'm kind of worried there. But there's always a way."
When asked what her way might be, Ms. Restuccio replied, "It might be two jobs, but if that's what it has to be, that's what has to be."
 
A Personal Plea
 Pete Janora, 50, of Trenton, a tool and die maker, approached a reporter and said he had something to say. Mr. Janora produced his own statement, handwritten on a small white piece of paper. An American flag had been drawn at the bottom.
"It's not just this plant that's having trouble," he read. "Everyone has to worry and realize that we're losing manufacturing throughout this country, plant by plant, and industry by industry. Everyone can't work for the Government and have Government services. The Japanese and other foreign countries are in an undeclared war with us. It's time for all Americans to wake up and protect what our fathers, our grandfathers, and their fathers fought and died for."
Jeff Bintz, president of United Automobile Workers Local 731, which represents workers here, was unavailable for comment. Bob Wieger, financial secretary of the local, said Mr. Bintz would be unable to return reporters' calls today because he had planned to spend Thursday meeting with union members at the plant, which is across Parkway Avenue from the union hall.
"He's on the floor right now, talking to the workers," Mr. Wieger said, "which is where he should be."
Guy Messina, another U.A.W. official, took some hope from the fact that jobs would remain at G.M.'s assembly plant in Linden, N.J. That plant is being remodeled to allow the assembly of three new truck models, a midsize truck and two four-wheel-drive utility vehicles.
"I'm hopeful that the new president of G.M. will do what he did in Europe and go to three shifts of production," said Mr. Messina, who is shop chairman for U.A.W. Local 595, which represents workers at the Linden plant. "If that happens, we can accommodate some of our brothers and sisters from Ewing."

HEADLINE: Insurers' Turnaround on Health Benefits Only Opens New Set of Questions

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's election has been interpreted by the health-care industry as a referendum for sweeping change. Factions recently at war now seem to be falling into line. But the growing consensus is on general philosophical principles, not the details, which still present big obstacles to final agreement on how to provide health care to everyone at reasonable cost.
On Nov. 9, six days after the Presidential election, business executives, hospital trustees and leaders of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association offered to cooperate with Mr. Clinton in writing legislation to revamp the health-care system. 
 On Wednesday, in a break from past practice, the Health Insurance Association of America, representing 270 commercial insurers, called for a new law requiring insurance coverage of all Americans. As a way to control costs, the insurers said they would welcome a limit on the open-ended tax subsidy for health insurance bought by employers for their employees.
After the promise of jobs and economic growth, health care was the biggest issue in Mr. Clinton's campaign, and his election has changed the political landscape for action on the issue. In the last Congress, Democrats could not agree among themselves on a national health plan, and there was even more disagreement between Congress and the White House.
But now, with the Bush Administration dying and the Clinton Administration still unborn, the sounds emanating from Washington are melodious and harmonious.
Frederick H. Graefe, a Washington lawyer who specializes in health-care policy, said: "The vote by the directors of the Health Insurance Association is a simple reflection of political reality. They're reading the tea leaves after they got hit with a 2-by-4. Their proposal indicates where policy is headed in the next Congress."
Mr. Graefe said that several companies recently announced plans to withdraw from the trade group "because of the seeming intransigence of the Health Insurance Assocation in coming to grips with political reality."
The political reality is complex and elusive. For consumers, health care is a pocketbook issue. The cost of health care and health insurance has been rising twice as fast as other consumer prices. But for middle-income families with health insurance, there is no prospect of immediate relief under the changes proposed by Mr. Clinton and the health insurance industry. Indeed, the middle class might be asked to make some sacrifices for which it has not been politically prepared.
The changes would be gradual. Prices would rise more slowly. Some consumers would have to sacrifice some of their freedom to choose doctors and hospitals. Under the industry proposal, millions of Americans who get health insurance from their employers would have to pay higher taxes.
Karen M. Ignagni, director of employee benefits at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said: "Middle-class workers with comprehensive health benefits will just say no to higher taxes. They have borne the burden of rising health-care costs for too long to accept this solution. They paid very dearly for the health benefits they now have. They sacrificed wages to get and maintain those health benefits."
Mr. Clinton has not said whether he wants to tax a portion of employee health benefits, as many economists recommend. Any effort to do so would fracture the coalition of his supporters.
Economic theorists say the tax code encourages employers to buy too much health insurance and encourages workers to use too much health care. Employees see the problem differently. Many workers are now paying more for less coverage than they once had.
Kevin E. Moley, Deputy Secretary of Health and Human Services, said the election of Mr. Clinton had scared members of the health-care industry into being more flexible.
"They no longer have the comfort of knowing that George Bush as President will veto stupid legislation," said Mr. Moley, who used to work for an insurance company. "They are confronted with Governor Clinton, who is very activist, believes in a strong role for the central Government and is willing to play with the levers of power in Washington."
In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to impose an annual limit on all health spending, public and private. Many health-care businesses and insurers oppose this type of constraint, known as "a global budget," and they are frantically seeking alternatives to control costs.
"If you are confronted with a President who wants global budgets, then the idea of a tax cap on the deductibility of health insurance costs is far more palatable by virtue of its being an alternative to something that is out-and-out awful," Mr. Moley said.
Congress and the nation are far from consensus on how to reorganize the delivery of health care, and there are hundreds of unanswered questions, including these:
*What will be in the basic package of benefits promised to all Americans?
*Will elderly people be entitled to all the benefits they now get under Medicare?
*Will the Government regulate drug prices? Will a new Federal agency be needed to regulate health insurance?
*Must antitrust laws be amended to let hospitals cooperate in eliminating the duplication of costly services?
*If every American must buy private health insurance, what becomes of Medicaid, the program for poor people? What becomes of veterans' hospitals? The Indian Health Service?
Consumer groups are skeptical of the health insurers' latest proposal. Rhoda H. Karpatkin, president of Consumers Union, said the proposal would help break "a logjam of unrelenting resistance to real reform." But she added, "This is a plan by the insurance industry to save itself without solving the underlying causes of our health-care crisis."
The sudden burst of interest in health-care legislation reflects political and economic pressure built up over more than a decade.
Many critics of President Bush, including some Republicans, say he did political damage to himself by virtually ignoring the health-care issue from 1989 through 1991, as medical prices soared and millions of people lost health insurance coverage.
White House officials expressed irritation with anyone who tried to prod them into action. They shunned officials of the American Medical Association after an editorial in the Journal of the A.M.A. declared in May 1991 that there was "an aura of inevitability to national health-care reform."
Mr. Clinton will soon be tested. Unless he pays close attention to the myriad details of health legislation in the next four years, he is unlikely to fulfill his campaign promise of "controlling health costs and covering all Americans."

HEADLINE: Fed Action On Rates Is Unlikely

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
Sounding more upbeat about the economy than they have all year, Federal Reserve officials said in interviews this week that they were not likely to change interest rates in the near future.
Speaking with unusual candor, the officials said that they were so pleased about the robust economic growth of the third quarter that they had no plans to cut interest rates soon and that they were so happy with the low inflation rate that they saw no need to raise rates either. 
 "I don't think there are compelling reasons at the moment for dramatic policy changes one way or the other," said John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve governor.
In the view of one Fed official, the Fed and President-elect Bill Clinton are engaged in a "mating dance," each seeking not to offend the other.
 
Greenspan and Clinton Meet
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was in Little Rock, Ark., today, meeting with Mr. Clinton for the first time since Election Day. The chairman has refused to talk publicly about economic developments, but his recent speeches have been optimistic about inflation, although cautious about growth prospects.
No change in Fed policy would be good news for Mr. Clinton, who is contemplating measures to stimulate the economy that would increase the budget deficit, in the short term at least.
The Fed governors remain hostile to the notion of short-term stimulus, and this week they were even more antagonistic than two months ago, because of the strong 3.9 percent growth in the third quarter.
"At this point, I'd say I am encouraged about prospects and consequently less inclined to think there is room for fiscal stimulus," Robert T. Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said in a telephone interview.
"We're not seeing pressures on the wage side," Susan Phillips, a Federal Reserve governor, said. "The overcapacity will continue to allow room for production increases without putting price pressures on the economy."
Fed officials indicated there would be no automatic increase in rates if Mr. Clinton decided to create jobs by raising the deficit. But they also said there was no need to cut rates further to spur growth.
David W. Mullins Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, said economic growth appeared to be strengthening gradually, although he, like most economists, said fourth-quarter growth would likely be weaker than the third quarter's.
Speaking about growth rates in 1993, Mr. Mullins said, "it could be anywhere from the high 2's to the mid-3's." That would compare with 2.8 percent so far this year, and should translate soon into higher employment.
Another Fed governor, Lawrence D. Lindsey, said, "A large number of fundamentals have fallen into place to suggest that conditions are there for sustained recovery." He noted that corporate profits and productivity were up. But the governors are also worried about consumer debt and slow European growth, which will hurt American exports.
As for the President-elect's policy plans, the interviews made clear that some officials are more hostile to stimulus than others, but most believe it could be counterproductive.

HEADLINE: K.J. Oberman, 62, Manager of Funds For Oppenheimer

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Kenneth J. Oberman, who managed the top-performing mutual fund in the United States last year, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 62 years old and lived in Brooklyn.
He died of Hodgkin's disease, his family said. 
 Mr. Oberman was senior vice president of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation in Manhattan and was the director of its Global Equity Investments. His responsibilities at his death included Oppenheimer's Global Fund, Global Bio-Tech Fund and Gold and Special Minerals Fund, with total assets exceeding $1.3 billion.
The Bio-Tech Fund rose 121 percent last year, ranking first among 2,400 mutual funds. It lost part of that gain this year with the general slump in biotechnology stocks.
Before last year's spectacular performance, Mr. Oberman turned in other strong results. While he managed Oppenheimer's AIM Fund in 1985, it rose 49 percent, ranking 10th among all funds. The Global Fund, which has more than $1 billion in assets, jumped 49 percent in 1985 and 46 percent in 1986.
Mr. Oberman was a booster of biotechnology companies' potential for scientific discoveries and financial growth. "This is the stuff that dreams are made of," he once said. He was also an expert in international investments, especially in Europe.
He worked at Oppenheimer for 12 years. Before that he was at Dreyfus for seven years, where he was the portfolio manager of the Dreyfus Fund and the Dreyfus Third Century Fund. Earlier, he was a vice president and research director at Delphi Management and at Model Roland.
Mr. Oberman was born in Brooklyn. He earned a bachelor's degree and a master's in economics from the University of California at Berkeley and another economics degree from the University of Stockholm.
He served in the Army from 1951 to 1953 in Korea and Finland and reached the rank of sergeant.
His wife of 24 years, Gretchen White, a lawyer, died in 1979.
He is survived by two daughters, Claire M. of Brooklyn, and Anneli of Stamford, Conn.; a son, Theodore of Brooklyn, and a stepmother, Jeanne Oberman of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: First Time Jobless Claims Fall

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time unemployment claims decreased in mid-November for the seventh decline in the last nine weeks, the Labor Department said today.
Separately, factory orders rose 1.7 percent in October, the largest gain in four months, while the productivity of workers increased 3 percent in the July-September quarter. 
 Today's reports suggest that widespread layoffs are tapering off while the economy struggles to recover from the recession. Analysts had expected a smaller decline in jobless claims and a bigger gain in factory orders. Productivity was within expectations.
 
 
'It's Not Horrible'
 "We're struggling along at a moderate rate of growth," said Marco Babic, an economist at Evans Economics, a consulting firm in Washington. "It's not horrible. I don't think the doomsayers have too much going for them."
The decrease of 12,000 jobless claims to a seasonally adjusted 362,000 in the week ended Nov. 21 follows a 12,000 drop, to 374,000 last week.
The level of claims was the lowest since 355,000 in the week ended Oct. 31 and was "considerably stronger than expected, suggesting clear improvement in labor markets," Stone & McCarthy Research Associates said.
However, the four-week moving average for jobless claims, a less volatile barometer of employment conditions, climbed to 369,250 in the latest reporting week from 368,750.
In addition, 23,289 workers in 52 states filed under a separate emergency program providing extended jobless benefits in the week ended Nov. 21, the Government said.
This suggests the overall level of claims hovered near 380,000. During the previous week, there were 21,005 claims filed under the emergency program.
In today's report, 46 states and territories, led by Michigan with almost 15,000 layoffs in the auto industry, reported increases in jobless claims. Seven states reported decreases, led by Ohio.
The 1.7 percent increase in factory orders in October follows a 1.3 percent gain during September as demand for durable goods -- expensive items made to last three or more years -- rose while demand for nondurable goods fell, the Commerce Department said.
Factory inventories, a barometer of consumer demand for goods, decreased one-tenth of 1 percent in October after rising three-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Meanwhile, the revised increase in nonfarm productivity shows that people who did not lose their jobs during the recession worked longer and harder to compensate for laid-off workers.
Productivity, the output per hour of a worker, is vital to improving production without raising labor costs or inflation. It also makes American exports more competitive.
The rise in nonfarm productivity in July, August and September, first reported as a 2.6 percent gain, follows a 1.7 percent increase in April, May and June, the Labor Department said.

HEADLINE: College Students Accused of Electronic Tax Fraud

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMPTON, Va., Nov. 27

 BODY:
About 40 students at a private college in Virginia and 50 of their friends are being investigated on suspicion of committing a new kind of fraud that was created when the Government introduced its electronic income-tax filing system seven years ago.
Officials say the students were taught how to defraud professional tax-preparation services and banks by filing phony returns, complete with forged wage statements and other supporting documents, and then pocketing bank loans arranged by the services in anticipation of tax refunds. 
 The scheme worked for a while because of an Internal Revenue Service policy that allows taxpayers filing electronically to mail supporting documents later, so by the time the returns are found to be fraudulent, the bank checks have been cashed.
In Virginia, officials said, most people in the group learned how to participate from a student who, in turn, had heard about it from a relative. The officials did not say what the source of the forged documents was. But as more and more students and others became involved, it became what investigators say is one of the largest fraud cases of its kind.
 
Trying to Keep Up
 "Our challenge is to not only keep up with the technology but to keep up with the crooks," said the prosecutor in the case, Richard Cullen, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia.
The I.R.S. said that in the first nine months of 1992, fraud was discovered on 12,333 electronic returns, more than double the number in the previous year, representing $33 million in refunds. The number of cases detected in 1992 does not include the 90 people in the Virginia case, in which they are accused of filing more than $230,000 in false refund claims.
Apart from its size, the group is also unusual in that most of its members had never filed income tax returns before and took advantage of the system, in part, because they were familiar with the technology needed to produce the phony documents. Investigators said that for the most part, previous schemes have involved people with histories of fraud.
 
It Seemed Easy
 Felicia D. German, a premedical student at Hampton University on the Virginia coast who is accused of taking part in the scheme, said a friend had told her that many students had made money without being caught.
"You had all these people who had gotten money," Miss German said in an interview. "Time had passed, and nothing had happened. When you hear it's so easy, it's easy to get caught up."
The I.R.S. introduced computerized filing in three cities in 1986. The program was phased in elsewhere but not available nationally until 1990. This year, 11 million people, or 9 percent of taxpayers, filed returns electronically. The I.R.S. expects the number to be 25 million by the year 2000.
Officials said they had been caught off guard by the high level of electronic fraud, which now accounts for more fraud than paper returns. The agency has begun holding seminars on how to detect such claims, particularly by examining supporting documents.
And for tax returns for 1993, the I.R.S. has announced a change in the handling of electronic filings that a spokesman said will make it harder to get loans made in anticipation of refunds.
 
The Trail Cools Quickly
 In the past, the I.R.S. computer compared a filer's Social Security number to debtors' lists and then sent a signal to a tax preparer as a preliminary indication that a return would be accepted for processing. The firms have relied on that signal in evaluating refund applications, and that has given people the opportunity to collect the bank loans before the I.R.S. detects the fraud.
"By the time we get there, often the trail is cold and the checks are cashed," said Phil Xanthos, the I.R.S. branch chief of criminal investigations in Los Angeles.
The authorities said that in these cases the losses are absorbed by the lending banks by agreement with the commercial preparers. The service is immensely popular; at one of the largest commercial services, H & R Block, more than 90 percent of electronic filers accept the company's offer of "Rapid Refund" loans.
Harry W. Buckley, president of H & R Block's tax operations division, said the industry was so concerned about the fraud schemes that competing preparers are sharing information, the first instance of cooperation that he can remember.
Miss German, one of the Hampton students, said she had learned about the scheme from a classmate after she saw fictitious wage forms stacked in his apartment. The forms had been produced on a word processor. The classmate, Steven E. Morgan of Chicago, said in court papers accompanying his guilty plea that he had learned about the scheme from his roommate's brother. Investigators said other people became involved through conversations with friends, and they said many of the conversations led back to Mr. Morgan.
 
'No College Prank'
 The lawyer for nine of the students, Dr. John J. Rice, a Hampton associate professor with a part-time law practice, said they were "quite naive."
"Some of these people had never filed a tax return before," Dr. Rice said. "They thought the worst thing that could happen was than they would have to repay the money."
But Mr. Cullen, who is prosecuting the students on counts that each call for one to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine, asserted that the scheme was "no college prank."
"They were greedy, and they're going to pay for it," he said.
In their filings, made from January to March, the students made up jobs, mainly at two area businesses whose employer numbers they knew, and claimed $2,400 to $2,800 in refunds for each claim. The refunds were increased by more than $1,000 each by claiming newborn children, a status that qualified a student for tax credits as head of a household and as a low-income parent.
"It's something they discovered could slip through the cracks," said Paul W. Littman, president of the Hampton franchise of Jackson Hewitt Tax Service.
 
'No Cleverness at All'
 Most of the students used their own names and Social Security numbers, and in several cases a student went to one tax-preparation office to file returns under different names, prosecutors and tax-preparers said. But after many similar claims were received, preparers at Jackson Hewitt became suspicious and decided to examine supporting documents more closely.
"There was no cleverness at all," Mr. Littman said. "It's actually a pretty rude scheme. Anyone who files a false return under their own Social Security number has no understanding of the system."
"You had all these students who had babies in 1991, and they all had about the same incomes," said Mr. Buckley of H & R Block. "When you called the employers, you found that they'd never worked there."
Mr. Morgan, a former midshipman in the Navy Reserve Officers' Training Corps, was expelled from Hampton and later enrolled in Norfolk State University. He pleaded guilty in United States District Court in Norfolk to one felony count of conspiracy to defraud the I.R.S. In October, he was ordered to make restitution and to report to prison after Christmas to begin serving an 18-month sentence.
Miss German was linked to the scheme by an investigator who had copied her license-plate number as she drove a student to file a bogus return. A fourth-year student from Montgomery, Ala., Miss German left Hampton and enrolled in Norfolk State this fall.
She said she had been offered a bargain in which she would plead guilty to the felony of conspiring to defraud the I.R.S. by filing a false tax refund claim. If she refused, she could be indicted by a grand jury and would face a trial.
"I'm stalling," she said. "I don't know what I'm hoping for. I guess I'm waiting to see what other people do."
 
Other Pleas Expected
 Several other students are expected to sign plea agreements in mid-December, a Federal official said. The official said prosecutors are pursuing more than 50 related cases.
A Justice Department spokeswoman said that last year, before the students were discovered, 65 people were indicted in a dozen states on charges of filing 1,850 falsified electronic returns for refunds totaling $4 million.
Other electronic-filing schemes have often used the names and Social Security numbers of people who otherwise would not file -- homeless or unemployed people, for example, or workers with very small incomes and no tax obligation. Some fraud rings recruit the people to fill out returns, and then the organizers collect most of the refund.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Steady Business In Temporary Jobs

BYLINE: By Steve Lohr

 BODY:
THE temporary-help industry stands at the front line of an economic recovery, and the news from the front is encouraging these days.
When business begins to pick up, companies tend to be cautious at first, renting temporary workers instead of rehiring permanent ones -- a labor-market phenomenon that seems well under way. The number of workers employed by temporary-help companies has been running about 14 percent ahead of last year since May, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 The big three suppliers of temporary workers -- Manpower Inc., Kelly Services Inc. and the Olsten Corporation -- report that revenues in recent months are up 15 percent or more over last year's levels. Profits are expected to increase even more sharply. And the rebound looks anything but temporary. Analysts predict that the earnings of the industry's three leaders will nearly double over the next two years.
The brightening outlook for the temporary-help industry has as much to do with the structural changes in corporate America as with the improvement in the economy. The fashion among big companies has been to strip down to a "core" work force to cut costs, and let outsiders do clerical and back-office work, data processing and other fairly routine chores.
The slimming down at big companies, which continues, is a key reason why permanent jobs have not come back despite recent signs of a recovery. "We are certainly a beneficiary of the reluctance to rehire in corporate America," said Mitchell Fromstein, president of Manpower. The company, based in Milwaukee, is the nation's largest supplier of temporary workers.
Other pluses for the industry are that the temporary-help companies have done a good job keeping their expenses under control without eviscerating their national networks of offices. In short, they should enjoy a rapid rise in profits when business picks up. Finally, as the economy strengthens and demand for temporary workers increases, the suppliers should be under less pressure to cut prices on big corporate contracts, which became standard practice during the slump as temp companies fought to hold onto their shares of the market.
"It's a very positive picture for the temporary-help companies," said Judith Scott, an analyst for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee.
Yet there is one big caveat: the uncertain course of this economic recovery. For the temporary-help industry, as with the general economy, there has been a false dawn or two. In late 1991 and early 1992 when there were signs of strength, stock prices rose, but then the incipient recovery faltered.
By most accounts, however, the improvement appears stronger and more durable this time, with a magnified impact on the industry's profits. In the last few months, for example, Mr. Fromstein of Manpower says revenues from his company's 880 offices in the United States are 15 percent ahead of last year, but operating profits are 30 percent ahead. Manpower's stock, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at $14.675, up 12.5 cents.
A near-term problem for Manpower is that more than half its business comes from abroad, mainly Western Europe, where the economy remains weak. Most analysts say this may be an advantage in the long run, but they expect Europe's doldrums to slow the pickup in the company's earnings. Ms. Scott, for example, estimates that the company's profits of 55 cents a share, or $40 million, this year will rise gradually to 75 cents a share, or $55 million, in 1993. In 1994, however, she expects a sharper rise, to $1.10 a share, or $81 million.
Kelly Services, based in Troy, Mich., is the second-largest temporary-help company. It does nearly all its business in the United States, so it should benefit more quickly from an American recovery, analysts say. And after moving to a more decentralized structure and bringing in new managers in the last two years, Kelly, a laggard in the industry's nascent recovery, may finally be positioned to rebound.
John Larson, an analyst for Barrington Research Associates, estimates that Kelly's profits for this year -- $1.25 a share, or $38 million -- will increase next year to $1.60 a share, or $48 million. In 1994, he estimates earnings of $2.15 a share, or $65 million. The recent optimism about Kelly has prompted a jump in its share price from about $32 at the end of October to $41.25 yesterday in over-the-counter trading, up 37.5 cents for the day.
The run-up in Kelly's stock price has caused some analysts to say that at roughly 26 times next year's estimated earnings, the price is high. "I like the company, but it looks pricey to me," said Mr. Larson, who changed his recommendation on Kelly from "buy" to "hold" when its share price moved above $40.
Of the industry's Big Three, Olsten, based in Westbury, L.I., has shown the most consistent profit performance during the downturn, helped by its large stake in the recession-resistant home health-care market. Olsten acquired Upjohn Healthcare Services for $58 million in December 1990, increasing Olsten's network of health-care offices by 200, to more than 275 offices. The division supplies workers to the growing market for home health care and supplemental staffing for hospitals and nursing homes.
The company's shares, which trade on the American Stock Exchange, were up 87.5 cents yesterday, to $35.75.
Olsten's profits have increased by 40 percent during the first three quarters of this year. "And if I had to pick one of these stocks that will do best over the next year," Mr. Larson said, "it would probably be Olsten."

HEADLINE: As Immigrants Face Crises, Neediest Cases Fund Helps

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Irma Contreras need only wander the aisles of a supermarket near her apartment in the Bronx to remind herself of why she left her small village in Honduras. The seemingly endless displays of milk and meat and produce piled high put into perspective the sacrifices she made to escape the poverty of her homeland and bring her six children to the United States.
Sometimes she appreciates the reminder. Like many of the more than one million immigrants who have settled in the five boroughs since 1980, she has faced crises as she has tried to start a new life in a land where work is often less plentiful than food in the local supermarket. 
 Since she arrived from Honduras in 1984 after separating from her husband, Ms. Contreras, 41 years old, had never been without work, mainly child care or housekeeping, until the last few months. But as the recession wiped away jobs, she turned to the Community Service Society of New York for help in paying her rent and feeding her children. She has also received legal and financial assistance to obtain her green card so that she can seek work that is more permanent. The society is one of seven charities aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which has begun its 81st annual campaign this week.
In an interview in her tidy apartment in the Highbridge section, Ms. Contreras spoke of her difficulties in finding a job. But she added that she was determined to remain in the United States with her family so her children -- who range in age from 10 to 24 -- would know English and receive a proper education. That, above all, was her goal.
"I want the best for them," she said in Spanish. "I don't want them to be like me, doing housework."
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was established in 1911, a year when New York City was also being flooded by immigrants. Then, as now, charities confronted growing responsibilities as they tried to aid both newcomers and those who had lived all their lives in this country.
These days, the seven charities linked to the fund are struggling because government aid and donations have leveled off at a time when immigration is at flood levels.
"What continues to stretch us very thin is the fact that at the same time that we are trying to deal with the increased needs of the indigenous population, we have a major responsibility for immigrant resettlement in New York," said Stephen Solender, executive vice president of United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, a Neediest charity.
This year's Neediest campaign will end on Feb. 28. The Times pays for the fund's overhead, so all contributions go directly to the charities.
Ms. Contreras said that even though she has depleted her savings and has had to seek help from the Community Service Society, she was still able to draw strength from the success of Maria, her 18-year-old daughter, who has recently graduated from high school and is planning to attend college.
"There are times when one has, and there are times when one doesn't have," she said, voicing the resilience of a woman who has often gone hungry to feed her children. "But all in all, New York has been good for me and good for my family."

HEADLINE: New York Pursues Truce In Job War With Trenton

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
New York State suggested yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey coordinate negotiations between the two states in an attempt to end their fight over New Jersey's increasing use of financial incentives to try to lure companies from New York.
Jon Shure, a spokesman for Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, said, "the idea of talking certainly interests us." 
 But there was no sign that New Jersey officials were willing to yield to New York's demands. Officials in Trenton repeated their view that they are neither specifically aiming for nor actively soliciting New York companies.
"We feel what we're doing is consistent with a state's obligation to promote itself, and we don't feel that we are in any kind of war with New York," said Barbara W. McConnell, New Jersey's Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development. If New York "wants to reach out and have discussions, that is certainly not unacceptable," she added. "But we're not at war, so we don't see what there is to negotiate."
 
'Come to a Resolution'
 Vincent Tese, New York State's Director of Economic Development, said he hoped the talks could begin within a week. "We've got to come to a resolution pretty quick," or New York will carry out its plans to retaliate against New Jersey, he said. "We don't think a border war is in the best interest of the region, nor either state."
While New York officials have also expressed some concern about some new Connecticut incentives, there were no plans yesterday to ask Connecticut to participate in the talks.
New York officials say New Jersey has used incentives that have enticed businesses from New York or forced New York to pay more in incentives to keep them. Unless New Jersey relents, they have vowed to begin a campaign by mid-December to solicit New Jersey companies in the hope that New Jersey will have to pay more to keep its companies.
Mr. Tese said a major thrust of the campaign would be to persuade New Jersey companies to move to Orange and Rockland Counties. New York State has an 8,000-acre business park near Newburgh next to the Stewart International Airport.
 
'In a Very Good Position'
 "We're calling on the Port Authority to get people together to avert a very unpleasant situation," said Mr. Tese, who is the authority's vice chairman. Noting that the two states work on transportation and development issues on a daily basis at the authority, he said, "The Port Authority is in a very good position to bring some sense and some reason to this particular situation."
An agency of the two states, the authority operates the World Trade Center in Manhattan, ports, the three major airports in the New York metropolitan area, the PATH railroad under the Hudson River and tunnels and bridges between the two states.
While the authority's mission -- to foster regional development and cooperation -- makes it seem a logical forum for trying to resolve the dispute, it is also in an uncomfortable position.
Saying his organization was happy to help, Richard C. Leone, the authority's chairman, added, "I'm not exactly delighted that we're caught in the middle of this one." A New Jerseyan who was State Treasurer in the 1970's, Mr. Leone served in the 1980's as managing director of Dillon Reade & Company, the investment bank, and as president of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
New York officials say the main issue is New Jersey's use of its new $224 million Economic Recovery Fund to finance incentives to lure New York companies to New Jersey. New York officials are angry that bonds that New Jersey sold to finance the fund will essentially be repaid from New Jersey's share of rental income from 2.1 million square feet in the World Trade Center.
 
'91 Agreement
 Mr. Tese repeated yesterday that New York officials believe that New Jersey's incentives violate the spirit of both the compact establishing the Port Authority and a limited nonaggression agreement signed in 1991 by New York State, New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut.
New York's share of the World Trade Center money is going into the state's general fund. Referring to the state's recent budget problems and cut in personal income taxes, Mr. Tese said New York's use of the money included "budget relief to reduce taxes."
Yesterday New Jersey officials repeated their position: under the World Trade Center agreement, each state is free to use the money as it wants. Admitting that New Jersey had not violated any legal agreement, Mr. Tese repeated that he nonetheless wants New Jersey to promise not to use the Economic Recovery Fund to woo New York businesses. He said he did not mind if New Jersey continued to offer such incentives to businesses in other states.
But New Jersey officials said his proposal was not feasible. "I'm more than willing to listen to any reasons for doing that, but I've got no reasons today anyway to draw those kinds of restrictions around the fund," said Anthony R. Coscia, chairman of New Jersey's Economic Development Authority.
Mr. Tese said he would also try to make future deals clearly stipulate that neither state may use funds involving the Port Authority to finance marketing or incentive programs that harm the other.
The Port Authority's board has six members from New York and six from New Jersey. Stanley Brezenoff, the authority's executive director, was First Deputy Mayor of New York City in the Koch administration.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
The Dreams From Fields Of the Past Are Saved

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
FOR decades, Coles Roberts and his family have been the stewards of about 300 acres of the other New Jersey, the one you don't see from the Turnpike.
Mr. Roberts grew apples. At one point he farmed a forest of apple trees, 14,000 strong and sturdy trees whose well-fed roots and well-pruned limbs produced the blossoms that attracted the bees that pollinated the flowers that became those little green knobs that grew into those bulging Red Delicious and Rome Beauties that left his land by the ton to feed the fruit needs of countless consumers all over (not to mention his homemade hot cider). 
 Farming is hard work, like anything worthwhile, farm fathers told their children for generations. You take care of the soil, and the soil will take care of you; you nurse an apple tree through a decade of infancy and adolescence, and it'll produce for you for a third of a century.
"I love the outdoors," says Mr. Roberts, "working with my hands and machines to help things grow and mature." But the 66-year-old Mr. Roberts isn't farming anymore. It got too hard and too expensive. His son, Sid, chose a future in computers, which don't make anything but don't take a decade to get going, either. Last spring when a hard frost annihilated this year's crop, the senior Mr. Roberts just gave up.
Now he's the curator of the two-year-old New Jersey Museum of Agriculture here, working to preserve the state's agricultural heritage through an eclectic collection of old farm machinery, tools, imagination and not a few scraped knuckles. Preserving a farming heritage isn't easy either in the face of modern-day lack of interest.
Farming is probably not the first image that springs to the minds of most Americans when someone mentions the nation's most heavily urbanized state, except perhaps for tank farms. But agriculture and ancillary services like grist mills were the principal reasons why many Garden State towns grew up where they did. (The parkway exits came later.)
This is, for instance, the 100th anniversary of the first parcel-post shipment of baby chicks in the United States. That first batch journeyed from Frenchtown, N.J., to Chicago in a special incubator. And while that event is obviously not as worthy of a postage stamp as, say, the cultural contributions of Elvis Presley, it did help inaugurate New Jersey's poultry industry. Once, New Jersey was the nation's chicken-egg capital. Once, chickens were so important here that they tattooed each one to combat rustling. Once, New Jersey's chickens were cause for local pride, not chuckles. Now, the state is better known for producing Bruce Springsteen.
That's where museums come in, as producers of perspective, institutional reminders of what once was. New Jersey agriculture may seem invisible, but museum visitors (Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.) learn it remains a multibillion-dollar business, especially in sod, nurseries, vegetables and even pond fish-farming. Cranberries will remain big, too, until someone conjures a more lucrative use for those bogs.
The museum, just off an old farm-to-market road called U.S. 1, contains two floors of machinery, photos and hands-on exhibits that come alive when Jennifer Martin demonstrates how brooms are made, how butter is churned or how ubiquitous corn is, even in urban lives. Sometimes they turn on that original incubator and hatch some eggs. There's a history of nails, a blacksmith shop, old milk wagons and tractors.
That's Mr. Roberts's favorite part. "I love antique machinery," he says. "We take it apart and clean it and imagine what the oldtimers were thinking when they designed it. Then we help it run again. Their work can seem pretty primitive, but so will ours, too, someday."
Mr. Roberts and his co-volunteers Charlie Broy and Martin Decker are particularly excited about an old grain drill recently uncovered in Elizabeth Blauvelt's big dairy barn up in Franklin Lakes. The machine was built when Theodore Roosevelt was President. With new housing closing in, Mrs. Blauvelt is selling her last 11 acres and moving to New Hampshire.
However, thanks to the perverse economics pervading so many aspects of American life, Mr. Roberts can still work his 300 acres, in a way. He's cutting down the remainder of the 14,000 apple trees on his Burlington County farm and turning them into firewood for the Saturday-evening enjoyment of approaching suburbia.
Clearing the land also has the possible advantage of increasing its value for that inevitable day when the developer's lawyer wipes his shiny shoes at the old farmhouse door. The sales contract will no doubt include the right to scrape off the former farm's rich topsoil for sale elsewhere. That's the usual procedure in the continuing disassembly of country culture, in New Jersey and beyond.

Mr. Roberts and Charlie Broy repaired a beetle duster. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sales Surge for Vehicles Built in the U.S.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 3

 BODY:
A surge of demand in late November pushed auto sales to the healthiest level in recent months, as sales of domestically built cars rose 14.5 percent and domestically built light trucks rose 37.4 percent.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 7.3 million from Nov. 21 to Nov. 30, up sharply from 5.8 million in mid-November and 5.6 million in the first third of the month. 
 "Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealers defintely have been witnessing the return of the individual consumers to the vehicle market," Robert L. Rewey, vice president for sales operations of the Ford Motor Company, said. Sales of the Taurus, which is contending with the Honda Accord for honors as the best-selling model, were 13,119, compared with 7,529 during the comparable 10-day period last year.
 
 
'Nothing Like a Good Contest'
 Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said, "There's nothing like a good contest to get sales cranking, and Ford clearly covets the calendar-year sales crown for its Taurus model."
Frank Arcurio, new-car sales manager of Dewar's Car World, a multibrand franchise in Johnstown, Pa., commented, "Showroom traffic picked up right after the election." Earlier in the year the dealership laid off 35 workers.
Sales of domestically built vehicles were 305,710, up 22.9 percent from a year earlier; they consisted of 180,367 cars and 125,343 light trucks, a category that includes sport-utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks.
Economists and automotive analysts have been disappointed that automotive demand during the last few months has not recovered as strongly as hoped. The last third of the month usually is stronger than the two earlier periods, so analysts are watching the early December numbers closely to see if stronger demand continues.
For all of November, sales of domestically built cars rose 5.9 percent from last November to 463,964. Sales of imported cars fell 4.6 percent, to 141,701. Over all, car sales rose 3.2 percent, to 605,665.
Sales of domestically built light trucks rose 29.4 percent in November to 341,706. Sales of imported light trucks fell 15.7 percent, to 27,627. Overall light-truck sales for the month rose 24.4 percent, to 369,333. Over all, vehicle sales in November rose 10.4 percent, to 974,998.
Ford, which had gained market share against rivals all year, posted a 26.1 percent gain, to 131,353 domestically built cars for the month. In light trucks, Ford gained 19.5 percent for the month, finishing with 110,457 sales.
 
 
G.M.'s Results
 The General Motors Corporation, the market leader, sold 190,811 domestically built cars in the month, down 7.5 percent. G.M.'s light-truck sales, however, gained 25.2 percent, to 120,898.
The Chrysler Corporation sold 56,949 domestically built cars in November, up 5.8 percent. Chrysler's light-truck sales were up 42.2 percent, to 88,523.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's domestic car sales fell 7.9 percent, to 21,945. The Honda Motor Company's domestic car sales rose 7.3 percent, to 32,727, and the Nissan Motor Company's domestic car sales more than doubled to 16,036.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rate-Cut Hopes Lift European Bonds

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
European bonds got a lift yesterday when hopes that Germany would cut interest rates were revived. The Bonn Government reported that the economy had declined sharply in the third quarter, and the country's largest trade union agreed to a wage settlement that is below the rate of inflation.
In Germany, the price of the 10-year bond rose about 1/2 point on the day. In France, bond futures grew about 1/3 point. 
 It's hard to predict when or if Germany might cut rates. But with the on- again, off-again expectations that often rule financial markets, the burst of hope was enough to spark a rally after the bad news from Germany earlier in the week.
 
Blunt Language
 On Monday and Tuesday, investors and traders were shaken by the blunt talk of the president of Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank. Forsaking the traditionally quiet approach of Europe's most important central bank, Helmut Schlesinger gave interviews and spoke publicly to make his view clear. He said that although his neighbors wanted lower interest rates, Germany -- which sets the pace for interest rates in Europe -- could not respond right now.
But for bond analysts and traders, yesterday's economic report and union settlement raised the possibility for two reasons. First, the decline in the economy shows that it is clearly in recession, a fact that Chancellor Helmut Kohl acknowledged last week. And the union settlement indicates that more such labor accords, with wage increases small enough to reduce the inflation fears of the the country's central bankers, might be reached. Taken together, a slow economy and low inflation might prompt a cut in interest rates.
According to the Government, the economy declined 1.5 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter. In addition, industrial production declined 2.2 percent in October, and the unemployment rate for the former West Germany rose to 6.9 percent in November from 6.7 percent in October.
In the wage agreement, IG Metall accepted a 3.25 percent, 18-month wage increase for 125,000 steel workers in northwest Germany. Inflation is now running at an annual rate of around 3.5 percent.
 
Treasury Market
 A surprisingly steep drop in the closely watched M-2 money-supply figure gave the bond market a little lift at the end of a day in which prices moved a lot but ended little changed.
The market managed to end on an up note, despite new data, including a decline in initial claims for unemployment insurance, that indicate the economy may be strengthening. A growing economy can worry bond investors because it can force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates and lead to rising inflation.
But yesterday this did not matter, in part because traders did little as they awaited today's employment report for November. In addition, some investors and traders may be thinking that prices have already fallen more than enough to reflect the impact of a stronger economy.
In late trading, the 7.625 percent 30-year bond was offered at 100 28/32 , up 3/32 from Wednesday, to yield 7.55 percent, down from 7.56 percent. Prices and yields move in opposite directions: Rising prices add to the value of bonds and notes and reduce the yields; when yields rise, the value of the security, in relation to the price paid for it, declines.
Prices of Treasury notes also rose a little, and the discount rates on Treasury bills fell a few basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
The drop of $8.6 billion in M-2, which includes currency in circulation, checking accounts, savings accounts and small certificates of deposit, was far more than the $1.9 billion in many forecasts. The decline is also another bit of information that is making it hard for traders and investors to decide how strong the economy is.
 
'An Upturn, but a Moderate One'
 "The notion has been that the economy will surprise us on the upside," said Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers. "We think we are in an upturn, but a moderate one."
While a flood of recent figures show the economy is stronger than had been thought a month or two ago, some individual reports, like the M-2 decline, have raised some doubts.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Some Ground As Mark Shows Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher against most leading currencies yesterday, strengthened by year-end demand, weakness in the powerful German mark and additional evidence that the American economy is improving.
Gold prices were off slightly. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fetched $335.50, off 40 cents from Wednesday. At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold was quoted at a late price of $335.30, off 40 cents from Wednesday. 
 Currency traders said the dollar's behavior was influenced partly by increased customer demand as 1992 draws to a close. American-based multinational companies, for example, often require large amounts of dollars in the final weeks of the year as they repatriate profits in foreign currencies.
The German mark, highly favored in global foreign exchange trading in recent months because of high German interest rates, retreated on news of rising unemployment, signaling weakness in Germany's economy. Currency dealers bought dollars instead.
Traders also said signs of a modest expansion in the American economy had helped the dollar somewhat, strengthening sentiment that domestic interest rates will rise. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated investments worth more.
Yesterday, the Government reported a rise in October factory orders, a fall in late-November weekly unemployment claims and stronger third-quarter productivity. There is some expectation that the November unemployment statistics, due out today, will also show improvement after months of persistent weakness.
The British pound defied the trend and strengthened against the dollar. Traders attributed the pound's behavior to technical influences in the market and expectations that British interest rates could start to creep up.
In London, the pound fetched $1.5675, up from $1.5480 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.5645, up from $1.5525 late Wednesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.55 yen, up 0.38 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar fetched 124.65 yen. In New York, the dollar fetched 124.65 yen, up from 124.50 yen late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Bush, Salinas and Mulroney To Sign Trade Pact Dec. 17

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3

 BODY:
President Bush will sign the North American Free Trade Agreement on Dec. 17, while President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada will sign the pact the same day in their countries, the White House announced today.
The agreement, which would eliminate trade barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States, will not take effect until legislatures in all three countries have approved it or legislation putting its provisions into law. 
 But the signing is nonetheless significant for two reasons. It will make it harder for President-elect Bill Clinton to make any changes in the agreement's text, and it insures that Congress will have to put the implementing legislation on a fast-track process, which permits no amendments.
The fast-track process that Congress authorized provides that any trade agreement signed by June 1 must be taken up by Congress on a yes-or-no basis.
Mr. Clinton and his transition team were not consulted before today's announcement, but Democrats did not seem to mind, in part because trade issues are politically touchy and addressing them exposes deep fissures within the Democratic Party over whether to open America's markets further to international competition.
Yet sentiment is growing in Congress to rein in the Administration.
The Bush Administration has engaged in a post-election flurry of trade policy initiatives. Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, threatened a trade war with the European Community two days after Mr. Bush's electoral defeat and ended up striking a broad trans-Atlantic deal two weeks ago to reduce farm subsidies.
Mr. Clinton has endorsed the North American pact, but he has promised not to sign legislation putting its provisions into law until he has negotiated three side agreements and has won Congressional passage of four other provisions to protect American workers.
The House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said in an interview two weeks ago that he did not expect Mr. Clinton even to submit the implementing legislation to Congress until after all of these issues were resolved, a process that could take months. But once the agreement has been signed, Mr. Clinton could in theory wait for years to submit it and the pact would still be covered by the fast-track rules.
Administration officials feel personal pride in the agreement and wanted it signed by their President. "We wouldn't have gone to all the trouble of negotiating it if the President were not going to sign it," a senior official grumbled.
Canadian and Mexican officials have pushed for a quick signing for their own reasons. Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada must call a general election by next November, and his Trade Minister, Michael Wilson, recently said the pact would be put to a vote of Parliament soon after its signing.
President Salinas has been pressing the President-elect to pay more attention to the pact and to push it through Congress as soon as possible. The Mexican economy depends heavily on investments by foreigners who have assumed that the pact will take effect. The Mexican stock market quivers at the slightest indication that the pact might succumb to pressures from labor unions and other opponents in the United States.
Strong governing party majorities in the Mexican Senate and the Canadian Parliament are expected to pass the agreement without difficult.
Some Democrats expect the agreement to win Congressional approval, too. But the pact's future on Capitol Hill is hard to predict, because many of the incoming Congress's 122 new members have no clear position on the agreement.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Work in Progress
There's still work to be done on the SoHo branch of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, which opened in June. A gaping hole remains on the first floor where a basement cafe is supposed to be, and the stairwells still don't have permanent lighting fixtures. Also missing are several architectural elements crucial to Arata Isozaki's design.
Indeed, the Japanese architect's plans called for an arched bridge of raw steel to cross over the cafe, an open staircase of raw steel with steel cable railings leading down to the basement, curved frosted-glass-and-steel display cases for the bookstore and gift shop, and walls of frosted glass at both ends of the second-floor galleries. The architect had also made a rough plan for the cafe itself. 
 Although there is speculation in the art world that the museum has simply run out of money, Michael Govan, the Guggenheim's deputy director, gives a different answer.
"It's not an issue of money," Mr. Govan said. "This was the fastest museum ever built. It's all been a learning curve because it's such a new space for us. We had a budget and went for the full design -- we spent every cent on such state-of-the-art equipment as climate controls for the art." So far, Mr. Govan said, the project, which included office space, has cost about $8 million, and will require $250,000 more to complete. "We don't foresee any problem in raising the money to complete the outstanding work," said Mr. Govan.
"It was critical for the museum to be finished at the same time as the uptown Guggenheim, no matter what," said David Gauld, the project architect who works for Mr. Isozaki. "After the opening we thought the museum would close for several weeks so we could finish the work. We did get two weeks between shows, but that was just enough time to finish things on the punch list. It appears the museum is stuck trying to get the funding."
 
Plans for Cafe
 It also appears that Mr. Isozaki will not design the cafe. Mr. Govan said the architect's involvement in the cafe had never been assured. "Nor was it meant to be a Guggenheim expense," said Mr. Govan. "Part of the reason the bridge and stair aren't finished was prudence: we wanted to see who the operator would be before we finished the design."
As of now, Miriam Novalle, who describes herself as "a self-taught nose, a perfumer," is to create an environmental cafe and tea emporium in the space. "I collect teapots, and I thought this would be a good idea," she said. "There's no place to go in SoHo anymore, and the museum needs the cafe and gallery owners need somewhere to go to make a deal."
Ms. Novalle is working with Paul Berman Lytle, an environmental architect based in New York who runs the firm Master Builders. Ms. Novalle said that besides food and teas, the cafe would also sell everything for the ceremony of tea, from teapots to homespun linen napkins. She said she hoped to open in April.
 
More Work Ahead
 But whether the rest of the museum will be finished by then is still not clear. Mr. Govan said the Guggenheim intended to complete the project as soon as it can clear several weeks to close the building. In addition to the missing elements from Mr. Isozaki's plan, lighting for the stairwells is being worked on by the artist Dan Flavin.
In the bookstore, 7-foot-high oak display cases have just been erected in place of the frosted-glass designs. And a 22-foot-long black steel table designed by Mr. Isozaki has been placed in the middle of the store.
Finished or not, the museum's 60,000 square feet of space has attracted a steadily growing audience since it opened in June. "We're up to about 6,000 visitors a week, which has exceeded our conservative financial projections," said Mr. Govan. "In my heart of hearts I always knew the museum would be popular."
 
In the Red and the Black
 Other news -- some good, some bad -- from SoHo this week:
On the bright side, Exit Art, the nonprofit alternative center for contemporary art, which has been at 578 Broadway for the last 10 years, is moving, expanding and changing its name. As of Dec. 12, the organization will be Exit Art/The First World and will triple its space -- to 17,000 square feet -- by moving to 548 Broadway, between Spring and Prince Streets.
"The word exit has actually become our entrance," said Jeanette Ingberman, who is the co-founder and co-director of Exit Art/The First World, with the artist Papo Colo. "We're putting together a center that we hope will be a model for the future," Ms. Ingberman said. "Our vision is to create a place where all the media can come together."
Ms. Ingberman said that she had been raising private funds to pay for the move for about a year, and that the current real estate market allowed her to lease the new space relatively inexpensively. The center will have a 5,000-square-foot gallery and will also include a cafe and the Apartment Store, a retail shop showcasing furniture and objects for the home, made by artists.
The complete expansion is planned in phases. By spring, Exit Art/The First World expects to open First World Theater, a 2,500-square-foot theater and performance space, and the Fashion Hall, a 2,000-square-foot space that would be used to explore the international influences between art and fashion. Foreign Affairs, a 5,000-square-foot exhibition gallery for events by artists from outside the United States, is to open next fall. The center is being designed by Mr. Colo as a series of open, flowing areas.
In its first exhibition, "Fever," which opens Dec. 11, the new Exit Art/The First World will show the work of 50 young artists from around the United States "There's a whole new generation out there of artists aged 22 to 35," said Ms. Ingberman. "They're the ones helping to define the future."
 
A Gallery Closing
 And now the bad news: Rubin Spangle, the two-and-a-half-year-old SoHo gallery that showed the work of Dan Flavin, Will Mentor, Carrie Smith and Michael Venezia, will close on Dec. 15. "With the economic situation being the way it is, we just couldn't go on," said Morgan Spangle, one of the owners. "We're going to take December and January off to think about how we will proceed with the business. We're not alone. There will be a lot more galleries closing, too."
 
Good Results in London
 The London auctions of Impressionist paintings, drawings and sculpture were uncannily similar to the sales of Impressionist work in New York City last month. Given the economic climate in England, which is considered to be far worse than it is in the United States, both Sotheby's and Christie's said they were pleased with the results.
"We're getting there," said David Nash, the director of the department of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's worldwide. "The London sales confirmed what we've been seeing this fall: a slow, steady improvement."
While at each house the sales brought in less money than the auction house had estimated, there were a few bright spots. At Sotheby's, the star work, Wassily Kandinsky's "Sketch I for Composition VII" (1913), sold for $8.25 million, right at Sotheby's estimate. The buyer was a European private collector who bid by telephone. Sotheby's total was $18 million, just below the house's $20.8 million low estimate. Of the 57 works up for sale, 22 remained unsold.
 
7 Cezannes at Christie's
 At Christie's, seven paintings by Cezanne, originally from the collection of Auguste Pellerin, a French industrialist and collector who bought his first Cezanne in 1895, were being sold by an unidentified European foundation. The paintings brought $15.8 million, $3 million short of Christie's pre-sale estimate. The top painting, "Man With a Pipe" from 1890-1992, sold for $5.28 million, well above Christie's estimate of $2.4 million to $3.6 million. The buyer was an anonymous telephone bidder.
While six of the Cezannes sold, the one that didn't, "Marion and Valabregue Setting Out for the Motif" from 1866 was purchased by an unidentified buyer immediately after the sale. Of the 51 works up for sale at Christie's, 20 did not find buyers. The entire auction totaled $28.3 million, under the $33 million to $46.5 million presale estimate.
"We are pleased," said James Roundell, who heads Christie's department of Impressionist and modern art in London. "Eighty percent of the works sold, which certainly shows a considerable improvement over the last two years. But we shouldn't get carried away. In this kind of a market, if you get overconfident, you can fall on your face."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cezanne's "Man With a Pipe" brought $5.28 million in London. (Christie's)
