HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:
Among the rising tide of
hotel dining rooms, a many-flavored luxury spot.
In the early 1980's, hotels in New York City and beyond caused quite a stir by revving up their sleepy dining rooms to compete with top restaurants. But when the recession hit, these hotel dining rooms sank faster than the Dow Jones industrial average, and with that the hoopla over a hotel-food renaissance ended. 
 In the last few years, however, there have been signs of another resurgence, most notably in Manhattan at places like the Essex House, the Mark, the St. Regis and the Royalton. Add the Peninsula Hotel and its luxury restaurant, Adrienne.
Adrienne's kitchen has seen more coming and going than most guest rooms in the hotel, what with ownership changes, management shuffles and cuisine shifts. The chef today is Adam Odegard, who came from the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Manhattan. Mr. Odegard has a flamboyant style, and sometimes his busy creations are the gastronomic equivalent of Penn Station at rush hour. But his sensibilities are on target, and one can fault him occasionally only for trying too hard.
The opulent Art Nouveau dining room offers plenty of privacy, deep armchairs and rose-tinted banquettes. This is the kind of comfort one rarely finds except in hotel dining rooms.
Adrienne offers a $28 prix fixe lunch that is one of the best bargains in midtown. One day it began with a rolled tower of faintly smoked salmon holding caviar accompanied by a potato-chive waffle and whipped mascarpone. The alternative starter was a superb wild mushroom risotto studded with lobster meat. For main courses there were a thick, gamey venison chop with braised red cabbage and a grilled striped bass with saffron rice holding chunks of salty chorizo. Dessert was a light but intense chocolate mousse with a sharp bittersweet chocolate lid.
Aside from the food revival there has been a marked improvement in service. Waiters are patient, informative and unremittingly polite.
Recommended starters on the regular menu include a cinnamon-perfumed pumpkin soup, crispy little won tons holding creamy goat cheese over a chicory salad, and marinated shrimp salad over green beans tossed in piquant horseradish-chili oil. One overproduced creation is barbecued chicken with a strong curry flavor, with chorizo, plantains, fried parsley, white bean chili and coriander oil. With so many flavor warheads detonating on the palate, it was impossible to tell what you were eating. At lunch one day, the risotto special was not risotto at all but tasty rice enhanced with sun-dried tomatoes, black olives and duck confit.
Adrienne's wine selection is aimed at clients who book the hotel's poshest suites, especially when it comes to Bordeaux. For more reasonable prices, look to California and the southwest of France.
Among the best entrees is grilled chicken in a bright fennel emulsion along with a potato-eggplant roulade. Grilled duck in a soy glaze with stir-fried vegetables and crispy lotus chips had a nice textural contrast, but the soy sauce on the plate left everything incredibly salty. Tuna is prepared in an interesting way, wrapped in rice paper, garnished with fried julienne of leeks and combined with sauteed foie gras and snow peas with a mild peppercorn sauce. Halibut steak with couscous and a fennel-chervil emulsion was a nice concept, spoiled only by fish that had an ammonia smell. (A week later, this dish was excellent.) An ungainly hunk of dried-out swordfish could not be rescued by a pleasing sweet corn sauce.
Among meat dishes, tender and succulent loin of beef is delightful in natural juices sweetened with port, along with caramelized winter vegetables. Roasted loin of veal is pleasing, too, with leeks, salsify and the same sweet corn broth that was paired with the swordfish.
Hotels have a thing about dessert trolleys, and this multi-decker hauls around plenty to entice the most abstemious. Sharp, cleansing lime tart is one of the lighter ways to go, as is the ripe pear tart. Moving up the caloric scale there is a smooth timbal-shaped banana mousse and a superb pumpkin pie. What is called peach clafouti is really more like a tart, but it is good nonetheless.
The serious efforts at Adrienne underscore the second hotel food renaissance in a decade. For those who appreciate comfort and creativity, it's worth a visit.

Adrienne
**
Peninsula Hotel, 700 Fifth Avenue, at 55th Street, (212) 903-3918.

Wine: High-priced Bordeaux and Burgundies; better deals among California and southwestern French producers.

HEADLINE: Look to the Grassroots in Aiding Russia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I have just returned from a year in Moscow as consultant for a banking start up, and read with great interest the views of former Ambassador Robert S. Strauss ("More U.S. Support for Russia," Op-Ed, Nov. 15). 
 Mr. Strauss argues that a weak Russia is not in the cards and that our support can help determine whether a strong Russia emerges as an open democratic state or a limited authoritarian society. I would add that the nature of the support we provide will critically determine both the effectiveness of the assistance program and the likelihood of success in achieving meaningful market and political reforms in Russia.
As Mr. Strauss appreciates, and I have no reason to doubt, President Boris N. Yeltsin seems to harbor a commitment to open, maybe even radical, change. Many Russians would like to try something new and less heinous than the politics and economics of the Communist past.
But my experience tells me that this is not enough. There is a whole layer of entrenched bureaucracy and self-interest that has woven itself into all aspects of Russian life. It is this network and access to it that determines a person's standing in Russian society. And it is this network that stands in the way of real progress.
In providing support to Russia, we would make a mistake in equating a strong Russia with a strengthening of its current institutions and practices. The trap would be to look only at the top -- the commitment of all or part of the Yeltsin cabinet team -- and ignore the realities just below the surface. To do so would not only reinforce a Russian penchant for elitist leadership that has plagued the country through the centuries, but would certainly undermine the chances for success as aid is diverted at the center from its intended targets.
So, while I agree to a strong Yeltsin presidency to guide and safeguard reform through this unstable transition period, I nonetheless strongly urge that we choose the more difficult route of a grassroots effort for our support. While in Russia I secured a technical assistance grant for my Russian client from the European Commission, the executive agency of the European Community. The disbursement is handled by a third party to help guarantee its desired application, and the grant supports the creation of local skills and new practices. This orientation strikes me as particularly productive.
We must resist the elitist and expedient temptation to focus on personalities and instead aim our support at lasting institutional and institutionalized change. In this way, U.S. support for reform in Russia can truly be in our and even the Russian people's self-interest.
 
GEORGE DERBY
Northport, L.I., Nov. 20, 1992

HEADLINE: Violence on the Job Is a Growing Threat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Social Workers: Targets in a Violent Society" (front page, Nov. 18) and "Wires, Meters, Phones and Fears" (news article, Nov. 22) shine some light on a serious and growing problem in New York City and nationwide: violence on the job. 
 It is true many social workers and utility workers face the risk of assault every day, but they are not alone. Violence on the job is a daily threat for a wide range of workers, including teachers, hospital workers, bus drivers, maintenance workers and anyone who works alone.
New York City Department of Health records show 128 homicides on the job in 1991 -- skyrocketing from 47 in 1989 and 84 in 1990. In 1991, 74 victims were store owners or retail employees, and 23 were cabdrivers. Workers in jobs that call for handling of money or providing of security are at the greatest risk of violence.
Preventing workplace assaults and homicides is a complex task. Unemployment, poverty and racism create an environment in which violence can thrive. As an important first step, unions across the country have been calling for adequate staffing and safety training in high-risk jobs. Now is the time for employers to heed that call: it can be a matter of life and death.
 
JIM YOUNG
Public Affairs Dir., New York
Committee for Occupational
Safety and Health (Nycosh)
New York, Nov. 24, 1992

HEADLINE: G.M. TO SHUT DOWN 7 PARTS FACTORIES IN STRATEGY SHIFT

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 3

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation identified nine plants today that it will close in the next three and a half years, including seven plants that make parts.
The announcement makes clear that the giant auto maker's strategy for becoming a leaner company involves increasing its reliance on parts purchased from outside suppliers. 
 The nine plants are in Flint, Kalamazoo and Livonia, Mich.; Syracuse; Ewing, N.J.; Wilmington, Del.; Euclid, Ohio; Sioux City, Iowa, and St. Catharines, Ontario. With their closing, 18,000 jobs will be lost.
 
Plants Can't Compete
 Automotive analysts have long maintained that many G.M. parts operations are uncompetitive, a significant reason for the company's financial woes. In some cases, the productivity of G.M. parts plants is not as high as that of competitors; in some cases, G.M. cannot compete with foreign factories or with suppliers who operate nonunion plants in the United States.
But the company has historically been committed to and proud of the extent to which it makes its own parts, a strategy known as vertical integration.
Before low-cost Japanese production made auto making so competitive, the company's vast parts-making operations were a big advantage: G.M. could profit at several levels of production, and outside suppliers could not hold it hostage to price increases.
 
Makes 70% of Its Parts
 But as cost control became more important, the company found itself locked into its own subsidiaries while competitors combed the world for lower prices.
 Auto industry experts estimate that G.M. makes at least 70 percent of its parts, far more than the Chrysler Corporation or the Ford Motor Company.
 The new strategy reflects the vision of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the company's vice president for worldwide purchasing, as well as that of its chief executive for the last six weeks, John F. Smith Jr.
G.M., which has lost $5.4 billion in the last seven quarters, said last year that it would close 21 plants and eliminate 74,000 jobs. With today's announcement, those totals have been revised to 23 plants and 80,000 jobs. The company said it had no plans at this time to close additional factories.
Detroit and scores of G.M. factory towns around the nation were braced for the announcements, which Mr. Smith had promised would be announced by the end of the year. For the last year many workers have lived in the executioner's shadow, knowing more plants were to close but not knowing their identity.
"The economic realities of the global marketplace dictate that we have too much capacity versus market demand," Mr. Smith said today. "To address that situation we are implementing fundamental changes and a restructuring to enable us to sustain profitability through all phases of the economic cycle."
 
Cadillac Offices to Close
 Although the city of Detroit was spared the closing of its only remaining G.M. final-assembly plant, which makes Cadillacs, the company said it would close the headquarters of its Cadillac division and transfer 1,125 workers to offices in Flint and Warren, Mich.
The closings announced today bear witness to the activism of G.M.'s outside directors, who are not employees of the company. Their frustration over the company's losses and glacial pace of change led to the resignation of Robert C. Stempel as chairman and chief executive on Oct. 26. Mr. Smith became chief executive and John G. Smale, the former head of the Procter & Gamble Company, the chairman.
G.M. said it believed that the more aggressive tactics would help it reach its goal of reducing production capacity in North America by about 25 percent, to 5.4 million vehicles annually, by 1995. But some experts on the industry quickly said that the closings announced today were simply not enough to stanch the company's losses.
Clifford Swenson, manager of production forecasting for Jacobs Automotive, a consulting firm in Little Falls, N.J., said today's announcements "don't go nearly far enough" toward balancing output with demand. "It appears G.M. has backed away significantly from the promises it made last December" to close six final-assembly plants, he said.
 
Fewer Assembly Plants to Close
 Of the nine plants identified today, two are final-assembly operations. The Wilmington factory produces the Chevrolet Corsica and Beretta, both compact cars; the Flint plant makes full-size vans. The 23 plants scheduled for closing include 4 final-assembly plants.
William O'Neill, a G.M. spokesman, said the company was able to reach its capacity goal by closing only four final assembly plants instead of six, as contemplated last year.
A company spokesman declined to say whether the auto maker would build the Corsica and Beretta beyond 1996, when the Wilmington plant is scheduled to close. A new full-size G.M. van model is set to be produced in 1995. The production site has not been decided, G.M. said.
Investors seemed unmoved by the announced changes. G.M. shares closed unchanged, at $32.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The United Automobile Workers union, whose top officials say they are more encouraged by Mr. Smith's management than the administrations of his predecessors, denounced the cutbacks, though in an unusually restrained tone.
"We hope that G.M.'s new leadership will grasp the opportunity to redirect their efforts so that these closings and disruptions will stop once and for all," the union said in a statement.
Five of the nine plants set for closing belong to G.M.'s Automotive Components Group, whose 200,000 workers worldwide produce about $25 billion worth of automotive parts and components, the vast majority for G.M. vehicles. G.M. said that in the future it would narrow its parts operations to seven broad areas: batteries and related accessories; ignitions, catalytic converters and related equipment; lighting; interior accessories like seats, air bags, armrests and such; suspension and steering systems; electrical and wiring systems, and heating, air-conditioning and radiators.
In other areas -- bearings, axles, bumpers and horns, for example -- the company said it might form partnerships with other manufacturers, sell the businesses or close them.
"Disposition of these businesses will be managed over time to reduce the impact on our employes and our customer base," said J. T. Battenberg 3d, the G.M. vice president and group executive in charge of parts and components.
In an effort to soften the blow to Detroit by closing the Cadillac headquarters, John O. Grettenberger, Cadillac's general manager, announced that a second production shift, of about 1,000 hourly workers, would be added next year at the Detroit-Hamtramck final-assembly plant, which will build a variety of Cadillac models.
The economically beleaguered city learned this week it was out of the running for a Department of Defense regional finance center, which would have employed 1,000 workers.
"Cadillac's rich history and longstanding relationship with the city of Detroit will continue," Mr. Grettenberger said.

HEADLINE: Europe's Champagne Goes Flat

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Europe's climate has soured in a dramatic reversal of the celebrations at the start of 1992, when the West was forging to a new union, Germany was enthusiastically putting itself together and the liberated East was hailing democracy and the market. Now the mood is worse than glum, full of bewildered anger and dire warnings that, I hope, are as exaggerated as 1991's euphoria.
Economic pressures, political mismanagement and the nasty resurgence of old demons are provoking fears of a relapse into nightmares Europe thought it had left behind. The summit meeting in Edinburgh on Dec. 11-12 threatens more of a confrontation than the resolution of issues it was meant to solve. 
 The eruptions -- an assortment of grievances -- are separate, but they form the heart of the troubles. It is all worrisome because others think the myriad problems have been sparked by "unification as a ball and chain dragging down Germany and all Europe with it," as Le Monde put it.
Right-wing violence and threats of violence seem contagious. Vicious attacks on foreigners in Germany are attracting the most attention. For the first time since Spain's democratic rebirth, swastikas have appeared on walls in Madrid. The tolerant Netherlands is complaining about migrants and refugees. The far-right populist Jorg Haider is stirring venom in Austria with his demand for a referendum against foreigners.
The extremists haven't been so noisily noticeable in France, mainly because furious farmers have taken the limelight with the demand that their subsidies be maintained. The French Government, almost certainly doomed to defeat in March elections, is caught between threats of a national upheaval over the farm issue or a crisis with its European partners if it vetoes world trade agreement.
This is more than the oilseed versus French wine export question that nearly provoked an trade war until a compromise was reached. There is general agreement that a world trade pact would help lift everybody's economy out of recession, and France is isolated in insisting that it can't be at the expense of its farmers. Still, there is a sense here that small farms are crucial to the quality, the very identity, of France. The British feel the same about their coal miners. It doesn't help to remind people that Europe gained by sharply cutting back its ship-building and steel industries when they were outpaced by the shifting world economy.
There is more awareness in Europe than in America of the disasters looming in the East as it grapples with acute problems. Rather than spurring an energetic response to help, this aggravates fears of competition and floods of refugees, and intensifies calls for defense of strictly national interests.
Germany's partners feel that the huge cost of German unification and the method of financing it by borrowing instead of taxes, which keeps German interest rates high, in effect makes them pay an unfair share of the burden: their money is devalued or may have to be, and they can't recharge their economies. European union, proclaimed by the Maastricht treaty, is in doubt.
Meanwhile, the ravaging war goes on in the former Yugoslavia and threatens to spread through the Balkans, perhaps Central Europe.
To the public, governments look impotent, merely self-serving. This doesn't have to be. We are seeing the reaction to the end of an era -- the cold war and its mobilizing assumptions -- and a failure to move quickly enough to build new hopes. The solutions -- cooperation and renewal -- are known and proved, and the institutions to carry them out exist. There is even good will. But there isn't courageous leadership. The result is dangerous entropy, which, to be reversed, requires new energy.

LENGTH: 1453 words

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Dips to 7.2% for Month on Jump in Hiring

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Solid confirmation of a perked-up economy emerged today as the Labor Department reported a rise in jobs and a two-tenths of a point decline, to 7.2 percent, in the November unemployment rate.
Unlike earlier improvements that have edged the jobless rate steadily downward from 7.8 percent in June, the latest included diverse gains in jobs, including factory employment, and did not result from a shrinking labor force. As a result, 9.2 million people are now out of work, nearly 800,000 fewer than in June. 
 Some private economists said the figures, which were better than most expected, meant that moderate expansion had replaced weak recovery.
 
 
Less Risk of a Relapse
 "There is some momentum building," said Alan Gayle, chief economist for Crestar Bank in Richmond. "The risk of any kind of backsliding is fairly minimal."
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which have been hit much harder by the recession than the country as a whole, the local economies appear to be have bottomed out. In New York State, unemployment fell to 8 percent, from 8.7 percent in October; in New York City to 10.5 percent from 11 percent. But in New Jersey, unemployment rose to 8.7 percent, from 8.1 percent in October and 7.1 percent in November of last year. Data for Connecticut were not released this week. [Page 47.]
"Some of the darkest clouds over the tristate economy are breaking up and moving on," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "But it is much too soon to throw your hat up in the air." He said the recovery in jobs could be slow and uneven.
In California, unemployment rose to 10.1 percent, the highest rate among the large industrial states, from 9.8 percent in October and 7.3 percent a year earlier. In Illinois, the rate rose to 6.2 percent from 5.5 percent, while in Ohio it rose to 7.4 percent from 7.2. But Michigan's rate fell to 7.9 percent from 8.6.
The November unemployment report, the first comprehensive measure of the economy's performance for the month, was quickly interpreted as a likely brake on the stimulus package being prepared by President-elect Bill Clinton. That notion reassured investors worried about inflation, producing a small rise in long-term bond prices and a corresponding drop in interest rates.
 
Figures Are 'Quite Nice'
 Alan Blinder, an economics professor at Princeton University and an informal adviser to Mr. Clinton, said: "The last four to six weeks of data have been quite nice. My guess is, if we get another six weeks of improving data like the last six weeks, the whole idea of fiscal stimulus" -- that is, spurring the economy through increased deficit spending -- "will be stillborn."
In Little Rock, Ark., George Stephanopoulos, the spokesman for the President-elect, called the jobs report "good news." He added, "One of the more encouraging signs is that actually more jobs were created" and pledged that the Clinton team would continue to watch the job market "very closely."
His tone was noticeably different from the grudging approach to post-election economic reports that the Clinton team took until now.
 
Response of Bush Adviser
 The Bush Administration adopted a largely hands-off approach to the economy, hoping a recovery to the prolonged slump would appear before the election. During the campaign, President Bush pointed to six straight quarters of economic growth, but the turnaround seemed too weak then to overcome the public's restiveness over lackluster job and income growth.
Michael J. Boskin, the President's top economic adviser, said the data "provide further evidence of continuing improvement in the economy." It is particularly encouraging, he said, that "the good news is spreading to the labor market."
Assuming that the employment gains are sustained, he added, "this would be the final piece in the puzzle of a more normal, self-reinforcing expansion."
 Economists were encouraged not only by the job gains -- 105,000 for nonfarm payrolls and 420,000 as gauged by the department's survey of households -- but by the fact that people worked longer hours. In addition, a third of the payroll increase took place in factories.
 The unexpected increase of 35,000 factory jobs followed declines totaling 205,000 in the preceding three months, with gains widespread among industries producing both durable and nondurable goods.
The labor-market report was not, however, without sober elements. Retailing jobs, for example, rose by less than they usually do in November, resulting in a 46,000 decline after seasonal adjustment. And construction jobs fell 11,000, reversing a small October rise and leaving the number of construction jobs virtually unchanged over the last year.
Analysts also noted that 45,000 of the 105,000 additional payroll jobs last month reflected only the very brief employment at polling places on Election Day.
"There are still a number of things troubling the economy," observed William C. Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, citing in particular a lag in income growth and a deterioration in the nation's recently thriving export sector, now that the economies of various large trading partners are in decline. He estimated that if the Clinton team came forward with a stimulus package, it might involve $25 billion, half of what was once discussed.
The average workweek in the private sector rose 12 minutes, to 34.7 hours, the highest in more than five years; the average includes part-time jobs. The workweek in factories, meanwhile, also expanded 12 minutes to match its highest reading since 1966. Long hours are often seen as a precursor to new hiring as employers exhaust their ability to handle increasing amounts of business with the existing work force.
The combination of more workers and longer workweeks drove the index of aggregate hours to 122.2, from 121.4 in October, indicating a sizable increase in industrial output for the month.
Yet another favorable sign in today's report was upward revisions in the payroll numbers for September and October, the former turning a 72,000 decline into a 12,000 advance.
"The economy looks stronger across the board," said Norman Robertson, chief economist for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "It's not really in much need of a shot in the arm."
 
Adds to Positive News
 Today's figures follow a string of recent positive economic statistics. Those included falling first-time claims for jobless benefits and a report on gross domestic product for the third quarter that raised the growth rate to 3.9 percent from a 2.7 percent rate that itself had been higher than analysts expected.
According to the Labor Department's household survey, the labor force expanded by 279,000 last month after losses totaling 600,000 from June to October. This combined with the biggest job gain in 14 months to cut the ranks of the unemployed by 141,000.
Although two-thirds of the November job gains were accounted for by adult women, a large number of women also entered the labor force; their unemployment rate remained at 6.1 percent.
The volatile teen-age jobless rate jumped 1.9 points to 20.2 percent, but remained under the September level.
But the jobless rate for adult men showed substantial improvement. It tumbled four-tenths of a point to 6.8 percent as fewer men sought work while jobs grew moderately.
Geographically, the department also reported, the jobless rate eased a tenth of a point in each of three regions: the Northeast, to 8 percent; in the South, to 6.8 percent, and in the Midwest, to 5.9 percent. The rate in the West climbed a tenth of a point, to 8.7 percent.
The report also indicated some lessening of unemployment-related hardship, with jobless spells of more than six months dropping by 170,000, the first significant decline since mid-1989. This helped push the average duration of joblessness down to 18.2 weeks, the level prevailing for most of the summer, from 19.4 weeks in October.
 
Gains Among Self-Employed
 And the number of people who lost their last job -- as opposed to those who quit or were entering or re-entering the labor force -- tumbled by 435,000.
Just over half of the rise in employment under the household survey occurred among the self-employed. That gain more than made up for a sharp decline in October.
Average hourly earnings for private production workers advanced six-tenths of a percent last month, with weekly earnings up a hefty 1.1 percent, an indication of improved spending power.
The payroll report found that the proportion of manufacturing industries adding workers soared to 56.5 percent in November, the highest level since April, from 37.1 percent in October.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 Solid confirmation of a perked-up economy emerged as the Labor Department reported an increase in jobs and a two-tenths of a point decline, to 7.2 percent, in the November unemployment rate. Unlike earlier improvements that have edged the jobless rate steadily downward from a peak of 7.8 percent in June, the latest included diverse gains in jobs, including factory jobs, and did not result from a shrinking labor force. Some economists said the figures meant that moderate expansion had replaced weak recovery. [Page 1.] The economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut appear to be bottoming out. [47.]
Senator Lloyd Bentsen has emerged as the top choice to be Treasury Secretary, Clinton campaign officials confirmed. [1.] 
 Democratic tax writers promised retroactivity to Dec. 3 for any tax credits adopted next year for business expenditures. [35.]
A Federal appeals court overturned a bitterly contested plan to compensate tens of thousands of workers who claim they were injured by asbestos products produced by Johns-Manville. [35.]
 
Companies
 Du Pont halted payments to farmers and said new data showed that its chemical Benlate did not cause crop damage. [1.]
A former G.E. employee was awarded $13.4 million by a Federal judge for bringing forward evidence that the company defrauded the U.S. [35.]
Carteret Savings Bank was placed in receivership by Federal regulators. It is New Jersey's largest savings and loan. [37.]
Macy's lawyers, accountants and advisers piled up bills of $5.7 million -- about $62,000 a day -- in June, July and August. [35.]
PNC Financial agreed to acquire Ohio Bancorp in an exchange of stock worth about $250 million. [37.]
The Zenith Electronics-A.T.& T. partnership suffered a setback when a Federal advisory committee decided not to conduct any more high-definition television tests for now. [37.]
Hawaiian Insurance Group will leave the insurance business, battered by claims from Hurricane Iniki. [37.]
The New York Times said seasonal advertising was far below last year's figures and operating earnings would be lower. [37.]
Hoffmann-La Roche announced the retirement of Irwin Lerner, president and chief executive for 12 years. [37.]
 
 Markets
 Treasury bond prices climbed and rates fell as economic news raised hopes that the Clinton Administration would scale back plans to spend money on economy-boosting programs. [42.]
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.15, to 3,288.68, ending a three-day losing streak. For the week, the Dow was up 6.48.[36.]
Crude oil for delivery in January fell to its lowest level since March. [44.] The dollar rose against other major currencies. [44.]
 
 International
Ford's chairman complained that Japanese auto makers may not fulfill their promises to buy more American parts. [35.]
Kuwait's Grupo Torras filed for insolvency protection in Madrid, suspending payments on more than $2.9 billion in debt. [47.]
 
Your Money
 Home-equity loans continue to grow in popularity, largely because of their flexibility and continued deductibility. [33.]
Brokerage account statements are important to your financial health. Ignore them at your peril. Susan Antilla: Investing. [33.]
The new Turbotax Personal Tax Planner should bring a smile to the face of any aficionado of computer or video games. The payoff: triumph over the tax man. Jan M. Rosen: Taxes. [34.]

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
An End Date for the Other Transition

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. Dec. 4

 BODY:
Arkansans who have been waiting for weeks to hear what would happen when Bill Clinton resigns as Governor -- some in an almost ungracious state of anticipation -- received mixed news today.
President-elect Clinton, it seems, will be leaving office by Dec. 14. And his successor, Lieut. Gov. Jim Guy Tucker, announced today that as his first official act as Governor he would probably try to raise taxes. 
 The State Supreme Court settled the last of a dispute over the succession of Governor, ruling that Mr. Tucker could indeed take over the job he has essentially been working at for nearly a year without holding a special election.
Mr. Clinton had been purposely vague about when he would resign his state job. He continues to live and conduct most of his Presidential transition business from the Governor's Mansion, where he will remain until he leaves for Washington. But he has been to the State House only three times since the Nov. 3 election.
On Thursday, The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette bluntly told Mr. Clinton in an editorial that his welcome had run out.
"What's the difference between a boor and a governor?" the lead editorial read. "A boor leaves without saying goodbye. A governor says goodbye without leaving. Alas, the difference between the two seems to be diminishing every day Bill Clinton insists on hanging around."
Today, Mr. Clinton's aides said the Governor would resign before the State Legislature holds a special four-day session to grapple with a Medicaid crisis.
As it happens, that will be just in time to allow Mr. Tucker to deliver the bad news. He said today that he would ask the Legislature to approve taxes on cigarettes, legal and medical expenses and soft drinks to raise $164 million in revenues to balance the state budget.
But even with that load to bear, Mr. Tucker seemed pleased and relieved that his future is now official. The court decision, he said, settled "the question of exactly what I was." He added, "Was I Lieutenant Governor or acting Governor or sort of Governor or some sort of funny three-legged animal?"
Mr. Tucker plans to begin lobbying on behalf of his tax package in a manner that would probably make Mr. Clinton, who must journey to Capitol Hill again on Monday, envious. On Saturday, Mr. Tucker plans to attend a frog leg lunch with members of the State Senate.
 
Binge on Economic Policy
 First it was an economic conference, then a retreat, then an audit. Now it is beginning to look like a huge round-table economic policy binge for a few hundred of Mr. Clinton's closest friends and advisers.
"Originally it was supposed to be a couple of dozen people," said one transition official. "Now it's a convention."
Mr. Clinton's intention to hold the high-profile meeting has attracted network news broadcasters and dozens more journalists to Little Rock to join the news-starved reporters who have been encamped here for weeks. His absence from the public eye has fueled much of the anticipation. And the endless speculation generated by economists and ad hoc crystal-ball gazers in Washington and elsewhere have elevated the meeting, scheduled for Dec. 14 and 15, to must-attend status.
Gene Sperling, one of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers, said the meeting would be a sort of public airing of concerns.
"It will be valuable for him in the same way that it is for a judge to hear oral arguments, even after he has seen the briefs," he said.
Questions about the meeting recur at each day's transition news briefing. Do favorable economic statistics mean Mr. Clinton will scale back his plans to address the deficit? Does Mr. Clinton plan to abandon the middle-class tax cut proposal he scaled back once already during the campaign? Will the list of invitees provide a clue to the makeup of Mr. Clinton's Administration?
But some of Mr. Clinton's closest advisers have warned reporters to expect little in the way of concrete proposals from the meeting. In fact, they will all but admit that they are mostly seeking images -- television pictures of Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore appearing to address economic issues.
This has not dimmed the interest of the reporters or of the prospective participants.
"Requests for invitations are flying all over here," said one transition official. "There is this optimism about the economy and everybody wants to put their 2 cents in."
 
Official Clinton Copier?
 There is cashing in and then there is cashing in.
David Leopoulos, who spent much of his time this year working on behalf of his childhood friend, the President-elect, is appearing on television commercials here on behalf of his business rental company, boasting that he rented the copy machines for the Clinton-Gore campaign headquarters based here.
Wearing a suit and sitting on the edge of a desk, Mr. Leopoulos, identified on screen by his middle name, Paul, chats about the virtues of renting copy machines from his company. A bright red, white and blue Clinton-Gore campaign sign is propped nearby.
During the campaign, Mr. Leopoulos spoke frequently on behalf of Mr. Clinton. Today, however, he could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
Crossing a Line, and Redrawing It

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4

 BODY:
The decision to intervene in Somalia marks a turning point in American foreign policy: for the first time American troops are entering a country uninvited, not to shore up an anti-Communist regime, protect American wealth or stifle a strategic threat, but simply to feed starving people.
President Bush, with the enthusiastic backing of President-elect Clinton, has crossed a red line. 
 He has said in effect that because the United States is now the world's only remaining superpower it cannot ignore responsibility for grave humanitarian crises in which American actions, and only American actions, could well mean the difference between life and death for hundreds of thousands of people. Even though the United States has no military, economic or political interests at stake in such crises, it must respond anyway, he said.
The problem is that if halting starvation or upholding human rights are now legitimate criteria for American intervention abroad, as compelling as protecting traditional strategic interests, where does President-elect Clinton draw the new red line? How much starvation is necessary, or how bad does the human-rights situation have to become, to justify American action? If Somalia, why not Bosnia, and if Bosnia, why not Kurdistan, and if Kurdistan, why not Haiti?
The question has particular poignancy for Mr. Clinton, who entered politics as a student leader fighting against the old rationale for military intervention in Vietnam and now must fashion a new rationale as the opening act of his Presidency.
In an era when America is facing no overwhelming strategic threats from abroad, and when it can afford to let its ideals increasingly govern its foreign policy, it will become critical for the Clinton Administration to explain not only where it chooses to intervene, but also where it chooses not to intervene. Otherwise, every area of the world will come clamoring for help.
 
Interests and Principles
 "The challenge for the Clinton Presidency will be twofold," said Michael J. Sandel, a political theorist at Harvard University. "On the one hand, he will have to articulate clearly the principles on behalf of which we may need to intervene -- whether it is upholding human rights, averting starvation or promoting democracy."
But on the other hand, said Mr. Sandel, those principles will have to be tempered by some sober practical considerations about where Washington can be effective at a cost that is tolerable to the American public.
"Clinton will have to be honest with the American people about both the principles justifying intervention and the practical considerations that might restrain such action," Mr. Sandel said. "Otherwise he will seem inconsistent and hypocritical and ultimately undermine the domestic consensus for intervention."
During his tenure, Mr. Bush tried to make those distinctions with his deeds instead of his words. First he intervened to rescue Kuwait, after an invasion by Iraq, which marked the first time since the Korean War that American troops led a coalition abroad to uphold the United Nations Charter and the principle of the sanctity of international borders.
That step forward, though, was made easier by the fact that behind the diplomatic principles at stake in the Persian Gulf were also the hardcore American interests in oil flows and strategic concerns about Iraq's growing arsenal.
Intervening in Somalia, though, goes one step further. In effect, Mr. Bush, through his actions in Iraq and Somalia, has now defined his vision of the boundaries of American post-cold-war intervention.
 
Necessity of U.S. Action
 There are the cases, Iraq for example, where principles and major strategic interests are at stake, which virtually demand that Washington organize an international coalition to respond. And there are the cases, Somalia for example, where there are principles and no strategic interests at stake -- or real opposition forces on the ground -- which make it relatively easy for Washington to organize an international coalition to respond.
The struggle comes in dealing with problems that fall in between the poles of Iraq and Somalia. In Bosnia, for example, there are just enough strategic interests and human rights at stake to draw world attention and invite action. But there are too many armed forces on the ground to make such an intervention easy and the strategic interest at stake for the United States is not major but rather limited, and thus cannot justify the potential costs in American lives.
Mr. Bush came about as close as he ever will to detailing the new rationale for American foreign policy when he said today: "In taking this action, I want to emphasize that I understand the United States alone cannot right the world's wrongs, but we also know that some crises in the world cannot be resolved without American involvement, that American action is often necessary as a catalyst for broader involvement of the community of nations."
Mr. Clinton has so far preferred to avoid any detailed description of his own vision. Today he had his spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, read a short statement in which he underscored his support for "President Bush's decision." When Mr. Stephanopoulos was asked later about whether that was a harbinger of the Clinton foreign policy, he said: "Well, I don't know if I can comment on that kind of a hypothetical. But at the moment, Governor Clinton supports this operation."
Clinton aides say privately that they are increasingly aware that while Mr. Bush is making the tough decision to go in, it is Mr. Clinton who will be saddled with the even tougher decision of how to get out. And they are growing worried about how it could divert Mr. Clinton from his campaign vow to remain focused like a "laser beam" on the economy.
They should be. Harry Truman first described the American intervention in Korea as a "police action." His successor, Dwight D. Eisenhower, found it to be something rather larger.
And even if Mr. Clinton finds he can withdraw the American troops from Somalia early in his term, as Mr. Bush suggested, that may not be the end of the story.
Ronald Reagan could attest to that. On Aug. 25, 1982, Mr. Reagan dispatched 800 Marines to Beirut to ease the withdrawal of Palestinian guerrillas in the wake of the Israeli invasion. He promised that they would only stay for a maximum of 30 days. So anxious was Mr. Reagan to get the American troops out that he withdrew them two weeks before the 30-day deadline, as soon as the guerrillas had gone.
Four days later, Christian militiamen stepped into the vacuum and massacred hundreds of Palestinians at the Sabra and Shatila refugee districts.
Two days after that, the Reagan Administration, racked with guilt for having pulled American troops out too early, ordered them back without any preparation or strategic rationale. Only after 241 American servicemen were blown up in a suicide-bombing 17 months later were the forces finally withdrawn.
But the lesson remained: that in accepting leadership for an international relief effort, whether in Lebanon or Somalia, the world's only superpower may assume a moral obligation for events that lasts well beyond the withdrawal of American forces.

HEADLINE: Data on Region's Economy Improve

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
The economies of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which have been hit much harder by the recession than the country as a whole, appear to be at or near the bottom, according to employment data released yesterday and Thursday.
"Some of the darkest clouds over the tristate economy are breaking up," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York-based regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "But it is much too soon to throw your hat up in the air." 
 New York State's unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 8 percent in November from 8.7 percent in October, the bureau reported. New York City's unadjusted rate fell to 10.5 percent from 11 percent. They were the lowest since May. A year ago the respective rates for the state and city were 7.9 and 10.2 percent.
In New Jersey, the unemployment rate rose to 8.7 percent in November from 8.1 percent in October and 7.1 percent a year ago. But for five months before October, the rate was 9 percent or more.
November data for Connecticut have not been released. But the state Department of Labor said Thursday that the adjusted unemployment rate dropped to 6.9 percent in October from 7.2 percent in September.
Manufacturing accounts for a fifth of Connecticut's jobs. With a large portion of them in the shrinking military industry, economists say unemployment could rise again. "Maybe Connecticut's economy has bottomed out in total, but I still wouldn't break out the champagne quite yet," said Anthony J. Ferrara, the New England regional commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Economists also cited other data as evidence that recession is bottoming out in the region.
Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said the signs in metropolitan New York include strong Wall Street profits and rises in home sales, air travel and the leasing of midtown Manhattan offices. "We're still awaiting signs of strong job growth," she said, "but we get a sense the worst is probably over."
In New York State's private sector, the seasonally adjusted number of jobs increased by 5,500 in October, reaching 6,266,000. While the increase was tiny, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, "it is the first time since April we have seen anything positive."
Because of a drop in government jobs, total jobs in New York rose by 3,000, to 7,689,000. That was 585,000 below the peak in June 1989.
The rise in New Jersey's unemployment rate broke a three-month string of declines. But that survey examines employment of the state's residents, regardless of whether they commute to another state. The number of jobs in New Jersey actually grew by 15,000 in October, to 3,394,000. The last rise was in January. While government jobs fell by 3,000, private-sector jobs rose by 18,000. The job total was 316,000 below the peak in February 1989.
"We have seen some firming up in some industries in New Jersey," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
In Connecticut, the seasonally adjusted number of jobs rose by 500 in October, to 1,492,000, or 195,000 below the peak of February 1989. Other encouraging signs in Connecticut include a drop in initial unemployment-compensation claims, stabilizing employment in banking and increases in personal income, car sales and building permits for homes, said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at Shawmut National Corporation.

HEADLINE: The Silence the Students Left Behind;
In Bridgeport, a University's Decline Has a Ripple Effect

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 4

 BODY:
On a gray overcast day, Kitty Davis sat on her front porch smoking a cigarette and staring sadly at the University of Bridgeport campus, recalling what her South End neighborhood was like just a few years ago.
"There were students everywhere," she said. "It was a bustling, exciting neighborhood filled with student houses and all the sights and sounds of an active college community." 
 But the university's troubles have changed everything. Enrollment has dropped from 9,000 in the early 1970's, when Ms. Davis moved into her home on Broad Street, to below 1,500, and many of the bars, restaurants and grocery stores that once catered to students are gone. Illegal drugs have become the community's biggest business.
"You see that empty yellow building over there, the one with the broken windows?" said Ms. Davis, pointing to the eight-story brick structure surrounded by a small barbed-wire fence. "It was a dormitory called Bodine Hall and it was once filled with the sounds of students laughing, partying and playing music, sometimes until after midnight. The parking lot was always filled with cars."
But that was when the university was at its peak, with more than half a dozen thriving colleges, before the recession started chipping away at enrollment and the university's financial base. It was before a bitter two-year faculty strike began in 1990, the longest ever in American higher education, that resulted in the hiring of nonunion professors and drove even more students away.
It was also before the university's board decided in April that the only way to keep the 65-year-old school open was to turn over control to the Professors World Peace Academy, founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, in exchange for $50.5 million over five years.
University officials say there are now 1,400 enrolled students and they say enrollment will rise by next fall. Students on campus are skeptical, however, and say they believe enrollment is closer to 400.
"I can't wait to get out of here, it's got to be the most depressing campus in the country," said Lee Henderson, a 22-year-old senior majoring in graphic design, who expects to graduate in May. "When I started here four years ago it was great. There were big parties with hundreds of students. This year, I threw a Halloween party and 10 people showed up."
"The campus is just dead," said Paul Henrique, a student at the law school, which last year broke away from the university and affiliated with Quinnipiac College in Hamden. He said that the library is virtually empty, except for law students. "To tell you the truth," Mr. Henrique said, "the only students I ever see on campus are in the law school. There's pretty much nobody else left."
The enrollment decline has hurt the business community too. "It's a disaster, that's the only way to describe it," said Jose Mota, a hot dog vendor who operates the J.M. Wagon on Park Avenue, in the middle of the campus. "Business is down 75 percent from two years ago and I don't see how I can stay open much longer."
Many other business owners say they don't know how much longer they can survive. Although they are concerned about the affiliation with the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's group, they say they will accept anything that will save the university.
 
'A Little Leery'
 "I'm a little leery about it, but this is better than seeing the university just die, which is what would happen to me if the school closes down," said Ernest A. Ursini, who owns a liquor store and My Mother's Place and Deli on Park Avenue, a block from the campus.
Some merchants, however, were forced to give up a long time ago.
Ved Mehta, the former owner of the Austin Street Cafe, said business was booming when he bought the restaurant in 1988. Just five blocks from campus, the bar was frequently filled with students and professors.
Crime and declining enrollment changed that.
"When the faculty strike started and enrollment went down, business went down fast," Mr. Mehta said. "And then, we had people being mugged in the parking lot and gunshots coming right through the windows. By last Christmas business had dropped by more than half, and we were forced to close. It had become a real nightmare."
Today, the building stands empty, much of it destroyed earlier in the year by fire.
On Broad Street, only police cars can be seen in the parking lot of Bodine Hall, which is used as a training center for Bridgeport and nearby police departments.
"Every once in a while, you can hear the training going on, you can hear them practicing things like: "Pull over! Get out of the car with your hands up,' " Ms. Davis said.
In the deteriorating South End, Ms. Davis and her neighbors say it is often difficult to tell whether they are hearing the sounds of training exercises or of actual arrests.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
January Crude Oil Contract Falls for 5th Straight Time

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 4

 BODY:
Crude oil for delivery in January fell for the fifth consecutive session, to its lowest level since early March, weighed down by burdensome supplies and slack demand, analysts said today.
Initially, crude oil rebounded in reaction to a report from the International Energy Agency that estimated first-quarter demand at 40 million barrels a day, up 600,000 barrels a day from the fourth quarter, for the countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. 
 "The attitude is to sell the rallies," said Victor Yu, senior trader at Nikkhah Energy Group, a division of Refco in New York. "People were skeptical of the report because the last report estimated demand one million barrels higher than it was."
January crude oil finished 14 cents lower at $18.94 a barrel. Oil products finished mixed. Heating oil for January delivery closed 0.08 cent lower at 54.22 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline for January delivery closed 0.12 cent higher at 51.42 cents a gallon.
 
Further Fall Seen
 Mr. Yu, like other traders and analysts, predicted crude oil futures could fall further still. "The market is oversupplied," he said. "There's too much oil here and in Europe, and not enough demand or cold weather."
Oil futures have been tumbling all week amid disappointment that OPEC did not agree to larger production cuts for the first quarter when oil ministers met last week in Vienna. OPEC set a production ceiling of 24.9 million barrels a day, which was about 400,000 barrels short of expectations. Many traders expressed concern that OPEC would even adhere to the new quotas.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Reports Of Gains in U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against other major currencies after November employment data pointed to strength in the American economy.
Gold prices were firmer, with spot gold on the New York Commodity Exchange closing up 20 cents at $335.70 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted gold up 25 cents, to $335.75, in late trading. 
 The Government reported that nonfarm payroll jobs rose by 105,000 in November, up from a revised gain of 34,000 in October, and that the unemployment rate fell for the fifth straight month in November, to 7.2 percent from 7.4 percent.
The dollar had already risen 12 percent since its September lows on an expected economic upturn, so the employment data did not cause much fanfare.
"The market tends to discount good economic news," said Andrew Hodge, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert. The recent gains inspired by the Presidential election euphoria had already discounted higher confidence in the recovery, he added.
 
German Bank Holds Firm
 Also holding the dollar back was the continuing reluctance of the German central bank to lower interest rates despite a growing recession in Germany, Mr. Hodge said. The country's relatively high interest rates bolster the value of the mark.
David Newman, a dealer at Harris Bank, said thin commercial interest in the few remaining trading days of the year was keeping a lid on the dollar. In the last three years, the dollar has rallied in Janaury.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.63 Japanese yen, up from 124.55 on Thursday. Later in London, it firmed to 124.90 yen. In late trading in New York, the dollar stood at 124.95 yen, up from Thursday's close at 124.67.
In London, the British pound slipped to 1.5595, from $1.5665 Thursday. It closed in New York at 1.5605, down from Thursday's close at $1.5640. The Australian dollar traded at 69.34 cents in United States currency, off from 69.63.
In New York, the dollar gained one pfennig to close at 1.5928 marks. It ended at $1.2774 (Canadian), up from $1.2746 Thursday.
Other late rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.4285 Swiss francs, up from 1.4135; 5.4070 French francs, up from 5.3875; and 1,395 Italian lire, up from Thursday's 1,392.

HEADLINE: Variety of Moving Events Prompt Donors to Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
June C. Starck wanted to usher in the 81st annual campaign by making its first contribution. Kathleen Whelen was eager to thank some men who came to her aid when her car broke down in the middle of the night in the Bronx. Valerie Eisman used her donation to honor the memory of a friend.
There seem to be an infinite number of reasons for sending money to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
 Many checks to the fund are accompanied by letters describing shocking, uplifting or sobering experiences that prompted people to give. It might have been the sight of a homeless person sleeping on a subway platform. Or a marriage or birth. Or a newspaper article about the plight of a New Yorker who, because of the recession, is unemployed for the first time. Or a recovery from a serious illness.
The day after last year's record campaign ended, Ms. Starck, a retired administrator in Manhattan, mailed in $500, saying that she hoped the money would help begin the next drive on the right footing. Donations received after the end of one year's appeal are held over until the start of the next.
"I thought that maybe if I start giving money earlier, they can start using it earlier," she said on Thursday. "I see more and more homeless people around my apartment, and it's very upsetting. And then I think: 'Who knows, is my luck going to change over the next 20 years?' "
Since the early years of this century, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has relied on the donations of people like Ms. Starck to change the lives of tens of thousands of suffering New Yorkers. These days, with the economy sagging and government aid declining, the seven charities that receive money from the fund are depending on private contributors more than ever.
This year's campaign will end on Feb. 28. All contributions go directly to the charities, because The Times pays for the fund's overhead.
Ms. Eisman and her husband, Steve Breiter, sent $85 to the fund in memory of Dr. Dan Pfeffer, a close friend who died last year. "He personally would be happy that people in New York City -- that was where he got started -- were being helped by this," Ms. Eisman, who lives in Baltimore, said the other day.
Ever since Ms. Whelen found herself lost in Mott Haven at 3 A.M., she has searched for a way to express her appreciation to the men who helped tow and fix her car: Ralphie from Protege Collision, Angel at the Gulf station and the men who work at Don Glo Towing.
"I was anticipating the worst possible experience," Ms. Whelen, who lives in Norwalk, Conn., wrote in a letter to the fund that included a $100 check. "Instead, everyone I met was helpful, reassuring and concerned for my safety. I am glad I took a chance and trusted these folks -- they could not have been kinder."
 
 
HOW TO AID FUND
 Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087, or to any of these organizations:
BROOKLYN BUREAU OF COMMUNITY SERVICE, 285 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217.

HEADLINE: Coup Fever in Venezuela

 BODY:
It matters very much to Americans -- North, South and Central -- that the coup fever raging in Venezuela finds a lasting cure.
President Carlos Andres Perez is, plainly, a flawed and unpopular politician. But he is just as plainly Venezuela's legitimately elected leader. To replace him by the ballot box next year would reinforce democracy throughout the region. To replace him by violence before then would undermine troubled democracies elsewhere. 
 Venezuela is not an obvious candidate for coup fever. Oil money has made it one of Latin America's richest nations. Its growth rate is among the region's highest. And its 34-year record of continuous democratic government is a proud achievement in a turbulent continent. When strongmen seized power last year in Haiti and this year in Peru, Venezuela led the hemispheric protests.
Now, however, Venezuela itself needs a strong show of democratic solidarity. In February, military conspirators came close to assassinating the President. An even more deadly revolt erupted last week. Opinion polls now show Mr. Perez's approval ratings below 10 percent.
Part of his unpopularity stems from free-market reforms that have greatly reduced the living standards of the middle class. Debts, lower oil prices and regional competition compelled Venezuela to cut consumer subsidies and other government spending. Meanwhile, rampant corruption around the Perez Government and a belief that sacrifices are not fairly shared helped transform economic suffering into political discontent.
As unpopular as Mr. Perez has become, Venezuelans don't seem eager for a military-backed regime. Their revulsion at the latest bloody rebellion helped insure its failure. As one coup supporter said: "I don't understand what's going on with these people. . . . They complain, they protest, and yesterday, which was the day to come out, they didn't take to the streets."
The conspirators don't seem to understand that Latin America has outgrown the era of military saviors. Military regimes have brought personal pain and economic ruin throughout the region in recent decades. Popular hopes now lie with expanded freedom, not iron rule.
Latin America's military leaders have been among the last to grasp this historic lesson. Civilian governments, even flawed ones, will need constant political reinforcement from democratic neighbors, especially the U.S., for years to come.
Today, every government in the hemisphere except Cuba and Haiti has some variety of democratic rule. That's a high-water mark. It warrants celebration, and vigilance.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Alaska's Plan to Shoot Wolves Is an Outrage;
Predation Helps Herds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Alaska's plan to kill wolves is destructive not only to Alaska's wildlife but to wildlife management and even to economic interests, which are presumably driving the proposal. 
 Alaska will sell permits to shoot wolves, and then sell even more hunting licenses to eager hunters lured by the hope of more moose, more caribou, or easy kills. But what the Alaska Division of Wildlife Conservation doesn't understand is that it is not at all certain that slaughtering wolves will increase the number of moose and caribou, because there are no data suggesting that wolf predation limits caribou or moose population size. In fact, wolf predation tends to keep prey populations healthy by removing sick and diseased animals.
Alaska is kidding itself if it thinks slaughtering wolves will promote tourism. We predict the public will not spend tourist dollars in a state that backs up 18th-century biases against predators with 20th-century technology.
 
JOHN W. GRANDY
V.P., Wildlife and Habitat Protection, Humane Society of the United States
Washington, Nov. 23, 1992

HEADLINE: Tax Credit Likely to Be Retroactive

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Moving to prevent delays in discretionary capital investments, the two most senior Congressional tax writers announced yesterday that any tax credits adopted next year for such business spending would be retroactive to yesterday.
The announcement by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, was intended to encourage businesses not to wait to buy costly items like machinery, Congressional aides said. 
 Mr. Bentsen has been frequently mentioned as a leading candidate for Treasury Secretary in the new Administration, giving his opinions on the matter even more weight. Aides to President-elect Bill Clinton said yesterday that Mr. Bentsen had been informed that he was Mr. Clinton's first choice for the post.
 
A Question of Timing
 The timing of the investment tax credit has been an issue for American businesses since the Presidential elections. Mr. Clinton campaigned on a promise to make such a tax benefit a central tool in his economic program.
But many members of Congress feared that the promise of a credit was creating a drag on the economy, because businesses would not act now, thinking they might get a tax benefit by waiting.
"We do not know at this time whether any such legislation will in fact be proposed or enacted," Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Bentsen said in a statement. "However, we wish to reassure the business community that we believe investments in depreciable tangible personal property made today and thereafter should be eligible for whatever tax investment incentives are ultimately enacted."
The two legislators may well have made this quarter one of the most advantageous for investments by businesses in capital goods, regardless of the terms of any legislation next year. Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Bentsen said that if the tax incentives were restricted to spending that exceeded the amount a business spent in some base period, then the current quarter should not be included in that period. That would mean that even if companies make heavy purchases in this quarter, the base level that they would have to exceed to qualify for the credit in the future would not be raised.
The statement by Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Bentsen, the most influential members of Congress in shaping tax legislation, is a strong assurance, but not a guarantee, that if such legislation is adopted next year, spending done now will qualify for a credit, Congressional aides said.
Such announcements by Congressional tax writers have become commonplace in recent years. In the past, however, they have at times been endorsed not only by committee chairmen, but also by the top minority members. With the Democrats soon to have both the White House and a majority in Congress for the first time in 12 years, such signs of bipartisan agreement are not as critical as in the recent past.
The statement by the two legislators came amid signs of a slowing in the purchase of large machinery and other big capital goods by American businesses. In October, the most recent month for which data are available, machine tool orders by American businesses fell 18.3 percent, to $184.2 million, while total tool order numbers fell 24.9 percent as the weak economies of the nation's trading partners cut exports in half.
The investment tax credit is an immensely popular tool for economic stimulation among politicians and business executives. The Clinton plan, reminiscent of the actions taken by John F. Kennedy when he became President in 1961 in the midst of a recession, would return to businesses as much as 10 percent of what they spent on machinery in excess of a certain level.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 9, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about proposals in Congress for an investment tax credit for businesses misstated the retroactive date proposed by legislators for the credit. It is Dec. 3.

HEADLINE: Du Pont Halts Compensations in Crop-Loss Furor

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 4

 BODY:
After spending $500 million to compensate farmers for crop failures linked to one of its agricultural chemicals, E. I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company has reversed course, rejecting any blame for the damage and halting its payments.
 Du Pont officials said the move, announced early last month, was based on new research into the chemical, Benlate. They described today what they said was an exhaustive scientific hunt for clues at a public meeting here of an advisory committee to the state Department of Agriculture. 
A top Du Pont scientist said that the company's new position was based on the results of $10 million in research it had conducted in Florida and Hawaii.
 
New Twist in Mystery
 More than a thousand growers, mostly in Florida, have reported damage on crops treated with Benlate. But the scientist, Dr. Bruce A. Hadley, said Du Pont could not duplicate the damage in carefully monitored tests on seven farms and nurseries in which the compound was applied to 250,000 plants. And a spokeswoman for Du Pont, Patricia N. Getter, said the company was thinking about putting the product back on the market.
 Dr. Hadley's presentation was another twist in a biochemical and legal mystery that began nearly two years ago when Du Pont pulled the product from the market after farmers in Florida, Texas, California and Puerto Rico said it was destroying their plants.
 Some of the Florida growers, and several dozen farm workers have since reported that their health was harmed by exposure to Benlate, a fungicide that was once one of the most popular chemicals on the nation's farms.
 The National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health said today that it had opened a preliminary investigation here to determine whether Benlate caused illnesses. It is one of the few studies the Federal agency has ever conducted on a pesticide-related incidents. Symptoms reported to the state by farm workers include dizziness, rashes, sore joints, nausea and nose bleeds.
The growers who still maintain that Benlate caused their losses, say Du Pont made a mistake in not pulling it off the market sooner. From their viewpoint and the view of state officials here who support them, the crop damage was the worst product failure in Du Pont history.
 But Jack A. Krol, the vice chairman of Du Pont, said in an interview today that the problems with Benlate were not a result to a product failure. He confirmed that the $500 million in liability claims were the most the company had paid in its history.
 "We acted at the time with the best information we had at hand," said Mr. Krol. "It was going to take another growing season to run all the tests. Now we have an answer. I wouldn't call what happened a mistake. I would call it a business judgment we made with the facts we had at hand. Obviously we aren't happy having paid $500 million in claims and if we had the information we wouldn't have paid the claims."
 
Harm to Company's Reputation
 Either way, the Benlate incident has presented an important financial problem for Du Pont's chairman, Edgar S. Woolard. It has also hurt the company's reputation as a supplier of safe and reliable farm chemicals, and put Du Pont, the country's eighth largest industrial corporation, in direct conflict with this state's wealthiest grower and its top farm officials.
 More than 100 lawsuits are pending against Du Pont here, and the state is seeking to intervene in one case to be heard this month in which a grower is asking a state court to open the company's private files to public inspection.
 "It is absolutely ludicrous for them to take the position they are after paying out $500 million in damages," said Bob Crawford, the Florida Commissioner of Agriculture. "The only common link we have found in all the damage reported to us is Benlate. I have no doubt Benlate is the cause. Du Pont changed purely for their negotiating position for all the lawsuits still pending against them."
 Mr. Crawford said no state suffered greater damage from the Du Pont chemical than his. He said Benlate shriveled tree, vegetable and flower crops from south of Miami to the Florida Panhandle. More than 1,200 of Florida's 14,000 growers have filed claims against the company for damages. Mr. Crawford said the Benlate disaster had caused economic losses of nearly $1 billion and was by far the largest agricultural disaster this state had ever experienced. He said hundreds of the state's farmers had been ruined by the Benlate disaster.
 "The human toll has been very high," Mr. Crawford said. "It's caused divorces and depression. It's put people under enormous financial strain all over the state. When your whole life is basically in the next crop and you apply a pesticide and it kills all your plants, what are you going to do? Along comes Du Pont who says they will pay. Then all of a sudden they decide summarily they are disavowing any liability. And that is what has irked me because that is so irresponsible for a company like Du Pont to do that."
 The amounts of the individual settlements and the types of damage they were meant to compensate have largely been kept private between the company and the growers. But of those settlements that have been disclosed in the Florida press and by some farmers, some have been for millions of dollars to cover destroyed crops and lost business.
Before Du Pont withdrew most formulations of Benlate from the market in 1991, the chemical was the most widely used fungicide in Florida. It was intended to protect crops from root rots and other fungal damage caused by Florida's hot and humid weather. The compound has been popular in American agriculture since Du Pont introduced it in the early 1970's, and Benlate helped the $7 billion Florida farm industry become a dominant supplier of fruit, vegetable, flower and nursery crops.
 But since the late 1980's Benlate has been been one of Du Pont's most troublesome products. In 1989, Benlate compounds sold by the company became contaminated with a herbicide that killed crops in Florida and other states. The company pulled Benlate from the market the same year and was fined by the Environmental Protection Agency, though the company and the Government are still negotiating the amount of the penalty.
 The company put Benlate back on the market in 1990 but then withdrew it again in March 1991.
 The questions about Benlate have led to the formation of an unusual coalition to challenge Du Pont, made up of farmers, farm workers and environmentalists, groups that historically have been at odds over problems involving pesticides. All three groups were well represented at the meeting here.
 "What's going on with Du Pont and this chemical is a crime," said Dale Smith, a 52-year-old grower of native plants from Homestead, Fla., who was wiped out by Benlate more than a year before Hurricane Andrew struck South Florida last August. "I used Benlate three times and I never used anything else and it dwarfed my plants and gnarled up the root systems. Nothing could be sold."
 Such stories are common among farmers who said they used Benlate. But Dr. Hadley, the research manager for Du Pont's agricultural products division, said the company's research absolved Benlate of responsibility.
 In the face of rising tensions in the room, Dr. Hadley described in a calm and measured voice the careful steps the company had taken to support its new version of events. He said Du Pont had identified the principal lots of the product that were involved in most of the complaints in Florida and other states. Du Pont subjected thousands of boxes of Benlate from those lots to batteries of analytical tests capable of measuring infinitesimally small concentrations of ingredients and found none that were contaminated with any chemical that would kill plants.
 Dr. Hadley said soil was tested for the presence of chemicals formed after Benlate dissolved and nothing unusual was found. He said plants grown in this soil thrived.
 He said the company reached agreement with six growers in Florida and another in Hawaii to test Benlate on hundreds of thousands of shrubs, flowers and vegetables without incident. He displayed photographs of apparently healthy plants taken from these tests. Some of them were grown after they had been doused with Benlate at levels hundreds of times higher than is recommended by Du Pont or permitted by the Government.
 "The bottom line is we have tried to recreate the plant damage from applications of Benlate and have been totally unsuccessful," he said. "We have no choice but to conclude that Benlate did not cause the damage."
 
Conclusion Is Assailed
 But Dr. Tim Schubert, a top plant pathologist for the state's Department of Agriculture, took issue with Dr. Hadley's conclusion today and suggested that the company was not being completely forthcoming about its findings. Dr. Schubert said he took a tour last month of two of Du Pont's research sites near Tampa and noticed that shrubs sprayed with Benlate had unusual numbers of small leaves, branches that had multiple buds and shoots and under developed root systems. Dr. Schubert said the abnormalities were among those commonly described by growers of woody ornamental plants who had used Benlate.
 "These effects were consistent with what the state has learned about Benlate's ability to cause phytotoxic effects in plants," Dr. Schubert said.
 Asked about Dr. Schubert's observations this afternoon, Dr. Hadley said underdeveloped root systems and leaves were "a normal occurrence and not related to chemical treatment."

(John Moran for The New York Times)
