Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 1; Page 35; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 759 words

HEADLINE: Chapter 11 Offers No Discounts For Macy

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
It is not unusual for lawyers and bankruptcy judges to wrangle over fees and expenses. But a report filed in the bankruptcy proceedings of R. H. Macy & Company illustrates just what happens when a big, fat turkey lands in bankruptcy court and its advisers start scrambling to carve off a juicy slice.
 Never mind that the department store chain rolled up a whopping $1.3 billion loss in its last fiscal year and that its cash flow was nil. In June, July and August, the lawyers, accountants and financial advisers working for Macy and its creditors piled up bills for services and expenses amounting to $5,705,591.30, or about $62,000 a day. 
The bulk of the charges involved Macy's accountant, Deloitte & Touche, which received nearly $2 million, and its law firm, Weil, Gotshal & Manges, which received $1.7 million.
 These are some of those charges:
 *A $6,930 bill filed by Weil Gotshal for looking at the bankruptcy papers of Ames Department Stores, which the law firm also represents.
 *A $4,070 bill from Deloitte & Touche for 37 hours of reorganizing files.
 *A bill for $13,425 for almost 90 hours spent researching and producing 30 slides comparing cost structures of five department stores.
 *Fees for three accountants from BDO Seidman, the firm representing Macy's unsecured creditors, who spent a total of 137 hours preparing routine fee applications each month.
 *A bill from the Blackstone Group, financial adviser to Macy, for a lunch that cost $418.91, even though guidelines by the bankruptcy court stipulate that meals may not exceed $20 a person and Blackstone had only four people working for Macy.
 
Ordered by Judge
 Concerned by the high cost of the advice to Macy, its bondholders and its trade creditors, Judge Burton R. Lifland, the judge who is overseeing the proceedings in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, formed a committee in September to analyze and evaluate the charges.
 Given Macy's dire financial straits, some of the law and accounting firms have found ways to economize. Weil Gotshal scaled back its work to lower its fees by roughly $200,000 a month.
 In its filing yesterday, the committee criticized some of the bills for being excessive and vague. The judge will hold a hearing on the report and bills on Tuesday.
 "We are unable to be impressed by legal fees being reduced to approximately $500,000 per month," the committee wrote of Weil Gotshal's cuts.
 William Jarblum, a partner in the law firm representing the trustee for one group of Macy's bondholders, wrote the report for the four-member committee, which included Herbert Hellman, Macy's general counsel.
 Mr. Hellman did not concur with the report's conclusions about Weil Gotshal or Berlack, Israels & Liberman, the bondholders' law firm.
 "I think Mr. Jarblum doesn't know what he's talking about," said Harvey Miller, a senior partner at Weil Gotshal and the lead lawyer representing Macy. "He's never staffed a large Chapter 11 case."
 He said Macy had actually reduced fees by doing many tasks in-house, like compiling financial documents.
 Mr. Miller said he was not going to cut fees and expenses just because of the criticisms. The $6,930 bill submitted for reviewing the Ames bankruptcy was legitimate, he said, because some of the strategies Ames used might be pertinent.
And he defended the use of a five-year, $200-an-hour associate, Susan Pearson, to draft the firm's fee application, a routine task.
 "Two hundred dollars an hour is not expensive in today's world," Mr. Miller said.
 
Compared With Federated
 A spokesman for Macy, James Fingeroth, said the advisers' fees were about half of what Federated Department Stores was charged at a similar point in its bankruptcy.
 David G. Heiman, head of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue's bankruptcy division and Federated's lead lawyer, said he could not verify Macy's contention.
 The report was most critical of Macy's advisers, though it suggested that advisers to the creditors could also be more economical. It questioned, for example, the amount of time Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin, advisers to the bondholders, spent on comparative analyses of other department stores' operations.
 More than 70 percent of the fees and expenses were billed by Macy's advisers. But it is typical, particularly in the early part of a bankruptcy case, for the debtors' advisers to have the lion's share of responsibility.
 Alfred Leach, a spokesman for Deloitte & Touche, said the firm had not had an opportunity to review the report and could not comment.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 5, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Dec. 5 about legal and other fees for the bankruptcy of R. H. Macy & Company misstated the position of Macy's general counsel, Herbert Hellman. He did not concur with the report's comments that the fees of the Blackstone Group were excessive. He did concur with its assessment of the fees of Berlack, Israels & Liberman, a law firm for Macy's bondholders. This correction was improperly delayed through an editing lapse.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1538 words

HEADLINE: Gardening

BYLINE: By Anne Raver; Anne Raver writes about gardening for The New York Times.

 BODY:
HENRY MITCHELL has helped me survive the annual deluge of numbing garden books. In ONE MAN'S GARDEN (illustrated, 262 pp., Houghton Mifflin, $21.95), a collection of his Earthman gardening columns for The Washington Post, he writes, "I have a useful rule of thumb for judging garden books: whenever I see charts in which you read down one side, then across, I know the book was written by some idiot whose learning and whose love are exhausted by a three-word summary."
You know the ones. Endless charts of plants, with their colors, heights and so forth. More English cottage garden books than Burpee tomatoes. Though I like one: ENGLISH COTTAGE GARDENING FOR AMERICAN GARDENERS, written and photographed by Margaret Hensel (239 pp., Norton, $50), has the usual charming photographs, but the plant combinations are interesting and the information on hardiness, culture and sources undeniably useful -- albeit only to the hopelessly English-obsessed. Still, I draw the line at paint-by-number gardening books in which each typically beautiful photograph is now accompanied by a diagram of curving numbered blobs with corresponding plant lists. You can even, those books claim, crack the genius of Gertrude Jekyll this way. 
 Balderdash. Just read Jekyll, if you can stand her prose, and go sit in your garden.
I won't even talk about the coffeetable books, whose preciousness and price have gone over the top. Perhaps they are parodying the people who buy them.
Which leads me back to my wholehearted hurrah for Henry Mitchell's new book, whose every page is filled with his irascible, wholly unpretentious voice: "It is agreeable to waddle about in one's own paradise, knowing that thousands of others have better gardens with better thises and thats, and better grown too, and no weeds at all. To know this and grin as complacently as a terrier who just got into the deviled eggs, and to reflect that there is no garden in England or France I envy, and not one I'd swap for mine: this is the aim of gardening -- not to make us complacent idiots, exactly, but to make us content and calm for a time, with sufficient energy (even after wars with bindweed) to feel an awestruck thanks to God that such happiness can exist. For a few days, of course."
Mr. Mitchell never tries to be funny or erudite. He just is. I don't fall asleep when he talks about the importance of architecture in the garden. He points out, for example, that many of the world's great gardens would be slim collections of plants, were their walls and pools and pathways removed. Then he offers a few simple suggestions to inspire those of us who would dream of having Sheffield Park in our backyards. We could try, he says, dedicating the whole garden to a copse of dogwood and sourwood, or a "huge informal pool fringed with peltiphyllums and reeds, overlooked by a mossy arbor of cedars." A Roman temple wouldn't hurt, either, he later notes.
A very different animal is the Massachusetts Horticultural Society's KEEPING EDEN: A History of Gardening in America, edited by Walter T. Punch (illustrated, 277 pp., Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown, $50). Mr. Punch is the head librarian of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society, and his collection of 16 essays sweeps from Gordon De Wolf's revealing chapter on colonial times, when the first settlers were digging holes in the ground for houses and taking their gardening tips from American Indians, to William Howard Adams's whirlwind look at 20th-century American gardens (from Edith Wharton's "well-bred" design standards to the low-maintenance gardens of Thomas Church and Garrett Eckbo in California).
Phyllis Andersen contemplates the evolution of city gardens, from William Penn's plan for Philadelphia's five green squares to Frederick Law Olmsted's democratic park systems to a brief nod to the community garden movement. Michael Pollan looks into the future with an essay that juxtaposes the American obsession with lawns against the wilderness park. In one landscape, we dominate nature with chemicals and machines that obliterate what Alexander Pope called "the genius of the place." In the other, Mr. Pollan writes, we rope it off and worship its untouched qualities: "The idea of a middle landscape -- a place that might partake equally of nature and culture, that might seek to strike some sort of compromise or balance between the two realms -- has received short shrift, with the result that, even after some 500 years, the American garden has yet to come into its own." And so, he adds, does a sensitive and sane approach to our environmental problems.
This is the most satisfying of all the essays, because Mr. Pollan has the luxury of focusing on one idea while the other writers are burdened with the impossible job of summing up too many major ideas, movements, economic patterns and brilliant insights in too little space. But as Mr. Punch gamely points out in his introduction, the book begins to trace the diverse history of gardening in this country. I found it a fascinating outline. The bibliographies at the end of each chapter are invaluable resources, as is Elisabeth Woodburn's summation of gardening writing in America. One could hardly order a better reader's guide for the long winter months.
Another mind-expanding work is THE MEANING OF GARDENS: Idea, Place, and Action, edited by Mark Francis and Randolph T. Hester Jr. (illustrated, 283 pp., MIT, paper, $22.95). This collection of 29 essays by such varied minds as Garrett Eckbo, Chip Sullivan, Ian L. McHarg and Catherine Howett, first published in a small scholarly edition two years ago and virtually unnoticed by most gardeners, is now available in paperback. The essays deal with such subjects as the garden as a reflection of faith (from ancient times to our own); the garden as an expression of power (from Adam and Eve to Louis XIV to a pioneer woman who carves a garden out of her husband's beanfield to assert herself); gardening as the imposition of order, as cultural expression, as personal expression. There is even one on gardens as places to die.
As for how-to books, there are two excellent guides for vegetable lovers. THE NEW ORGANIC GROWER'S FOUR-SEASON HARVEST, by Eliot Coleman (illustrated, 212 pp., Chelsea Green Publishing, $17.95), clearly explains how to use cold frames and simple hoop greenhouses (with full instructions on building them) in order to eat fresh vegetables the year around. Mr. Coleman explains composting, the value of green manure, the importance of soil aeration and other basics with the easy style of a man who knows that mistakes in the garden often teach us the most about its mysteries. If he can grow food the year around in Maine, I figure I can too. STEP BY STEP ORGANIC VEGETABLE GARDENING, by Shepherd Ogden (illustrated, 297 pp., HarperCollins, $23) is a thorough guide to the basics of good gardening. Building good soil is the key, writes Mr. Ogden, who draws on the wisdom of his gardening father, Big Sam, as well as the experience he and his wife, Ellen, have gathered from their trial gardens for The Cook's Garden, their mail-order seed company in Londonderry, Vt. You will find a bounty of insights here on growing specific crops.
In the flower world, ANNUALS FOR CONNOISSEURS, by Wayne Winterrowd with photographs by Cynthia Woodyard (210 pp., Horticulture/Prentice Hall, $25) shatters the cliche that annuals are just fill-in plants. Even the most misused annuals have their place, Mr. Winterrowd writes. Take blue Salvia farinacea out of the bed of white petunias and red Salvia splendens, and put it next to the buttery yellow perennial Anthemis tinctoria. But more important, this Vermont gardener introduces us to many unusual annuals that can easily be grown in our own gardens, like Abelmoschus manihot, a six-foot mallow with dark green leaves and pale yellow five-inch-wide flowers with deep burgundy centers, and the green-flowered Nicotiana langsdorfii.
In brief: THE ENVIRONMENTAL GARDENER, edited by Janet Marinelli, THE TOWN & CITY GARDENER, edited by Linda Yang and TREES: A Gardener's Guide, edited by Judith D. Zuk (each 96 pp., Brooklyn Botanic Garden, paper, $6.95) add three well-written volumes to the garden's handbook series (four handbooks a year are included in the $25 membership, but each can be purchased separately). And for gardeners who need to conserve water (and many across the country now do), DRIP IRRIGATION: For Every Landscape and All Climates, by Robert Kourik (illustrated, 118 pp., Metamorphic Press, paper, $12) explains the arcana of drip systems and why they are better for many plants; it also tells how to install the right system.
XERISCAPE GARDENING: Water Conservation for the American Landscape, by Connie Lockhart Ellefson, Thomas L. Stephens and Doug Welsh (with photographs by Ms. Ellefson, 323 pp., Macmillan, $30) is a comprehensive guide to designing and planting a garden that doesn't guzzle water. THE ORGANIC GARDENER'S HANDBOOK OF NATURAL INSECT AND DISEASE CONTROL, edited by Barbara W. Ellis and Fern Marshall Bradley (illustrated, 534 pp., Rodale Press, $26.95) offers a concise listing of controls and clear photographs of common garden pests as well as diseased plants.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A formal garden designed by Rudolf Ulrich at Linden Towers, a house in Menlo Park, Calif., 1878. (From "Keeping Eden")

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 6, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 20; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1249 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Gifts of Gab for '93

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
With all thy getting," the publisher B. C. Forbes liked to quote from Proverbs 4:7, "get understanding."
With all thy quoting, get a quotation book. The old editions are good, but the new ones are better be cause people are making new quotations every day. 
 The heaviest hitters in the field are Bartlett's Familiar Quotations, 16th Edition (Little, Brown), edited by Justin Kaplan, and the Oxford Dictionary of Quotations, New Edition, edited by Angela Partington. (It's the Fourth Edition, duly noted on the title page; I don't know why the publishers prefer the vague "new edition" on the jacket.) If you have a very large Christmas stocking, get both, because each has its separate virtues. If you have to choose, the best buy for Americans is Bartlett's.
That's not only because the publisher offers 1,400 big pages for $40 while Oxford falls short of 1,100 pages for $35; the reason for Bartlett's dominance of the field is its scholarship and zest. When Mr. Kaplan quotes Margaret Fuller's "I accept the universe," he footnotes Thomas Carlyle's comment, "By God! She'd better." Oxford does it the wrong way around, under Carlyle, making it harder to look up.
In selections from the Book of Job, an interest of mine, Bartlett's has twice the text; Oxford leaves out lines like "He is a king over all the children of pride." Both stick to the familiar King James Version of 1611; Oxford should consider shifting to its own beautiful and more accurate Bible translation in future editions.
Mr. Kaplan is a careful man: he lists "There's no such thing as a free lunch" under the economist Milton Friedman. I wrote to Milton about the origin of that adage some years back, and he cheerfully acknowledged it had not been original with him; that's why the quotologist adds a careful "attributed" next to the line.
Oxford is more specific about dates, however, and shows better judgment on the selection of the sayings of Ronald Reagan. Both books cite evil empire, but Bartlett's goes beyond Reagan's 1983 usage to its origin in the 1977 George Lucas film, "Star Wars." (Both also have the line "Go ahead, make my day," delivered first by Clint Eastwood, but only Bartlett's has the right citation. Oxford cites the 1971 film "Dirty Harry" as its origin; instead, it started in that film's 1983 sequel, "Sudden Impact," written by Joseph C. Stinson.)
"The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is that good men do nothing." If you want to find out how some of us have broken our heads to find the coiner of that, get "Nice Guys Finish Seventh: False Phrases, Spurious Sayings and Familiar Misquotations" by Ralph Keyes (HarperCollins, $18). It wasn't Edmund Burke, and if you were there when it was first said, speak up.
Mr. Keyes's title is drawn from the way the sportswriter Frank Graham edited Leo Durocher's "The nice guys are all over there. In seventh place." We remember it as "Nice guys finish last." (Who said "Show me a good loser and I'll show you a loser"? In a mean-spirited moment years ago, I attributed that to Henry Kissinger, but it wasn't his coinage. Keyes suggests Knute Rockne, but Richard Nixon credits his college football coach, Chief Newman.)
Then there's "Dickson's Word Treasury: A Connoisseur's Collection of Old and New, Weird and Wonderful, Useful and Outlandish Words" (have you noticed how subtitles are getting more hard-sell lately?) by Paul Dickson (Wiley paperback, $14.95). His chapter on journalese offers such gems as densely wooded area, defined as "where most 'badly decomposed' bodies are found," and flawed, "used by critics in reviews in which they actually enjoyed the film, play, book or whatever but feel compelled to say something negative lest their boss think that they have gone soft in the head." A section on phobias is useful: a copy was sent to me with levophobia tagged; it means "fear of things on the left."
Stephen Glazier, who died this year just before his chef d'oeuvre was published, was a modern Peter Mark Roget -- a putter-together of word lists. The Random House Word Menu (guess what publisher, $22) combines dictionary, thesaurus and glossary in an original way that is of great use to writers. Look up cooks, for example, to find baker, barkeeper, confectioner, publican ("manager of tavern") and, among many others, a solution to the waiter-waitress-waitron problem that some linguistically correct types have posed: server.
Under grunts, as a category of speech many other word books neglect, the writer may select from a range including aah, har rumph, la-di-da, oof, ta-da, unh-unh, varoom and the ever-popular yech.
Palindrome freaks, a small category of word lovers who like to read back and forth, will snap up the slim and somewhat overpriced paperback "If I Had a Hi-Fi" by William Irvine (Laurel, $5.99), which includes We panic in a pew and Desserts, I stressed and the ambitious Some men interpret nine memos. (Gary Muldoon of Rochester, in the course of explaining to me that the word mnemonic comes from the Greek goddess Mnemosyne, contributes a palindrome of interest to parents proud of their grown-up offspring: Diapers repaid.)
For serious linguists, the gift of the year is a reprint of Otto Jespersen's 1924 "The Philosophy of Grammar," with an introduction and a new index by James D. McCawley (University of Chicago Press paperback, $17.95). When I recently offended who-whomniks by opining that than was a preposition, not a conjunction, Professor McCawley rode to my rescue by citing the great Danish linguist Jespersen's conclusion that so-called subordinating conjunctions are prepositions with clause objects. (Anybody still there? Helluva book.)
For librarians of major Wall Street investment houses -- not a huge audience, but somebody has to look out for their interests -- here's The New Palgrave Dictionary of Money and Finance (Stockton Press, 3 volumes, $595). General readers will find more than they want to know about takeovers, leverage and the quantity theory of money, but word freaks will be titillated by such entries as contango, "a fee paid by the buyer who wants to postpone delivery," a sultry dance by the buyer of futures options that is the reverse of backwardation.
The Wizard of Oz entry by Hugh Rockoff was an eye-opener: this children's story by L. Frank Baum is explicated as an 1890's allegory about bimetalism. The Yellow Brick Road is the gold standard (an oz. of gold); the Cowardly Lion is William Jennings Bryan, derogated for lack of courage by free-silver populists; President William McKinley, friend to financiers, is the Wicked Witch of the West, and the Wizard in Emerald City (Washington, D.C.) is Mark Hanna, the Republican leader. The New Palgrave does not say who Dorothy's dog is supposed to be.
Finally, for word lovers who appreciate an example of simple and lucid writing on a subject of infinite complexity, try the new edition of Robert Jastrow's short classic, "God and the Astronomers" (Norton, $18.95). By running the big-bang theory backward, scientists must deal with the moment of cosmic creation, a subject usually confined to theologians. To describe the reach of Hubble's Law of the Expanding Universe, he writes, "It applies not only to the Cosmos, but also to inflating balloons and loaves of bread rising in the oven." The bigger the subject, Jastrow demonstrates, the more effective are homely words.

PUB-DATE: December 6, 1992

SECTION: Section 5; Page 8; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 4155 words

HEADLINE: Days and Nights in Disney World

BYLINE: By NANCY SHARKEY; NANCY SHARKEY is an editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
THERE is a perverse rule in economics that applies to luxury goods: All else being equal, people believe that when they pay more, they get better quality. This applies to furs, platinum watches, Lamborghinis, Gucci briefcases and, apparently, Walt Disney World. Little else can account for the difference in price between the low-end and high-end hotels at the Walt Disney World complex in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.
In a 10-night visit last summer, our family of three stayed in eight Disney World hotels ranging in price from $85 to $400 a night, excluding taxes. To our surprise, we found that $100 a night buys good accommodations and nearly the same level of comfort that the high-end places offer. At Disney World, a guest at any hotel can use the facilities of any other hotel. No matter where we were staying, we were able to ride throughout the complex on the sophisticated transportation system, including water taxis, monorails and trams; we had our pick of pools, restaurants, parking lots, even laundry facilities and baby-sitting services. As Disney guests we could reserve meals at park restaurants two days in advance. 
 We also found, not surprisingly, that newer is better at Disney World. The furnishings are spiffier and the amenities more amenable at the brand-new Dixie Landings ($85 or $104 a night) and the Yacht Club (we paid $260 a night) than at their older counterparts, the Caribbean Beach resort at the budget end and the Contemporary in the middle range.
The length of our stay, 10 days, solved a big problem: the perceived necessity to see it all, and fast. With a resort-style pool and pleasant accommodations, we didn't feel compelled to spend more than four hours a day in any of the three amusement parks: the Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center or MGM Studios. We arrived at each park early to avoid the heaviest crowds and fled to our hotel by lunchtime for a boat ride, tennis , horseback ride or swim.
While changing hotels every day is few people's idea of relaxation, we had deliberately set out to try as many hotels as possible, and in the process discover how to get the greatest value from the Disney hotel system.
Everywhere, we were ensconsed in a "setting," which of course is the Disney plan. The resorts evoke various benign themes. There's ersatz Louisiana plantation or New England clapboard resort, Polynesian village and faux Fifties Miami Beach.
I chose the eight hotels for their variety of price, location and style. We stayed in every type of accommodation that Disney offers, except a tent site. Many hotels are paired, with slightly different decor but the same price and architecture. We stayed in only one of each pair. We ate lunch or dinner in every resort and were impressed by the quality of the food -- far better and more carefully prepared than in the crowded restaurants inside the three amusement parks, and above average for typical hotel restaurants. Food prices generally followed room rates: the Grand Floridian was the most expensive, Dixie Landings among the most reasonable. I traveled anonymously.
Disney World's hotels are priced primarily by location -- the closer to the Magic Kingdom, Epcot or MGM, the grander and more expensive. And within each facility, rooms are priced by the view. "Parking lot or lagoon?" one reservations agent inquired.
At the high end, paying $250 a night or more, we stayed in the Grand Floridian, the Dolphin, the Yacht Club and the Contemporary. In the midprice category, between $100 and $250, were the Vacation Club and a trailer in Fort Wilderness. At the budget end, less than $100 a night, were Dixie Landings and the Caribbean Beach. The Vacation Club apartment and Fort Wilderness trailer had kitchens and dining areas. The others were large hotel rooms, with two double or queen beds, a terrace, a double sink outside the bathroom, which we appreciated, and an honor bar with reasonably priced sodas and snacks.
We each had our favorites. Chris, who is 12, loved the splashy Dolphin, with a health club, a waterfall pool, pedal boats on the lake, a game room, ice cream parlor with 50's jukeboxes -- and swarms of well-behaved teen-agers. My husband, Joe, liked the low-key Vacation Club apartment, with a private terrace opening onto shade trees; Jacuzzi room, washer-dryer and well-equipped kitchen. I liked Dixie Landings for its value, with good landscaping, a riverboat ride, bicycle rentals, central children's pool and the quiet adult pools adjacent to each of six clusters of buildings, a fishing pond and a decent, moderately priced Cajun restaurant.
There were specific highlights as well. The best pool was the Yacht Club's serpentine affair, with water slide and beach area for toddlers. The easiest access to the Magic Kingdom was from the Grand Floridian, which has its own monorail station and ferry landing. The best access to MGM was from the Dolphin and Swan, and to Epcot from the Yacht and Beach Club, both within walking distance, though there's a five-minute tram ride available.
The best service was on the concierge floor at the Dolphin, a section with full-time concierge service, central lounge, breakfast, tea and desserts. The hotel is operated by Sheraton, and the pleasant staff is less frenetically friendly than at hotels operated by Disney. At those, the staff seemed to have a divided mission -- part helper, part movie extra. Employee changing rooms and offices are labeled with signs, "Cast Members Only." Dressed as ranch hands, serving wenches or sailors, employees were young and usually desperately eager to please.
All of the hotels we stayed in were inside the vast Disney World complex, which has 17,460 rooms in 20 hotels, campgrounds and apartments. Outside the complex, the highways are lined with an astonishing clutter of hotels and motels, with an additional 53,000 rooms. And Disney plans more hotels. The most recent to open have been at the budget end, $85 and $104 a night, and Disney is planning to build more in that range by 1995, including a Hollywood-theme hotel near MGM Studios.
In addition to the hotel telephone numbers, there is a central reservations number, (407) 934-7639. Only the Dolphin, operated by Sheraton, has an 800 number.
 
Yacht Club
Our first stop was the Yacht Club, where the decor, not surprisingly, is nautical: white shoulder-high wainscoting, thick blue carpet with nautical flags and maritime prints, charts and shipboard details. The gray clapboard 635-room building, and its sky-blue companion hotel, the Beach Club, with 580 rooms, are meant to evoke the Cottage Era on the Maine coast. They would do so better, were it not for rows of metal flags atop the roof, permanently unfurled against the Disney sky. The lagoon in front of the hotel has a pristine white beach; its fine sand, free of seaweed or mollusks, is imported from the White Sands of New Mexico.
Our room had two queen-sized beds and a nice terrace overlooking the lawn and lagoon. The wood furniture had a nautical flavor, and there was plenty of light. The huge serpentine pool, with whirlpools tucked away in rocky overlooks and a sandy area for toddlers, was a highlight. A shipwreck waterslide empties into one end; I was content to let Chris stay in the water alone, because there were lifeguards every 50 feet.
The restaurants were uncrowded, and food was good and generous -- big sandwiches in the Yacht Club Gallery -- and at night, the three of us shared a tender, flavorful chateaubriand ($35) in the Yachstman Steakhouse. On the down side, the waiter asked if we knew the difference between bearnaise and bordelaise sauces, and a table of people near us were taking flash pictures of each other after every course.
Activities were uncrowded. Use of croquet sets was free and the tennis courts were ours alone. Late in the afternoon, we rented a small motorboat ($12 for a half hour) to explore the lagoon.
Across the lagoon from the Yacht Club, Disney's plans call for a boardwalk style hotel and amusement park, a bit like the old Atlantic City. This will undoubtedly affect what I found the greatest charm of the Yacht Club, its serenity.
Yacht Club Resort, (407) 934-7000, opened in 1990, 635 rooms, rates from $195 to $445 a night; from Dec. 20, $205 to $470. Adjacent is the Beach Club Resort, with a salmon and aqua beach theme.
 
Caribbean Beach Resort
Next, we stayed at the Caribbean Beach Resort, which is very popular because of the $85 room rate, among the lowest in the complex. The 2,112-room motel complex was jammed when we arrived; the separate guest registration building had a 20-minute wait to check in. Our room, despite the price, was surprisingly similar in size to the Yacht Club's. The beds were double, rather than queen, and the room didn't have a private balcony. But the covered walkway off our second floor room was wide enough that we simply could pull chairs outside and watch the afternoon rain, a fact of life in central Florida's summers.
The hotel has no bellhop service, no full-service restaurant and no room service, but a small central mall offers a wide selection of fast food. I found a stand there selling cereal, juice and milk, which I stashed in our room refrigerator for breakfast.
For dinner that night, I had booked what the reservations agent told me was the most popular dinner show in Disney World, the "Hoop De Doo Revue," a stage production at Fort Wilderness, about a 20-minute ride away. We couldn't understand the appeal. Our table was on a U-shaped balcony, wedged between the stage curtain and the kitchen door and overlooking a Dickensian scene of diners pressed tightly together at a mass of tables below. The production is billed as an all-you-can-eat meal with a two-hour vaudeville frontier show. Dinner, served at 7:45 and cleared at 8:10, consisted of fried chicken, barbecued ribs, corn on the cob and salad. I complained to the waitress about my ribs, which had an odd taste that I suspected was oven cleaner. The waitress asked the cook, and reported back that he didn't think it was, but he sent out a replacement anyway.
Then the four Disney performers danced onto the stage below. We had never seen the hokeypokey performed professionally before. Inevitably, there was audience participation, and we were roped in unwillingly by a young man in a Hee Haw suit.
"They're from New York," wailed the singing troupe, improvisationally, as the crowd applauded wildly. "Remember to use a fork!"
Wishing we'd said "Afghanistan," we slunk out before dessert. Back at our hotel, we complained to the Caribbean Beach manager about the seating, the food and the show, requesting a refund of part of the $100 we had spent. We were politely informed that the "Hoop De Doo Revue" is one of the most popular attractions in Disney World but that the Hoop De Doo manager would contact us. Chastened, we waited, even left a forwarding number, but he didn't.
Caribbean Beach Resort, (407) 934-3400, opened in 1988, 2,112 rooms, rates $85 (parking lot view) and $104 (lagoon view) a night; from Dec. 20, $87 and $114. Bus service only to the theme parks.
 
Grand Floridian
Next stop was the Grand Floridian. Here was grandeur, Disney style. The lobby of the main building has a five-story atrium, overlooked by oval ivory painted balconies. Outside, the white wood frame building with its turreted red roof looks remarkably like San Diego's Victorian gem, the Hotel del Coronado.
Our room was furnished in wicker and chintz, with big thick towels in the bathroom. We stayed on the concierge floor, which had a private lounge, overlooking the lobby, in which buffet breakfast, afternoon tea, wine and cheese and cakes and brandies were served. Snacks were available free, around the clock. Our crisp, cheerful, well-informed concierge thoughtfully sent Chris a child's bathrobe to match the two terrycloth adult robes in the room.
The Grand Floridian has the best tennis facilities at Disney -- two red clay courts, empty when we were there. The big L-shaped central pool is surrounded by deck chairs, many of them occupied by English and German guests. We ordered sodas from a small gazebo.
The hotel also has Disney's most expensive hotel restaurant, Victoria and Albert's, designed like an English men's club, with leather, wood -- and, in July, a fire in the fireplace. The intimate circular dining room has a domed trompe l'oeil ceiling. For our fixed-price dinner of $75 each, excluding wine, we received personalized menus, folded and closed with sealing wax.
The maitre d'hotel introduced our waiters, a handsome young couple one of whose name-tags said Albert and the other, Victoria. They recited the menu, taking turns. We noticed that the wine steward's tag also said Albert.
"You're all named Victoria and Albert, like the museum?"
The waitress nodded.
"What's your real name?"
She leaned forward, smiling conspiratorily. "Linda."
The food was superb, and so was the service. We had salmon carpaccio in three-pepper sauce with balsamic vinegar; consomme of elk and antelope with morels, a filet of beef with horseradish crust, salad of wild greens, Stilton and poached pear and a chocolate-raspberry terrine for dessert. Because there were only three other tables occupied, I asked if we could meet the chef. He turned out to be an Alsatian, trained in Colmar, who had until a couple of years ago owned a restaurant in Miami.
Later in the week we would return to the Grand Floridian by boat from the Magic Kingdom, just to enjoy the pleasant setting by the pool.
Grand Floridian Beach Resort, (407) 824-3000, opened in 1988, 900 rooms, rates from $220 to $400 (concierge floor) a night; from Dec. 20, $230 to $430. Tram, monorail and water ferry service to Magic Kingdom. 
 
 Fort Wilderness
Late the next morning, we crossed time and space to the quasi-rustic Fort Wilderness. After a half-hour wait in the reception shed -- our trailer was not ready -- we took a bus to River Country, the water park in the complex. Parking is heavily restricted throughout Disney World. -- Here, each trailer has a space, well shielded from its neighbor, but there's no parking on the roads; people leave their cars in the main lot or beside their campsites and use the frequent but often jammed buses.
At a very crowded settlement area near the lagoon, we bought ingredients for a picnic at the canteen and then took the ferry to Discovery Island, a tiny zoological park. The attractions at River Country -- inferior to better-designed water parks all over America -- were packed elbow to elbow. Tickets to these two parks were included in our six-day Disney passes; had we known they were so crowded and so unexceptional, we would not have bothered.
We had to wait until late afternoon for our trailer. After returning room keys -- and a resort charge card -- that belonged to another guest and had mistakenly been given to us, we finally settled into a comfortable, well-appointed tan-and-brown Fleetwood. It was equipped with a kitchenette, a surprisingly spacious bathroom with tub, shower and linen closet, a bedroom and in the living room, a Murphy bed, an artifact that Chris had seen only in black-and-white movies. We were so grateful for the extra space that we overlooked the aluminum and plastic.
There's a nightly organized campfire gathering in the complex, which was canceled because it rained. Fort Wilderness has a pool the size of the Grand Floridian's, a small, crowded game room, a depot grocery, a bike rental shack and a small lagoon for pedal boats. The main lagoon, a big man-made lake at the northern part of Fort Wilderness, has small motorboats, called water sprites, that skitter like gnats on the surface. Chris and I took out one, but the lagoon was so crowded that I spent much of the half hour worrying about collisions.
We spent two nights at Fort Wilderness, giving us our first full day without changing hotels. So we decided to start early at the Magic Kingdom amusement park, taking advantage of the one-hour's early admission (opening time is normally 9 A.M.) available to Disney hotel guests on Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday. We left our trailer at 7:30 and drove a few miles to the Grand Floridian guest lot, where we caught the monorail into the park, leaving our swimsuits in the car.
Chris and his father immediately headed to the Magic Kingdom's most popular attraction, Space Mountain, which is a steel roller coaster whose only real distinction is that it is in a large building, so the descent is in the dark. Not a fan of roller coasters in general, let alone at 8 A.M., I read the paper outside in the sun.
The long lines and dense crowds made us glad that we made lunch reservations from our hotel at the Liberty Tree Tavern, a large restaurant inside Magic Kingdom whose small tavern rooms give a feeling of intimacy. Afterward, we took the water shuttle back to the Grand Floridian, changed in the locker room, and spent the afternoon by the pool. Back at the Magic Kingdom in the evening, we fled when the curb of Main Street began filling up at 7 P.M. for a 9 P.M. parade.
Fort Wilderness Resort and Campground, (407) 824-2900, opened in 1971, 408 trailers $165 and $185 a night, ($180 to $195 from Dec. 20) and 784 campsites, $30 and $49 a night ($32 to $49 from Dec. 20). 
 
 Dolphin
Our next stop was the Dolphin, one of the hotels Disney commissioned from prominent American architects, this one a post-modern extravaganza by Michael Graves, whose splashy decor and Matisse colors, poster-bedecked walls and bright paintings suited the unashamed artifice of Disney better than our homey trailer in the damp woods.
Our peach and aqua room on the 19th floor, which had two queen-sized beds, pale wood furniture and marble sinks, overlooked MGM Studios to the right and Epcot to the left. The Dolphin has four choices for swimming -- a lap pool, a wading pool, a large pool with bridges and a swim-under waterfall and waterslide and a beach on the lagoon. There we could rent pontoon chairs, pedal boats and small sailboats.
We had lunch at an outdoor cafe, where things like pizza in a frisbee are served by lithe blonde waitresses wearing bikinis and tiny sarongs. The staff throughout the complex is young and good-looking, and seems to have been chosen partly on the basis of appearance. (In the Magic Kingdom, for example, the Tom Sawyer's raft drivers tended to be tow-headed and as aw-shucks cute as the young Ron Howard). Ethnic diversity among the staff seems not to be part of the Disney vision.
The proximity to MGM Studios was so easy that we went in the late afternoon, avoiding the crowds for the popular Indiana Jones show, and again first thing the next morning.
Dolphin Hotel, (800) 227-1500 or (407) 934-4000, opened in 1990, 1,514 rooms, $219 to $238; from Dec. 20, $229 to $299. Its sister hotel is the Swan, operated by Westin. Tram and water ferry service to MGM Studios; bus service to Magic Kingdom. 
 
Contemporary Resort
Our next stop was the Contemporary, once the most famous hotel in Disney World. Like so many once "futuristic" Disney concepts, the Contemporary today evokes nothing so much as the late Eisenhower Administration. A giant A-frame structure, with rooms fitted into each side, the hotel has a monorail line boring right through the lobby. It also has something of an attitude. As we were checking in, the man ahead of us, checking out, complained about the noise in an adjoining room. I asked the clerk if the hotel was noisy. "We're not going to get anxious about that already, are we?" he said, fixing me with a firm look.
I asked for a room on a high floor so we would have a great view of the fireworks that light up the night over the amusement parks. Our room was a disappointment, not worth the $275 we paid. A king-size bed, studio couch and worn sofa all needed sprucing up, and the rug was quite worn. The terrace had settled so that a 12-inch puddle formed in the center after the day's rain, and one of the tubular chairs was broken.
But the view of the fireworks was great. Chris ordered a pizza and watched from the terrace, while we went to "Broadway at the Top," a professionally done, agreeable revue of show tunes performed by a six-piece band and five singers. And before dinner, seated at the bar with picture windows overlooking the amusement parks, we had the hoped-for view. The food was standard nightclub fare, but prepared with care. The salad, our waitress said, was made with hydroponically grown bibb lettuce raised in a display at Epcot Center -- a rather poignant tribute to the original vision of Walt Disney, who had hoped Epcot would become an environmentally innovative working community rather than the permanent World's Fair that it is.
Service in the hotel itself was brusque. When our room service breakfast the next morning arrived half an hour late without milk for the cereal, the waiter threw the deadbolt on our door so that it would remain ajar as he left. "This way, I don't have to knock when I come back," he announced as Chris and I sat eating while my husband was in the shower. On two other occasions that morning,maids strolled in without knocking.
Contemporary Resort, (407) 824-1000, opened in 1971, 1,053 rooms, $180 to $435 a night; from Dec. 20, $190 to $435. 
 
Dixie Landings
By the time we got to Dixie Landings the next day, we were grateful for the privacy, as well as the reasonable price. An immense motel complex with an attractive central public area, Dixie Landings and its counterpart, Port Orleans, are the newest resorts in Disney World. Our room was in one of eight buildings designed to look a little like Louisiana antebellum mansions.
Our room, which overlooked the pool, had two double beds and plenty of feather pillows, but we missed having a refrigerator. Besides the price, at $104 a night, we found several advantages to staying here. There is a swimming pool, attractively designed, between each building, and a large central pool for children, as well as a water slide and small playground, together with a well-stocked fishing hole and bike rental station. Chris rented a bike for $2 an hour and spent hours happily circling the complex on wide walkways. We all rode the free water ferry through winding rivers to the Disney entertainment complex, Pleasure Island, where we looked into a couple of the bars, including one that seemed to be modeled after the Explorers Club in New York, complete with mounted heads.
Another advantage to staying at Dixie Landings, particularly compared with the Caribbean Beach Resort, was the availability of both a full-service restaurant that serves Cajun food and a cafeteria food court serving all meals. Though the complex was full, the pools were not crowded, and we had an easy time making dinner reservations. We had learned that Disney restaurant portions tend to be large, so the three us of shared two entrees and salad.
The next day, we decided to try the last item on our pass, a water facility called Typhoon Lagoon. Its main attraction is a huge wave pool, capable of generating an eight-foot wave. It did, but it was so crowded that we were concerned about injury.
Dixie Landings, (407) 934-6000, opened this summer, 2,048 rooms, $85 and $104 a night; from Dec. 20, $87 and $119. Its sister hotel, Port Orleans, has the iron grill balconies and floor to ceiling pastel shutters of the French Quarter. 
 
Vacation Club
Our last stop, the Vacation Club, looks like a high-rent suburban condominium complex. Our spacious two-room apartment had a separate Jacuzzi room and bathroom with walk-in shower, as well as a laundry room. The kitchen was fully equipped with good appliances, and Chris was delighted with the 30-inch television and V.C.R. in the living area, which had two pull-out couches. Our large balcony overlooked the river and a golf course fairway.
The Vacation Club units are rented like hotel rooms but also are promoted and sold on a time-share basis, though the only sign of that we saw was a couple of discreet brochures in our mailbox.
This was our last night, and we would have been happy to have stayed here all week. In fact, we didn't leave the complex that day, except for dinner. Had we called ahead, the staff would have stocked our refrigerator for a reasonable fee.
The difference between our less-expensive room at the Vacation Club and the room at the Contemporary was astonishing; we assumed that the 20-minute bus ride to the Magic Kingdom was the reason. Joe and Chris played tennis on a private court, while I read by the pool.
Ten days after we arrived, we had finally found a place to spend a relaxing vacation.
Vacation Club Suites, (407) 827-7700, opened in 1991, 197 units; $180 (studio) to $325 (two bedrooms); from Dec. 20, $190 to $340.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Carl Sommers

 BODY:

Round-the-World Air Fare
Q. Do airlines still offer round-the-world fares that allow a traveler to stop at several destinations for one flat price? -- L. Masone, New York, N.Y. 
 A. Some airlines, generally in conjunction with other carriers, do continue to offer such fares. British Airways, (800) 247-9297, for example, maintains a round-the-world desk. Tickets, good for a year, must be bought at least 14 days before the first flight. With a travel agent or ticket agent, a buyer works out an itinerary, which does not require dates for any but the first flight. There may be any number of stopovers, with no minimum or maximum stay, as long as stops are continuously in one direction. Passengers may make a total of five stops in the United States and Canada in addition to the first stop on entering North America. There is no charge for making dates for flights, for changing dates or for making one change in the routing. Subsequent route changes are $25.
There are several optional side-trip flights available along the way. For example, when passengers arrive in London, they may make round trips at no charge to other cities in Britain, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Switzerland, or for $128 to Austria, Denmark, Finland, Greece, Italy, Norway, Portugal, Spain or Sweden. Another option, out of North America, is to fly to the Cayman Islands, $175 round trip out of New York (the price varies by city), with a free flight to Cayman Brac. Those who arrive in Honolulu can make one free round trip to any of the other islands.
A British Airways trip, in conjunction with United, that makes the Pacific leg in the north (with choices of Japan, Hong Kong, and so on) is $2,570 in economy class, $3,618 business class and $5,020 first class. First-class passengers can fly the Concorde on the trans-Atlantic leg for $863, and business-class passengers can take it for $1,718. A South Pacific route (including Australia and New Zealand), with United and Qantas, is $3,274 in economy; $5,180 business class and $6,744 first class. The route also allows some stops in Africa.
 
Chelsea Flowers in America
 Q. You recently answered a reader's question about the Chelsea Flower Show in England. I have heard there is to be a Chelsea America Flower Show held in the United States. Is it associated with the one in England? -- Sandra J. Fusco-Walker, Kinnelon, N.J.
A. The Chelsea America Flower Shows in the United States are "patterned" after the Chelsea Flower Show in London, a spokesman for the Chelsea America Foundation says. But he notes that there is no formal relationship between the foundation and the Royal Horticultural Society, which runs the London show. Some of the show's advisors, including Stephen Bennett, the show director of the Royal Horticultural Society in England, have been involved with the Chelsea Flower Show in England.
Chelsea America Flower Shows will take place outdoors (with parts under tents) and will include model gardens, floral and cut flower displays and educational exhibits.
The first show will be held at Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., Feb. 6 to 9, 1993. It will take place on 40 acres on the former site of Marineland at the south end of Santa Monica Bay, in Los Angeles County. Information: (310) 648-6602.
The second will occur Feb. 20 to 23, at West Palm Beach, Fla., on 30 acres at the Vista Center of Palm Beach, on Okeechobee Boulevard at the West Palm beach exit of Florida's Turnpike. Information: (407) 793-7577. Both shows, which are planned as annual events, take place from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. and admission to each show is $10 a day. The organizers say admission is guaranteed, so buying tickets ahead of time is not necessary. However, tickets bought in advance in groups of 10 or more are $8.50; call (212) 207-1774.
The shows are likely to expand to other cities as well, the company spokesman says.

An Expo in Korea
 Q. Where will the next world exposition be held? -- Mary Greenwood, Key West, Fla.
A. The next world exposition will take place Aug. 7 to Nov. 7, 1993, in Taejon, Korea, about 100 miles south of Seoul. The theme of Taejon Expo '93,"The Challenge of a New Road to Development," addresses the problems of industrial development, such as the effort to maintain the environment and traditional culture while developing economically. Taejon, with nearby Taedok Science Town, has emerged as a Korean science and technology center. The exposition will use computer technology to present information on the grounds and also in airports, bus and train stations and at hotels and tourist information centers. It is unusual for the Bureau International des Expositions, the sanctioning organization for world expositions, to allow an event two years in a row. The Korean exposition is sanctioned as an international exposition, which has a narrower focus than a universal exposition such as the Seville event. More information: Korea National Tourist Office, 2 Executive Drive, Seventh Floor, Fort Lee, N.J. 07024; (201) 585-0909.

HEADLINE: Focus: Philadelphia;
A Center for the Hispanic Community

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
A TWO-SQUARE-BLOCK area in the center of North Philadelphia's Hispanic community is being redeveloped to preserve its role as an economic and cultural hub.
The site, near Fifth Street and Lehigh Avenue, used to house St. Christopher's Hospital for Children. It has been dark nearly two years. Construction is scheduled to begin by year's end on a $20 million, 250,000-square-foot complex with housing, municipal and social services and educational facilities. 
 Knitting and textile mills were once the primary employers in this industrial area dating to the 1870's. Most of the mills now are silent, but when St. Christopher's closed its Lehigh Avenue complex two years ago and moved to a new facility at Front Street and Erie Avenue, hospital officials hoped to restore the area's lost vitality.
The officials got proposals from several developers, choosing to sell the site to Canus Corporation of nearby Manayunk, whose plan includes social service facilities, housing and public meeting space.
Of the total cost, about $4 million will come from state, local and Federal agencies, with the restexpected from bond sales and private investors, who will be eligible for low-income-housing tax credits. The project will create a community center at the crossroads of the city's most concentrated Hispanic population. This, it is hoped, will lure independent real estate development, said Susan Rabinovitch, Canus's president.
In all, the Lehigh Park Center project includes 90,000 square feet in one building redeveloped for a nursing home; 41,000 square feet in another redeveloped building for offices of Congreso de Latinos Unidos, a social service agency; 80,000 square feet of housing in 29 rental apartments for low-income families in a variety of apartment and rowhouse buildings and 17 units in rowhouses on as many sites to be developed by a local nonprofit housing development corporation.
There also will be 21,000 square feet for a business and vocational training center and 15,000 for a municipal "mini city hall" and educational facilities.
The corner of Fifth and Lehigh is called "El Bloque de Oro" -- The Golden Block -- because of its many businesses, cultural and community groups.
Ms. Rabinovitch said the area had all the ingredients needed for successful grass-roots economic development.
"I don't know of another project in the city that brings all these parts together and all the different types of financing," she said. "Here was an urban renewal problem waiting to happen. But if I had to pick a community with hard-working people who'll raise their kids there, it would be here."
She said saw the site's potential 14 years ago on a visit from Montreal when her husband, Hyman, was interviewed at St. Christopher's, where he still works as a surgeon.
In addition to the construction jobs, Ms. Rabinovitch saw Lehigh Park Center as a way to replace some 300 workers who relocated with the hospital and to bring in other needed jobs or services. In particular, she said, the area has a severe shortage of nursing home beds.
Canus has done similar projects before, combining neighborhood restoration with self-sustaining economic activity. In the Powelton Village neighborhood, next to Drexel University in West Philadelphia, it developed a block of shops with apartments above in the 3600 block of Lancaster Avenue.
In 1988, when St. Christopher's Hospital announced plans to move 14 blocks from where it was founded, hospital officials recognized a duty to reuse the disparate buildings they had outgrown, said Gretchen Sennott, a hospital spokeswoman. They considered several plans, but chose to sell the site to Canus for $2.5 million.
In addition to larger industrial buildings, the hospital had used several rowhouses as doctors' offices.
"We had a strong commitment to the community and community leaders felt strongly that the creation of more abandoned buildings in North Philadelphia was a problem," Ms. Sennott said. "While the buildings were difficult to administer in a hospital setting because they're separate, they're easier to use in a multiple-use redevelopment."
ST. CHRISTOPHER'S is one of the oldest pediatric hospitals in the country and some of its buildings date to its founding before the turn of the century, Ms. Sennott said.
Now its buildings look much like other graffiti-covered red-brick plants in the area that date to the Industrial Revolution. One architectural exception is a white-brick, two-story city library fronting for a full block on Lehigh Avenue; it, too, is scarred by graffiti.
More than a dozen multi-story factories once produced textiles, carpeting, wagon wheels or yarns and were surrounded by the rowhouses and small apartment buildings for their employees.
Many are in dilapidated condition yet stand side-by-side with homes covered in colorful siding with tidy front yards or pocket gardens.
While Philadelphia's total population shrank from 1.7 million in 1980 to 1.6 million in 1990, its Hispanic total -- primarily from Puerto Rico -- grew in that same period, from 63,570 to 89,193. The overwhelming majority of the city's Hispanic residents live within a mile of the Golden Block, according to census data.
In 1995, political redistricting of the city will yield a City Council district that is 26 percent Hispanic. Angel Ortiz, who pressed for the creation of the district, is currently the only Hispanic member of the Council, but he is an at-large member, as opposed to a district representative.
Alba Martinez is executive director of Congreso de Latinos Unidos, a social service agency for the Hispanic community. She said the headquarters at Lehigh Park Center would create a more visible identity for the organization.
"It would be for us a dream come true to centralize all our programs under one roof," she said. "We could be more efficient and effective and it would allow us to do more with less."
The group currently has 26 programs operating in five sites throughout the city providing drug, alcohol and AIDS awareness efforts and counseling plus after-school activities. Its $3 million annual budget allows for only $90,000 a year in rent, Ms. Martinez said. The rest of its rent in the Lehigh Park building will come from a $1 million Federal grant obtained this fall.
"ANY developer that comes into a neighborhood to work with social service agencies is aware of their precarious financial situation," Ms. Martinez said. "But we're being conservative."
The city also has a Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, which has developed a small business loan fund to assist minority business start-ups. Several banks have committed a total of $1 million to the fund, said Gualberto Medina, the chamber's president. Mellon Bank/PSFS is among the private lenders involved in the loan fund and in financing Lehigh Park Center.
Jim Dever, a bank spokesman, said the bank had so far committed a $500,000 loan for the project.
Mellon/PSFS is among several banks approached by Canus, but it has no branches in the immediate area. Indeed, there are no major bank facilities at the heart of Fifth and Lehigh. It took a community protest in nearby Kensington to get Fidelity Bank not to close its offices about a mile from the Lehigh Park Center site.
Another bank, Provident National Bank, is looking for ways to bring banking service to the neighborhood. It was also a lender to Canus for Lehigh Park Center, said Don Kelly, the bank's community reinvestment manager.
"The need has gotten greater and greater because of the conditions there and because of the structural changes in the economy and the recession," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Graffiti mar buildings at former St. Christopher's Hospital, to be renovated as a neighborhood hub. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2038 words

HEADLINE: What's in Store For the West Side

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
ON the west side of lower West End Avenue, a scrubby and uninhabited quarter of abandoned rail yards, parking lots, rubbish heaps and a service station, an entirely new neighborhood is being planned with enough room for 14,650 residents and a variety of impacts that will be felt citywide.
As a focal point, this new neighborhood might have something akin to a town square: a privately owned, one-acre park between 63d and 64th Streets where three enormous developments converge. The park is part of Daniel Brodsky's Manhattan West proposal, whose 38-story towers would border it on the south. A twin-towered, 41-story apartment building, one of 16 in Donald J. Trump's Riverside South project, would rise to the west. Over the north end of the park would be the 39-story apartment towers of a residential and studio complex proposed by Capital Cities/ ABC. 
 "What we're talking about, with these proposals put together, is the development of a new community," said Richard L. Schaffer, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "It's a community that will complete the western edge of the Upper West Side."
Should all the projects get built, the transformation would be astonishing. Riverside South alone might have from 11,030 to 11,350 residents by the year 2002, added to 1,700 residents in Manhattan West and 1,600 residents on the ABC site. More people would live in these projects alone than now live in the area from Central Park to the Hudson River, 58th to 66th Street.
Local leaders, city officials and private planners are struggling to measure and mitigate the impacts of these projects. These negotiations reveal the broad concern over development at that scale.
Directly or indirectly, the impacts of Riverside South might be felt at a sewage plant in Harlem, a rail yard in the Bronx and television studios in Queens. With the other projects, it would add hundreds of students to crowded elementary schools and thousands of riders to crowded subway stations.
Although the three projects abut one another, they have come through the city review procedure at different times. And that is one of many things that frustrated the neighbors in dealing with the proposals.
"I'm very dismayed by the process, by the inability to consider the cumulative effect of all this building," said Councilwoman Ronnie Eldridge, a Democrat who represents the area. "It seems to me that the role of city government should be to plan. We don't plan. We process applications."
IN 1990, the Board of Estimate approved Manhattan West, between 61st and 64th Streets. This 900,000-square-foot development would include 1,000 apartments and a park at the north end.
On Dec. 17, the City Council is to vote on Riverside South, a 7.9 million-square-foot development on the abandoned Penn Yards, from 59th to 72d Street, which would have as its civic centerpiece a waterfront park ranging from 15.8 to 21.5 acres. ABC's plan for a 1.2 million-square-foot project between 64th and 65th Streets is now being considered by Community Board 7, after which it will be reviewed by Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, the City Planning Commission and, finally, the Council.
ABC has proposed an L-shaped apartment structure on the northwest corner of West End Avenue and 64th Street, with three towers and 937 units. It would adjoin a 113-foot-high structure containing the new Studios 25 and 26, which would be linked to the existing Studios 23 and 24. There would also be a 350-space parking garage.
Residents of the development, which is to be finished in 1996, would be "relatively affluent" managers and professionals, mostly in their mid-20's to mid-40's, said the draft environmental impact statement prepared for ABC by the Manhattan firm of Allee King Rosen & Fleming.
According to the impact statement, the project "would likely increase" displacement pressures on as many as 978 people living nearby in single-room-occupancy hotels or in buildings with five apartments or fewer, which are not typically subject to rent regulation. However, the impact statement also noted that the pressures would exist without the ABC development.
Without any mitigation, traffic would grow significantly more congested along West End Avenue, from 57th to 72d Street, particularly in the morning rush hour, as well as at Central Park West and 65th Street. The project would also crowd the M104 bus on Broadway in the morning.
On the positive side, the impact statement said, the project would increase employment in the television and film industry, as well as related companies, such as those supplying lights and equipment. This would be "a much needed boost to the industry during lean times, as well as a gesture of confidence in New York City."
By ABC's calculations, the project would create 255 new jobs on the site: 100 in the production of a new daytime entertainment show and 155 in the apartment building, stores and garage. The complex would free existing studios for use by newly created news programs, according to ABC's impact statement, accounting for 200 more new jobs.
Building the project would create a year's worth of employment for about 3,720 people, principally construction workers and material suppliers, 70 percent of them living in New York City. Construction would also generate from $17 million to $20 million in tax revenues for the city and state.
"I think ABC has much to commend it as a project," Mr. Schaffer said, but "the residential component is too large."
Large as it is, the ABC development would be overshadowed by Riverside South, whose effects would be felt not only in other neighborhoods but also in other boroughs.
For example, the North River Water Pollution Control Plant, four miles away on the Harlem waterfront, has taken center stage in the debate over Riverside South, whose sewage might push the already strained and odor-filled plant beyond its capacity.
"If the capacity is reached and you have no other place to put the sewage, you're not going to be able to have any more hook-ups," said Councilman Stanley E. Michels, who represents upper Manhattan. "We would inhibit further development in the northern part of Manhattan."
North River has a permitted capacity of 170 million gallons a day of sewage. In August, the flow was 171 million gallons, according to the impact statement, but the 12-month average was 169.1 million gallons. Riverside South would generate 1.42 million gallons of sewage a day in 2002, by which time conservation measures are supposed to have reduced the overall flow.
Under a restrictive declaration signed by Mr. Trump, Riverside South buildings cannot be hooked up to the North River plant unless the chairman of the City Planning Commission certifies that the sewage will not cause the plant to exceed allowable capacity. Alternatives include the construction of a sewage plant at Riverside South or a pumping station that would send Riverside South's sewage to a plant on Ward's Island.
Another example of the potentially far-reaching consequences of Riverside South involves the television studio proposed at its south end. Council members worried that the creation of a huge new studio in Manhattan might undercut efforts to promote the existing Kaufman-Astoria and Silvercup studios in Astoria and Long Island City, Queens.
ALTHOUGH the Council did not eliminate the Riverside South studio, it required Mr. Trump to come back for a special permit in order to build it. "The reality is we stopped the studio," said Peg Breen, the spokeswoman for Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone of Queens. "The likelihood is that economics will dictate that the studio never be proposed and the reality is that whatever is proposed will be modified by the time it goes through the process."
The Bronx would also feel the effects of Riverside South. Because Mr. Trump's development would foreclose any possibility of reusing the Penn Yards as a rail freight terminal, its construction would increase the strategic importance of the Harlem River Rail Yard in the South Bronx. As part of the restrictive declaration, Mr. Trump is to provide $7 million to the city for capital improvements at the Bronx yards.
More general economic benefits, as outlined by the impact statement, would include $220 million in tax revenues generated by construction of the project. Riverside South would create enough work to employ 27,000 people for one year or 2,700 people for 10 years, the expected construction period.
Its most tangible and enduring benefit for the public would be the creation of a public park along the Hudson River. This would be 21.5 acres if the West Side Highway is relocated from the shoreline viaduct on which it now runs to a curving, inland route. If the highway stays in place, the park would be 17.5 acres. The park could lose another 1.7 acres if the development of pier space is not approved by the Army Corps of Engineers.
The impact statement discloses that if the highway were to stay in place, noise levels in the park "would be higher than those generally recommended for outdoor activities." If it is moved, the amount of noise would be "comparable" to that in existing parks adjacent to major roadways.
Among the finer points covered by the impact statement is the fact that small portions of the site along the original shoreline may have been used by Indians as summer fishing camps and that there may be undisturbed "evidence of prehistoric occupation," such as shell piles, known as middens.
The environmental impact statement, prepared for Mr. Trump by Allee King Rosen & Fleming, also includes these findings:
* Riverside South might add 844 students to the public schools. Of these, up to 430 children would be of elementary-school age, "significantly exacerbating" overcrowding. Mr. Trump has agreed to provide space on site, for sale or lease to the Board of Education, to accommodate 600 students.
* It would add as many as 3,600 riders to the subway system at rush hour and nearly 1,500 riders at mid-day. Mr. Trump has agreed to contribute $10 million toward the construction of a new headhouse and stairs at the 72d Street IRT station and $2 million for a new stairway at 66th Street.
* It might hasten the displacement of up to 960 people who live in small apartment houses and single-room-occupancy hotels nearby. But Mr. Trump has agreed to set aside at least 12 percent and as much as 20 percent of the housing for lower-income families and this "may provide housing opportunities for those persons."
RIVERSIDE SOUTH was rejected by Community Board 7 but approved, with modifications, by Ms. Messinger; by the City Planning Commission, unanimously, and by the Council's Land Use Committee, 12-to-2.
Because they fail largely to address the key question of overall density, the modifications and mitigations have not done much to placate Riverside South's critics, who have long maintained that Mr. Trump's project should be no larger than the 7.3 million-square-foot Lincoln West proposal, which was approved for the same site by the Board of Estimate 10 years ago.
The chairwoman of the community board, Hope L. Mason, said: "What each player, except for the Community Board, has done is to pick out those elements of the project that are palatable to a certain degeree and leave the harder issues -- in particular, the issue of density -- to the next participant."
"The buck doesn't stop with anyone," Ms. Mason added.
But Mr. Schaffer said the process had resulted in a "very reasonable package," with key concessions on sewage, subway stations and park development.
Rather than contrast Riverside South to Lincoln West, Mr. Schaffer compared its density to that of the nearby community, saying that both had approximately 100 dwelling units an acre.
"I think it's entirely consistent with the built fabric of the Upper West Side," he said. "What people aren't used to is seeing a 56-acre site developed."
Since the Riverside South impact statement presumes a 10-year construction period, he said, it accounts for the effects of the Manhattan West and ABC developments, which are to be completed earlier.
"I think the far West Side can sustain the population of the new community," he said.
