HEADLINE: Delegation Gains Edge on Capitol Hill

BYLINE: States News Service

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NOT since Harry S. Truman's 1948 campaign to clean up Capitol Hill has the United States Congress hemorrhaged so badly: This year the House of Representatives alone lost one quarter of its members. A total of 123 Congressmen either were beaten or retired, many choosing to quit rather than face a backlash from an electorate chafing at news of proliferating scandal and a deepening recession.
But Connecticut voters resisted the anti-incumbency tide sweeping the rest of the country, sending back to Washington a fully intact delegation. In an institution where the parameters of power are defined by seniority, this could give Connecticut an edge over other state delegations, many of which will see their strength diluted by freshmen legislators. 
 The Connecticut delegation is looking at the kind of clout in the House and the Senate that it had in late 1970's when former Representative Robert N. Giaimo and Senators Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Abraham A. Ribicoff presided over some of the most influential committees and subcommittees in Congress.
"I think the delegation is poised to be more powerful than it's been in a long, long time," said former Representative Toby Moffett, who now works for the Wexler Group, a lobbying firm in Washington.
The combination of enhanced seniority, personal access to the White House, and the likely election of Connecticut's more experienced members to major committees and leadership positions, should bring the state power in the Democratic-controlled Congress that far exceeds its modest size.
 
Rewards for Early Clinton Backers
 "We have some great opportunities with seniority in our delegation and ties to a new Administration," said Democratic Representative Rosa L. DeLauro of New Haven, who is returning for her second term. Ms. DeLauro and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of New Haven were among the first members of Congress to publicly support the Clinton bid for the Presidency.
Ms. DeLauro and her husband, Stan Greenberg, one of President-elect Bill Clinton's closest campaign advisors who is poised to play a high-profile role in his Administration, are considered two of Connecticut's best assets going into the 103d Congress.
"It's an intangible measurement but it will be extremely important to the state to have that duo covering both the legislative and the executive in a crunch," Mr. Moffett said.
Congressional staff members already have stamped Ms. DeLauro and Mr. Greenberg as personae grata with members of the vanguard political elite. As one Congressional aide put it, "You know they're going to be dining at the White House."
Mr. Lieberman will also enhance the state's position in Washington with his ties to the new Administration. The Senator has been an assiduous campaigner for the President-elect, who is an old friend and colleague from their law school days at Yale. Mr. Clinton, who worked on Mr. Lieberman's first State Senate campaign in New Haven, already has consulted with Mr. Lieberman on a range of issues, from the conflict in Yugoslavia to an economic recovery program.
 
Friends in High Places
 "I look forward to having a friend in the White House," Mr. Lieberman said. "It will give me an opportunity to do a lot more for the state. I will be able to gain access when we need it if there is a special problem. We will at least get a hearing.
"We in Connecticut will benefit more from his Administration than other places," the Senator added, "because we are more in need and also have a skilled work force, too much of which is out of work."
Mr. Lieberman's background on environmental issues in the Senate also places him in a natural position to work with Vice President-elect Al Gore on his top priority: integrating environmentalism with economic development.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of East Haddam, will move up in his committees, although with 12 years in the Senate, he has already established seniority and considerable power as the chairman of three subcommittees in the Foreign Relations, Banking and Children's Committees. One of Mr. Clinton's top priorities, according to campaign aides, will be Mr. Dodd's family-leave bill, which is expected to be one of the first to make it into law in the next session of Congress.
 
A Patchy Seniority Record
 Unlike states such as Massachusetts that have had lawmakers serving for a quarter of a century and longer, Connecticut has a patchy record of building seniority in Congress. Since Congressman Giaimo and Senator Ribicoff served for 22 years, and Governor Weicker for 20 years, no member from Connecticut has served more than a dozen years.
During that earlier period, the Connecticut delegation boasted chairmen of the House Budget Committee, Senate Governmental Affairs Committee and Senate Small Business Committee.
"What kills us is that lawmakers go on to run for other offices," said Howard Reiter, professor of political science at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. "They go on to run for Senator and Governor, so Connecticut has not stacked up on seniority very well," he said, noting the cases of former Representatives Bruce A. Morrison and John G. Rowland, who ran unsuccessfully for Governor in 1990.
The greatest gain in seniority this year will be in the House, where Democratic Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Hartford will move up seven places on the influential Ways and Means Committee and will likely retain her current position as the House Chief Deputy Whip, the only woman in the Congressional leadership.
Mrs. Kennelly's seniority on the tax-writing committee also all but guarantees her a joint appointment to the Budget Committee, another pre-eminent panel. Mrs. Kennelly said she would work to secure programs like heating oil subsidies, which were crucial for the state.
 
In Line for a Chairmanship
 Democratic Representative Sam Gejdenson of Bozrah, who narrowly survived one of this year's tightest races, will move into the second spot on the Foreign Affairs Committee. If the committee's chairman, Lee Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, moves to the Clinton Administration, as some politicians believe, Mr. Gejdenson would be in line to be chairman.
Mr. Gejdenson, the delegation's longest serving House member who is beginning his seventh term, has become a high-profile member of the House having led the campaign finance reform movement last session as well as directing the re-election bid of Representative Tom Foley of Washington as Speaker of the House.
Mr. Gejdenson, who also came to Mr. Foley's aid when the Speaker was reeling from the recent House Bank scandal, said that it took him years to get to the point where he could push his own legislative agenda. "I spent my first eight years here hoeing in the back fields," he said.
Unlike most members, Mr. Gejdenson has excellent access to the Speaker, who decides which bills live and die. "No one in the world is closer to Foley," Mr. Moffett observed. During the waning hours of the 102d Congress, for example, Mr. Gejdenson dropped by Mr. Foley's office half a dozen times in a successful attempt to get two of his bills -- a jobs-for-exports bill and one to protect whistle blowers at nuclear sites -- to the floor for a vote.
 
Coveted Seats Up for Grabs
 But even Connecticut's neophyte members will probably benefit from the losses suffered by the larger states. Almost every large and mid-size state lost veteran members, who had been sitting on the major committees for decades.
Ms. DeLauro, for example, is the leading Democratic contender for a spot on the Appropriations Committee, the panel that doles out money for everything from highway projects to medical research. Even though the Congresswoman is only going into her second term, there is an unprecedented number of openings on the committee -- 13 -- making it possible for her to be considered.
Not since the days of former Representative William R. Ratchford, Democrat of Danbury, and Senator Weicker has Connecticut had representation on the Appropriations Committee.
"It's been a very long, dry period for Connecticut," said Mrs. Kennelly. Both Mr. Gejdenson and Mrs. Kennelly, who sit on the panel that decides committee assignments, have worked hard to secure Ms. DeLauro a spot.
Assignments, which will be handed out before the end of the year, are based on votes on the Democratic side by the Steering and Policy Committee, and on the Republican side by the Committee on Committees. Members of each committee have the final say on assignments and it is up to the individual legislators to lobby these members, who base their votes on seniority, geography, personal qualifications and political connections.
Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Stamford, also is trying for a spot on the Appropriations Committee. This will be his second run for the assignment and he says he has persuaded the Committee on Committees that New England needs representation. There are no other members from the New England region bidding for the spot, which puts Mr. Shays in a strong position.
"We would be thrilled to have a member of the delegation on Appropriations, where some of the most important decisions are made," said Terry Muelenberg, director of Governor Weicker's staff in Washington. "The states that do best are those sitting at the table."
Ms. Muelenberg said that Connecticut would have a better chance to fulfill its wish list of favored projects which the state office gives to the delegation every session. On the tentative list for the next session are hundreds of millions of dollars for the highway and transportation fund, energy assistance and defense conversion programs.
 
Republicans Jockey for Positions
 With the Democratic-controlled Congress and White House, Republicans will play a diminished role, although they too will benefit from seniority. Representative Gary Franks, Republican of Waterbury, is lobbying for a seat on the Energy and Commerce Committee. Mr. Franks also is slated to move up in seniority on the Armed Services and Small Business Committees, although he would have to relinquish his seat on these committees if he secures a seat on Energy and Commerce.
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of New Britain, may follow her Democratic colleague Mrs. Kennelly into a leadership position. Mrs. Johnson, who also moves up in seniority on the Ways and Means Committee, is running for the position of vice chairman of the Republican Conference, the leading Republican group in the House.
Mrs. Johnson is lobbying her colleagues for votes and, with the support of Minority Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia, she has a good chance, according to House Republicans. Mrs. Johnson helped shore up moderate votes for Mr. Gingrich when he ran for whip.
"She's gained a great deal of respect for her leadership already," said Representative Dean Gallo, Republican of New Jersey, who is working for her election. "Her involvement, expertise and tenacity to get resolutions all bode well for her."
Tony Blankley, press secretary for Mr. Gingrich, put it more succinctly: "She's no shrinking violet. And we don't have as many women in our conference as we would like."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: Readers' Questions;
A Converted Orphanage, and a Stickley Connection?

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
This is another in a series of columns answering questions from readers about New York's changing streetscapes.
 
402 East 90th Street
 Q. We live in a condominium at 402 East 90th Street, converted about nine years ago from an old building. I've been told it was once a convent with land and gardens extending almost to the East River. Can you tell me about the building? . . . Ruth J. Natinsky, Manhattan. 
 A. Before reconstruction into apartments, your building was used as a garage but it was indeed built as part of an orphan asylum.
St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum was founded in 1857 for the care of Roman Catholic orphans of German origin.
The asylum built various structures on the block bounded by 89th and 90th Streets, First Avenue and York Avenue, and 402 East 90th Street was built in 1898.
Designed by A.F.A. Schmitt, the large brick building was apparently used as a church. Facing 90th Street, it has a facade similar to a power plant or warehouse, but the principal, eastern facade -- originally facing the orphan asylum grounds -- has a curious temple front, which is still largely intact. The orphanage was operated by the Sisters of Notre Dame.
In 1918, the building was converted to a garage.
In the 1970's, there were several plans filed with the Department of Buildings to convert the building to tennis or squash courts but it appears that these were not carried out and that the building was converted to apartments by adding several stories in 1986 in a conversion that, incidentally, preserved some of the original facades.
 
6 East 39th Street
 Q. I am trustee of the Craftsman Farms Foundation, which operates the farm and residence of Gustav Stickley, the furniture designer, in Parsippany, N.J. We have frequent inquiries about the Craftsman Building at 6 East 39th Street in New York City. Did Stickley build it? The story has it that his acquisition of the building caused his bankruptcy in 1915. . . . Muriel F. Berson, Mountain Lakes, N.J.
A. The 12-story loft appears to be a conventional speculative building. It was built in 1912 by the estate of Henry Cram and designed by Schwartz & Gross, active commercial architects.
Stickley's firm moved in soon after completion and indeed took the whole building. But it appears he did not actually own it -- bankruptcy proceedings in 1915 described the chief assets of the firm but do not mention any real estate.
 
Labor Temple
 Q. There is a building called Labor Temple on East 14th Street used by church groups in the late 1940's. I'm interested in its history and architect. . . . Femmy Lundstrom, Woodbury, L.I.
A. Labor Temple was established as a center for the working classes in the old 14th Street Presbyterian Church at the southwest corner of 14th Street and Second Avenue in 1910 by the Rev. Charles Stelzle, once a machinist. The church was demolished in 1924 but a professional developer agreed to build space on the site for the Labor Temple in exchange for control over the store's apartments and other offices in the six-story Romanesque-style building.
Designed by Emery Roth -- known for his high-rise apartment houses like the San Remo -- the $750,000 building contained an auditorium, gym, chapel, roof playground and other spaces.
The Rev. Edmund B. Chaffee, the director at the time of opening, described the mission of the Labor Temple as the study of "the great industrial and social problems that face modern society."
 
101 West 86th Street
 Q. My great-grandfather, Joseph Silk, lived at 101 West 86th Street in 1912. How old was it in that year? . . . Judith Sylk-Siegel, Manhattan.
A. This structure, at the northwest corner of Columbus Avenue, was built as the Ormonde in 1886-87. It was designed and owned by John G. Prague, an architect very active in opening up the West Side.
Joseph Silk, a fruit merchant who moved from 30 West 65th Street in 1908, is shown in the 1910 census here with a household of eight people. Those in your immediate family line were your great-grandfather, 63 years old, and his daughter (your grandmother), Hannah Siegel, 35.
The five-story Ormonde, which has stores on the ground floor, originally had half-floor apartments and was considered a "flat," midway between a tenement and a luxury apartment house. It has since been reconstructed within to add many more apartments.
 
565 West 169th Street
 Q. I am not sure when my co-op apartment house on the east side of Broadway from 169th to 170th Street was originally built, but the stock certificates refer to its incorporation in 1921.
Older residents of this six-story structure contend that it was the very first such venture ever built. Is this true? . . . Emmanuel Lemakis, Manhattan.
A. No. The building application for your complex, Woodrow Court at 565 West 169th Street, indicates a construction date of 1917-1918. It was built for the 169th Corporation of which the principal was Jacob Axelrod, of 200 West 72d Street. Axelrod was known as an active rental apartment house builder; his architect was George F. Pelham.
It is difficult to determine Axelrod's intention for Woodrow Court, but it was sold six times between its completion and August 1920, when it was acquired by "Woodrow Court Inc.," the co-op corporation. None of the owners were active, identified co-op builders or converters in this period.
The first co-ops were built in the 1880's with a revival just after 1900, but these were uniformly aimed at luxury tenants. Inflation after World War I drove up rents in Manhattan and for a few years there was a flurry of middle-income co-op activity, of which Woodrow Court is an example.
It is possible it was conceived as a co-op, but the delayed transfer suggests it was really a conversion by a subsequent owner. The 1925 census lists its residents as about half native-born, with occupations like bookkeeper, shoe salesman and accountant.

GRAPHIC: Photos: St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum, circa 1900, 90th Street and First Avenue. (St. Joseph's Church Archives); The Labor Temple at 14th Street and Second Avenue in 1949. (Office for Metropolitan History); Woodrow Court, an early co-op, at 565 West 169th Street, 1943. (Office for Metropolitan History)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 5; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Flip Tax on an Inheritance
 
Question: A co-op apartment was left to me and my sister by my mother, who died two years ago. The apartment passed into my mother's estate, to which my sister and I are sole heirs. 
 The managing agent for the co-op maintains that while the estate may own the apartment and must pay the maintenance, the heirs may not occupy the apartment unless they pay a flip tax of $20,000. We believe the current market value is about $120,000 to $140,000. It seems to me that the imposition of this large fee -- 15 percent -- when no sale is involved is questionable. Does the flip tax apply? . . . Carol Williams, Stamford, Conn.
 
Answer: Probably not. According to Brook Boyd, a lawyer with the firm of Herrick, Feinstein in Manhattan, if the co-op's documents were standard it would be unusual for the flip tax to be triggered by mere occupancy of the apartment. But from a practical standpoint, the co-op has substantial leverage when it come to occupancy and rules regarding flip taxes.
"It would depend on the specific language in the proprietary lease or the offering plan," Mr. Boyd said. "If the flip tax applies only to a sale, then the inheritance of the apartment should not be subject to a flip tax."
The so-called flip tax, which is not a tax but a transfer fee on the sale of shares, has been upheld in New York State courts as a legitimate way for co-ops to raise money. The corporation's board has the right to determine the amount of the fee and how it is imposed.
You should refer to the co-op's documents for specific references to how flip taxes are applied and may want to want to consult a lawyer specializing in co-op law.
 
Refinancing in a Co-op
 
Question: Our building has 250 apartments and is dominated by the sponsor. When I became a shareholder about five years ago, the co-op had a $3.147 million mortgage. It was replaced with a five-year mortgage of $3.792 million. I am told that another mortgage will be taken for $4 million. I never feel comfortable with the verbal explanation of why almost $1 million has been added to our debt in the past several years. The building needs work, but wouldn't a one-time assessment be more beneficial to shareholders? . . . Clarence Jones, Long Beach, L.I.
 
Answer: Maybe not. According to Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, sequential refinancing of the building's underlying mortgage during such a short period of time, is not necessarily a poor financial strategy.
"If each new mortgage has been taken at a lower interest rate," said Ms. Rothman, "it may have been prudent management of the building's debt."
Even with the increase in the loan size, if the interest rate drops were significant, the board may have been able to raise cash while maintaining or lowering the portion of the maintenance used to pay the mortgage.
However, your board should be willing to provide you and other shareholders with more than a verbal justification of its refinancing strategy. Co-op boards are obligated to provide shareholders with annual financial reports. You might suggest to the board that it include a discussion of its refinancing in this year's report.
 
Bothersome Smoke
 
Question: The building directly across from mine constantly belches smoke from its chimney, often right into my window. I have been told that I have no recourse because the smoke is usually white and white smoke is legal. It is smelly and gritty all the same. Is this true? . . . Stephanie Winston, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. According to Ian Michaels, a spokesman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection, the air pollution control code laws make no distinction between white smoke and smoke of any other color. Any visible smoke is prohibited. The use of incinerators is still legal in New York City, but their use will be banned in all residential and most commercial buildings after next June 30. The only legal use will be in connection with medical facilities. You can file a complaint by calling the agency's 24-hour hotline at (718) 699-9811, or write to the D.E.P. at 59-17 Junction Boulevard, Corona, Queens 11368.

LENGTH: 1611 words

HEADLINE: Wounded Waterbury: No Place to Go but Up

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN

 BODY:
IT is a Chamber of Commerce nightmare. There lies Waterbury, perched up and down on some hills in western Connecticut, still known as the Brass City though the big brass companies have all passed away, a community down on its luck that obviously could use a bit of encouragement.
So what happens? Money magazine, in its annual survey of the best and worst places to live, rated the city No. 300 out of the 300 largest metropolitan areas in the country. That's dead last, the end, the pits. Adding insult to injury is that it is the second straight year that Waterbury has attained the status of lowest of the low: 1991, No. 300; 1992, No. 300. 
 What the survey seems to have accomplished, in addition to angering the business and political establishments and ordinary citizens as well, is the urge to fight back.
The anger is mostly based on the contention by city leaders that the Money survey is unscientific and unfair, biased toward isolated cities of the Midwest and the Great Plains that have little relationship to the older cities of the crowded Northeast.
How, they ask, can a city like Sioux Falls, S.D. -- this year's No. 1 -- be compared with Waterbury, Conn.?
 
Industrial vs. Prairie Town
 Sioux Falls has a far more homogeneous population of 123,000 spread over a huge area by Eastern standards. "If we had that area, we could include Boston if we went one way or New York City if we went the other," commented Waterbury Mayor Edward D. Bergin. His city's population of 110,000 is tucked into about 28 square miles.
Waterbury has always been an industrial city while Sioux Falls is a prairie town currently enjoying prosperity as a center for back-office bank operations that were attracted to South Dakota because the state places no legal limits on usury.
Critics of the Money survey also charge that cities in states with big economic troubles, or with income taxes, do not fare well in the survey, an additional economic burden for Waterbury to bear.
"We have the highest unemployment rate in the state," said Frank D. Fulco, president of the Greater Waterbury Chamber of Commerce. Waterbury has an unemployment rate of about 14 percent while the rate Sioux Falls is 2.6 percent.
 
Bridgeport's Weather Better?
 Economics aside, Mr. Fulco said other aspects of the survey baffled him. One of the most puzzling was a category on the weather. He can understand why, for instance, Honolulu would be rated better for weather than Waterbury. But so was Bridgeport. Waterbury was given 18 points out of a possible 100 for weather. Bridgeport was given 28 points. "They've got different weather in Bridgeport than here?" he asked.
Richard Eisenberg, a senior editor of Money, denied that the survey had any geographical bias and he noted that five years ago, when the Northeast was booming, the No. 1 city for quality of life was Danbury, Conn. He said that he found "the difference" in weather between Waterbury and Bridgeport "an interesting question," but that the weather statistics were based on Government statistics and, to his understanding, even neighboring cities could have different weather patterns.
Regardless of how the Money survey was conducted, and its fairness or unfairness, this year's slur on Waterbury's name, following the indignity of last year, seems to have galvanized the old city.
A citywide forum, "Town Meeting for Tomorrow," is going to be held in February, to give residents a say in what direction the city should go, Mr. Fulco said. In addition, he said, the American Institute of Architects has given preliminary approval to a request for a team of architects and planners to study the city and make recommendations for its future.
 
$100 Million Shopping Center
 But the best bet for getting Waterbury out of its economic doldrums could be a $100 million shopping center planned for a 100-acre tract near downtown and along Interstate 84, which cuts through the city. The site is that of the old Scovill brass works where the brick ghosts and pollution of the city's manufacturing past must be cleared before the developers of the mall can come in.
The city's cost of clearing the land could run as high as $30 million, but Mayor Bergin said the city had a "novel approach" for obtaining some of the money. The idea is to have the Department of Defense participate in demolishing the buildings because the Defense Department, the Mayor noted, helped create the plants that provided materials like shell casings in World Wars I and II and, therefore, should help in taking them down.
But even if that approach does not work, he said, he is convinced the land will be cleared, the mall built and 3,000 jobs produced in a city that needs jobs.
 
Image From Interstate 84
 An added benefit of clearing away the Scovill mills, Mayor Bergin said, is that it would also clear away the image of Waterbury presented to motorists passing by on Interstate 84 or Route 8. In this, Mr. Fulco concurs: "People driving by see old factories, the image of a blue-collar town. 'It's dying,' that's what they say."
Waterbury even gets little respect from other cities in the state, Mr. Fulco added. "Radio and television stations, particularly the ones in Hartford and New Haven, don't even mention Waterbury when they give the weather," he said. "They mention the three biggest cities, Hartford, New Haven and Bridgeport, and then Danbury. But Danbury isn't the fourth biggest city in the state. We are."
As Mr. Fulco sees it, that and other slights have created sort of a municipal inferiority complex in Waterbury. Residents, he said, do not readily admit they come from Waterbury. "The enemy is us," he asserted. "We've got to change our image of ourselves."
 
Municipal Politics
 The level of city politics could be one reason why some residents don't broadcast where they live. Connecticut's most famous corruption case, in the era before World War II, was known, rightfully, as "The Waterbury Scandal," which involved the conviction and imprisonment of the city's Mayor, T. Frank Hayes, who was also the Lieutenant Governor of the state, and about two dozen cronies, for embezzling several million dollars from the city. Then, in June of this year, a former Mayor, Joseph J. Santopietro, was sent to prison for embezzlement. Even Mayor Bergin, whose long tenure was temporarily interrupted by a loss to Mr. Santopietro, was once indicted on charges of taking a bribe but was found not guilty. Politics in Waterbury is heady stuff.
Despite that, and despite the judgment of the Money survey, city officials and many others maintain that Waterbury is a fine place to live, a place of proud and hard-working people, with charming old business buildings of brick or brownstone, with the old-fashioned department store, Howland-Hughes, which dates back more than a century and specializes in the customer service once common in retail establishments before the chains took over.
"This is not a city of the very rich and the very poor," Mr. Fulco said. "It's middle-class American and we've maintained our middle class."
Mayor Bergin said Waterbury has not had the suburban flight that the three larger cities in the state have experienced. "Residents may have moved to other parts of town for better neighborhoods but they stayed in the city instead of fleeing to the suburbs," he said. "To people who live here, this is a good city."
 
827 Hotel Rooms, 300 Restaurants
 It is also a good city to people from the outside, said Jim Whitney, executive director of Waterbury Convention and Visitors Commission. He said he felt that the Money survey was "totally flawed" but it was not going to change his approach to attracting visitors. His boasting runs on: "We have 827 hotel rooms, more than Hartford. We have 300 restaurants. We have one of the prettiest greens in New England. We have accessibility. And the cost to stay here is 25 percent less than other cities in state."
These are people, of course, who are expected to say nice things about the city. Their jobs depend on the city. Not so though for a Roman Catholic nun who has become a Waterbury booster.
Sister Marguerite Waite, president and chief executive officer of St. Mary's Hospital, said she looked on the results of the Money survey as a lack of knowledge about Waterbury. It does not reflect the Waterbury she knows. "This is a nice city with wonderful health care and a symphony orchestra and a great museum," she said. "I think it's a great place to live. And the people here are special, who pull together."
If that kind of testimonial isn't enough, there are always the comments of a real outsider to consider.
 
Sioux Falls Disk Jockey
 His name is Kevin Flynn but in Sioux Falls, S.D., he is known as Maxx Boogie, the morning disk jockey for radio station KPAT.
After Sioux Falls was named the best city in the Money survey, Mr. Flynn thought it would be fun to hold a contest with first prize being a trip to Waterbury, "the First to the Worst." He arrived in Waterbury with the contest winner in tow and said both were delighted with what they discovered and how they were received -- dinner with the Mayor, an aerial foliage trip, a tour of the historical areas, riding the sightseeing trolley.
Back home in Sioux Falls, Mr. Flynn now sings the praises of Waterbury.
"What is Money magazine thinking of?" he asked, with some wonderment, on a recent day after his chores at the station were done. "Waterbury is a wonderful place. If we're No. 1, we've re-ranked Waterbury from No. 300 to No. 1 1/2. No, make that 1 1/8." Mr. Flynn is a real civic booster, for Waterbury.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
A Hispanic Center for North Philadelphia

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
A two-square-block area in the center of North Philadelphia's Hispanic community is being redeveloped to preserve its role as an economic and cultural hub.
The site, near Fifth Street and Lehigh Avenue, used to house St. Christopher's Hospital for Children. It has been dark nearly two years. Construction is scheduled to begin by year's end on a $20 million, 250,000-square-foot complex with housing, municipal and social services and educational facilities. 
 Knitting and textile mills were once the primary employers in this industrial area dating to the 1870's. Most of the mills now are silent, but when St. Christopher's closed its Lehigh Avenue complex two years ago and moved to a new facility at Front Street and Erie Avenue, hospital officials hoped to restore the area's lost vitality.
The officials got proposals from several developers, choosing to sell the site to Canus Corporation of nearby Manayunk, whose plan includes social service facilities, housing and public meeting space.
Of the total cost, about $4 million will come from state, local and Federal agencies, with the restexpected from bond sales and private investors, who will be eligible for low-income-housing tax credits. The project will create a community center at the crossroads of the city's most concentrated Hispanic population. This, it is hoped, will lure independent real estate development, said Susan Rabinovitch, Canus's president.
In all, the Lehigh Park Center project includes 90,000 square feet in one building redeveloped for a nursing home; 41,000 square feet in another redeveloped building for offices of Congreso de Latinos Unidos, a social service agency; 80,000 square feet of housing in 29 rental apartments for low-income families in a variety of apartment and rowhouse buildings and 17 units in rowhouses on as many sites to be developed by a local nonprofit housing development corporation.
There also will be 21,000 square feet for a business and vocational training center and 15,000 for a municipal "mini city hall" and educational facilities.
The corner of Fifth and Lehigh is called "El Bloque de Oro" -- The Golden Block -- because of its many businesses, cultural and community groups. Ms. Rabinovitch said the area had all the ingredients needed for successful grass-roots economic development.
"I don't know of another project in the city that brings all these parts together and all the different types of financing," she said. "Here was an urban renewal problem waiting to happen. But if I had to pick a community with hard-working people who'll raise their kids there, it would be here."
She said saw the site's potential 14 years ago on a visit from Montreal when her husband, Hyman, was interviewed at St. Christopher's, where he still works as a surgeon.
In addition to the construction jobs, Ms. Rabinovitch saw Lehigh Park Center as a way to replace some 300 workers who relocated with the hospital and to bring in other needed jobs or services. In particular, she said, the area has a severe shortage of nursing home beds.
Canus has done similar projects before, combining neighborhood restoration with self-sustaining economic activity. In the Powelton Village neighborhood, next to Drexel University in West Philadelphia, it developed a block of shops with apartments above in the 3600 block of Lancaster Avenue.
In 1988, when St. Christopher's Hospital announced plans to move 14 blocks from where it was founded, hospital officials recognized a duty to reuse the disparate buildings they had outgrown, said Gretchen Sennott, a hospital spokeswoman. They considered several plans, but chose to sell the site to Canus for $2.5 million. In addition to larger industrial buildings, the hospital had used several rowhouses as doctors' offices.
"We had a strong commitment to the community and community leaders felt strongly that the creation of more abandoned buildings in North Philadelphia was a problem," Ms. Sennott said. "While the buildings were difficult to administer in a hospital setting because they're separate, they're easier to use in a multiple-use redevelopment."
St. Christopher's is one of the oldest pediatric hospitals in the country and some of its buildings date to its founding before the turn of the century, Ms. Sennott said.
Now its buildings look much like other graffiti-covered red-brick plants in the area that date to the Industrial Revolution. One architectural exception is a white-brick, two-story city library fronting for a full block on Lehigh Avenue; it, too, is scarred by graffiti.
More than a dozen multi-story factories once produced textiles, carpeting, wagon wheels or yarns and were surrounded by the rowhouses and small apartment buildings for their employees. Many are in dilapidated condition yet stand side-by-side with homes covered in colorful siding with tidy front yards or pocket gardens.
While Philadelphia's total population shrank from 1.7 million in 1980 to 1.6 million in 1990, its Hispanic total -- primarily from Puerto Rico -- grew in that same period, from 63,570 to 89,193. The overwhelming majority of the city's Hispanic residents live within a mile of the Golden Block, according to census data.
In 1995, political redistricting of the city will yield a City Council district that is 26 percent Hispanic. Angel Ortiz, who pressed for the creation of the district, is currently the only Hispanic member of the Council, but he is an at-large member.
Alba Martinez is executive director of Congreso de Latinos Unidos, a social service agency for the Hispanic community. She said the headquarters at Lehigh Park Center would create a more visible identity for the organization.
"It would be for us a dream come true to centralize all our programs under one roof," she said. "We could be more efficient and effective and it would allow us to do more with less."
The group currently has 26 programs operating in five sites throughout the city providing drug, alcohol and AIDS awareness efforts and counseling plus after-school activities. Its $3 million annual budget allows for only $90,000 a year in rent, Ms. Martinez said. The rest of its rent in the Lehigh Park building will come from a $1 million Federal grant obtained this fall.
"Any developer that comes into a neighborhood to work with social service agencies is aware of their precarious financial situation," Ms. Martinez said. "But we're being conservative."
The city also has a Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, which has developed a small business loan fund to assist minority business start-ups. Several banks have committed a total of $1 million to the fund, said Gualberto Medina, the chamber's president. Mellon Bank/PSFS is among the private lenders involved in the loan fund and in financing Lehigh Park Center.
Jim Dever, a bank spokesman, said the bank had so far committed a $500,000 loan for the project.
Mellon/PSFS is among several banks approached by Canus, but it has no branches in the immediate area. Indeed, there are no major bank facilities at the heart of Fifth and Lehigh. It took a community protest in nearby Kensington to get Fidelity Bank not to close its offices about a mile from the Lehigh Park Center site.
Another bank, Provident National Bank, is looking for ways to bring banking service to the neighborhood. It was also a lender to Canus for Lehigh Park Center, said Don Kelly, the bank's community reinvestment manager.
"The need has gotten greater and greater because of the conditions there and because of the structural changes in the economy and the recession," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Graffiti mar buildings at former St. Christopher's Hospital, to be renovated as neighborhood hub. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Chinatown;
Beneath the Bustle, A Malaise Emerges

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
COMPARED to the rest of the city, Chinatown is booming. Rents are high, buildings are still going up, offices are still being leased.
What promises to be its largest restaurant ever, with a capacity of nearly 1,500, is scheduled to open on Elizabeth Street next year. And Chinatown long ago crossed its traditional Canal Street boundary, making ever deeper inroads into Little Italy. 
 But compared to itself scarcely two years ago, Chinatown is ailing. Its jewelry centers, where booths once commanded waiting lists, have "space available" signs in the windows. Its restaurants are suffering revolving-door ownership as restaurateurs discover diminished volume no longer supports high rents.
Storefronts on Canal and Mott, the main shopping streets, remain pretty well occupied, but local owners say some are in arrears on their rent. Stores that used to command $145 a foot now can be had for $100 or so. It no longer takes $100,000 in key money for a 10-year lease on Canal. And on secondary streets like Mulberry or East Broadway, no key money is needed at all.
"Retail space never used to go on the market here," said Stephen D. Dadourian, a managing director of D.G. Hart Associates Inc., which owns several Chinatown properties. "Tenants would sublet, there'd be key money. Now stores can sit for a month."
Office space, which generally rents for between $22 and $35 a foot, sits far longer than that. Even buildings offering the kind of luxury space that is almost impossible to find in this cramped, bustling downtown area are having a rough time.
No one expects the area's newest buildings -- Ka Wah Bank Ltd. of Hong Kong's 15-story Glory China Tower at 11 East Broadway, Chinese American Bank's 8-story building at 77 Bowery, and Bank of East Asia's 8-story building at Canal and Mulberry streets -- to be rented soon.
"With space in the World Financial Center at $26 a foot, it's not easy to woo triple-A tenants here," said Y.M. Yang, an executive vice president of Chinese American Bank.
Dashed hopes are rife. Three years ago, when the Chinese American Bank started construction, it expected to occupy five floors and rent out three. Now it will be happy to rent two floors. It has not hired a broker or aggressively sought tenants itself.
"We'd be lucky to get $100,000 in yearly rents, and after all the taxes we'd pocket half that," said Mr. Yang. "So sure, we'd like to find tenants, but right now we've got other things to devote our manpower to."
The picture is even bleaker regarding space targeted at jewelers. The New York Jewelers Exchange at 70 Bowery, once exclusively for jewelers, recently let space to a travel agent. Williamson, Pickett & Gross Inc.'s new building at Elizabeth and Hester Streets, built with ground-floor jewelry boutiques and upstairs apartments, is empty.
"I've put 'for rent' signs out for the first time in 25 years," said Irving R. Raber, a prominent Chinatown building manager. "And I've reduced rents as much as 25 percent for the jewelers I do have."
Many buildings are being hastily converted to new uses. On Canal Street near Lafayette Street, the owners of one building carved space previously used by a large discount store into a series of smaller areas, hopin to create a jewelry mall. There were no takers, and they have recently reopened the space and leased it to a big stereo store.
D.G. Hart, which has rented most of the office space in its renovated building at 168 Canal Street, has had less luck with a renovated loft on Elizabeth Street it had hoped to rent to jewelers. It is now looking for light manufacturing and office tenants.
Similarly, the new Golden Gate Mall, on Canal and Mulberry Streets, was originally intended as a retail mall; it has converted the top floors to office space.
The problems go beyond the recession. For one thing, Chinatown is facing competition for residents and businesses for the first time in its history. Many Chinese-Americans, and even some immigrants, have wearied of the congestion and high rents of Chinatown, and have gone to the boroughs.
There is a mini-Chinatown in Brooklyn, stretching from 50th to 62d Street on Eighth Avenue, and one emerging on Avenue U, between Coney Island and Ocean Avenues. Chinatowns have also emerged in Queens, in Flushing and Elmhurst-Jackson Heights.
"Many of us who grew up socializing in Manhattan's Chinatown are hanging out in Brooklyn now," said one Chinese-American professor who asked not to be named.
Moreover, Chinatown's real estate operates by a different set of rules than midtown. Lower floors command higher rents than upper ones, in part because many buildings are old and lack elevators and in part because Chinese businesses use window signs to attract drop-in traffic.
Superficially desirable stores on well-traveled corners can stay vacant for months because they are said to have bad feng shui -- a Chinese expression describing a belief that the shapes and textures and juxtaposition of surrounding buildings and natural fixtures have an impact on the success of anyone operating in their proximity.
"IF your location is said to have bad feng shui, you won't rent easily," said Joseph G. Genovesi, a managing partner of D.G. Hart.
Workouts and foreclosures remain rare, though. Many Chinese people are averse to debt and few buildings are heavily mortgaged. And seeking protection from creditors is, culturally, just not Chinese.
"Chinese people believe that paying a debt is more important than anything else, even if you have to go into your own pocket to get the money," said Paul Ho, manager of Citibank's Chinatown branch at 164 Canal Street.
Chinatown has a lot going for it that midtown does not have. Everything is on a small scale. Building floors rarely have more than 3,000 square feet of usable space.
Businesses, too, are small -- a typical Chinatown accounting or law firm has one, maybe two partners, and would fit into 500 square feet. Thus, even rents that are high on a square-foot basis can be affordable to a modestly profitable business, while a vacant office rarely represents a huge drop in a landlord's income.
Chinatown also is attracting people and investments from Hong Kong, in anticipation of the colony's reversion to China in 1997. David Chin, a local insurance agent, notes that Hong Kong investors readily pay $1.5 million for decrepit buildings worth a third that amount, just to move their assets to town.
"They assume they will be able to recoup their money when another immigrant wants to transfer funds," Mr. Chin said.
Scarcity is also keeping building prices high. Most Chinatown buildings are old, and many are mixed residential, retail and industrial. Apartment houses are often rent-regulated, making it almost impossible to evict the tenants and renovate for commercial use.
"Empty commercial lofts are so rare that they become very expensive," said Sonya Chiang, a broker with A.O. Realty. Indeed, Sing Tao Newspapers got $4 million for an old seven-story building at 105 Mott Street, which the buyers converted into commercial lofts.
Geographically, Chinatown is a hub for such prime nearby tourist destinations as Little Italy, South Street Seaport, SoHo and Wall Street, and development related to tourism is also picking up.
In February, Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger formed a Chinatown Tourism Council to market Chinatown as a tourist attraction. And the new Holiday Inn Downtown on Lafayette Street near Canal -- until recently the Hotel Maria -- is advertising in Chinese-language papers in Canada, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Hong Kong.
Phyllis Berlingeri, the hotel's sales director, says bookings are brisk. About 30 percent of the guests are Asians (60 percent of those from Hong Kong), 40 percent are domestic tourists and the rest are foreign tourists.
The hotel, whose rates top out at $120, is chasing a different crowd from pricy downtown hotels like the Vista International.
"There's a lack of competition for the price-conscious Asian traveler," Ms. Berlingeri said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Empty space advertised at a Chinatown jewelry exchange; open-air market on Canal at Mott Street bustles. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ballroom Dancing Is Back in the Swing Again

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
BALLROOM dancing, which flourished during the Depression, World War II and, briefly, the 1970's oil crisis and then went into eclipse, is on the rise again, and thousands of New Jerseyans are dressing up and going out to waltz, fox-trot and rumba.
Baby boomers, weary of the solitary gyrations of the 80's, have joined their jitterbugging elders on the dance floor. Men and women in their 20's and 30's, who never suffered through the white-gloved misery of formal dance classes, are learning for the fun of it. And couples of all ages are flocking to join the first New Jersey chapter of the United States Amateur Ballroom Dancing Association. 
 Experts offer a variety of reasons for the resurgence. Some credit the recession, on the theory that cutting the rug on Saturday night, waltz or fox-trot style, may make it easier to face the bills on Monday mornings.
"Whenever we have had a war or hard times, ballroom dancing has been popular," said Neil Clover, a dance instructor at Princeton University, which offers ballroom dancing as a noncredit course.
Dr. David Dodd, an associate professor of sociology at Montclair State College, said the return of ballroom dancing might also be part of an overall "return to social conservatism," manifesting itself in a "nostalgic yearning" for the glamour and structure of ballroom dance. After years of "do your own thing" rock-and-roll dancing, he added, ballroom dancing may represent "settling down to safe middle age" for baby boomers.
And Russ Patrick, owner of the Stardust Ballroom in Pennsauken, who has watched the ebb and flow of social dancing over 40 years as a dance band musician, suggests that the decline of social drinking has played a part. "People come to the ballroom to meet each other," he said, "and dancing gives them something else to do."
 
An Increasing Membership
 Last March, Robert Cassel of Cedar Grove started the first state chapter of the national dance association, which now has 225 members. More New Jersey chapters are in the works. And while most of the ballroom association's members are from northern New Jersey, the art is also gaining in the south.
Some 250 to 400 people glide, spin and box-step across the Stardust Ballroom's white maple surface each night in what Mr. Patrick described as a "resurgence" over the last two years. Sandra Fortuna, a Cherry Hill ballroom dance coach and competition producer, said her "festival" competition and exhibition has grown from being "a large dinner dance" when it began in 1988 to having 1,000 entrants this year.
Ballroom dancing is right in step with some of the dominant social themes of the 90's -- it is healthy, economical and ecologically sound. Dee Murray, owner of the Arthur Murray Dancing School in Fair Lawn and no relation to Arthur, touts ballroom as a way to reduce stress and build confidence. Some of her students, she adds, have lost weight in the process of mastering the art.
Price, experts say, is a factor. From the Stardust Ballroom to the weekly dances at the Boys and Girls Club in Lodi, couples can put on their dancing shoes and tighten their belts at the same time, since many establishments that hold regular dances charge less than $10 a person for an entire evening of tripping the light fantastic -- sometimes to the beat of live music.

 
Lessons on the Basics
 Many newcomers to the ballroom have never had basic dance instruction. ("They don't know their left feet from their right," Mr. Patrick said). To make up fpr this, and to win new converts, the Lodi Boys and Girls Club and the Friday night dances at the Stardust Ballroom often begin with a group lesson where would-be dancers are guided through basics by an instructor.
Though a group lesson will not turn a nondancer into Fred Astaire, novices "learn to maneuver on the floor and switch partners," Ms. Murray said. The lessons at the Stardust Ballroom focus on a different dance each month and draw about 100 students.
Group lessons can be contagious. Angela Darata, director of development for the Lodi Boys and Girls Club, began the club's weekly dances. "I didn't know how to dance," she said, "and now I can hold my own on the dance floor."
Mr. Cassel and his wife, Valerie, wanted a leisure activity they could pursue as a couple. They signed up for group lessons and now dance regularly in amateur competitions.
But learning to dance is sometimes more effective when undertaken on a private basis. Ms. Murray said the most common reason her students gave for taking private lessons was the daunting prospect of having to dance at a wedding.
Occasionally, all the members of a wedding party call her in a state of nondancing desperation. More often it is only the lone bride or bridegroom attempting to stave off first-dance embarrassment.
 
Rise in Competitors
 At the opposite end of the spectrum from the self-conscious novices are the growing numbers of ballroom competitors, both professional and amateur, who skim the parquet, the women dressed in voluminously skirted gowns upholstered with sequins, and their partners clad in tuxedos or tails. Ms. Fortuna's "festival" competitions are held in October each year. This year's event, in Cherry Hill, included professional and amateur events.
The American Star Ball, an annual amateur competition, was held last October at the Meadowlands Hilton.
Dance fads come and go. Brian Nash, a dance instructor in Rutgers's two-year-old, noncredit dance program said the "mambo craze" and the "swing craze" have lately taken hold in New Jersey. Swing dancing, as practiced in the big-band era of the 1940's, has returned with some rhythmic variation as "West Coast swing."
The "electric slide," a freestyle line dance, is especially popular, Mr. Nash said, at dances where there are a large number of singles. And country and western dancing, combining country tunes with traditional dance rhythms, is also popular in dance clubs and ballrooms.
Dr. Dodd thinks that the return to the pastime of earlier eras may also have something to do with traditional dance music. "Pop music has gone to extremes," he said, "and people may be looking for music that is more soothing and painless."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 29 - December 4

BYLINE: By Frederik Eliason

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Insurers Change Their Minds on Universal Health Coverage 

The United States insurance industry made a big break with its past when it proposed a plan that would require coverage of all Americans. The insurers' plan provides tax incentives for employers and tax penalties for consumers who do not purchase insurance so that all Americans would have an "essential package" of health benefits. Those whose benefits exceed the essential package would pay income taxes on the amount by which they exceed the standard. The Government, of course, would have a big role in defining the basic package. The plan also agrees that everybody would be covered regardless of existing medical conditions. The proposal by the Health Insurance Association of America, which represents 270 commercial insurers, reflects a realization that comprehensive health legislation is almost certain to come, with or without insurers' participation, in the Clinton Administration.
 
A Leading, or Misleading, Index
 
The Commerce Department reported that the index of leading indicators, which is supposed to predict future economic strength, rose a heathy 0.4 percent in October, after two months of declines. But having been burned by previous false starts in the recovery, a number of economists cautioned against overoptimism. They cited factors that might not continue and other forces that are not measured by the index that could be drags on the economy. In light of the reluctance to believe its findings, maybe they should call it the index of misleading indicators.

A number of other reports last week suggested it may be time to start believing in the economic pickup. These included a sharp jump in the purchasing managers' index of manufacturing activity in November, a 1 percent gain in new construction in October, a drop in first-time unemployment gains and a 1.7 percent rise in factory orders in October.
 
Trying to Read the Home Data
 
One statistic that did not improve was the report on sales of new homes in October. It tumbled 10.3 percent. But even this may not be as bad as it looks. Month by month for more than a year, the Commerce Department has revised its initial report upward when final data are received. For September, for example, the Government initially reported a decline of 1 percent from August. Last week that was revised to a gain of 7 percent.

Zoom Goes the Taurus
 
Car sales surged to an annualized rate of 7.3 million in the last 10 days of November after lazing along below 6 million earlier. Some dealers said their showrooms no longer resemble funeral parlors. Sales were particularly strong at Ford, in part because of the company's all-out campaign to drive Taurus past the Honda Accord in the contest to be the best-selling single model in 1992. In the last 10 days of November, 13,119 Tauruses were sold, 74 percent more than a year earlier.
 
Metropolitan Cease-Fire. Not.
 
A nonaggression pact involving New York City, New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut has lasted a bit longer than the cease-fires in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but not by much. The pact, signed in October 1991, was intended to prevent negative advertising and economic development programs that simply lured businesses from one jurisdiction into another without doing anything for the region's overall economy. But recently there have been a number of skirmishes, and in the latest round of aggression, New York has vowed to retaliate against New Jersey's initiatives in the ongoing Hudson River tug-of-war.

Finally, Payrolls on the Upswing
 
While factory closings still provide front-page headlines -- General Motors identified nine plants that it will close in the next three and a half years -- the underlying trend is actually much brighter. The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 7.2 percent in November, from 7.4 percent in October. It was the fifth consecutive decline and brought the rate to its lowest point since April. But the report, issued on Friday, did represent a turning point of sorts. It was the first of the declines caused by an increase in payrolls rather than a decrease in people seeking work. The Labor Department also said the rise in nonfarm payrolls was the biggest since July; 105,000 jobs were added, of which 35,000 were in manufacturing.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Lashing Out at Foreign Steel
 
The Commerce Department imposed temporary taxes on steel imports from 12 nations where United States steelmakers claim the Governments provide unfair subsidies. Whether the taxes become permanent depends on further review by the Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission. Six countries affected by the temporary taxes are in Europe, and the European Community has lodged a protest.

Women Need Not Apply in Japan
 
One of the glories of the Japanese economy is its low unemployment, which now stands at 2.2 percent. But the rate may soon be rising. For the first time in four and a half years, there are more people looking for work in Japan than there are jobs available. The problem is especially tough on women workers. A recent report said there are 2.2 job openings for every man seeking a position and less then one opening for each woman. And while Japan passed an equal-opportunity law seven years ago, it does not seem to be working for women seeking "career track" positions -- those above the clerical level. "Only when jobs are plentiful does the law have any meaning for women," said one college senior who has been frustrated in her job search.
 
Signing Off on Trade
 
The North American Free Trade Agreement will be signed on Dec. 17. The three national leaders involved all have strong reasons for a quick signing. Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada must call an election within a year, and he would like to get this matter behind him before doing so. President Salinas of Mexico is eager for the positive economic impact that the pact may have. And President Bush wants to get the measure to Congress before his successor and others find reasons to pick it apart and rework it.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
ABC Gets Into The Rerun Game
 
The top 10 lists of novels, albums and films often seem to be monopolized by certain names that appear again and again. But recurring hits are much rarer among the people who create television series. Nevertheless, ABC is betting that Wind Dancer Production, producers of the sitcom "Home Improvement," may be an exception. ABC has set up a partnership that will guarantee the show three more years and set up a profit-sharing arrangement for two future comedy series by Wind Dancer that ABC will broadcast. If either series endures until enough episodes are created to be sold in syndication, ABC could share in hundreds of millions of dollars in rerun sales.

Keep Off the Microcodes
 
A long-running legal battle in Silicon Valley is the dispute over whether the clones of Intel's dominant "86" series microprocessors violate Intel's copyrights. Last week's decision was that Advanced Micro Devices did not have the right to copy Intel's microcode embedded on its 486 chip. This means more months of sales by Intel without direct competition until Advanced Micro or somebody else figures out a way to duplicate Intel's chip without stepping on its codes.
 
Beating Clinton to the Punch
 
The two top executives at the Walt Disney Company exercised their options to buy millions of shares at about $3.60 each and then sold most of them for about $40. The pretax gains for Michael D. Eisner and Frank G. Wells were put at $187 million. Mr. Eisner, Disney's chairman, said they were trying to protect shareholders from a large tax bill in the future. President-elect Clinton has discussed limiting deductions for executive pay to $1 million per executive, and so if Mr. Eisner and Mr. Wells had waited to cash in, Disney might have added tens of millions of dollars in taxes. The President-elect has also talked of putting a surtax on millionaires.
 
Power to the Viewers
 
The nation's biggest cable television company announced last week that the future of television may soon involve more than 500 channels per set. Tele-Communications said that through "digital compression," it expects to be able to offer 10 programs on each of its channels. This means viewers may ultimately choose from a huge menu of movies, sporting events and current shows that can be watched whenever the viewer chooses rather than when the network specifies.

Punishing Salomon
 
Although Salomon Inc. has already settled charges related to the violations of Federal securities laws that were uncovered in August 1991, it was only last week that the Securities and Exchange Commission started dealing with individuals involved. Two former managing directors, Paul W. Mozer and Thomas F. Murphy, were accused of submitting billions of dollars in phony bids in Treasury auctions; Mr. Mozer is also accused of insider stock trading. The S.E.C. also reached settlements with three former top executives. John Gutfreund, Salomon's former chairman, agreed to pay a penalty of $100,000 and to be barred forever from heading a securities firm. Thomas Strauss, the firm's former president, and John Meriwether, a former vice chairman, agreed to smaller fines and suspensions of a few months. The fines were said to be the first for failing to provide adequate supervision of a firm's activities.

Comptronix's Tricks
 
Another company whose actions in the face of bad news are under intense scrutiny is Comptronix, an Alabama-based electronics company whose seemingly sterling record of profit growth had actually been silverplated by its top officers. It now develops that the board knew of the accounting irregularities for 10 days before they were disclosed to the world. In that interval someone made $350,000 in profits by buying put options, betting on a decline in the stock. But Comptronix's lawyers did prevent its founder, now suspended, from selling 100,000 shares.

HEADLINE: Leading Health Insurers Into a New Age

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A DINOSAUR sits on the desk of Carl J. Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America. The plastic toy is an apt symbol of an industry struggling to save itself from extinction as the political climate changes.
Mr. Schramm, chief lobbyist and spokesman for the nation's commercial health insurance companies, says many people tell him "this is an industry of dinosaurs." 
 The trade association, often perceived in Washington and elsewhere as a symbol of intransigence, is trying to deal with tumultuous economic, social and political changes shaking the worlds of health care and insurance. But it is not easy for a risk-averse industry whose culture and mentality have been shaped by actuaries.
In a break from past practice, the Health Insurance Association, representing 270 commercial insurers, called last week for a new Federal law that would require coverage of all Americans, define a basic set of benefits and limit tax breaks for the purchase of its own product, health insurance.
The association, founded in 1956, often seems to be on the defensive, under siege from consumers, labor unions, state regulators, members of Congress, state legislators and other politicians.
Critics say the industry wastes billions of dollars on overhead costs. In addition, they denounce the industry for raising premiums, cutting coverage and discriminating against people with potentially expensive medical conditions, the very people who most need insurance.
Through aggressive lobbying and advertising, the association appears, for the moment, to have bested liberal Democrats like Representative Marty Russo of Illinois, who wanted to establish a system of national health insurance managed and financed mainly by the Government. But the insurers know that bigger battles are coming after the inauguration of President-elect Bill Clinton, and their new proposal signals a willingness to work with him.
Mr. Schramm, a health policy researcher, is resigning after five and a half years as president of the association. He will become executive vice president of Fortis Inc., the American arm of an international insurance and financial services company. The next president has not been named. But Mr. Schramm, a former associate professor at the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health, said his successor would be "someone who is a recognized political presence."
That is appropriate. The insurance industry and its trade association are entering one of the biggest political battles of the decade as Congress joins Mr. Clinton in trying to revamp the nation's health-care system.
The insurers' new proposal reflects a commitment to controlling health costs and providing coverage for all people, the main objectives of Mr. Clinton's health program.
A requirement for universal coverage would help 35 million people with no health insurance, but it would also create a big new market for private insurers. The proposed limit on tax-free health benefits is not in the insurers' short-term interest, but they find it more palatable than efforts to control costs directly through Federal regulation. (Under the association's proposal, employees would have to pay income tax on any health benefits exceeding the value of a standard health plan to be defined later.)
While the association's proposal might seem to imply unity among member companies, in fact the industry no longer speaks with a single voice.
In the last 18 months, three big companies, Cigna, Aetna and Metropolitan Life, announced that they were withdrawing from the association. The three said they believed they could be more effective in lobbying, public advocacy and building coalitions outside the association. There is also a widespread perception of tension between big and small companies inside the association, where each member has one vote regardless of size.
The three defectors have a strong commitment to "managed care," in which insurers coordinate networks of doctors and hospitals serving large groups of workers and their dependents. The association appreciates the importance of such networks and, in recent years, has placed more emphasis on managed care. But it apparently did not move fast enough to satisfy all the big companies. The trade group also had to consider the needs of smaller companies that still emphasize conventional forms of insurance and have difficulty making the big investments needed to organize managed-care networks.
Michael J. Morrissey, chairman of the board of the Firemark Group, an insurance research and consulting concern in Parsippany, N.J., suggested another reason for tension between the big insurers and some of the smaller companies. The big companies, he said, are more willing to accept laws that spread the cost of health insurance across all members of a community and prohibit insurers from charging extremely high premiums for people who are deemed to be at high risk or have chronic ailments like diabetes.
Several states have passed laws limiting variation in health insurance premiums, and many members of Congress favor Federal legislation to require such "community rating."
"MOST big companies feel that community rating is inevitable," Mr. Morrissey said. "They want to be part of shaping that process, rather than fighting it."
Some of the small insurance companies have found a lucrative market by distinguishing good risks from bad ones and refusing to write coverage for the bad risks. They are reluctant to abandon this practice, known as cherry-picking. Some of these insurers could be put out of business if Congress bans the practice.
The chairman-elect of the Health Insurance Association, G. David Hurd, chief executive of the Principal Financial Group, in Des Moines, said: "Small companies always have suspicions about big companies. Big companies have suspicions about small companies."
But Mr. Schramm said it was simplistic to portray the tensions within the association as a spat between big and little companies. Some small insurers have made large investments in managed care, just like the big companies, he said.
If the association has had difficulty defining itself, that may be because the definition of an insurance company is blurring. More and more insurers are in the business of providing or managing health care. Some administer health-benefit plans for companies that insure themselves. Many commercial insurers have established health maintenance organizations, which offer a wide range of services in return for a fixed monthly fee.
Thus, for example, John D. Moynahan Jr., executive vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said: "Our role has changed dramatically from providing the standard type of insurance to being a manager of care. We're on an irrevocable march in that direction. We can operate more effectively as an independent company than within the structure of the industry trade association."
Soaring health costs and the shift to managed care have affected the bottom line at many insurance companies.
A. Michael Frinquelli, a managing director at Salomon Brothers who follows the insurance industry, said: "Most of the big insurance companies are making money on their health insurance business, but the profit margins are slim, only 1 or 2 percent of premiums and equivalent income. The health insurance business has strained the capital positions of these companies, partly because of the large capital investment needed to start managed-care networks."
The challenge for the Health Insurance Association is like that facing the American Medical Association: how to reorient itself, adopt new positions and create a more progressive image while still protecting the financial interests of its members.
 
 
 
THE EFFECT OF MR. CLINTON
 TEN months ago the Health Insurance Association of America was fighting to preserve a role for private insurance in the face of Democratic demands for the expansion of government health programs.
Under Republican fire in the Presidential campaign, President-elect Bill Clinton made clear that he did not favor proposals to enroll everyone in a public health program. By the end of the campaign, he was espousing ideas that would dramatically expand the role of private health insurance. He would encourage uninsured people to buy private coverage through big purchasing cooperatives. And he said that low-income people on Medicaid should get private insurance, with the Government paying part or all of the premiums.
In fending off calls for a Government-run program of national health insurance, Carl J. Schramm, president of the association, worked closely with the Bush Administration. But he expects Mr. Clinton to pay much closer attention to health care, and he welcomes that.
"The industry has done badly under Republican regimes," said Mr. Schramm, a Democrat. "In many ways, we do better historically under Democratic regimes. There are a lot of Democrats on our board of directors. There is a much larger number of Democratic policy analysts, who have a sophisticated view of health issues and realize that this is not a simplistic question of the free market versus regulation."
"The touchstone of Bill Clinton's policy is that health costs are the first problem you have to deal with," Mr. Schramm added. "We agree. Our members say, 'Boy is that right!' "

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Will the Good Times Roll Again for Tiffany?

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
THE 1990's have not been good so far to Tiffany & Company.
A domestic recession that caused Americans to cut back on luxury purchases was bad enough. But Japan's economic troubles, reflected in the Tokyo stock market's tumble, have also hurt. Indeed, Japanese customers, many of whom make their purchases of robin's-egg-blue Tiffany packages through Mitsukoshi Ltd., a department store, account for about a quarter of the company's sales -- meaning crimps in Japanese spending have hit Tiffany's bottom line. 
 But signs are emerging that Tiffany's troubles may have bottomed out, with the stock price having risen from $24 in September to as high as $30 last week. Even though Mitsukoshi recently cut back its purchases, with the Tokyo market rallying and with indications of an American economic revival, the world economy may be signaling that the demand for crystal bowls and sterling silver is on the way up.

HEADLINE: Sound Bytes;
Taking a Hands-On Approach at Aldus

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
Aldus Manutius, a 15th-century Venetian scholar, developed a printing system to make books widely accessible. Paul Brainerd started the Seattle-based Aldus Corporation in 1984 with a similar goal. His Aldus PageMaker software, used with Apple's Macintosh and LaserWriter printer, allowed the average PC user to produce professional-looking documents. Mr. Brainerd had entered the newspaper business while in school and later worked for the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company. His interest in publishing technology then took him to Atex Inc., a maker of newspaper editing and composition systems. Aldus is now the ninth-largest PC software company.
Question: You're known as the father of desktop publishing. Are you a proud parent? 
 Answer: When we first started, professional publishers viewed desktop publishing as a toy. The LaserWriter wasn't good enough, there weren't enough fonts, the Mac didn't even have a hard drive. The early users were really the creative people. Today the market is split, largely because of its success, between the general users and the professional users, who want color separations and control over all the dials and levers.
Q: Computers were supposed to lead to a paperless office. Yet desktop publishing has probably felled more trees than anything in recent memory. Will this continue?
A: People culturally are very attached to paper. It's a very efficient way of organizing and dealing with information. So I don't expect paper to go away in our lifetimes. What I do expect to see is the emergence of more interactive electronic media; that's already occurring. It's not necessarily replacing paper, but it will some day.
Q: Aldus recently had four down quarters and its first layoffs. How are things now?
A: We're back on track. The recession hit us more than others because a lot of our customers are from marketing, advertising -- the industries hit hardest by the slowdown. We scaled back by about 100 people. I have been playing a much more hands-on role in three key areas: professional graphics, consumer products and service and support
Q: Hands-on in service and support?
A: I go and sit down with the support technician, take my headset and listen in on the calls. It's a great way to understand how people are using the product. The other day, a Windows customer trying to print to a film recorder and having trouble. It was a complex problem that actually was in the Windows print driver, not in our application. But the customer doesn't care, he just wants to get it fixed. He's very upset, on deadline. It's always amazing to me how our tech support people are able to calm them down and go to work on the problem. It's part technical, part psychology.

Hobbies: Photography, running, cross-country skiing.
