HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
In Hong Kong, Foreigners May Lose Again

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Faith in China remains strong, especially if you are far enough away from it.
That became clear Friday when foreign investors rushed in to halt the slide in Hong Kong stock prices, a plunge that had sliced 16.8 percent off the Hang Seng index in the first four days of the week. 
 "Everybody has been conditioned to believe these crises provide buying opportunities," commented Barton Biggs, Morgan Stanley's international strategist. "U.S. and European investors are very eager to buy Hong Kong." The foreign buying pushed up prices 5.8 percent for the day, cutting the weekly decline to 12 percent.
The panic in Hong Kong was brought on by a spat between Britain, which is running the colony until 1997, and China, which will then take over. Chris Patten, the Governor, wants to introduce a little democracy. That outrages China's rulers, who don't like uppity citizens and fear their people might get some dangerous ideas. That dispute had been festering for weeks, generally ignored by investors who bid Hong Kong prices to new highs as recently as Nov. 12. The belief, especially strong in overseas investors, has been that Hong Kong was the way to play China's inevitable growth and emergence as an economic powerhouse.
But the locals started to get nervous when China threatened that commercial deals made now might not be deemed binding after China took over. That was serious. Beijing was -- shockingly to those who have long since dismissed as irrelevant the fact China continues to be a Communist country -- threatening to unravel business deals.
For investors these days, the world does not look all that friendly. In Europe, the currency system is again in danger of collapsing, notes Steven Nagourney, a Lehman Brothers strategist, and the bulls are hoping that the Bundesbank Council, when it meets Thursday, will announce higher monetary targets, opening the way for lower interest rates. Unfortunately, Bundesbank President Helmut Schlesinger has been hinting that lower rates will not come soon.
In that atmosphere, Hong Kong has been one of the few countries where forecasts of rapidly rising profits seemed to be reasonable. It is no wonder that foreigners hope the current crisis will blow over.
But the sad fact is, as Morgan Stanley's Mr. Biggs noted, that Hong Kong stocks even now are not cheap. Stocks there trade at a higher multiple of cash flow than in almost any other major market, he said, adding that the history of Hong Kong is that it goes to extremes of valuation in both directions. He thinks Hong Kong has further to fall.
In the long run, buyers of stocks in any country are placing a bet that the country's business climate will continue to be hospitable. The certainty of that in the United States is now bringing in foreign money and helping to support valuations at the high end of reasonableness. In China, however, it is a major uncertainty that only now is beginning to be reflected in stock prices.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Recovering From Annus Horribilis

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Funds that invest in health and biotechnology companies have had a tough year, falling 10.2 percent through Nov. 19, on average, compared with a 3.7 percent rise in all growth funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J.
As a group, the funds lost 11 percent in a first-quarter bloodbath and had not posted positive results for two consecutive months until November. The industry was sanguine about the funds last year, when they gained an average of 74 percent, and a handful of new health care funds -- Franklin Global Health, Dean Witter Health Sciences, Govett Global Health Care and Merrill Lynch Healthcare (spun off from its old Science and Technology Fund) -- started up in 1992. 
 Given the sector's strength over the last three years, is 1992's retrenchment enough? And what impact will the Clinton Administration have, in light of the President-elect's promises of affordable health care?
Managers of the funds blame a trio of ills for the group's 1992 performance: a big spike in health care stocks at the end of 1991 as the market surged broadly on lower interest rates; a market preference for cyclical growth companies, which tend to do better than stable growth companies as the economy moves out of recession, and what Cheryl Alexander, who manages the $975 million Putnam Health Sciences Trust, in Boston, calls "fear of the election" -- concerns that a new Administration would make changes that would hurt the health care sector.
Going forward, however, managers find the group more attractive. Valuations for health care companies, they note, are the lowest in 30 years as stock prices have fallen and earnings growth rates risen. So many opportunities abound that the $200 million Oppenheimer Global Bio-Tech Fund reopened to new investors in October.
As for the election, the managers differ on what changes might be made, but agree change is needed. "There's too much waste, parallel ways of delivering health care and idiosyncrasies to be corrected," said Edward P. Owens, who manages the $600 million Vanguard Specialized Health Care Fund.
While Mr. Clinton promised to introduce health care legislation in the first 100 days, many managers believe he now thinks change should be slower. Health care spending accounts for roughly 13 percent of gross national product, and "to do something dramatic to something that accounts for that big a piece of the economy will be difficult, particularly in the middle of a recession," said Charles Mangum, who manages the $800 milllion Fidelity Select Health Care Fund.
John Kaweske, who manages the $812 million Financial Portfolios Strategic Health Sciences Fund, has bet heavily on managed care, a concept much talked about in Washington. Managed care is personified by health maintenance organizations, of which he owns a fistful, including US Healthcare, United Healthcare, Qual-Med, Healthsource and Takecare. These and other companies delivering health care account for 30 percent of his fund. Twenty percent is in generic drug makers -- like Mylen and Zenith Labs -- because of their focus on cost containment.
As for harnessing inflated drug costs, price increases have already fallen from triple the rise in the consumer price index to 1.5 times the index, says Ms. Alexander, of Putnam. Even given legislation to fine-tune drug pricing through Medicaid rebates or deductibility of marketing expenses, "Clinton's timing is providential in that he can make only minor changes and still claim victory," she said.
Roughly one-third of Ms. Alexander's portfolio is invested in drug companies, and she has been adding lately. Her top five holdings are companies with new products plus experience with flat pricing: Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer, Smithkline Beecham, Abbott Labs and American Home Products.
Sandra Panem, associate manager of the Oppenheimer fund, which invests solely in biotechnology companies, said "the package of new incentives that the new Administration is looking at, especially investment tax credits and capital gains relief, would benefit the types of entrepreneurial companies that characterize this sector." She sees broad opportunities in biotech and has been buying Amylin and Alteon, two companies developing new approaches to treating diabetes.
Edward Owens of Vanguard has taken a small new position in the drug store industry because earnings have been stable and because he believes "the Phar-Mor bankruptcy would benefit the remaining players in a modest way." His five largest holdings are Beckman Instruments, Pfizer, Imcera, Bristol-Myers and Ciba-Geigy.
About half of Fidelity Select Health Care is invested in drug stocks, says Mr. Mangum. Because valuations have fallen on higher-quality companies, he has been expanding positions in Warner Lambert, Schering-Plough, Pfizer and Merck.
Jordan Schreiber, who has managed the health care part of Merrill Lynch's Sci-Tech Fund since 1983 and now manages the $100 million spinoff, increased its European allocation from 20 percent to 50 percent in anticipation of the election, mostly in drug makers like Astra in Sweden. The concern was that pressure on pricing and slower growth rates would hurt American companies.

HEADLINE: FOR GIVERS AND RECEIVERS, CHANGING LIVE WITH NEEDIEST FUND;
'Everything's Coming Up Roses'

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Vince H. realized that times were tough when he discovered that he had worn out his record of Ethel Merman belting out the finale of "Gypsy." That song, "Rose's Turn," had raised his spirits on the days that he could not find work. And there were many.
Like thousands of New Yorkers, Vince H., a 52-year-old office clerk, was laid off this year for the first time in decades. And like so many people in a city whose unemployment rate has jumped to more than 10 percent, he searched for a new job for months, visiting every employment agency and office temporary firm that he could find. 
 "I couldn't get nothing to save my soul," he said the other day as he savored a cup of black coffee and a cigarette at a diner in Chelsea. "I went through my savings and my credit cards. And then I hit rock bottom."
 
Threatened With Eviction
 After he fell five months behind in his rent, his landlord threatened to evict him from the apartment in Jackson Heights, Queens, that he had lived in for 12 years. With nowhere else to turn, he called Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, one of seven charities aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Catholic Charities gave him money from the fund to help pay his back rent, and then he began another push to find a job. He was finally hired as a clerk by an office-supplies manufacturer in Chelsea a few months ago.
He said that at first, he was reticent about seeking help from a charity, because he thought he would be made to feel guilty about his misfortune. But he said that as soon as he walked into the office of Catholic Charities, he immediately felt comfortable.
"It wasn't a demeaning experience at all," he said.
 
Held On to Optimism
 Vince H. said that in the months he was out of work, he tried to remain optimistic, filling the extra time by catching up on reading. But he added that he was surprised to find out how exasperating the search was.
"If you have a job, then you don't have any idea how frustrating it can be," he said. "For every job out there, there are 15 or 20 of us word processors."
Returning to work, he said, has rejuvenated him. And he has bought a new copy of Ethel Merman's record, one that he hopes he will not wear out any time soon.
"Being part of the rat race again does something for you," he said. "It feels good to be back again."

HEADLINE: The New Blood Culture

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
ON a Sunday night in 1938, Orson Welles caused a national panic by broadcasting an hourlong adaptation of "The War of the Worlds." Despite repeated announcements that the radio show was only fiction, terrified Americans took to the streets, convinced that Martians were invading and destroying the country. Why? With perfect timing, a month after the Nazis got their claws into Czechoslovakia, Welles had tapped right into the proliferating, if still subliminal, American fear that war was on its way.
In November 1992, a Wellesian director of our own time, Francis Ford Coppola, tapped into a similarly rampant, and no less lethal, real-life terror running through the public consciousness. "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula,' " a movie that was ridiculed in advance by much of Hollywood and the press as a certain flop, a "Bonfire of the Vampires," was an unexpected sensation in its opening weekend, selling $32 million worth of tickets. 
 Is there any doubt which foreign invasion Americans are fearing this time? The audience that turns out for "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " smells blood even more literally than Welles's audience did.
And Mr. Coppola gives it to them, in a movie that both frightens and arouses by playing off the unchecked fear of further AIDS invasions of the national bloodstream. "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " is an orgy of bloodsucking, bloodletting and blood poisoning. It's beyond Grand Guignol: it's opera for the new blood culture.
The new blood culture is the bizarre pop byproduct of a national obsession with all bodily fluids. It's a high-pitched, often hysterical acting out of the subliminal fantasies, both deadly and erotic, of a country that has awakened to the fact that the most insidious post-cold-war enemy is a virus. AIDS, after all, actually does to the bloodstream what Communists and other radicals were once only rumored to do to the nation's water supply. Its undiminished threat has made the connection between sex and death, an eternal nexus of high culture, into a pop fixation, finally filtering down to the vocabulary of commercial images.
The blood culture is pervasive, for Mr. Coppola's movie is no fluke unreeling in a vacuum. As so often happens in this large country, and not by coincidence, a psychic obsession has surfaced everywhere at once. The same week that "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " was the highest-grossing movie, the No. 1 fiction and nonfiction books on the best-seller lists were Anne Rice's "Tale of the Body Thief," in which another vampire, the contemporary Lestat, puts on a "little rubber sheath" rather than infect a lover with a "dark seed that might harm her," and Madonna's "Sex," a burlesque instruction manual for sadomasochistic sex in the era of AIDS.
Since the advent of AIDS is hardly new, why have the floodgates of the blood culture opened now? Call it trickle-down anxiety. AIDS awareness -- specifically, the awareness that the disease is not the exclusive property of homosexuals, drug users and hemophiliacs -- has increased exponentially in the year of Magic Johnson, heightened further by its sporadic prominence in a political campaign. Once the distraction of the election was over, Americans could turn their full attention to the fear.
It was on election eve that Mr. Johnson announced his second retirement from basketball, a decision prompted by the ominous, if ill informed, remarks of a fellow player, Karl Malone, who felt that his game-induced "scabs and cuts" put him at risk of infection. Only a few days later, in the election's immediate aftermath, did the possible lifting of the ban on homosexuals in the military prompt a virulent controversy that caught even that adept reader of the public mood President-elect Bill Clinton by surprise. Here again the not-so-hidden agenda was the irrational fear that one's blood could be contaminated by casual contact with those who are H.I.V. positive. Blood fear skyrocketed even as the country's previous dominant fear (the economy) eased.
Enter "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " -- which is to say, Francis Ford Coppola's "Dracula." In retrospect, it is clear that the movie's mid-November nationwide opening was as brilliantly, if as unintentionally, timed to ride a wave of public trauma as that of "War of the Worlds" in 1938.
Though set mostly in Victorian England, this movie touches every 1992 blood button it can. The neck wounds inflicted by Gary Oldman's Dracula, seen in close-up, look like the lesions of Kaposi's sarcoma. The film pauses, irrationally but mesmerizingly, for an extended microscopic view of what appears to be rampaging blood cells. And its cinematography is often tinted capillary red, day and night, saturating the viewer's entire perspective with blood. What horror tale more than Stoker's, or this unfaithfully anachronistic retelling of it, could be more metaphorically appropriate to this moment?
"Blood is too precious a thing in these times," says Dracula, who leaves his victim, a Victorian English maiden named Lucy, with what her physician labels a "disease of the blood unknown to all medical theory." A blood specialist played by Anthony Hopkins likens Lucy's ailment to venereal disease -- "syphilis and syphilization have advanced together," he says -- calling it a threat to the "ethics and ideals" of humankind and potentially a plague. Unsafe sex is depicted as an exchange of blood with lubricious vampire vixens, and not even babies are immune to the threat. At times vampires appear as mist and fog -- vaporized fluids that can invade unsuspecting bloodstreams even when least expected and most protected.
The AIDS invocations are so unsubtle that it is hard to understand how Hollywood, which is nothing if not cynical, failed to realize what "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " was and how it might play to an alarmed public. But the explanation for this myopia may not be so complex. Since Hollywood has yet to release a major movie with AIDS as its explicit subject, it follows that it would fail to notice in advance that Mr. Coppola had made a movie implicitly about the disease and that there might even be a huge market at that.
Yet, fear is not the only appeal of "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula' " and other artifacts of the blood culture. The eroticism of these works, however much mocked by critics, is real, even as that eroticism is entwined with death. What was once forbidden and dangerous is now titillating to a mass audience -- at least if viewed on screen or in a book. Violent sex, once considered an offbeat taste, is now a common denominator of eroticism, even if cartoonishly presented with mail-order leather and harness accessories as it is by Madonna in the pages of "Sex" or with ripped flesh and bestial rapists by Mr. Coppola in "Bram Stoker's 'Dracula.' " No wonder that torn clothes and bondage fashion, with their intimation of rough trade, have become popular. No wonder, too, that Mia Farrow's poison-pin valentine to Woody Allen, with a steak knife plunging into a heart, became an image of national fascination the moment it was disseminated by "60 Minutes."
AS the new blood culture has made America take a second look at sadomasochism, so it has uncloseted homoeroticism. The early appearance of AIDS among gay men forced a large heterosexual public to examine gay sex for the first time. And if the marketplace is any measure, people were titillated to some extent by gay sex as they were by sadomasochism -- at least from a distance. Gay or lesbian fantasies are a standard feature in the threesomes of "Sex," in Anne Rice's vampire fiction and in the iconography of fashion advertising, whether on behalf of Calvin Klein or his many imitators. Request Jeans produced a 48-page advertising supplement to the October issue of Details magazine, in which two voluptuous female models and a man nearly as large-breasted act out a crude bisexual porn-film "Thelma and Louise" scenario (in and out of their jeans) in a cheap Western motel.
The fetishization of the condom, the blood's ubiquitous defender, is also an inevitable product of the blood culture. Like jeans, condoms turn out not to be a simple, utilitarian product available in a single style and color -- once the market demands more options. Indeed, the new pop porn -- whether the Request Jeans portfolio or "Sex" -- has appropriated condom imagery for its packaging; shrink-wrap is nothing if not a giant condom that reinforces the safeness of the masturbatory sex that porn is meant to induce. And as with actual condoms, shrink-wrapping is developing its own status-minded variations, with Madonna choosing silver Mylar over plain old cellophane. Never one to miss out on a trend, Barneys New York unveiled new windows on Thanksgiving weekend that include a tribute to Madonna and her Mylar and another to Magic Johnson, who hovers near a Christmas tree brightly festooned with gold-wrapped condoms.
So begins the holiday season in the jittery blood culture. Deck the halls with shades of apocalypse now.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 12; Column 3; Styles of The Times

HEADLINE: All-Consuming Art

BYLINE: By JOAN KRON

 BODY:
THORSTEIN VEBLEN, meet Wendy Wasserstein.
Conspicuous consumption may be as passe as the power suit, but conspicuous references to status symbols -- from Louis Vuitton handbags to Asprey candlesticks to Manolo Blahnik mules -- are bringing down the house at Miss Wasserstein's new play, "The Sisters Rosensweig." 
 The play deals with the midlife crises, assimilation conflicts and relationships of three Jewish sisters: Sara Goode (played by Jane Alexander), a twice-divorced London bank president who wouldn't throw away an old cashmere sweater; Gorgeous Teitelbaum (Madeline Kahn), a Newton, Mass., housewife and radio call-in-show host who calls herself "Doctor" and overdresses in faux Ungaro, and Pfeni Rosensweig (Frances McDormand), a rootless travel writer who wears Birkenstocks and hauls her belongings around in plain shopping bags.
But on another level, the play, at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, demonstrates how material culture and consumer products are used (and abused) for self-definition, for character judgments and as currency in interpersonal relationships. A Chanel suit plays such a pivotal role that to reveal it would be as bad theater-going manners as divulging the name of the murderer in an Agatha Christie whodunit.
Brand-name dropping isn't new in the arts. Dr. Monroe Friedman, a professor of psychology at Eastern Michigan University, said that since World War II, the use of product names as puns, metaphors and punchlines in films, novels and plays has been proliferating faster than street vendors selling fake Rolexes. Although such references abound in contemporary fiction and were the foundation for pop art, this trend is deeply disturbing to self-styled culture cops who decry the commercialization of language.
Shakespeare managed with elegant metaphors like "taffeta phrases" and the "pink of courtesy." But contemporary authors often dot their works with what Dr. Friedman calls "metaphors for the mundane."
Coinages like "Teflon candidate," "McPaper," the "Edsel of" whatever and assorted detergent references abound in the professor's book "A 'Brand' New Language: Commercial Influences in Literature and Culture (1991, Greenwood Press). "Some humanists find this degrading to language," Dr. Friedman said recently. . "Can we only relate to each other through things?"
Dr. Mary Douglas, an eminent British anthropolgist, sees no alternative. "How else should one relate to the Joneses if not by keeping up with them," she asserts in "The World Goods," a 1979 book that she wrote with the economist Baron Isherwood. "Consumption is the very arena in which culture is fought over and licked into shape."
Dr. Douglas believes that an important part of the enjoyment of goods is in "sharing names that have been learned and graded."
Dr. Douglas, meet Miss Wasserstein.
ON almost every page of Miss Wasserstein's script, the sisters, their men and the people they gossip about are defined by or relate to one another through the shared (or disputed) meanings of things -- movie and song titles, schools and, of course, brand-name products: Wedgwood, majolica, Retin-A, Susie Cooper china, Portobello Road antiques, poodle skirts, Ralph Lauren shirts, Groton, The New York Times, sushi, fish and chips, Fruit of the Loom, Newsweek, Sacher torte, hot-oil treatments, Diet Coke, Tanino Crisci and Harrods.
Miss Wasserstein's choices were carefully made. Things don't provide "the complete definition" for a character, the playwright said. "But it's part of the picture," she continued. "It gives the character more detail, specificity. It sets a time and a place."
Take Sara, for example. President of a bank. Radcliffe grad. Reads The Financial Times. "Sara still has LP's," Miss Wasserstein said. "Her record player is not a CD player. That marks her right away. Sara believes CD's belong in the bank. Her candlesticks are Asprey. She has majolica and gives you its date: 'Victorian, 1893.' "
Clothing, with its infinite and minute levels of meaning, resonates with sophisticated audiences. And Miss Wasserstein knows the territory.
Mervyn Kant (Robert Klein), a suitor of Sara and furrier turned leading supplier of "synthetic animal protective covering," enters carrying a Turnbull & Asser shopping bag. From it, Merv, who wears brown suede shoes with his linen suit, takes a proud purchase -- a lavender shirt with "Bonfire of the Vanities"-style white collar and cuffs.
Why Turnbull & Asser? Partly for the sound of it, Miss Wasserstein said. "It's more lyrical than saying 'I bought an expensive shirt.' " It also has the right connotations. "My brother is a banker," she said in a bit of an understatement (Bruce Wasserstein was an architect of leveraged buyouts in the 1980's). "I noticed several years ago that he and all his friends were getting their shirts made in London at Turnbull & Asser."
The shirt does double duty, semiotically. Miss Wasserstein uses it to bring out the snob in Nicholas Pym (Rex Robbins), the pompous, pin-striped Thatcher M.P. who dates Sara. Why is it, Nick asks Merv, "that so many Jewish-American men I know, professionals mostly, wear those shirts?"
"It's a money-lending uniform," Merv says, skewering Nick's stereotyping. "They're so well-designed, you'd never know it costs a pound of flesh to get them."
The entrance of the flamboyant Gorgeous, a bargain-basement shopper, is a sight gag: she's dressed head to toe in Chanel knock-offs and is carrying an imitation Louis Vuitton handbag. For those in the audience who don't see what's so funny, the dialogue makes it clear that she wears counterfeit couture.
"What interests me about Vuitton pocketbooks," Miss Wasserstein said, "is that the real ones and the fakes are both vinyl and that I can tell a fake from a real. Women have been taught to size things up quickly."
Gorgeous gets an extra laugh for carrying a Filene's bag. But wouldn't a Filene's Basement bag be more in character?
Not in this case, Miss Wasserstein said: "In the bag is a gift for Sara. Gorgeous wouldn't buy a gift in the basement."
Gorgeous gets her biggest laughs mispronouncing European shoe brands (Gucci, paired with Pucci, is a run-down-at-the-heels cliche, Professor Friedman said; Neil Simon has used it, and so has Miss Wasserstein, in a previous work.) In "The Sisters Rosensweig," Miss Wasserstein opens some new shoe boxes. In one scene, Gorgeous vows that if she gets a cable-television job she's after, "I'm marching myself right into Saks and treating myself to Bruno Maglis, Ferragamos and Manulo Blanchikis."
Manulo Blanchiki?
That's how Gorgeous pronounces Manolo Blahnik, the esoteric brand favored by fashion editors, socialites and Hollywood stars.
A self-described shoe maven, Miss Wasserstein, who grew up wearing fake Pappagalos from Chandler's and occasionally real ones, said a fashionable friend introduced her to the Manolo Blahnik store on West 55th Street, where a pair of shoes costs $400 to $1,200. The playwright owns one pair. "Red satin," she said. "Very high. I've only worn them once."
She said she selected the brand for the script because "it's hard to say -- a fun name to use," and because the women Gorgeous gets her values from "would have seen Geena Davis in those shoes on the cover of Vanity Fair," she said, adding, "Those ladies would say these are the best."
But Manolo Blahnik almost got cut from the script. The name meant nothing to Daniel Sullivan, the director, and he wondered how many in the audience would recognize the name. Miss Wasserstein reasoned that even if people didn't know, they'd surmise it was a shoe brand when it followed the two better-known names -- Bruno Magli and Ferragamo. She won.
But she could lose when little theaters all over America start doing the play. "Brand names don't always travel well," Dr. Friedman said. And a generation from now, it's likely that plays that include them will "have to have footnotes all over the place," he added. Just like Shakespeare.
But it's a no-lose situation for the manufacturers that are mentioned. "Word-of-author advertising," as Dr. Friedman calls it, has proven to raise confidence in a product's value. That's why many companies will even pay to be mentioned. (When they pay, it's called solicited-word-of-author advertising.))
In "The Sisters Rosensweig," the mentions are all unsolicited. But not unappreciated. On opening night, Chanel sent Miss Kahn and Miss Wasserstein flowers. And after the opening, Ferragamo sent them both the shoes that Gorgeous rhapsodizes about in Act II -- the flats with the bows.
Manolo Blahnik has yet to be heard from.

HEADLINE: COINS;
Ancient Collections: A Lesson in History

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:
WITH the decline of the economy in the last several years, sales of coins have slowed and prices are down. But several auctions this month may tell whether times are changing. Two auctions next weekend should show if the market for ancient coins is improving.
Ancient coins are often more difficult to sell in this country than their American cousins. Most American collectors prefer the United States coins they saved as children. Certainly the quality of those collections has improved over the years, but rarely do the collectors move to the larger and more complex domains of Greek, Roman or Byzantine coins. 
 Why would anyone want to change from collecting American coins to ancient ones? One reason might be the history behind those coins.
Lot 679 of Christie's sale this Friday is a silver Abderan tetradrachm minted about 460 B.C. Try to forget its age. Try to forget that it comes from a city in Thrace, a country in the eastern part of the Balkan Peninsula that was a pathway for Persian armies invading Greece. One of Abdera's citizens, Democritus, held the farfetched theory that all matter consisted of small particles called atoms.
Thrace was one of the earliest countries producing coins, and Abderan coin makers created some unusual designs at a time when some of the most beautiful coins were being produced.
The griffin on the obverse or front of the coin is taken from Abdera's history; the griffin is the symbol of the Ionian city of Teos, whose people rebuilt the city. But while other Abderan coins also showed the griffin, the individual design often changed. The griffin might be rearing, trotting or just standing. Soon, other symbols began appearing on the obverse. Today, numismatists think that those symbols, one of which is a fish, were the signatures of the designers.
The reverse of the coin shows a simple incused square broken into quarters. This design is reminiscent of Greek coins minted 200 years earlier. But the designers of Abdera later added their ruler's name around the outside of the square, the first coin designers to do so. The inscription on this coin reads "Abideriteon," and James Lamb of Christie's says it translates as "Of the people of Abdera." The inscription on the obverse is the name Kallidamos, who was probably the magistrate who directed all the mint activities.
An Abderan coin can bring thousands of dollars. It can be seen at Christie's, 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, on Monday from noon to 5 P.M. and Tuesday through Thursday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. For more information: (212) 546-1000. Other ancient coins, including another one from Abdera, will be sold on Friday and Saturday by Superior Galleries at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers, 811 Seventh Avenue, at 53d Street. They can be seen Tuesday through Saturday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
A New Dorm For Temple

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace

 BODY:
THE first new dormitory in 25 years on Temple University's North Philadelphia main campus is being built on North Broad Street. The school plans to open it in time for fall 1993 classes.
The $19 million hall, not yet named, is part of a 19-project capital improvement program whose cost is estimated at $347 million. It will house 562 students and 15 staff members in two-bedroom suites arranged in units having a kitchenette and study lounge. Laundry, exercise and recreation facilities and a convenience store are included. The building will have a computer link to Wise Owl, Temple's data communications network, letting students communicate with each other and look up telephone numbers for campus personnel and other information. 
 The Philadelphia-based Hillier Group Architects designed the four-story brick and limestone building in an H-shape with two interior garden courtyards not visible from the street.
The 146,000-square-foot dorm, between Diamond Street and Susquehanna Avenue, will rise across the street from a row of abandoned red brick one-family homes. It will sit on the 1.5-acre site of a state armory that was razed after a 1989 fire. State officials leased the land to Temple for 50 years. The project is part of a community development plan created by the school in tandem with residents, area merchants and city officials.
Temple financed the dormitory project through a 1991 long-term bond issue. In October, the school also received $61.9 million in state funds, with plans to raise $28.7 million of its own for such projects as a new recreation and convocation center, a classroom and laboratory building plus fire and safety renovations to 11 existing high-rise structures.
School officials said the influx of new campus residents would bring increased economic and social activity to an area that includes some of the city's most impoverished neighborhoods.
Along with the dormitory, community development efforts have been begun to restore commercial and residential properties on neighboring streets, such as Susquehanna Avenue, Carlisle and 15th Streets, said James S. White, Temple's vice president for public affairs.
The community was seeking a way for business owners to "take advantage of the audience created by the new dorm and try to arrest the disinvestment that's plagued the commercial strip," Mr. White said. Small businesses such as full-service drugstores, shoe repair, clothing or service shops are envisioned, he said.
Only 2,400 Temple students, about 10 percent of the main campus enrollment, live on campus. Most take classes at some of the six satellite campuses and live elsewhere in the area.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Clinton Tries to Learn From Carter and History

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONE big shadow hanging over the Clinton transition is the shadow of the early failures of the Carter Administration. Hardly a day goes by without a warning to Little Rock about well-known mistakes, like being too much of an outsider, or without an answering boast that the canny new guys won't casually insult Congress.
But many of these dark images are false or exaggerated, cast by shadow puppets constructed out of cardboard memories, shaped by the defeat of 1980, and so they do not offer very useful hazard signs for the new "outsider" administration from the South. These images have haunted the Clinton team to the extent that the President-elect's aides have spent hours talking with former Carter Administration officials to find out what worked and what didn't. 
 In fact, if not in the conventional wisdom of 16 years later, the Carter Administration succeeded pretty well with the public and Congress in its early days. His walk down Pennsylvania Avenue at the head of his inaugural parade, a televised fireside chat, a town meeting and a radio call-in program, with Walter Cronkite in the role of Larry King, all conveyed a very popular common touch.
His first moves with Congress were generally successful, except for the failed selection of Theodore Sorensen to head the Central Intelligence Agency. But he worked with Congressional leaders on an economic program, and the Senate even passed an emergency natural gas bill of his without sending it to committee.
Serious trouble began in the late spring of 1977, when he sent a complicated energy bill to Congress without proper groundwork, and the rest of that year was often difficult. But he strengthened his Congressional liaison team and set up a skilled office under Anne Wexler to mobilize outside support for his policies. He built a historically underrated record of accomplishments, from airline and trucking deregulation to civil service changes and the Panama Canal treaty.
 
Battered by Events
 In the end, surging inflation and interest rates, the Iranian hostage crisis and a bloody intraparty challenge by Senator Edward M. Kennedy made Jimmy Carter the first elected incumbent to be defeated since Herbert Hoover, and the popular image of his Administration became one of near-total failure. In fact, its economic growth record was one of the strongest since the war. As Jody Powell, Mr. Carter's press secretary, pointed out the other day, the deficit was around $40 billion, and there was a healthy trade surplus.
The real history does provide lessons. But they include successes, like that informal touch, as well as mistakes, like setting a 90-day deadline for proposing his energy program, in the view of Prof. Charles O. Jones of the University of Wisconsin. Professor Jones is the author of "The Trusteeship Presidency," the leading scholarly examination of the Carter Administration.
 
Times Have Changed
 But the most important lesson is that this is not 1977. The public is much more worried about the economy and about the ability of government to solve national problems than it was then. And most of all, this Congress and this President-elect look at each other differently than their predecessors did, seeming to share a sense of mutual dependency.
The Congress Mr. Carter encountered was rather full of itself. It had limited Presidential authority to make war and manage budgets. It had overidden vetoes. And it had forced a President from office.
The President whom the 95th Congress faced was almost equally self-confident, morally sure of himself, and at first not much interested in how issues seemed from the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue.
They often failed to speak the same language. Mr. Carter, for example, almost mystified lawmakers when he made major issues out of water projects and government reorganization, issues that seemed almost sub-Presidential to the Hill. He won those fights, but at great cost. Mr. Clinton, however, seems content to soft-pedal irritants like his desire for the line-item veto.
This time, after a deeply ineffective 102d Congress that made "gridlock" a household word, there is a shared sense of fear at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue. In 1977, said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, both sides thought the return of a Democrat to the White House was a return to the natural order. He said that neither Congress not the Carter Administration "realized that this was a significant opportunity that we had to capitalize on."
But now, he said "Everybody feels pressure from the people to make this work."
Mr. Gephardt is metaphor for his message. As a junior Democrat in 1978, he fought Mr. Carter over hospital-cost containment. As a leader in 1992, he urges his colleagues to treat Mr. Clinton as the "quarterback" whose plays they must run.
Mr. Powell agreed that the times invited cooperation, and he added that the Clinton team was hardly the bunch of outsiders that the Georgians had been, but he offered one caution anyhow. He said that no matter how much Congressional consultation and stroking Mr. Clinton engages in, "If you ask them to do something that's going to be politically hard for them, it's still going to be hard."
The most frequently cited mistake of the early Carter Administration, and the one the Clinton folk claim to know by heart, is the idea that the Georgians failed by not setting priorities and trying to do too much all at once. Mr. Powell said, "We certainly did ask Congress to do more than the institution was capable of handling."
But the problem was broader. Mr. Carter's staff compiled a list of hundreds of his campaign commitments, which the press promptly dubbed "Promises, Promises." He was asking for more than his Administration could manage. As Mr. Powell put it, "We had so much going in that it was hard to communicate any sense of what we were about, because we were about everything."
For a politician with as many promises as Mr. Clinton, keeping to a few priorities will require self-restraint. But there seems no chance that Mr. Clinton will display another of Mr. Carter's faults, a failure to claim success even when he achieved it. As Professor Jones observed, even when Mr. Carter won, he often complained that he had not won everything: "He couldn't even extract victory from victory."
But Mr. Clinton, after all, proclaimed himself the winner when he finished second in New Hampshire.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
U.S. Bomb Labs, Waging Peace, Shift Their Targets

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A wiry, chain-smoking, Sanskrit-quoting genius by the name of J. Robert Oppenheimer traipsed through the snow atop a densely forested mesa in northern New Mexico to found the Los Alamos lab, the birthplace of the atomic bomb and spiritual home of what grew into a maze of 20 or so nuclear sites around the country. That complex, which today, some 50 years later, has some 100,000 employees and an annual budget of $11 billion, is scrambling to reinvent itself amid celebrations marking the birth of the nuclear era. The soul-searching, which began at the cold war's end, is accelerating because of Bill Clinton, who has pledged his presidency to domestic renewal. The question of the moment is how far, and how fast, the nuclear complex can move beyond the bomb.
"It's the most radical change we've ever faced," Dr. Siegfried S. Hecker, director of Los Alamos, said Thursday. "There still are defense jobs we need to do, but we have to be more responsive to helping solve the nation's economic problems." 
 The 9,000-person lab, with an annual budget of more than $1 billion, has no nuclear arms under development for the first time in its history, officials say. The situation is similar to Ford or General Motors producing no cars, and pondering whether to get into a new business.
Today the push throughout the nuclear complex is to aid industry, chiefly by sharing exotic skills and technologies. Los Alamos, for instance, claims global preeminence in supercomputing. But the red tape around such jewels is often thick and intimidating.
About 3 percent of the Los Alamos budget goes to joint ventures with private industry. Bill Clinton has called for up to 20 percent to go into such partnerships, saying the Federal labs are slumbering giants of industrial might.
"We have these incredible resources," Mr. Clinton said of the labs during the campaign, adding that "we have but only scratched the surface of their potential."
Perhaps. The atomic breakthroughs of World War II fed the popular notion that scientific wizards and Federal funds could team up to achieve almost anything. The Apollo moon program did nothing to diminish that idea, although the marriage of money and brains produced countless flops like synthetic fuels, breeder reactors and Star Wars.
 
Painful Rebirth
 A spiritual rebirth for the bomb makers, the founders of the Federal-science paradigm, may be quite painful not only because of the inherent difficulty of making bold advances outside their field, but also because they succeeded at their military job for so long. Their institutional habits, and obsessions with secrecy, are now a half century old.
The hunt for what would become Los Alamos predated the celebrated test of the world's first reactor in Chicago on Dec. 2, 1942, which showed that sustained nuclear fission was possible and likely to lead to a bomb. Impatient for success, Oppenheimer, a 38-year-old physicist chosen to direct the bomb designers, led Army officials visiting New Mexico on Nov. 16 to a high mesa with stunning views of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. A light snow was falling. He wanted the site for its beauty, sure it would inspire his team. The military liked its isolation. By the time scientists starting arriving in March 1943, Army crews were erecting a small city of barracks and Quonset huts and lab buildings, all ringed by barbed wire.
Other sites followed -- Argonne outside Chicago to advance reactor studies, Hanford in Washington State to produce plutonium for bombs, Oak Ridge in Tennessee to enrich uranium and fashion it into arms. After the atomic bombing of Japan and the start of the cold war, the network grew: Sandia in Albuquerque to make firing and safety circuits, Livermore in California to design more bombs, Pantex in Texas to perfect mass assembly.
Herbert S. Marks, general counsel of the Atomic Energy Commission, once remarked that the bomb enterprise bore no relation to the industrial or social life of the nation. "It was a separate state, with its own airplanes and its own factories and its thousands of secrets," he said. "It had a peculiar sovereignty, one that could bring about the end, peacefully or violently, or all other sovereignties."
Today the complex itself is torn by change. Warhead production has been thrown into reverse, with disassembly and storage now in the fore. Some facilities are being mothballed. The biggest challenges, and hopes, center on the science labs of Sandia, Livermore and Los Alamos, which are seen as treasure troves of intellectual riches.
"We are living in a world where brain power will determine the lives of all our people," Mr. Clinton told Sandia workers during the campaign. "I want to make sure that each of you has a chance to contribute your full potential."
Los Alamos is already shifting gears, Dr. Hecker says. In two years it has signed 31 cooperative agreements with industry, and has 40 pending. It has teamed with Motorola to cut the use of chlorofluorocarbons, which work wonders in cleaning electronic circuit boards but are also destroying the Earth's ozone layer. In another joint venture, Los Alamos is working with Life Technologies to develop an innovative technology aimed at speeding the quest to map the human gene.
Dr. Hecker said Los Alamos is also pioneering technologies on its own that the Government might ordain for wide civilian use, such as high-speed supercomputer networks similar to the national "information superhighways" advocated by Vice-President-elect Albert Gore.
 
Hiding Old Loves?
 The lab is also devoting much energy to what Dr. Hecker called the "nuclear draw-down," dismantling arms, cleaning up the weapons complex and developing ways to limit the bomb's spread around the world. "The country needs the smarts to deal with whatever nuclear weapons are left and their legacy," he said. "That's the core of what we do. But I'm optimistic we can also aid the domestic agenda."
Critics say the new industrial drive could simply provide a cloak for old loves. "The labs are not only looking for new ideas in nuclear weapons," said William M. Arkin, military research director for Greenpeace, "but are doing so in a manner that is increasingly secretive."
John Stroud, an official with Concerned Citizens for Nuclear Safety, based in Santa Fe, said Los Alamos was expanding its bomb work as other centers were retired. "They pay lip service to industrial partnerships," he said, "but are unwilling to take any risks that would commit the lab to an alternative course."
Dr. Hecker said some nuclear work at Los Alamos was indeed growing but would only "help to slow the decline." And with scientific caution, he added that the industrial push, while promising, offered no guarantee of a surge in national innovation.
"I'm optimistic because the private sector is taking a significant interest in us," he said. "But now we have to demonstrate that we can actually do some good."

HEADLINE: A Living, Barely, Behind the Wheel;
Low Pay and Long Hours Cut Through Taxi World Stratum

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
On the rivers of hurtling steel that New Yorkers call streets, Majeed Salhab, Tharwat Bekheit, Tony Smith and Majeed Moughal are a beleaguered breed of gondolier.
All drive taxis, but they represent different species within a vast and varied industry. While Mr. Moughal ferries tourists around Manhattan in his sparkling yellow medallion cab, Mr. Smith uses his rattling Chrysler as a gypsy cab to illegally shuttle Queens residents from subways to their homes. Mr. Salhab makes six trips daily in his black car, a climate-controlled Lincoln, but Mr. Bekheit makes as many each hour as a car service driver in a road-worn Cadillac, taking orders over the radio from a dispatcher in Brooklyn. 
 And though all of them fear crime, Mr. Smith's work is easily the most dangerous: statistically, he and illegal drivers like him are more likely to be killed in their cabs than police officers are on the beat.
Yet for all their differences, the four share a hard routine that, in the city's sputtering economy, has become harder. Ridership is down, tips are smaller, workdays are longer and, consequently, turnover among drivers is rising, according to the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission.
In an effort to stabilize the billion-dollar business, the Dinkins administration has proposed revamping the city's taxi regulations, some of which date to the 1930's. The plan is intended to clamp down on illegal cabs, cap the number of car-service bases and expand the number of medallion cabs by 400. But the proposal has received mixed reviews from the industry and faces an uncertain fate in the City Council.
Amid questions about who should be regulated and how, some experts say the city should abolish taxi regulation and let competition dictate the industry's growth. "Deregulation will mean more diverse service and improved quality because of competition," said Dick Netzer, a professor of economics at the Wagner Graduate School for Public Service at New York University.
In this cantankerous and protean industry, regulation never stopped diversification. When yellow cabs gave up on cruising neighborhoods outside Manhattan 20 years ago, new businesses, many built on the labor and entrepreneurial energy of immigrants, stepped into the void. Inexpensive car services emerged in middle-class communities. Radio-dispatched luxury black cars won corporate accounts. And "$1 cars"-- unlicensed, or gypsy, cabs -- sprouted like wildflowers in poor neighborhoods.
Today, there are about 60,000 taxis of all types that transport nearly a million New Yorkers each day. With more cars chasing fewer riders, passengers are waiting less for cabs and reporting fewer complaints about drivers, according to the taxi commission.
But for the drivers, stiffer competition in a weak economy is taking a toll. The stories of Messrs. Bekheit, Moughal, Salhab and Smith provide a glimpse into those hardships and also the vast changes that have swept the industry and made it so difficult to regulate.
Though their cars are as different as their clients, the drivers' hopes, fears and even paychecks are much the same. All are immigrants who, like generations of cabbies before them, see taxi driving as a poor man's gateway to mainstream America.
"With a cab, you feel you have your own job," Mr. Moughal said. "It gives us a little respect."
 
Car Services
An 18-Hour Day, $70 Taken Home
 When the "check engine" light flashed yellow inside Mr. Bekheit's cab on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway recently, an untypically good day suddenly turned sour. He stopped the wheezing car at a garage, discharged his passenger and, as green fluid trickled from a radiator hose, tallied the losses: an $11 fare, $50 for repairs and three hours of precious driving time.
Eighteen hours into a workday, Mr. Bekheit (pronounced beck-EAT) was weak with hunger, red-eyed from exhaustion and brimming with disgust. As the mechanic tinkered under the car, Mr. Bekheit ducked into a storage room, kneeled on some grease-stained rags and prayed to Allah. Then he barreled back into business.
"One dollar!" the Egyptian immigrant muttered, stuffing the remains of his earnings into a pocket. "And today was busy, today I was going to make money."
Mr. Bekheit, 26 years old, came to the United States from Alexandria in 1987, drove a medallion cab briefly and then returned to Egypt. But he returned to the United States a year ago, hoping to save enough money to attend graduate engineering school in New York City.
A friend recommended taxi driving, so he bought a car for $1,200 and became one of 22,000 drivers in the neighborhood car business. One year later, he is on his fifth car: a 1985 Cadillac Brougham with 240,000 miles, a dented passenger door and a cockeyed headlight. The car cost him $2,700.
 
Independent Operator
 Like most car-service drivers, Mr. Bekheit is an independent operator who pays a 25 percent commission to the licensed radio base that arranges his trips, Apple Express in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Unlike yellow cabs, car services and black cars are not allowed to pick up street hails, though many do anyway.
On a good, 18-hour day, Mr. Bekheit says he can take home $70 after expenses. To pay his bills and save some money, he almost always works seven days a week. In the last year, he has been robbed three times and shot in the leg once.
A handsome, soft-spoken man, Mr. Bekheit says crime has not deterred him from driving all night. But fear of it has kept him from bringing his wife and 4-year-old son to New York City. Unable to save enough to begin graduate school, he has begun thinking about returning to Egypt.
"Sometime, you must stop," he said. "You miss your wife, you miss your son, you miss your country. Sometime you must stop."
 
Gypsy Cabs
Earning a Living Could Be Fatal
 Tony Smith's choices have also been bleak.
An automobile mechanic who was laid off last year, the Jamaican immigrant says he began driving a gypsy cab when he couldn't find work paying more than the minimum wage.
"I never sold drugs, but the thought do cross my mind," he said. "I said to myself, you make bigger money, faster money. But I don't want to go to jail. In this business, the most I get is a ticket."
Mr. Smith, 27, is one of scores of gypsy-cab drivers who make illegal street pickups in Southeast Queens. Because many gypsies work part time, there are no accurate estimates of their numbers. The Taxi and Limousine Commission estimates about 8,000, but the licensed car-service industry says the number is over 20,000 and growing as unemployed people join the business.
With virtually no overhead or licensing fees to pay, gypsy drivers can charge less than licensed taxis or buses, usually $1 per short, local ride; anything longer is negotiable. But city taxi officials say there is a downside to the price: many gypsy drivers carry little or no insurance, drive dilapidated cars and even commit crimes against their passengers.
Such concerns seem not to have deterred Mr. Smith's clientele. On a good day, he can earn $20 an hour during rush hour and take home $75 for the day, he says. However, when taxi commission officials patrol the area, as they did on Friday, he stops work. During that crackdown, a taxi inspector was stabbed in the leg by an unlicensed driver. The driver was charged with second-degree assault.
 
'We Move Faster'
 Every morning, Mr. Smith cruises Hollis Avenue, honking his horn and beckoning to people near bus stops, some acquaintances, some regular riders. "People aren't stupid," Mr. Smith said. "They say we move faster than the buses. And why should they ride the bus when they know I can take them to their door?"
Tall and lanky, with a mustache and flat-top haircut, Mr. Smith does his best to provide clean, friendly service. The red-velour interior of his white 1985 Chrysler Le Baron is immaculate, though riddled with cigarette burns. He carries several Luther Vandross tapes favored by riders.
But the car, which was given to him by a relative, shakes when Mr. Smith accelerates over 30 miles per hour. He says the vehicle has been inspected, properly registered and carries liability insurance, for which he pays $1,500 a year.
Despite the low overhead, there is one high cost to gypsy cab work: crime. Of the 33 murders and approximately 3,000 robberies committed against all cab drivers last year, gypsy drivers were probably the most common victims, the police say.
Mr. Smith, who routinely gives rides to local drug dealers carrying guns, says he protects himself with a black jack he carries under his seat. "I'm scared," he said. "But I have no choice but to work late. I can't go home with just $50 in my pocket."
 
Black Cars
Tie and Town Car, But Still Sweating
 After almost losing the use of his left arm when his yellow cab crashed on a rainy night in 1987, Majeed Salhab moved into safer work. He bought a black car.
The move has been costly, with high start-up costs and overhead. But his peace of mind is greater. Instead of hustling nonstop for fares, fearing that passengers will rob him and battling Manhattan traffic on 12-hour shifts, the Palestinian immigrant sets his hours, picking and choosing from what amounts to the cream of taxi work. Unlike the other drivers, Mr. Salhab has little fear of crime, because his passengers do not pay him directly. Instead they pay the black-car company, which deducts a commission and fees and pays the balance weekly to Mr. Salhab.
"I know this is not big business," he said. "But at least I'm my own boss. That's worth a lot to me."
Mr. Salhab, 32, who lives in Bergen County, N.J., sits near the top of the taxi spectrum as one of 7,000 drivers of black cars, the radio-dispatched luxury cars that primarily serve corporate accounts.
The industry evolved in the early 1980's when the city ordered medallion cabs to remove their radios. Then, several fleets quit the yellow industry and began operating just radio cars. They lost the right to pick up street hails, but they retained lucrative corporate customers. During the flush years of the 1980's, black-car companies were bustling and profitable.
 
Harder Times
 But in the lean 1990's, they have suffered. Most black-car companies are cooperatives in which drivers become shareholders by buying radios that give them access to the companies' corporate customers. The more revenue the client list produces, the more expensive the radios. In the 1980's, some radios sold for $80,000 and more. Today, those radios sell for half that or less.
Those woes have not affected Mr. Salhab because he leases his radio from his company, Skyline Credit Line Inc. But he says that he must work 50 percent longer to earn the same money he earned three years ago.
Mr. Salhab dislikes one aspect of black-car work: People think he is rich. "They see your suit and tie, your Lincoln, they want to steal from you," he said. "They don't know how we make our money. They think it came easy."
 
Medallion Cabs
Bright Yellow Cabs And Faded Dreams
 As dusk descends on Greenwich Village each night, Majeed Moughal and dozens of other Pakistani medallion drivers descend on Greenwich Village.
Rush-hour traffic eddies around their taxis outside Gaseteria on Houston Street as the drivers gossip and gripe in preparation for changing shifts. In Pakistan, the drivers had been lawyers, engineers and business owners. They came to America for political reasons, education or better jobs. They settled, uncomfortably, for taxi work.
"Tell me, what else can I do?" said Mr. Moughal when someone ribbed him for driving for more than two years. "At least I have a piece of bread at night. At least it is better than being a criminal in the street."
Mr. Moughal (pronounced MOE-gull) had taught psychology at a teacher's college in central Pakistan. But when his career stalled five years ago, he came to America to obtain a graduate degree, a sure-fire ticket to promotion in Pakistan, he thought.
Little has turned out as he planned. He found a job as a security guard but was laid off in 1989 and turned to taxi driving. Since then, he has divorced his wife in Pakistan and married a Russian emigre he met in a Brighton Beach meat market. "Now I have no reason to leave," he said. "Now I work for my family."
Mr. Moughal, 41, is typical of the new medallion driver. In 1991, 21 percent of the new applicants for hack licenses were from Pakistan, more than double any other group of applicants.
 
Well-Educated Drivers
 Though there are no statistics on the subject, interviews with dozens of Pakistani drivers suggest many were college-trained professionals in their homeland. For some, cab driving is a painfully embarrassing fall from grace. "Don't tell anyone what I did in Pakistan," said an electrical engineer. "It is a disgrace to my profession."
But others who have tasted the bitterness of unemployment or minimum-wage labor view cab driving as something better. Such people often seek to buy their own cars or medallions -- the city licenses that allow taxi drivers to pick up street hails.
Mr. Moughal is one. He currently leases his cab and medallion for $550 a week. But he knows his prospects of buying them are uncertain. Medallions cost as much as $140,000, and few drivers can save enough. He works 12-hour shifts seven days a week to bring home $500 weekly -- just enough to support his wife, her daughter and mother in their one-bedroom Brighton Beach apartment.
He still studies psychology textbooks in his car during breaks, but his dream of graduate school has faded. "With a child, a wife, a home, how can you get to where you want to be," he said. "We stay at home and watch TV; that's all we can afford. And it is getting tougher. I'm lost in this profession."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Reaction in Congress;
Some Republicans, but Not All, Praise the Expected Appointments

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Republican members of Congress joined their Democratic colleagues today in praising the expected appointment of Senator Lloyd Bentsen as Treasury Secretary, but some raised concerns about other leading candidates for President-elect Bill Clinton's economic team.
Democrats said the reported list of economic advisers reflected Mr. Clinton's commitment to move the party away from traditional tax-and-spend liberalism toward pragmatism.. 
 Members of both parties voiced enthusiasm for Senator Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, who is widely expected to be chosen Treasury Secretary. And they thought that Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, would make a strong advocate for fiscal discipline should he be selected director of the Office of Management and Budget.
But some Republicans predicted that Robert B. Reich, a Harvard instructor who is widely expected to assume a senior economic post, would become a lightning rod for partisan controversy.
 
Criticism From Gramm
 Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a ranking Republican on the Banking and Appropriations Committees, criticized Mr. Reich as "a state socialist, a national economic planner" who might push for the kind of economic policies that failed in Eastern Europe.
Still, the overall reaction from both sides of the aisle was positive. "Wonderful appointments," said Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, a ranking Republican on the Banking and Finance Committees. "Bentsen is thoughtful and sound. If Clinton's got Panetta in there, he's picking someone who is concerned about the deficits and is willing to do something about them."
Speculation on the economic appointments has reached a high pitch on Capitol Hill, in large part because Mr. Bentsen's and Mr. Panetta's departures would trigger potentially significant leadership changes on the Senate Finance Committee and the House Budget Committee that they now head, with possible policy implications affecting social security, health care, trade and the environment.
The ultimate effect on Congress is still a matter of speculation, but an appointment for Mr. Panetta could set off a donnybrook between Democratic liberals and conservatives over who would become chairman of the Budget Committee, which has special rules on succession. Several members said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's accession to the chairmanship of the Finance Committee would lend the panel greater creativity in dealing with the rising costs of entitlements like Social Security.
Mr. Moynihan is expected to give up his chairmanship of the Committee on Environment and Public Works to assume the Finance Committee post, opening the way for Senator Max Baucus, a Democratic environmentalist from Montana, to take over for Mr. Moynihan. Already chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on International Trade, Mr. Baucus would assume substantial leverage in his goal of pressuring the Mexican Government to improve its environmental standards in exchange for ratifying the free trade agreement with Mexico.
 
Democrats Offer Praise
 Not surprising, Democrats greeted the expected announcements with the warmest praise.
"It's a very good team that combines new ideas and pragmatism," said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, a ranking Democrat on the House Banking Committee. He added that Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Panetta, Mr. Reich and Roger Altman, a New York investment banker expected to become deputy treasury secretary, would push to open new export markets and promote high-technology industries without involving the Government in areas where the private sector is better off left alone.
Senator Richard H. Bryan, a moderate Democrat from Nevada, said the expected appointments "show that Clinton is indeed a new kind of Democrat."
Even some conservative Republicans voiced approval for some of the expected appointments.
Senator Steve Symms of Idaho, a Republican member of the Budget and Finance Committees, said the appointment of Mr. Bentsen "should send strong signals to everyone in the financial community that there will be a steady hand at Treasury." And should Mr. Panetta receive the nod, Mr. Symms said, "the deficit will no longer be the Reagan deficit and the Bush deficit; we will have everyone involved in it."
 
Bentsen Departure Assailed
 Mr. Gramm had kind words for Mr. Panetta and Mr. Bentsen, his fellow Texan, but with the inclusion of Mr. Reich, who he believes is an unreformed liberal, he said, "I don't see a consistent team there."
Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut, a Republican member of the House Ways and Means Committee, was also critical of Mr. Reich, saying he "is clearly identified with one extreme of thinking in terms of manipulating economic growth." She also said she regretted to see Mr. Bentsen leave the Senate "because he is one of the most knowledgeable and balanced thinkers on health care reform."
And as for Mr. Panetta, Ms. Johnson criticized his leadership role in defeating the proposed balanced budget amendment last year, adding, "If you're trying to break gridlock, it seems to me unwise to choose appointments that focus on partisan differences."
Although Mr. Panetta's appointment is not certain, House Democrats are already expecting that Representative Charles W. Stenholm, a conservative Texan who is a chief promoter of the balanced budget amendment, will run to replace him as Budget Committee chairman. Liberals are expected to rally behind Representative Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, as Representative John M. Spratt of South Carolina jockeys to become the compromise winner should no candidate win a first ballot caucus victory.

HEADLINE: Amy Fisher Locales Shunned by Producers

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 4

 BODY:
Three production companies are racing to complete television movies of the Amy Fisher story, but none of the filming is being done on Long Island, where the drama played itself out.
The contradiction has not been lost on officials of Nassau and Suffolk counties assigned to attract film makers to the island. But they say that few movies set on the island have been filmed here lately and that things have been especially difficult since a labor dispute led many production companies to boycott the New York City area. 
 The scene of the May 19 shooting -- the front steps of Joseph and Mary Jo Buttafuoco's white split-level house on Adams Road West in Massapequa -- is being re-created at studios in Los Angeles, Toronto and Vancouver, British Columbia.
It was on these steps that Miss Fisher, then 17 years old, shot Mrs. Buttafuoco in the head. She recovered, but not without damage to her hearing and jaw, and the .25-caliber bullet remains lodged in her neck near her spinal cord.
Miss Fisher, who insists that Mr. Buttafuoco put her up to shooting his wife, was sentenced on Tuesday to 5 to 15 years in prison. Mr. Buttafuoco has denied the charges and has said he never had an affair with Miss Fisher.
 
Little Contact
 Debbie Markowitz, director of cinema and television production for the Nassau County Department of Commerce and Industry, said, "So far, all we've gotten are requests for police badges and photographs of police uniforms. Other than that, we've had very little input into the Amy movies. They all started production without us."
Ms. Markowitz said the motion picture and television production industry contributed at least $10 million a year to the economy in Nassau, but she said it appeared little would come this year from the Fisher story.
Huntington Hospital, where Miss Fisher was taken by her lawyer, Eric Naiburg, after two suicide attempts, is in Suffolk County, but it has not been approached by the Fisher film makers. Christopher Cook, director of the Suffolk County motion picture and television bureau, said he had received no inquiries.
"I think the bottom line may be the weather factor," he said. "It's sunnier in California at this time of year, and they're racing to put it all together."
"There's also the matter of a wage differential between the United States and Canada and the exchange rate, which favors the Canadian dollar over the U.S. dollar," he said.
 
Perception on Expenses Cited
 He noted that Long Island was the place to make moves in the mid-80's but that the industry was "faddish" and had moved elsewhere. "But it's cyclical and will return," he said.
A seven-month Hollywood boycott of the New York City area over labor costs also played a part, Mr. Cook said. The boycott ended in mid-May 1991, when film-production unions in the area granted concessions on overtime wages in return for enhanced health and pension benefits.
Bruce Feinberg, the new director of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's film office, said his mission is to promote film making from Montauk to the Canadian border. And while Long Island has all the expertise and settings for a Fisher film, he said, "You can't argue with the Canadian exchange rate."
He said the film industry, which is produced by a blue-collar work force behind a glamorous facade, adds an estimated $2.5 billion to the state's economy each year.
Mr. Cook, meanwhile, said he remained philosophical about the loss of the Fisher film projects. He noted that the movie of "The Great Gatsby," set on the North Shore, was filmed in Newport, R.I.; "The "Amityville Horror," about a haunted house on the South Shore, was filmed in New Jersey, and Peter Benchley's "Jaws," about a shark that terrorizes the East End of Long Island, was filmed off Martha's Vineyard.
Of the three Amy Fisher movies, ABC's "Beyond Control: The Amy Fisher Story," starring Drew Barrymore was the first to set a broadcast date, Sunday, Jan. 24. The film, based on press accounts of the case, is being made in Vancouver.
The NBC movie is being made by KLM, a Long Island production company, but is being filmed in Toronto. Based on Miss Fisher's account, it is called "Treachery in the Suburbs" and will star Noelle Parker, a newcomer. It will also be shown Jan. 24.
CBS's "Casualty of Love," stars Alyssa Milano, formerly of "Who's the Boss". The film, produced by Tristar and based on the Buttafuocos' story, is being filmed in Los Angeles and is to be shown Jan. 26..

HEADLINE: C.E.O. of Public Education Inc.

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 3

 BODY:
Bundled in a camel's-hair coat behind the wheel of his Lincoln Town Car, Dr. Philip E. Geiger looks more like a Fortune 500 C.E.O. than a school superintendent.
He sounds like one, too, as he enthusiastically talks about "zero-based budgets," "strategic planning" and "electronic spreadsheets." And the 45-year-old school superintendent is as proud of his master's degree in business administration from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance as he is of his doctorate in education from Columbia University. 
 Make no mistake about it, though. Phil Geiger's business is running the 10 public schools in Piscataway Township, and in the eyes of admirers he is a model of a new generation of school administrators who must manage the conflicting forces of constricting budgets and expanding educational needs.
 
Hiring Private Companies
 His major cost-cutting weapon has been the hiring of private companies to provide noninstructional services, a trend seen across the nation. He and other school administrators say that one way to cut costs without interfering with the quality of education in the classroom is to focus on the wage and benefit contracts awarded in palmier economic times to support workers like bus drivers, custodians and cafeteria workers.
At the same time, Dr. Geiger is putting the savings into an array of new programs that he says will make the district, which has 6,000 students and a budget of $51 millionthis year, a leader in classroom instruction in the region.
Plans are under way for programs to accelerate students' computer, science, mathematics and reading skills. Also, parents and teachers are examining ways to use community resources more effectively.
For school administrators, who have seen their work loads jump, and for parents and teachers, the reaction to Dr. Geiger is often mixed. Some express outright or grudging admiration for the superintendent's attempts to cut overhead, while others worry where the ax will fall next.
"He is a dynamic, innovative figure who has created a lot of excitement in our schools," said Paula Van Riper, an assistant dean of academic services at Rutgers University who serves as president of the Piscataway Township Board of Education.
But others peg Dr. Geiger, who took over in mid-1991, as a heartless bureaucrat with a bottom-line brain and a calculator for a heart.
"He has come into this town and caused chaos," said Marge Mathews, 58, a school bus driver for 30 years who says she will go on unemployment next year rather than work for the low wages a private bus operator would pay.
Dr. Geiger's own view, shared by many educators in the region, is that the present political climate of cutting costs allows the schools to cast off old ways of doing things that were expensive and introduce new programs that in calmer days would have met strong resistance.
"That's where a zero-based budget comes into play," said Dr. Geiger, who this month is concluding a long series of budget talks with administrators.
"Every year we clear the decks and justify every dime we spend," added Dr. Geiger, whose salary is $120,000 a year. "If a program can't be justified other than by tradition, we look at how its costs can be re-allocated to improve instruction without spending new money."
The district diverted $2.4 million from noninstructional expenditures into the classroom last year, a feat Dr. Geiger hopes to more than match in his new budget.
 
Concerns of Unions
 Just how far school administrators take the move to use private companies is a matter of concern for unions that represent teachers and school support personnel.
A few districts have contracted with private companies even to supply teachers. In Baltimore, Educational Alternatives Inc., a Minnesota-based company, has a five-year contract to manage and staff five city schools.
Until last year when the board awarded the school cafeteria contract to Service America Inc., 55 lunchroom workers, who were not unionized, were paid $8 to $15 an hour by the district. Even though they worked only five hours a day during the school year and had summers off, Dr. Geiger said, the 55 were given full health and dental benefits equal to those of teachers, costing the district $8,000 per employee in premiums. The workers also qualified for pensions.
The district saved $500,000 in the first year and expects similar savings in the future, said Dr. Geiger. Meanwhile, daily use of the cafeterias by students rose because of better menu choices, he added.
All the cafeteria workers at the school were offered work by Service America at a 20 percent reduction in pay and no health benefits other than what they would pay out of pocket, Dr. Geiger said. Two out of three made the switch but about 10 quit during the past year, he said.
The move to privatize the school bus system by early next year has run into more public resistance because the bus drivers, unlike the lunchroom workers, are familiar faces to parents. Drivers who earn $12 an hour plus full benefits expect cuts similar to those experienced by the cafeteria workers.
"We are opposed to it for the safety of the children," said Michele Martin, president of the Piscataway Township Education Association, the union which represents the district's teachers and bus drivers.
If privatization goes through as expected, the saving will be $1.5 million a year, Dr. Geiger says. And the sale of the existing bus fleet should net an additional $1.3 million, he said.
 
New Computer System
 The district plans to use these and other savings to establish a new $4 million computer network that, Dr. Geiger says, will be unrivaled in New Jersey. It will vastly improve learning skills in the elementary grades, he said.
Dr. Geiger, who has been a school superintendent since the age of 29 and has also worked as a private consultant, was recruited from Lexington, Mass., an affluent suburb outside Boston. It was his experience in contracting out school services to private companies in Lexington, as well as his budgeting prowess, that caught the attention of those in the New Jersey district.
As if to underscore his point, supposing anyone had missed it, Dr. Geiger has designed a symbol of his administration that is widely displayed in the schools. It shows the letters B.A.U. within a circle with a red line drawn diagonally through them. "No more business as usual," he said emphatically.
