HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
Aides Say U.S. Role in Somalia Gives Bush a Way to Exit in Glory

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Friends and advisers to President Bush say that mounting concern about the fate of more than one million starving people was the major goad to his decision, 11 days ago, to offer troops for use in Somalia. But it is no coincidence, they add, that Mr. Bush is leaving office with a show of American might in a noble cause.
Having seen a chance to exit with an example of America's global responsibility in a fragmented world, they said, the President has shaken off considerable bitterness over his political loss and seized it. 
 In interviews during the last week, several associates and aides who have spoken to Mr. Bush about Somalia said the American expedition represents the sort of hard-nosed foreign policy decision that political concerns have constrained Mr. Bush from making openly, and which defeat has freed him to pursue.
None of those people, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, suggested that Mr. Bush delayed action in Somalia for political reasons during a campaign that was obsessed with domestic economic concerns. In fact, it was not until after the election that Administration and United Nations experts began to regard the situation as so dire that only military force could change it.
 
Political Considerations Denied
 One senior Administration official argued that political considerations were not involved, noting that the United States has steadily increased its military and diplomatic role in Somalia since last summer.
Still, that aide noted that Mr. Bush's campaign advisers were "fearful of accusations that all the President cared about was foreign policy," and strongly urged him to take a lower public profile on all foreign issues until after the election.
"Would we have been a little more vigorous otherwise?" the aide asked. "That's harder to answer."
Viewed from a strictly humanitarian point, Mr. Bush's aides said this week, the White House's decision on Nov. 25 to commit troops to Somalia was forced by a steady decline in the country's military and social condition that began in mid-October and reached a peak days before Thanksgiving.
 
Airlift Began in August
 The United States began airlifting food into Somalia on military transport planes on Aug. 14, and after both aircraft and relief convoys began to come under scattered attack by rival gangs, the Pentagon dispatched 2,400 marines in mid-September to ships in the Indian Ocean off Somalia's coast.
Late that same month, the United Nations sent 500 Pakistani soldiers to Mogadishu, the Somali capital, but the troops were never deployed outside the city's seaport and airport because gang leaders could not agree on their placement. By mid-October, the gangs had forced the closure of the nation's second-biggest seaport, at Kismayu, and the flow of relief began to shrink more rapidly.
But officials said that it was not until late October or early November, when the Mogadishu seaport also was forced to close and the city was virtually blockaded by the warring gangs, that the need for military intervention began to become apparent to the White House.
By Nov. 7, when the seaport shut down, only 20 percent of aid shipments were reaching starving citizens; the remainder was being stolen by gangs. In the week before Mr. Bush offered the use of American troops, gangs shot and seriously wounded a Pakistani soldier in the United Nations force and a United Nations official was robbed at gunpoint in Kismayu.
 
U.N. Ship Forced Back to Sea
 The day before Mr. Bush's offer, a United Nations ship carrying 10,000 tons of supplies was hit by artillery fire as it tried to dock in Mogadishu, and was forced back to sea.
"We started early last summer flying the aid in because the U.N. wasn't doing the job," one senior aide said.
"After the Pakistani troops arrived, things really, really just kind of closed down -- a month ago, maybe," he said "I mean, it wasn't a precipitous thing, but it's just pretty much closed down now."
That relentless deterioration of conditions ultimately led Mr. Bush to commit American troops to a United Nations efforts inside Somalia, aides and friends said. But they said that other factors, including Mr. Bush's desire to leave office on a high note, may well have played roles, too.
 
White House Drove U.S. Role
 Throughout the summer and fall, Administration officials said, decisions to commit aircraft to relief flights and deploy marines to the Indian Ocean were driven by the White House, sometimes amid reservations by military leaders in the Pentagon.
One friend and adviser described Mr. Bush as the last of a series of Presidents who were steeled by the experiences of World War II and the cold war.
"The President represents a strong current of thinking about foreign policy . . . about the need for international engagement," another senior Bush aide said.
From a purely personal standpoint, another senior official said this week, the President wishes to be seen ending his term as a decisive leader, not as a vanquished politician. To the extent that pictures of starving Somalians can be replaced by Jan. 20 with images of American troops handing out food, that aide said, Mr. Bush will leave the White House a content man.

HEADLINE: Eskimos Learn They've Been Living Amid Secret Pits of Radioactive Soil

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE

 BODY:
The season of darkness, two months without a sunrise, has fallen over much of the Alaskan Arctic, and with it has come a sense of betrayal and uneasiness among the native people not seen for some time.
Thirty years ago the Inupiat Eskimos north of here successfully stopped a plan by the Federal Government to create an Arctic harbor with a huge atomic blast near the village of Point Hope, on the Chukchi Sea in northwestern Alaska. Now the Eskimos have learned they were not free, after all, of the Government's nuclear experiments. 
 While the idea of blowing a hole in the ice was shelved in 1962, the Government went ahead with a secret project the same year to bury several thousand pounds of radioactive soil in the same area.
 
Shallow, Unmarked Mound
 The soil, which Government documents said contained trace amounts of fallout from a nuclear explosion at the Nevada Test Site, was placed in a dozen pits to examine how radioactivity spreads in an Arctic environment, then was scooped up and buried in a shallow mound. The site was unmarked by warning signs; the people who live and hunt in the area were never told of its existence.
The Eskimos learned of the buried nuclear waste this fall when Dan O'Neill, a researcher at the University of Alaska, made public documents he had found while researching a book on the abandoned harbor plan, which was publicly reported at the time but had been largely forgotten.
In October, after acknowledging the details of the 1962 plan, Government scientists tested the soil and concluded that it no longer posed a health hazard. But many native leaders say they don't believe the scientists, and they are thinking of hiring their own experts to test the site. Natives of the North Slope have a cancer rate that far exceeds the national average.
 
Nothing but a Wasteland
 "I can't tell you how angry I am that they considered our home to be nothing but a big wasteland," said Jeslie Kaleak, Mayor of the North Slope Borough, which governs eight Arctic villages, including Point Hope. "They didn't give a damn about the people who live up here."
In Point Hope, an ancient whaling village of 700 people that anthropologists say is one of the oldest continuously inhabited sites in North America, Mayor David Stone said: "We feel betrayed. The people have lost their trust in the Federal Government."
When Senator Frank Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, visited the village in the fall, an elderly woman threw herself at him and shouted, "You have poisoned our land!"
The disclosures highlight a jarring collision of two worlds: the hunting and whaling subsistence life of the natives, in a relatively pristine environment, and the Government's can-do engineering mentality.
The plan to set off a nuclear blast in the Arctic was known as Project Chariot and was designed in the late 1950's to demonstrate a peaceful use of the atom. The idea was to create a deep-water port that could be used to export coal in the three months of summer, when the Chukchi Sea is not frozen.
Project Chariot ran into fierce opposition at Point Hope, which lies less than 100 miles from the Russian border. The blast, to have been set just offshore from the village, would have contaminated prime caribou hunting grounds and disrupted fishing and whaling in the area. At the time, many of the people still lived in sod houses and spoke the native Inupiat language.
 
Derision, Then Another Plan
 While the native opposition may have been a crucial factor in killing Project Chariot, the Government was also unable to find a commercial partner who thought it might be economically feasible to operate a man-made harbor in the Far North.
"It was real lame-brain operation that nobody in Alaska saw much merit in," said Chuck Kleeschulte, an aide to Senator Murkowski.
But late in 1962, about the same time the Government announced it was abandoning Project Chariot, it went ahead with the plan to see how radioactive isotopes would react in an Arctic environment. This project, a United States Geological Survey study done under a license by the Atomic Energy Commission, was never given a public hearing.
Although the documents from the time are sketchy about the real purpose of the project, Mr. O'Neill said he suspected the Government was trying to prove that radioactivity was less harmful in frigid conditions. and that Project Chariot was therefore feasible.
To do their experiments the scientists chose some Federal land on Cape Thompson, 25 miles south of Point Hope, and placed several thousand pounds of radioactive soil in a dozen pits over a two-mile radius to monitor its leaching.
According to the documents, the soil came from within a mile of ground zero of a nuclear blast in Nevada and contained strontium-85 and cesium-137. Tom Gerusky, a Government health physicist who visited the site in October, said the amounts were small enough to have been carried to Alaska in a cloth bag, with some of the most intensely radioactive isotopes in lead pouches. The strontium would typically have lost all its radioactivity years ago, and the cesium would still have about half its radioactivity after 30 years.
 
'Up Through the Food Chain'
 Many Eskimos fear they were harmed by exposure to the contaminants. "Both cesium and strontium are extremely worrisome because they can go up through the food chain," said Mr. O'Neill.
He said the scientists greatly exceeded limits on the volume of radioactive material that may be buried unsealed. "The documents show that what they did was illegal," he said. "What they buried was a thousand times higher than the allowable standard for that kind of nuclear burial."
After conducting experiments, the Government scientists scooped up about 15,000 pounds of contaminated soil, buried it in an unmarked mound and left the site as a sort of anonymous nuclear grave. That was the end of it until September, when Mr. O'Neill made public his documents.
The news shocked Point Hope. Perhaps no one was more upset than Wilfred Lane Sr., an Inupiat who had chosen 160 acres adjacent to the burial mound as his part of an aboriginal claim to which he is entitled.
 
Abandoning a Dream
 When he picked the land in 1971, he said, no one from the State of Alaska or the Federal Government informed him that the site contained radioactive contaminants. His family had long hunted near Cape Thompson.
"My plan was to build a youth camp there," said Mr. Lane, who is 52 years old and lives in Kotzebue, south of Cape Thompson. "I wanted to make a place where we could teach the youth about native culture in the summer."
Mr. Lane said his brother, who had regularly hunted caribou, picked berries and eaten murre eggs in the Cape Thompson area, died of cancer a few years ago.
Although Mr. Lane and other natives now blame radioactivity for the Eskimos' high cancer rate, Government researchers say it is because of poor diet and cigarette smoking.
Department of Energy officials, who are charged with cleaning up the nation's nuclear dump sites, say they are working on a plan to remove the Cape Thompson waste next year.
 
Little Harm, Physicist Says
 "I know people are upset, but we don't believe anybody received any significant radioactive exposure from this," said Mr. Gerusky, the Government health physicist.
It is unclear how much radioactivity from aboveground nuclear blasts by the Soviet Union may have drifted into the Arctic, but American officials say the amount could be considerable.
There is also concern that the Bering and Chukchi Seas are contaminated by radioactivity: Russia has acknowledged that over the last three decades the Soviets dumped old submarines with damaged nuclear reactors, and more than 10,000 containers of nuclear waste, in waters of the Far North.
Although Energy Department officials said they knew of no other American nuclear waste sites in the Arctic, Mr. O'Neill said he expected more disclosures. "It's unfortunate, because right now relations between the natives and the Government have been poisoned by all of this," he said.

PUB-DATE: December 6, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 56; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1133 words

HEADLINE: Hospital Bills and Paying Them

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
By court order, New Jersey had to change the way it compensated hospitals for unpaid care. But last week the state went far beyond that task, not only adopting a controversial alternative on paying for indigent care, but making momentous changes in the rules governing health insurance and hospital charges.
An odd alliance of a Republican majority and a Democratic Governor churned out a bewildering group of new laws with effects that will not be known for years. News of the far-reaching changes in the insurance market was almost lost amid the drama of the close vote on the hospital compensation plan, which will draw on money from the state unemployment fund. Gov. Jim Florio, for his part, claimed that the state had entered a new era: "These reforms will help make sure no one in our state has to lie awake at night wondering how to pay the bills if someone in the family gets sick."
 
Falls Short of Clinton's Goal
 Hyperbole aside, the new insurance measures should make health coverage more widely available. They put New Jersey in the forefront of a handful of states that are making major changes in health care and are also consistent with changes that President-elect Bill Clinton is expected to seek for the whole country. 
 But for all they may accomplish, the changes in New Jersey also illustrate the difficulties the states face in the field: the measures fall well short of the goal Mr. Florio expressed and Mr. Clinton has set: universal health coverage. And they hold little promise of holding down the surge in medical costs, the root of the crisis.
New Jersey has faced the same breakdown in health security as the rest of the country. Officials estimate that more than 800,000 residents -- more than 10 percent of the population -- now lack health insurance. Most are the working poor and their families -- those not poor enough to get Medicaid but not affluent enough to afford premiums. Others have been denied coverage or quoted exorbitant rates because they have medical problems or are otherwise deemed high risk.
The underlying goal of the new measures is a transition that all sides are seeking. Now, medical bills of the uninsured are picked up by the state when they are hospitalized or use emergency rooms. The new aim is have more people insured, covering primary care as well as hospitalization. Payments to hospitals for charity care are being reduced.
 
City Hospitals' Rocky Future
 The Governor had used the pressure of a Nov. 30 deadline on indigent care financing to push through additional major changes in the health insurance system. These include measures to end price discrimination by health insurers against the sick and the old; creation of a new form of subsidized insurance for the working poor; requiring insurers to offer five standardized plans to small businesses and individuals, allowing for comparison shopping; and putting new limits on insurers' administrative costs and profits.
The Republicans, securing their goal in the grand bargain, radically reduced the regulation of hospitals. Bucking a national trend, the Republicans ended hospital price controls, which they said hampered competition between institutions, but which many experts said had actually helped to hold down the state's medical costs.
The deal they put together includes the most ambitious attempt of any state to extend coverage. Still, it is unclear how many people will secure it, and the change may be a rocky one, especially for urban hospitals, which now serve many uninsured patients. "This change makes sense, but with such radical shifts occurring, it's hard to tell what's really going to happen in terms of the coverage of the population," said Anne Gauthier of the Alpha Center, a nonprofit health policy group in Washington, who has studied state reforms. "Will the patients walking in the door really have the insurance?"
Some consumer advocates said that the new insurance rules gave too much power to the industry and may result only in higher insurance prices for everyone, without much relief for the needy. Officials respond that for the first time, insurers will be forced to compete over price, rather than over who can sign up the healthiest group of customers.
Whatever the gaps, New Jersey overnight moved into the forefront of change at the state level. Despite all the talk of insurance reform, only a few states, including New York, Minnesota, Vermont and Maine, have actually passed anti-discrimination measures resembling those in New Jersey; how they will work in practice remains to be seen.
While Oregon and Massachusetts have drawn up more ambitious plans that would mandate universal coverage, these have been stalled by legal challenges and the economic recession. Hawaii remains the only state with near-total coverage, achieved by requiring employers to offer insurance and creating a state-subsidized plan for others.
 
Trying to Tame the Monster
 In part, the limits of New Jersey's plan reflect its local political constraints: new taxes are anathema for now, state government is starkly divided by party and lobbyists for private hospitals and insurance companies have wielded great power.
But the shortcomings also reflect the problems facing any state trying to tame the health-care monster on its own. Mr. Clinton has said he will propose a national plan for universal coverage and cost control early next year. While the details are still being debated, his proposals are expected to include curbs on discrimination by health insurers, much like those adopted in New Jersey, and also a much more sweeping requirement that all employers offer insurance to their workers.
"We'll make a dent in the number of uninsured; we'll do the best we can," said Brenda J. Bacon, Governor Florio's health adviser. "But we don't want to be the first state" to enact employer requirements, she said, "because of the possible negative impact on job growth."
State officials hope that hundreds of thousands of the working poor, and unemployed or part-time workers, will buy coverage from a new, subsidized plan called New Jersey Shield. While details remain to be fleshed out, a family of four earning $33,500 a year might pay $105 a month, a small fraction of the market rate, for comprehensive coverage in a private managed-care plan, officials said.
The needed public subsidy for the subsidized coverage is projected to rise from $50 million in 1994 to $200 million in 1997. Initially the money will come from the same pool as that for uncompensated hospital care: the state unemployment insurance fund. But that makeshift arrangement is supposed to end by Jan. 1, 1996.
Officials hope that by then a national program of health financing will be in place, providing some financial aid.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "NEW INSURANCE RULES"
 
Paying for the Uninsured
New insurance regulations adopted in New Jersey last week are aimed at reducing the number of uninsured residents, now estimated at more than 800,000.
Standardized policies: For individuals and small groups (2 to 49), insurers will be required to offer five standardized policies, encouraging direct price competition between companies.
Ending discrimination: Now, commercial insurers pick and choose among applicants. New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield, a nonprofit group that is required to serve as insurer of last resort, has seen its expenses soar as more high-risk patients enroll in individual and small group policies, a market it dominates. Under new "open enrollment" rules, commercial companies, too, will have to offer individual policies to all applicants up to a quota equal to their share of the overall health market, or pay an assessment to Blue Cross. Commercial insurers will also have to accept all small-group applicants. Under a "community rating" requirement, each insurer must set the same rates for all individuals and those in small groups, regardless of age, health status, sex, occupation, place of residence or other factors. A company's rates will vary only by the amount of coverage the customer chooses. This should reduce rates for the sick and the old but may raise them for healthy applicants.
Setting fees: Insurers in the individual and small group markets will be required to pay out at least 75 cents of every dollar collected for medical care; some now pay only about 60 cents, the rest going for administration and profits. The Insurance Commissioner's approval power over rate increases for individual policies has been lost, but officials hope that competition will prevent profiteering.
Subsidized insurance: Beginning in 1994, a new program, New Jersey Shield, will offer a subsidized managed-care plan, with premiums on a sliding scale based on income. Officials hope that as many as 450,000 people, mainly low-wage or part-time workers or the unemployed, will sign up. The subsidies, which could total $200 million or more annually within a few years, will initially come from the state unemployment insurance fund, but after 1995 a new source may be needed.
(Source: Office of the Governor)

HEADLINE: 10-Cent-a-Pack Cigarette Tax Increase Proposed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The State Health Department has proposed a 10-cent-a-pack increase in the cigarette tax, partly to pay for children's health programs and anti-smoking campaigns.
The increase would raise $28.6 million a year, health officials said in budget documents submitted to the State Office of Policy and Management for the 1993-94 fiscal year. 
 The Department of Health Services wants to spend $2.1 million on anti-smoking campaigns aimed at children and at women of childbearing age. Smoking causes 4,200 deaths in the state each year, resulting in economic losses totaling $700 million, state officials say.
The increase to 45 cents per pack also is proposed so the state will not become a destination for Massachusetts residents shopping for less expensive cigarettes, Health Services Commissioner Susan S. Addiss said.
Massachusetts will increase its cigarette tax by 25 cents, to 51 cents a pack, on Jan. 1.
"We feel it kind of behooves us to keep up with them," Ms. Addiss said. "From a public health point of view, we don't want to be seen as a mecca for purchasing cigarettes."
Bourke Spellacy, a Hartford lawyer who represents the Tobacco Institute, said cigarette companies would oppose the tax increase.
 
Last Increase Was in 1991
 "There is no industry that favors increasing taxes on itself," he said. "All our smaller businesses get hammered whenever that occurs."
The state last increased the tax in 1991, when it went up 5 cents per pack to the current level of 45 cents.
Health officials would like to use the tax revenue to make hepatitis B vaccine available to children whose families cannot now afford it. Federal health authorities recommend that the vaccine be given to all children in the first year of their lives, but the series of three shots costs $50 to $100, so many children are not being vaccinated.
Ms. Addiss said she would also like to expand school-based health clinics, a health insurance program for poor children and substance-abuse programs for teen-agers and pregnant women.
A Washington-based organization of state legislators, however, says Connecticut would be unlikely to get as much money through the tax increase as it expects.
Studies show that such increases often drive consumers to other states to buy cigarettes, said Noel Card, director of public affairs for the American Legislative Exchange Council. While out of state, some of those consumers will buy groceries, liquor and other products in addition to cigarettes.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Giuliani Lining Up His Team For Race

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
When he ran for Mayor of New York City in 1989, about the biggest criticism professional politicians made of Rudolph W. Giuliani was that he did not have enough political professionals helping him. Sure, his media adviser was Roger Ailes, the Peck's Bad Boy of the 1988 Republican Presidential race, and Mr. Giuliani came within 2 percentage points of winning, after a tough campaign.
But Mr. Ailes has more or less retired from politics, and Mr. Giuliani is trying to cast his net wider for his planned rematch against Mayor David N. Dinkins next year. Now comes word that he has been talking with Ed Rollins, the political consultant who was an architect of Ronald Reagan's 1984 landslide and who briefly defected from his party to work for Ross Perot this year, before quitting in irritation that his advice wasn't taken. 
 "No decisions have been made" about the campaign staff, said Mr. Giuliani's spokesman, Ken Frydman. But friends of Mr. Giuliani confirmed that discussions had been held.
One stumbling block may be that Mr. Giuliani has also been flirting with another high-powered consultant, David Garth, the New York media expert. New York Republicans said the challenge would be sorting out and melding the talents and egos of all those who might be willing to work for Mr. Giuliani.
 
Dueling Parties
 Live in New York tomorrow night -- separated by 40-odd blocks -- two decidedly opinionated women may both be asking, "Can we talk?"
But no one is likely to confuse them.
"I plan to say that if you're waiting for Joan Rivers to come on, you're at the wrong party," said Ruth W. Messinger, Manhattan's Borough President, who will be holding her annual winter fund-raiser at the National Arts Club off Grammercy Park at the same time Ms. Rivers will be on stage at City Council President Andrew J. Stein's fund-raiser in the Rainbow Room in Rockefeller Center.
Mr. Stein is asking his guests to pay $1,000 for a cocktail buffet and entertainment by Ms. Rivers and the chanteuse Andrea Marcovicci. Ms. Messinger -- who has made no secret of her willingness to serve in Bill Clinton's Administration, or her hope to someday hold citywide office -- is asking her guests to bring a wrapped gift for a child in a homeless shelter, along with their $500 or $1,000 contribution. She is a strong supporter of Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Stein's mayoral rival, and there is little warmth between her and Mr. Stein. So did she schedule her party to give him a little competition?
"Actually, I set it up long before I knew when his was," she said.
 
Election Day Experiment?
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who threw away convention two years ago in running for governor as a third-party independent and who has marched to his own drummer on other issues since then, now wants elections in Connecticut to be held on Saturdays.
He raised the issue this week after State Senator Kevin P. Johnston, a Democrat from Putnam, resigned to take a job as a state auditor. Under law, the governor must call a special election within 10 days of a legislator's resignation, and the election is then held exactly 46 days after the election writ is issued.
Tradition has dictated that those writs be issued on a Friday, thus requiring a regular Tuesday vote. But Mr. Weicker said this week he may well sign the document on Tuesday, mandating a Saturday election in mid-January. Connecticut's constitution and statutes books require Tuesday elections for statewide votes and most municipal elections, but are silent on the rules for filling mid-term vacancies.
"For a long time I've believed that we as a nation should be voting on Saturdays and Sundays," Mr. Weicker said on Friday. "When we vote on weekdays, there are a lot of other things that have to go on -- there's many other endeavors that make it difficult to exercise the voting franchise," he said.
But the Governor said the economic realities of the recession might short-circuit what he called "my great experiment in democracy." Town officials in Mr. Johnston's district have said that opening and heating the schools on a Saturday, and paying overtime to all the people needed to run the election, would batter some local budgets.
"I don't know if it's going to be this election or not, but I'd like to go ahead and give it a test," Mr. Weicker said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
From Poverty to Pushcart to Pros

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
The shame of poverty kept his brothers under their sheets during those unbroken mornings. The feeling, if not overpowering, wasn't foreign to Tony Fernandez, either, as he prepared to step into the streets and the stench and the dreams of San Pedro de Macoris.
Fernandez would rise with his parents. His father, with his quick smile and the deliberate, hitched stride of a field worker, would leave for the distant acres of sugar cane. His mother, sterner than his father, would set before Fernandez the pathetic pushcart his older brothers scorned. 
 Fernandez would swallow his pride and head off to collect the vegetables, items his mother would then sell in the street that day.
"There is not too much of a secret to your story when you are 8 years old and pushing that thing through the streets," Fernandez said. "You are poor, and the embarrassment of that was great for my brothers. Me, I don't know why I didn't feel ashamed."
Fernandez was not a natural for heroism. At birth, he was given the nickname Cabeza, meaning head in Spanish, because his frail frame was dominated by a large bald head.
With age came epithets and he was later termed a tullido, a cripple, by some because of a knee disability. His father was overprotective; his mother adored him but clung to no illusions about his promise.
"We were in the kitchen one day, and my mother came in and told my dad to send all of us boys off to work," Fernandez said. "She said we'd never be anything. But my dad said, no, that he believed Cabeza would do something, be something."
Jose Fernandez, father of 11, his hands cracked in equal parts by age and effort, held his child's head in his hands and looked into his eyes.
"They have a saying in my culture that at a certain age you can see what a boy is going to become," Fernandez said. "My dad was 60 years old. He was aware of life. I don't know what he saw. But he could look in my eyes and see something, listen to my words and hear something. He said Cabeza would do it."
It turned out that there was little Cabeza wouldn't do with a bat or a glove. He played his way out of the barrio. He played so well that the Toronto Blue Jays ultimately told Alfredo Griffin, Fernandez's idol, to play for somebody else. He played in All-Star Games for the American and National leagues. And he will play for the Mets in 1993, having been acquired from San Diego in late October.
 
Playing Forever
 Fernandez will, he says, play on into his 30's, and perhaps one day he will play in a World Series.
That, though, won't be enough, and so his wife, Clara, has insured that Fernandez, 30 years old, will be able to play forever. She has designed a baseball field cut out of the mountains outside San Pedro. The field -- which is three-quarters finished -- is placed at the outer reaches of Fernandez's 50-acre farm of corn and sugar cane and it measures 320 feet down the left-field line, 365 to center, 310 to right.
"The infield reminds me of Shea Stadium," a smiling Fernandez said as he stared out over the project from the hilltop chapel that is also being built as part of the estate. "That's coincidence," he said of the field's evocations of Shea. "I'm a Christian man, you know. Coincidence is all I can attribute it to."
Coincidence has otherwise played an insubstantial role in Fernandez's life. Labor and desire have won out. It's a story with a lot of the recognizable surface facts -- the rise from poverty to athletic stardom, but there are also ancillary and untold tales, as well as a broad, stubborn subtext of disillusionment, confusion and hurt.
It's a history that Fernandez helped trace recently as he and his wife and three children drove from their home in Santo Domingo to their surreal spread in the mountains.
"People don't know me; I know I am right about that," Fernandez said. "And I'm probably the wrong guy to ask, too. I don't even know how to describe myself. I believe I have a strong will. I believe that my story in baseball has mostly been one of joy. I believe I overcame many obstacles."
 
Armed Guards
 The chief obstacle for those leaving Fernandez's house in Santo Domingo was unease, for the guard at the gate had an impressive pistol on his hip and he may or may not have been old enough to have a driver's license. He was one of any number of armed security men posted around the exclusive, although by no means opulent, neighborhood.
The celebrity enjoyed by major league baseball stars in the Dominican Republic is a mix of the bizarre and the poignant. There is the need for security and the presence of guns, but more memorably there are the moments of delicacy and respect.
No fewer than half a dozen attendants swarmed to check the appointments of Fernandez's jeep at the debris-dominated local gas station. The banter was wonderfully informal, the requests modest.
"Hats, they'd like a couple of hats," Fernandez said. "Hats, hats, hats."
The newspaper boy on the street, for whom every sale is a small fortune, wouldn't take money from Fernandez and pushed a copy of Listin Diario through the window. The barefoot vendor who worked the traffic light raced alongside the jeep for a block, breathlessly updating Fernandez on neighborhood news.
Fernandez made a right-hand turn and was soon staring at the Estadio Quisqueya. The stadium was built in 1955, and in 1986 Fernandez, already a starter for Toronto, hit .364 to win the winter league batting title.
There has been talk in Santo Domingo of poor attendance, the high cost of tickets to games, the increasing reluctance of Dominican superstars to play again in the winter league.
"I wish it could be the same as before, but it won't ever be," Fernandez said. "People want you to play. People miss us. I understand their feelings. It's hard to explain, but there has been too much baseball for me to play. I haven't in five years. I'll do it again, though, before I retire. I promised them that."
The 90-minute drive to San Pedro was epic in its range of experience. Dead dogs were scattered along the seaside highway. Unclothed children barely out of infancy roamed the road's shoulders. Police officials randomly stopped cars and arbitrarily exacted instantly invented fines.
 
Flashbacks
 Fernandez was largely unmoved. It was not insensitivity. It was familiarity. But there were occasions when memory shattered his detachment, and when Fernandez's jeep skirted the Dario Contreras in Santo Domingo it was impossible for the 30-year-old shortstop not to flash back to his stay in that hospital as a 14-year-old.
Fernandez's mother, Andrea, had made her way from San Pedro to Santo Domingo at least twice a week for more than a month to plead for her son's admission to an overcrowded public hospital, imploring someone to attend to his gimpy right knee.
"She begged and begged, one doctor in particular," Fernandez said. "In the end, he had a little compassion. He told her one day to go get me."
He remained at the hospital for six weeks. Fernandez, forced to share a bed with another boy -- "There was no disease and so there was no reason for us each to have a bed, they said," -- had surgery to remove bone chips.
"My mother was not too pleased with the game of baseball," Fernandez said.
Cresting the bridge that leads to San Pedro, Fernandez's jeep encounters the wall of heat and odor that circles the city. It is a city of churches and smiles, merengue and misery and baseball. Fernandez swung past the Estadio Tetelo Vargas and slowed but did not stop.
Later, he spoke about his childhood adventures in the stadium, his hands covering his eyes. Fernandez was not crying, but he was once more feeling the force of an early and obviously enduring passion.
The mental pictures of himself are powerful: an ill-proportioned child laughing and snatching major leaguer Ray Knight's glove to take grounders; a young boy banished to right field by his own disdainful brothers; an adolescent, whose evolving elegance was undeniable, blossoming amid the tutelage and belief of Epy Guerrero, the Toronto scout who would sign him. The most modest desires of those days are the ones that still ache in the heart.
 
Playing for Love
 "Thinking about the uniforms of those players in that stadium was enough for me then," Fernandez said. "To have a uniform like theirs was all I wanted."
"A lot of writers say that we played to get out of poverty," Fernandez said. "But that's not the only reason or even the main one. The kids I saw in the street today, are they playing because they think they are going to make money? Come on. They are playing because they love the game. They are playing to have fun.
"My mother didn't even believe professional baseball was for real for me when I was signed. It was not until I had the actual money. I put 3,500 pesos on her bed at last. 'Here it is,' I said. 'I'm a professional ballplayer.' "
Fernandez is certifiably among the most accomplished to come out of his country, a land that has produced Juan Marichal, the Alou brothers and generation after generation of quality shortstops, from Griffin to Nelson Norman to Julio Franco, to the emerging kids like Jose Offerman and Andujar Cedeno.
But for all the numerical wonders -- a .322 average in 1987, a career fielding percentage of .980, the 17 triples in 1990 -- there has been a persistent cloud of disappointment.
Fernandez's father died in 1982 before he had played in the majors and his mother died within two years of his breakthrough. Fernandez broke his elbow in the September stretch in 1987 when the Tigers overcame the Blue Jays for the title, and there have been injuries to his knees, thumb and face, too.
His experience in Toronto soured, and Fernandez, forced to combat the dual stereotypes of Latin ballplayers and Christian athletes, retreated into a cultivated, theoretically more secure, remoteness.
His time in San Diego was disfigured by player standoffs with the manager and it was ended by a terribly lopsided trade to the Mets that was dictated by economics. The Padres had decided to reduce their payroll; Fernandez and his $2.3 million salary were auctioned to the Mets.
"Latin players have been misunderstood, made out to be moody, hostile, lazy, erratic," Fernandez said. "We are an emotional people. But we are honest and sincere, and the difficulty of the change in cultures has just never ever been fully accepted and appreciated.
"Of course it all still hurts. But not as much as it used to."
As Fernandez surveyed his "farm" in the mountains, there was, to be sure, nothing to wince at except the blaze of the sinking sun.
Altitude brought relief from the suffocating conditions in San Pedro. A horse grazed in left field. A river rumbled in the distance. His three sons sprinted toward the horizon.
"We lost a bond in our family when my parents died," Fernandez said. "I want that bond back and I thought baseball could do it. That field out there, where I can play with my sons and again with my brothers and sisters and their children, that's as close as I can come to an answer."
Cabeza looked once more before turning back to the house.
"I didn't imagine those mornings with the pushcart," he said.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Red Sox and Dodgers Are Desperate to Add Punch to Lineups

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Don't tell the Boston Red Sox and the Los Angeles Dodgers that pitching is 75 percent of the game, or 90 percent, or whatever Connie Mack proclaimed many decades before the 1992 Red Sox and Dodgers proved a team has to hit home runs and score runs occasionally to win games.
Because they didn't hit home runs and score runs, the Red Sox finished last for the first time in 30 years and the Dodgers finished last for the first time since 1905, when Connie Mack was in only the fifth year of his 50-year tenure as manager of the Philadelphia Athletics. 
 Lou Gorman, the Red Sox general manager, and Fred Claire, the Dodger general manager, have emerged from the devastation of the last season and have brushed the debris from their shoulders.
"I've been busy up to my ears," Gorman said before departing for the winter meetings in Louisville, Ky., where he and Claire will intensify their reclamation efforts. "I hope to get a bat with some pop in it to impact us offensively. We need someone to drive in some runs and generate our offense."
Gorman has explored the possibility of signing Barry Bonds, Mark McGwire or Joe Carter, and he plans to talk with Ruben Sierra's agent, too. He also had a fling with Kirby Puckett before Puckett returned to the Minnesota Twins. These players have been the most attractive run producers available as free agents. The Red Sox are prepared to pay dearly for one of them because they paid dearly for their lack of offense last season.
"It was an unbelievable year," Gorman said, "a year in which we lost Carlos Quintana before the season opened. Ellis Burks was out pretty much from the All-Star break. We lost Mike Greenwell at the end of May for the rest of the year. Wade Boggs hit 85 points below his career average. Jody Reed hit 41 points below his career average, and Jack Clark didn't hit one home run at Fenway all year. That all added up to no offense."
The Red Sox generated so little offense that they could have joined Clark in filing for bankruptcy. From the perennial .300 hitter Boggs, they got a .259 average, and from Clark, Greenwell and Burks they received a collective 15 home runs and 81 runs batted in.
 
No Support for Pitchers
 As a result, the Red Sox squandered a strong effort from their pitching staff, which placed second in the league with a 3.58 earned run average, second in complete games with 22, second in fewest home runs allowed by only one with 107 and third in strikeouts with 943.
The Red Sox traded their No. 1 reliever, Jeff Reardon, to Atlanta, so Gorman is looking for a replacement. He signed infielder Scott Fletcher as a free agent last week after losing second baseman Reed in the expansion draft.
Reed, who will be replaced by Fletcher or Tim Naehring, wound up with the Dodgers, filling one of the needs Claire identified after the Dodgers' disastrous season. The general manager also felt the need for improvement at third base, in left field and in the bullpen closer's role.
Obviously, those same glamorous free agents, most of whom play or could play left, have been available to the Dodgers, who last season finished last in the league in home runs and runs scored.
"If one was going to be in the free-agent market in a big way, it was going to be in a big, big way with premium players," Claire said. "But our focus wasn't in that type of investment. We wanted to see if we could work something out with Eric Davis."
 
Injuries Curb Performance
 Once upon a time, Davis was classified with the Bondses, Pucketts and Carters. But an injury-prone body and a classic case of underachievement has rendered him one of the major disappointments in years. In 1992, Davis, whom the Dodgers acquired from Cincinnati a year ago, batted .228, hit 5 home runs and drove in 32 runs in 76 games.
Surgery was performed on his left hand, wrist and shoulder. The Dodgers nevertheless signed him as a free agent, giving him a $1 million salary and the chance to earn an additional $1 million, based on payment of $5,494.51 every day he is on the active roster.
"Eric will be our left fielder," Claire said. "I have been asked if we are concerned with a player coming off surgery? Of course. You can't run from that. But Eric has worked very hard."
As he headed for Louisville, Claire was looking for a third baseman and a relief pitcher. Yesterday, the Dodgers signed Cory Snyder to a $3 million, two-year contract and re-signed Roger McDowell to a two-year, $3 million contract.
Snyder, 31, hit .269 last season for the Giants with 14 home runs and 57 r.b.i. He played five positions: all three outfield spots, first base and third base.
"I know they need a third baseman," Snyder said of the Dodgers yesterday. "I'd like to start with that. I'm versatile. I'm not sure what's going to happen."
McDowell, 32 later this month, was 6-10 with 14 saves and a 4.09 e.r.a. last season. He pitched in 65 games, and opponents batted .306 against him.
On Friday, the Dodgers re-signed outfielder Mitch Webster to a two-year deal worth $1.2 million.
The Dodgers had one of the largest payrolls in the major leagues this year, nearly $40 million, but Claire said the team had "redefined where we think our payroll should be: it's coming down."
 
Trading at a Standstill
 The flurry of trades that cascaded out of the expansion draft last month might have to hold the tradeniks for a while. Barring a sudden outbreak of meetings between general managers, this week's Louisville gathering doesn't promise to produce many player swaps.
"I can't get anyone interested in trades," Lee Thomas, the Philadelphia general manager, said. "They're all worried about free agents. A lot of clubs have said let's talk at the winter meetings, but I think until the free-agent thing settles, not much will happen."
Thomas's view was echoed by many other general managers.
"I haven't had a chance to talk to anyone about trades," Larry Himes of the Chicago Cubs said.
"I've been trying to trade, but everybody is talking about free agents," Dan Duquette of Montreal said.
Herk Robinson of Kansas City said he hadn't heard much trade talk.
"Too many free agents out there and not enough have signed to allow your attention to be turned to that as much as you'd like," said Robinson, who is waiting for word from Joe Carter on whether he wants to play for the Royals or stay with Toronto.
John Schuerholz of Atlanta says the trend in recent years has been toward free-agent domination of the week of the meetings.
"The agents inundate the lobbies of the hotel and take up your time," Schuerholz lamented. "You go through the smorgasbord of free agents. That's what the winter meetings have become."
 
No End to Giveaways
 The executive board of the Players Association met in Boca Raton, Fla., last week, and the players and union officials were treated daily to high-priced entertainment from the owners. After months of doom-and-gloom talk about the game's economy, clubs could hardly contain themselves, shoving lucrative contracts and offers at free agents faster than the players and their agents could read them or sign them.
Five pitchers signed contracts that guarantee their salary for four years. A sixth, Greg Maddux, was offered so much money by the Yankees, slightly more than $34 million for five years, that the deal would average nearly $1.5 million more per year than the next-highest-paid pitcher.
The Minnesota Twins signed Kirby Puckett to a $30 million contract before someone else could sign him for $35 million. The Yankees offered Barry Bonds slightly more than $36 million for five years, and it was apparent that someone else was willing to sign him for even more money.
The Yankees gave Spike Owen, a journeyman shortstop with limited range and a below-average arm, $7 million for three years.
Change the system, cry the owners? Why should the players want to change the system?
 
Newcomers Take the Plunge
 Besides the continued spending, this free-agent market is noteworthy for the new teams that have plunged into it. That's right; clubs that have not played the market much previously are playing big time. The Seattle Mariners have signed Chris Bosio to one of those four-year contracts, and the Houston Astros have signed a pair of pitchers to them, Doug Drabek and Greg Swindell.
"We indicated when Drayton McLane bought the ball club, the next logical step for us would be a re-entry into the free agent market," Bill Wood, the Astros' general manager, said. "Last year we dabbled around the edges. Now we're at a point where we need to be aggressive to improve the ball club."

HEADLINE: On AIDS, Let's Keep the Issue Clear

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was disappointed in the attempt to plead the case for an increase in funding for AIDS research based on economic considerations ("Financing to Meet AIDS's True Costs," Viewpoints, Nov. 22). AIDS research should be expanded for a host of reasons, the strongest among them that immune system technology should be the core of all disease research, with predictable benefits in the form of clues to virtually every other antigen, including those that would fight cancer. 
 Presenting the economic case provides easy fodder for the short-sighted; increased funding runs the risk of being shot down by merely countering these weak and even fallacious arguments.
For example, the article argues that 51,000 AIDS deaths in 1992 will result in a loss of $15 billion to $20 billion in Federal and state tax revenue. If revenue is an issue at all, that revenue could be easily replaced by expanding the oversubscribed State Department immigration lottery, bringing in replacements in the form of the brightest and the best from overseas.
And the article implies that cancer and heart disease funding would be better spent on AIDS because those diseases "strike older Americans primarily," while AIDS afflicts the young. But cancer and heart disease generally take their victims at the prime of life, canceling enormous investments in education and life experience. They kill people at the peak of their earning and contribution potential. The economic loss is astronomical and measurable. As any insurance underwriter will tell you, in dollars and cents, the young just aren't worth much.
It is shaky ground when you try to argue the spiritual in physical terms. Let's argue the expansion of AIDS research based on the need to alleviate human suffering. Let's avoid offering easily refuted logic that can serve to confuse those whom you would hope to convince.
 
SAM REDMAN
Dallas, Nov. 25

HEADLINE: Ex-Communist Countries Look to U.S. Cities

 BODY:
When the former Communist countries of the old Soviet bloc seek advice on capitalism, they look not just to financial centers like New York and Chicago. More and more, former Soviet republics and other Eastern European countries are turning to smaller post-industrial American cities, like Baltimore and Pittsburgh, for economic advice and intellectual exchange.
"Old industrial societies of the West have faced the same environmental and economic problems Russia now faces," said Blair A. Ruble, director of the Kennan Institute for Advanced Russian Studies in Washington. "Russians see difficulties and need desperately to talk to people who have faced these issues on a similar scale." 
 The mid-sized American cities are eager to develop these relationships, hoping that they will pay off in academic and business relationships once capitalism starts rolling in the former Communist lands.
 
A Visit to Baltimore
 St. Petersburg recently sent a delegation to Baltimore to learn how it had turned its gloomy industrial waterfront into a vibrant tourist and commercial center.
It may seem odd that the most majestic city of the former Soviet Union would be taking cultural cues from an American city known for baseball, crabcakes and the Babe Ruth house. But the guidance they seek, St. Peterburg's leaders say, is in planning, and Baltimore is reaching out to them.
"Baltimore is the first American city that has taken an interest in St. Petersburg, and we are so thankful for them," said Boris Nikolashchenko, the Russian city's planning chief, who took part in the visit. "We find that our city has a lot in common with them, not really in appearance, but spiritually."
There are similarities in the cities' histories. Baltimore, which was in decline in the 1960's, managed to pull itself out of the red by matching federal and state funds with local business investment in the region.
A private-sector bailout greatly interests St. Petersburg, whose woes include public housing problems, a dismantled arms industry that left many unemployed, pollution and second-banana status to Moscow, which contributes to the shortage of public funds.
 
Ties With Hungarian City
 The University of West Virginia in Morgantown has established links with Pecs, a city in Hungary. Pecs, like Morgantown, is in the heart of a slowly fading coal-mining region scrambling to rebuild its economy, said Andrew Isserman, director of the regional research institute at the university.
"There is an incredible bond among coal miners in the world, and that translates into the relationship between these two cities," he said. "Hungarians are concerned about what they are going to do, now that their coal is not competitive on world markets. We in Morgantown have been very successful in developing new industry for the labor that once worked in coal mining."
Pittsburgh is working with cities in Siberia for similar reasons. The University of Pittsburgh has had several exchanges with the Center for Urban and Social Research in Novosibirsk, through which professors, business people and students have gotten together to exchange ideas on everything from art and literature to steel.
"Both of our towns are based on heavy industry and resource extraction," said Ronald H. Linden, director for the Center for Russian and East European Studies at the university.
"They are looking at Pittsburgh to see how we have adjusted to the decline of industry in our region," he said. "We have experience in dealing with the decline of manual labor and the growing need for intellectual labor. We know how to construct a tax base. These are the kinds of issues that Russia has never had to deal with."
 
Warmth at Universities
 American universities are eager to exchange students and professors and eventually perhaps to foster business relationships between cities. "The long-term payoff is that Siberia will soon be an important region," Mr. Linden said. "This interaction affords us access to influential people."

HEADLINE: FOR GIVERS AND RECEIVERS, CHANGING LIVE WITH NEEDIEST FUND;
In Time of Growing Need, Harsh Attitudes Grow Softer

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN

 BODY:
The cycle seems to be turning. Slowly perhaps, but turning. Images of self indulgence so flagrantly flaunted for so long are blushingly turning more sedate. Stretch limousines seem less obvious and less stretched, perhaps as budgets become more so. And charitable organizations are reporting increases in the numbers of volunteers as well as requests.
As it does every few years, the relationship of the contented "us" to the unfortunate "them" is changing, drawing closer. Compared with a few years ago, people now seem less inclined to take full credit for their own good luck and are not quite as ready as they used to be to blame the down-and-out for their poverty. Denial is giving way to compassion and the idea seems to be growing that to a greater degree than we believed, we really are all in this together. 
 From tenement days in Manhattan's Five Points 150 years ago, different stereotypes at various times have taken hold to establish a precise distance that the lucky and well-to-do want to maintain between themselves and the disposessed. There have been the deserving poor, undeserving poor, religious ideas of predestination, Darwinian images of workhouse rigors, Horatio Alger's optimistic waifs, huddled masses, greenhorns, exploited sweatshop workers, labor agitators, rabble, lumpen, Bowery bums, derelicts, and most recently, the homeless.
During the 80's when many were prospering in plain view some others declined and a few even sank beyond general awareness as the fortunate were not only turning away from the suffering of others but were out to banish tragedy from their lives -- as if that could be done simply by working out or going on a diet. Now, as the recession claims more in the mainstream, and as the election campaign leaves exposed veins of need and anxiety among neighbors and relatives, the comforts of denial are more difficult to sustain. Tragedy, we are learning once again, is universal, as unavoidable as loved ones dying. It is a lesson that has often brought people together.
It may be that the current trend toward greater fraternity, if that's what it is, developed because there simply was nowhere else to go. It may also be explained by how rapidly and broadly misfortune has spread. No longer can the crazed, the dirty, the scabrous, and the addicted who live as our neighbors on our streets be regarded as rare aberrations in a land where social mobility was long assumed to go only upwards. There are too many of them for that.
David Jones, the executive director of the Community Service Society of New York, an agency supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, is one of those who have noticed the change in public attitues. "I am getting more and more calls from people who are expressing interest in doing volunteer work for the first time," he said, adding that he thought the period was over when people concentrated on their careers to the exclusion of other pursuits.
"I am starting to see a trickle of people who are talking about volunteering," he said. "For the first time I'm seeing younger people who are still early in their careers who are engaging in all sorts of discussion about social welfare and poverty. I think there is a shift."
As of three months ago, the number of people receiving some form of public assistance in New York had risen above 1 million, to 1,018,302. It was a 9.4 percent increase over a year earlier. With numbers like that comes a growing awareness that bad luck and hard times do not settle exclusively or even primarily on those whose appearance and behavior at times strains or impedes empathy.
In this season, when both good intentions and cries for help rise, the Neediest Fund stands ready to match those who give with those who need, establishing another of those ties that binds this city in community. Like the reservoirs upstate it preserves and enhances life by collecting and distributing.
These days entire epidemics of bad luck are raging. Who by now has not met or heard of someone infected with H.I.V.? Or known someone dead of AIDS? Who has not had acquaintances who lost jobs? Who has not learned of friends or children of friends who, after finishing college, or even graduate school, have not found jobs that would allow them to pay back their educational loans? Who has not heard about or seen men and women who put on fraying clothes to salvage some pride as they eat regularly in charitable soup kitchens. And who has not established eye contact, often on a daily basis, with the more troubled homeless as they hold to their neighborhood routes like mailmen?
And, of course, beyond such more or less familiar tragedies loom particuliar misfortunes: homes and hopes destroyed by fires, households smashed by various addictions, people victimized by crime, by discrimination, and a resurgence of tuberculosis preying on the weak.
Despair tends to be particular. It is custom-made like the revulsion and confusion felt by Angela, the 24-year-old mother who lashed out violently at her 3-year-old child. Fortunately, there came a moment when she realized she needed help, and fortunately, she was able to find it when she approached the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, another agency supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. With the help of a social worker there, she has found the source of her rage and the abuse has abated. Her life and that of her child are better.
Sometimes relatively small things can loom as major obstacles when there is no place to turn. For Angelique James, it was a business suit, a blouse and dress. Without them she could not attend a career program sponsored by the Children's Aid Society that would enable her to gain the most from her almost-completed college education. The money was supplied by the Neediest Cases Fund, and prospects for Ms. James, as well as dozens of other potential job applciants, brightened.
And sometimes even a quick fix can be a lifesaver in rough seas. For a while, Vince H. thought he would be swamped. Having been laid off, he fell behind in rent and faced eviction. But with help from anohter program aided by the Neediest Cases Fund, Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, Vince H. was able to pay the back rent. His anxieties diminished, he was able to find a job. The storm subsided.
Despite the fluctuations in attitudes, through recessions, depressions and periods of prosperity, there has in the last 80 years been at least one area where impulses of empathy and charity have increased regularly. Ever since 1911, when Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, started the first of what have been annual appeals to help the Neediest Cases, responses have grown with each year.
In that first year when funds were solicited with the headline: "Santa Clause, Please Take Notice," 117 contributors gave $3,630.88. The campaign last year was the most successful ever, with 16,415 people giving $5,083,550.81. Among the contributions was a marked increase in the numbers of modest donations, reflecting gifts from people of moderate or limited means.
All of this suggests that compassion is on the rise and that perhaps we may be entering a time of greater fraternity. One can hope.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The Economic Team;
CHOICE OF BENTSEN IS CALLED A SIGNAL OF NEW TEAMWORK

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton picked Senator Lloyd Bentsen to be his Treasury Secretary to send the political signal that the deadlock between the White House and Congress is over and to assure the financial markets of a calm, steady hand on the nation's economic levers, Clinton advisers said today.
But the advisers, here and in Arkansas, also said the Texas Senator's selection and the fact that the top candidates for the directorship of the Office of Management and Budget also come from Congress indicated how, after 12 years of Republican Presidents, Congress is the only realistic place to turn for experts who have dealt with pivotal matters like taxes and the budget deficit. 
 The President-elect apparently set aside concerns that Mr. Bentsen might be more valuable in his current post as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and that Republicans might win his Senate seat in Texas in a special election next spring.
 
Announcements in Midweek
 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said today that if he replaced Mr. Bentsen as finance chairman, as he expected, his most important priority would be "to get the President's agenda through."
Mr. Clinton is expected to announce his choice of Mr. Bentsen officially on Wednesday or Thursday after returning to Little Rock, Ark., from a two-day trip to Chicago and Washington.
Clinton staff members said that the selections for some other top economic posts would probably be announced then as well, but that the need to complete background checks might delay some announcements.
Roger Altman, a Wall Street investment banker who was a student at Georgetown University with Mr. Clinton in the 1960's, is in line to be Deputy Treasury Secretary, the staff assistants said.
The top candidates to be budget director, probably the second most important economic post after Treasury Secretary, are said to be Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee, and Alice M. Rivlin, the first director of the Congressional Budget Office, who is now an economist at the Brookings Institution.
Ms. Rivlin was the early betting favorite, partly because of Mr. Clinton's determination to have women in top positions in his Administration. But an associate of Mr. Clinton said the President-elect's thinking began to change after he read Ms. Rivlin's new book and interviewed Mr. Panetta. The Congressman is now said to be the more likely choice.
In her book, "Reviving the American Dream" (The Brookings Institution), Ms. Rivlin argues for a huge shift away from Washington and to the state capitals of programs like job training and public works that are intended to foster economic development. That is a sharp contrast to Mr. Clinton's position that his foremost responsibility as President is to promote economic growth and job creation.
On the other hand, Mr. Panetta, a legislator with moderate political views and a firm grasp of the budget, was said to have made a strong impression on the President-elect during their interview last week.
Mr. Panetta would not take reporters' calls today. But in a recent interview, before the prospects of his joining the Administration became apparent, he argued that the new President should move quickly to win Congressional approval of a five-year plan to cut the Federal budget deficit in half. That squares almost precisely with Mr. Clinton's stand during the campaign.
 
'An Institutional Memory'
 In selecting Mr. Bentsen, who is 71 years old, Mr. Clinton turned to a veteran lawmaker whose steady temperament and statesmanlike presence became nationally known in 1988 when he was the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate.
A Clinton adviser said Mr. Bentsen's main asset in the President-elect's eyes was his "deep knowledge of Congress."
"The issue of overcoming gridlock is fundamental to the success of his Presidency, both substantivally and politically," the adviser said.
Another Senator who has talked with Mr. Clinton about economic appointments characterized Mr. Bentsen this way: "He has an absolute familiarity with all the issues on the table. He has an institutional memory for all the economic decisions, good and bad, in the last generation. He knows taxes. And he has the credentials for fiscal responsibility."
But this Senator and others said one of Mr. Bentsen's strongest suits was that with his lanky stature, white hair and soothing voice he looked and sounded like a Treasury Secretary.
Two others under consideration for the position, Mr. Altman, who is 46, and Robert E. Rubin, co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, who is 54, look young for their ages, and that was said to be detrimental.
Two others who had been on the list for Treasury Secretary, Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation in New York, were thought to be unlikely to subordinate their own strong philosophies and ideas to the new President's, Clinton advisers said.
Although Mr. Bentsen has normally voted with the mainstream of his party, he is probably somewhat more conservative than most other Democratic lawmakers and more oriented toward the views of business.
As chairman of the Finance Committee, he has been a strong supporter of tax breaks for real estate interests and oil and gas producers, and he has advocated more favorable tax treatment of savings by affluent taxpayers.
The Finance Committee also has jurisdiction over such crucial issues facing the new Administration as Social Security, health policy, trade and welfare, and Mr. Bentsen has mastered those topics like few other lawmakers.
Nonetheless, Mr. Bentsen and the others Mr. Clinton picks for economic positions may have only limited influence in developing policy.
Mr. Clinton took such detailed stands on these matters in his campaign that the main responsibility of the Cabinet members and others will be as implementors and lobbyists with Congress.
Though it was bitterly cold this morning in Little Rock, Mr. Clinton emerged from the Governor's Mansion to drive his daughter, Chelsea, to a school outing, and then he jogged and went for a round of golf in the rain and sleet.
At the end of his jog, he stopped at a McDonald's downtown and was asked by reporters about the selection of Mr. Bentsen. "I never discuss appointments until I make them," he said with a chuckle. "Next week, you'll know."
Asked about the possibility of an international crisis interfering with his domestic programs, he said: "It's just part of the job. I can't control it. We're living in a time of instability. The United States has responsibilities there, too; we can't shirk them."
 
Other Possibilities
 Mr. Rubin, a major Democratic fund-raiser with a reputation as a good manager, is a leading candidate to head the Economic Security Council, the White House office Mr. Clinton intends to set up to parallel the National Security Council, which helps the President make foreign policy.
Robert B. Reich, director of the economic policy transition team, is another possibility for that post. Mr. Reich is said to prefer a spot where he could be a strong advocate for his own views rather than having to spend much of his time analyzing the views of others. He would probably prefer being chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
But Mr. Reich (pronounced REISH) is a lawyer, not an economist, and to make him chief economic adviser would be, to some minds, like putting an economist on the Supreme Court.
Some people here who follow these matters closely but have no inside information think that Mr. Reich might be named Commerce Secretary and that, with Mr. Panetta as budget director, Ms. Rivlin, who has a strong reputation as a professional economist, might be named chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers to have a woman in a top economics slot.
Another person under consideration to be the chief economics adviser is Lawrence H. Summers. Mr. Summers, who is now working on the transition, is on leave from his position as chief economist at the World Bank, a post he took after going on leave from his tenured position on the economics faculty at Harvard University.
At age 38, he has an incomparable pedigree. His father, Robert Summers, and his mother, Anita Arrow Summers, are both widely published economists. Two of his uncles, Paul A. Samuelson and Kenneth J. Arrow, have won the Noble Prize in economics.
 
Back Home in Texas
 Senator Bentsen's new position would open the way for what politicians in both parties expect to be a bloody campaign to fill his Senate seat.
The history of Texas politics is that once someone gets into the Senate, it is difficult to dislodge them. But Gov. Ann W. Richards, a Democrat, is said to have warned the Clinton staff that Democrats could have a tough time holding Mr. Bentsen's seat. The other Texas Senator, Phil Gramm, is a Republican, and President Bush carried the state in the November election.
The primaries could be as early as March, with the general election in May.
One possibility was that Governor Richards would name former Mayor Henry G. Cisneros of San Antonio to fill the seat until the election, possibly giving him a campaign advantage. But Mr. Cisneros, one of the nation's most prominent Hispanic politicians, may also be in line for a spot in the Clinton Administration.
On Wall Street, the choice of Mr. Bentsen to be Treasury Secretary was mostly applauded. Many senior executives from the financial industry said in interviews that they were comfortable with his politics and personality and had developed a close working relationship with him over the years.
"Bentsen has clearly gained the respect of the business community in the Senate," said Donald Marron, chairman and chief executive of Paine Webber, "and I think he is basically a solid choice. The markets are more comfortable with known quantities than unknown quantities, and Bentsen is a known quantity."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 8, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Sunday with sketches of candidates for top economic positions in President-elect Bill Clinton's Administration misstated the age of Lawrence H. Summers, an economist. He is 38, not 48.

HEADLINE: Mixed Blessings Seen In Student-Loan Rules

BYLINE: By States News Service

 BODY:
WHEN Federal lawmakers revamped aid programs to help pay college bills, they increased eligibility for grants and loans. Next month a loan that does not require students to prove need will be available, and in July the Government will stop considering the value of a family's house when determining need.
That sounds like good news, particularly for high school seniors from the middle class, students, who are frequently left out of financial aid. Aid counselors often assume that parents can borrow on their home equity, which often bars children of middle-class homeowners from obtaining assistance. 
 "The home equity came from two things," said Sarah Flanagan, an aide to the Senate education subcommittee that helped draft the changes to the Higher Education Act. "At the very basic level, families should not have to put up their home for a college education.
"In a very specific sense it was put in because of increasingly fluctuating home and farm values, particularly on both coasts and the Northeast. Home prices tripled in some areas. Eligibility was fluctuating on the real-estate market."
But some counselors on Long Island said they were concerned that the changes were not necessarily improvements.
 
Decrease in Grants, Rise in Loans
 "The supposed goal of Congressional reauthorization and the changes was to increase grants for students and decrease student borrowing," said Larry Seligman, associate director of financial aid at the New York Institute of Technology. "What they ended up with will decrease grants and increase student borrowing."
The new loan allows first-year students to borrow up to $2,625 and others to borrow up to $4,000 a year at an interest rate of 6.94 percent. The interest rate for subsequent years is capped at 9 percent overall.
But unlike other Government-guaranteed loans, students have to start paying back the interest right away,or they can to wait until after graduation to begin payments, a strategy that ends up costing much more in the long run. Under the new system, unpaid monthly interest payments are added to the balance, and subsequent interest payments are calculated on the new total, substantially increasing the amount of the loan.
"Even though it's a good thing on its face, in the long run we're giving them quite a burden to bear when they graduate," said Jacqueline Pascariello, associate director of financial aid at the State University at Stony Brook. "Is it good to have a student graduating from a state university owing between $13,000 and $15,000? No matter how much you counsel them, they have no idea what that really means."
Many private institutions say they are continuing to require the home-equity information or are going to start requiring it.
"We plan to still use the home value," said Jean Belmont, director of financial and academic records at Hofstra University. "If you take two parents who are both 45 and make $35,000, and one lives in an apartment and has no assets and the other has a $500,000 house -- because our assets are limited we would need that information."
The guidance director at Garden City High School, Irvin Faust, said the provision was highly controversial. He said: "I can only tell you after talking with them that the colleges independently will factor in the home equity. My guess is almost all of them will do it."
Not enough money has been allocated for the increased demand that could stem from the change, some counselors said. Congress authorized $2 billion more for the fiscal year that began in October, up from $11.7 billion last year, for the program.
But borrowing limits may be lower. Students last year could borrow up to $2,400 under the Pell Grants, the biggest Government-aid program, that has been trimmed to $2,300.
The Education Department has not estimated how many more students will seek aid, but counselors estimate that requests could jump as much as 50 percent. Last year, 5.1 million students received loans, according to the department.
"It sounds wonderful depending on how they sell it to the public, but I don't know where all this money is going to come from," said Joanne Graziano, director of financial aid at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University.
Some counselors are more positive. The executive director of the National Association of School Financial Aid Administrators, Dallas Martin, said although his group was not in favor of removing the home-equity provision, "simply because we knew there was not enough money to serve all the students that apply," it did support the new loan. He added:
"As I go out and do college-aid talks, I'm hearing from middle-class families, 'I don't want student aid, I just want a loan.' It will provide some needed help to a lot of them having cash-flow problems. I personally was glad to see Congress address that group of families."
High school guidance counselors are dealing with problems like parents who are jittery because financial aid forms that usually arrive in mid-November will not be available until the middle of this month, at the earliest. "We think it's a mess from my standpoint," Mr. Faust said. "A lot of this is still unofficial in that we have not received any of the materials. It's making kids and parents a little itchy."
