HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

WHITE ELEPHANTS IN CONNECTICUT
The lush suburban landscape of Fairfield County, Conn., has become home to hundreds of vacant executive offices that analysts say are among the worst white elephants of American business. It was places like Stamford, Greenwich, Westport, Fairfield and Danbury that provided new and spacious homes for the first large wave of corporations that moved from Manhattan in the late 1960's and the 1970's. But the takeovers, leveraged buyouts and reorganizations of the 1980's -- compounded by the recession -- have wiped out or drastically shrunk many of those companies, which can no longer use all the suburban space they created for themselves. And experts say that because of bad judgments in the design and location of the offices, many have been unable to attract new tenants. A1.
 
RESOLUTION OF AN INSURANCE FAILURE
The insurance commissioners of New York and New Jersey have agreed on how to resolve the largest insurance company failure in history, increasing the interest that will be paid on the savings of hundreds of thousands of customers of the failed Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company. But most customers may still have to wait up to seven years before they have access to all their money. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 

HISTORIC DECISION FOR TRIBECA
TriBeCa is nearing a decisive moment. Tomorrow, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission is to consider a plan to create three new historic districts there, a move that would bring all or part of 34 blocks northwest of City Hall under its regulation. While historic district status would not rule out construction, the design of any new structure would have to be deemed appropriate by the landmarks panel before it could be built. B3.
 
OFFICER CHARGED WITH TAKING A BRIBE
A Port Authority police officer was arraigned on charges of taking a $300 bribe to escort an undercover agent posing as a cocaine dealer past drug-detection security systems at La Guardia Airport. Officials said the suspect was the first officer in the 65-year history of his force to be charged with a felony of the highest level, carrying a maximum penalty of 25 years to life in prison. B2.
 
KEEPING CUSTOMERS HAPPY
Ed Germano, owner of the Hit Factory, likes to say his business is making people happy. Not that the recording-studio owner doesn't charge people like Madonna, Bruce Springsteen and Michael Jackson plenty for the use of equipment reminiscent of the starship Enterprise. But he delights in throwing in some extras. Things like a 24-hour gym and steam bath, two-bedroom apartments for out-of-towners, and mountainous baskets of fresh fruit. This might all sound irrelevant to most business people, but Mr. Germano, who rents space to record companies and producers, sees his function as basically that of a hotelier. He provides not only the musical precision demanded by artists of a studio, but the human comforts as well. Strictly Business, B4.
 
REGION
 
DRUG ARRESTS ON LONG ISLAND
The police have arrested a Long Island man whom they identified as the leader of a major narcotics ring in western Suffolk County. The suspect and 27 other suspected members of the drug-distribution ring were seized in several simultaneous raids on the island by Federal, state and county drug-enforcement agents. B6.
 
STILL A DAY OF REST
Bergen County still enforces blue laws; it is the only one of the 21 New Jersey counties to maintain them since the Legislature permitted their establishment 33 years ago. And even though it's Christmastime in one of the nation's largest and richest shopping hubs, and even though every other county in the state permits shopping, Sunday is still the merchants' day of rest in Bergen. Paramus Journal, B6.
 
Metro Matters by Sam Roberts B3

HEADLINE: No Sleighs For Santas Trudging Sidewalks

 BODY:
The night-sky sleigh riding, the last-minute list checking and the down-the-chimney ho-ho-hoing are the easy part. For some sidewalk Santas in Manhattan, December means long days collecting donations for the Volunteers of America, the nonprofit group that is New York State's largest provider of shelter services for single adults. The group provides a home away from the North Pole, a shelter on the Upper East Side.
The Santas' presence creates some only-in-New-York scenes: suited Santas clambering onto the M5 bus, Santas picking up midday snacks in a deli, Santas trudging along a lonely sidewalk as night falls. 
 Sixteen Santas, mostly homeless or unemployed men from upstate New York, fanned out across the city yesterday, ready to keep track of who was naughty and who was nice.

The Economy
Bill Clinton's economic team is likely to take a tougher stand on the deficit than what the President-elect spelled out in the campaign. Recent upbeat economic news makes it less likely that the new Administration will push the deficit up to give the economy a jolt, Clinton advisers say. [Page A1.]. Concerned that his first cabinet appointments might be entirely white and male, Clinton plans to expand this week's announcements to include posts to be filled by women and members of minority groups. [A1.]
The news that Lloyd Bentsen is expected to be nominated as Treasury Secretary was well received on Wall Street. [D1.] Not surprisingly, Texas business people welcomed the news. [D3.] 
 The new Administration will seek to halt operations at the nation's newest hazardous-waste incinerator until Congress investigates its safety, Vice President-elect Gore says. [D9.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Mood Supports Clinton

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The sharp rally in the bond market after the release of employment data on Friday seems to show a surprising comfort among market players with President-elect Bill Clinton, a Democrat who will govern with a Democratic-controlled Congress.
The bond market is peopled by investors, traders, speculators and analysts who have had little confidence in Democrats in the past and a real fear of rising deficits. Yet, the avid buyers of Treasury bills, notes and bonds on Friday appeared to be giving Mr. Clinton every benefit of the doubt.
 
Shift in Investor Mood
 "The shift in mood in the last six to eight weeks is phenomenal," said Maureen Allyn, chief economist at Scudder, Stevens & Clark. "They thought the economy was going down the drain and he was evil incarnate. Now they think the economy is growing at a 4 percent rate and that Clinton is smart, practical and will do the right thing." 
 Mr. Clinton's reported choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, as Secretary of the Treasury, may be unsettling to the bond market, and trading today may reflect that. Many bond traders and analysts preferred Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who had an unchallenged anti-inflation reputation.
But if Mr. Clinton is gaining the confidence of Wall Street already, Mr. Bentsen's choice will not be judged in isolation; it will be read in an overall context that will also include other appointments and the President-elect's commitment to cutting the Federal budget deficit.
 
Stronger Economic Signs
 The employment report for November was solid across the board. Nonfarm payrolls were up 105,000. The September decline of 72,000 jobs was revised to an increase of 12,000. The average workweek and hourly earnings rose, two factors that had forecasters like Ed Yardeni of C. J. Lawrence and Joseph Liro of S. G. Warburg & Company preparing to increase their growth forecasts for the fourth quarter.
Normally, these kind of data would be bad for the bond market, especially coupled with Mr. Clinton's promise to stimulate the economy with new spending on road and environmental projects and tax incentives to encourage business investment.
For shorter maturities, a stronger economy raises the possibility that the Federal Reserve could soon increase short-term interest rates. For longer maturities it makes investors wonder if the stronger growth will push inflation higher.
In fact, it was worry over a stronger-than-expected economy and Mr. Clinton's fiscal stimulus package that caused much of the recent selloff in Treasury bills and notes.
But instead of declining on Friday, bond and note prices rose and the discount rates on Treasury bills declined. The price of the 30-year bond was up 25/32 to yield 7.48 percent, down from 7.55 percent on Thursday and the first time the yield has been below 7.50 percent since Oct. 14.
And the apparent faith in Mr. Clinton is one of the reasons why.
 
Fine-Tuning Fiscal Stimulus
 Bond traders, fund managers and economists indicated in numerous interviews that they assumed Mr. Clinton would scale back the stimulus program he promised during the campaign if the economy grew stronger and strengthen it if the economy was weaker. Mr. Clinton and his transition aides have indicated that this is the case. But no one knows yet whether a reduced Clinton program would be close to what the bond market would consider scaled back.
Mr. Yardeni of C. J. Lawrence said in his commentary on the employment report, "Job report reduces likelihood of Clinton short-term stimulus program."
The rally also seemed to reveal two other factors at play in the market. One is that investors appear more scared of a yet-to-be-detailed fiscal stimulus program than of an economy that is growing faster then anticipated just two months ago.
The second factor is that skeptical investors, traders and analysts, who have been burned in the past, are showing growing comfort with the thought that inflation will remain low for some time to come. This is one reason the long bond has outperformed other Treasury securities in recent trading.
 
Economic Drag
 The General Motors Corporation's announcement last week of its plans to shut nine plants within the next three and a half years is a vivid reminder of the painful corporate restructurings that have kept the economy sluggish, at best, for the last four years.
Economists and executives hope that the paring of debt and the cutting of costs will lay the groundwork for future robust economic growth.
 
Only Moderate Growth Predicted

 
 But in a report on the economic outlook next year here and abroad, Salomon Brothers warns that debt restructuring for both companies and individuals is not yet over. And that is one reason the firm projects only moderate growth in the economy next year.
Combined with a continued low rate of inflation, the moderate growth will open the way to a decline in the yield on the 30-year bond to the vicinity of 7 percent. The firm does not think, however, that a break of 7 percent, if possible, can happen before 1994.
On the consumer side, the report notes that while debt service burdens have fallen from their peak, they are still high enough to limit the burst in spending needed for a conventional recovery. The analysis also contends that consumer behavior may be becoming more conservative, meaning less willingness to take on new debt and a stronger tendency to save.
One reason for this view is the pattern of mortgage refinancings, which show a marked move to 15-year mortgages, from 30 years. This means that consumers still make about the same monthly payments. That makes for a slower-spending consumer as individuals build up equity in their homes much faster.
 
Rise in 15-Year Mortgages
 Overall mortgage data show that the share of 15-year mortgages has risen to about 30 percent in 1992 from 10 percent in recent years. Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation data show that refinancings to 15-year mortgages jumped to 43 percent in the first three quarters of 1992, from 17 percent in 1990.
On the corporate side, the change has also just begun."The recuperation owes more to the absolute decline in interest rates and a strong stock market rally than to corporate balance sheet restructuring or robust income growth," according to the report written under the direction of John Lipsky, Salomon's chief economist.
Among other conclusions: The Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates until the second half of 1993; when it does, the increase will be modest.
Mr. Clinton's economic stimulus plan and the need to create jobs will mean that "deficit reduction plays a subordinate role," a fact that may eventually shake the bond market, the Salomon report says. As for the actual fiscal stimulus, much of the spending on road, environmental, communications and other projects may be delayed by "significant legal and regulatory obstacles."

HEADLINE: 28 Suspects in Suffolk Drug Ring Arrested

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Dec. 6

 BODY:
A Long Island man who the police said bragged that for $5,000 he could make people disappear was arrested early this morning and identified as the leader of a major narcotics ring in western Suffolk County.
The suspect, Raymond Kaisen, and 27 other suspected members of the drug-distribution ring, were seized in several simultaneous raids on the Island by Federal, state and county drug-enforcement agents. The police also seized 12 luxury cars, a 33-foot speedboat, numerous weapons, explosives, anabolic steroids, marijuana plants and about two pounds of cocaine. 
 Maj. Anthony J. DiResta, commander of New York State Police Troop L, said Mr. Kaisen was a supplier of one to two kilos of cocaine a week, from which Mr. Kaisen alone profited more than $45,000 weekly.
 
Weapons on Display
 He said the electronic surveillance of Mr. Kaisen's house at 7 Stafford Drive in Huntington Station disclosed that Mr. Kaisen not only bragged that he could make people disappear, but also that "no cops would ever take him down."
He said Mr. Kaisen's narcotics operation was "a violent organization," as reflected by the nearly two dozen weapons seized by the agents this morning. The evidence, spread out for display at Troop L headquarters here at Republic Airport, included an Uzi, shotguns and handguns and ammunition.
The display of weapons was banked by several marijuana plants and had been seized at the home of one of suspects, Albert Lowe, at 84 Rhode Island Avenue in Massapequa.
The agents who raided Mr. Kaisen's home said they entered a house of mirrors, which made it difficult to find their way around. The house was also surrounded by an extensive security system, including lights and television cameras connected to monitors in every room.
The agents said they found Mr. Kaisen trying to stuff packages of cocaine down a toilet near his bedroom. Capt. Walter Heesch, head of Troop L's narcotics-enforcement unit, said Mr. Kaisen lived in the house with his wife, three children and his parents. He said Mr. Kaisen was unemployed. The police said the parents were under investigation.
James Catterson, the Suffolk County District Attorney, said the case began six months ago. Mr. Catterson said the drugs were supplied to the Suffolk ring by dealers in New York City.
The suspects were charged with criminal sale and possession of a controlled substance, criminal possession of weapons and conspiracy. They were to be held overnight in Suffolk County Jail in Hauppauge for arraignment on Monday in First County Court. Those convicted of the sale of a controlled substance could face a minimum of 15 years to life in prison.

HEADLINE: Landmarks Panel to Hear TriBeCa Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
After years of veering between conflicting impulses -- to preserve its architectural heritage (about five stories high) or exploit its development potential (more like 50) -- the TriBeCa area of lower Manhattan is nearing a decisive moment.
Tomorrow, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission is to consider a plan to create three new historic districts there, a move that would bring all or part of 34 blocks northwest of City Hall under its regulation. 
 While historic district status would not rule out construction, the design of any new structure would have to be deemed appropriate by the landmarks panel before it could be built.
Best known in recent years as a cutting edge of social and cultural life, TriBeCa was once a thriving center of textile and dry goods dealers, warehouses and factories. On the outside, at least, many blocks remain almost unchanged.
 
Interest in New Offices
 Depending on the extent of the new districts, which would join one created last year, TriBeCa West, the designation may put the landmarks panel at odds not only with real-estate interests but with the City Planning Department, too.
That is because one of the proposed districts, TriBeCa South, includes the Church Street corridor, which city planners described in a recent study of lower Manhattan as an area that "may be appropriate for new office construction."
Since the existing five-story scale is a prime quality in many parts of TriBeCa, it seems improbable that the commission would approve anything like the new 52-story Tribeca Tower on Duane Street, between Church Street and Broadway, even though it was allowed by zoning rules.
Leslie Feldman, an owner of several properties in the proposed TriBeCa South district, said he worried that the commission would say, "Everything should be frozen."
 
Playing Down Conflict
 City planners, in an August study, noted a conflict between zoning and the proposed TriBeCa South district. They also cited reasons for development: Church Street is a main artery, subway stations are at hand and the area is close to the civic and financial centers.
Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the landmarks commission, minimized any potential conflict. She noted that the discussion was part of a study by the planning agency staff, not a formal report by the City Planning Commission, which will not review the districts until the landmarks panel has acted.
Ultimately the matter will go the City Council. "I don't know what side the Council will come down on," Ms. Beckelman said. "They did remove a few buildings from the TriBeCa West district, but on the whole, they kept the district we recommended."
But preservationists fear that the planning commission may recommend the deletion from the district of Reade Street, east of Church Street, and that the Council would go along. This block has a remarkably uniform fabric of five-story, mid-19th-century buildings, with arched and ornamented windows arrayed in almost regimental precision.
Hal Bromm, a leader of the local preservation movement for eight years, said that "the concern we have about the conflict on TriBeCa South is only heightened by the fact that the district is so tiny to begin with."
The chairman of the Council's landmarks subcommittee, Stephen DiBrienza, a Brooklyn Democrat, would not discuss the new TriBeCa districts until they come before him. But generally speaking, he said, "The work of preserving history and architecture has to be viewed as economically important."
Under the plan, TriBeCa South would take in all or some of six blocks between West Broadway and Broadway, Chambers and Worth Streets. TriBeCa East would include 15 blocks between West Broadway and Lafayette Street, Worth and Canal Streets. TriBeCa North would encompass 13 blocks between West and Varick Streets, Hubert and Watts Streets.

GRAPHIC: Map of lower Manhattan showing locations of TriBeCa North, TriBeCa West, TriBeCa East and TriBeCa South, the proposed TriBeCa Historic Districts, and the Existing TriBeCa Historic District.

HEADLINE: Texas View of Its Senator Is Quite Rosy, Of Course

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Not surprisingly, the news that President-elect Bill Clinton had settled on Senator Lloyd Bentsen as his Treasury Secretary was welcomed by the Texas business community.
"He has been in the business world, and he understands the necessity of jobs and economic growth," Norman Brinker, chairman and chief executive of Brinker International Inc., said. "I don't think he will do anything short-sighted that would compromise that." 
 A Republican who supported President Bush, Mr. Brinker said he was concerned that the Democratic White House would seek higher business taxes, raise the minimum wage and force business to make costly changes in health-care programs. His Dallas-based restaurant company has 30,000 employees and annual sales of $780 million. "Jobs cost money," he said. "In our industry, it's $20,000 of capital per job."
Mr. Bentsen would provide business with a sensible if not always sympathetic channel to the President, he said.
Ronald G. Steinhart, president of Bank One, Texas, the second-largest banking company in the state, said Mr. Bentsen's "tremendous knowledge" of the ways of Congress would be a great advantage for the Clinton Administration.
"I think he will be very high on business tax incentives to get the economy moving, and that reducing the Federal debt will be a very high priority," Mr. Steinhart said.
Bernard L. Weinstein, director of the Center for Economic Development at the University of North Texas, predicted Mr. Bentsen would be a "good counterweight" against forces in the Clinton Administration that are expected to favor higher taxes on business and wealthy individuals and Federal spending on new job programs of as much as $50 billion.
"He is a pragmatist, a compromiser and a leader," said Dr. Weinstein, who worked for Mr. Bentsen as a staff economist on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. "He is the best economist in the Congress. He is far and away the best choice for the job."

HEADLINE: Better Times May Lead Clinton to Focus on Deficit

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The economic team that President-elect Bill Clinton has chosen and a recent pickup in economic growth mean that Mr. Clinton is likely to take a tougher approach to reducing the Federal budget deficit than he expressed during the campaign, transition team members said this weekend.
In interviews, a number of advisers said the encouraging economic news and the likelihood that the President-elect would choose a deficit "hawk" to be his budget director made it less likely that Mr. Clinton would decide to push the deficit up temporarily to give the economy a quick jolt. 
 "If, come January, employment is substantially on the rebound, then obviously there's less need -- there may be no need -- to take immediate action" to stimulate the economy in the short term, Robert B. Reich, the head of Mr. Clinton's economic transition team, said.
Mr. Clinton's advisers have been weighing whether the Government should spend $20 billion to $50 billion more on public works next year with the aim of creating more than a million jobs. But, they said, the drop in the November unemployment rate to 7.2 percent, from 7.4 percent, is making them reconsider whether a stimulus program is needed. They add that if job growth stalls, action may be required.
 
Focus May Shift
 Mr. Clinton's apparent choice for Treasury Secretary, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, and the other members of the new economic team are expected to follow most of the economic proposals Mr. Clinton promoted during the campaign, the advisers say. Nonetheless, a few advisers suggested that Mr. Bentsen might seek to graft on some of his own ideas, like expanding individual retirement accounts in the hope of increasing the amount that Americans save.
Because of the surprisingly strong economic growth in recent weeks, transition team members said, Mr. Clinton may shift his economic focus away from short-term stimulus and toward long-term problems, like slow income growth, low investment and poor worker training.
Mr. Reich, who aides say is being considered to be Commerce Secretary or to run the proposed economic security council, said that "when job growth comes back, the long-term challenges will still be there." He said those included reducing the deficit, improving the quality of the work force, and rebuilding highways and other public works "to insure that our children have a higher standard of living."
Over the last decade, neither Senator Bentsen nor Mr. Reich has made deep reductions in the deficit a top priority, many economists say. But the other candidates whom Mr. Clinton is considering for his economic team are all known for tough views on the deficit. They include the two candidates favored to be budget director, Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, and Alice M. Rivlin, former director of the Congressional Budget Office.
Roger C. Altman, an investment banker at the Blackstone Group who advisers say has been tapped to be Deputy Treasury Secretary, shares Wall Street's concerns about bringing down the deficit. So does Robert E. Rubin, the co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, who, like Mr. Reich, is being considered to run the economic security council.
One adviser said that because Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Panetta and Ms. Rivlin all knew their way around Congress, Mr. Clinton might find it easier to push some tough deficit-reduction measures through the House and Senate.
 
 
'Great Deal of Experience'
 Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said of Mr. Bentsen, "He certainly would bring to the job a great deal of expertise about the tax system and how revenues might be raised," as well as "the likely Congressional reaction to those proposals."
In the past, Mr. Bentsen, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has favored tax breaks for the oil and gas industry and for real estate investment. But several Clinton advisers said they would expect him to put those preferences on the back burner while pushing for Mr. Clinton's agenda, which calls for increasing taxes on the rich.
Aides to Mr. Clinton say Mr. Panetta has the edge in the competition to be director of the Office of Management and Budget. He was one of the most outspoken Democrats in Congress for deficit reduction, and in an interview last month he said that as part of any economic program, Mr. Clinton's advisers needed to "lay out first and foremost their deficit-reduction plan."
"This is a guy who has talked about deficit reduction as an overarching goal," said Gary D. Bass, director of O.M.B. Watch, a liberal budget research group in Washington. "And I'd say Alice Rivlin has much the same viewpoint."
 
 
Possible Criticism
 Several advisers acknowledged that if the President-elect appoints Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta this week, the man who ran on a platform of change might be lambasted for turning his Administration over to pillars of the Washington status quo.
"Whatever the first week's perception of these people as Washington insiders, what the country cares about is whether or not you produce change," one Clinton adviser said, adding that with their contacts in Congress, Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta would lubricate the wheels of change.
As for the economic security council, Mr. Clinton's advisers admit they have not figured out its exact structure and scope. In proposing such a council during the campaign, Mr. Clinton sought to signal that he wanted to roll up his sleeves in taking on the economy and get tougher with America's trading partners.
At the least, Clinton aides say, the council will coordinate economic policy under an economic security adviser and supporting staff. It would resemble the National Security Council, and like that body would present policy options -- and perhaps recommendations -- to the President after consulting with other departments.
Mr. Clinton's advisers say the council will replace Mr. Bush's Economic Policy Council and will take a less piecemeal approach to stimulating the economy than previous such councils did. While past councils focused on taxes, deficits and regulation, the proposed council, they say, will also look at how schools, job training and technological research can be improved to make American industry more competitive. The council would also focus more on international issues, like removing foreign trade barriers.
 
 
'Honest Broker'
 That Mr. Clinton is weighing two very different men to run the council indicates that he has not made up his mind on what its role should be. Some advisers say the council should be run by an "honest broker" who would analyze proposals from Treasury, Labor, the Office of Management and Budget and other agencies and then impartially present policy options to the President.
Some advisers say Mr. Rubin of Goldman, Sachs would be well suited for this role. He does not have a policy ax to grind and has shown considerable managerial talent, and this might help him get this new council running smoothly.
Under another view, the council would not just coordinate policy, but would develop new ideas. The problem with this structure, aides say, is that other agencies might conclude that the council too often favors its own proposals over those from other agencies.
If Mr. Clinton decided that the council should be a hothouse of policy ideas, several advisers said, then Mr. Reich, a lecturer at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, would be best as the economic security adviser.
In an interview this weekend, Mr. Reich said Mr. Clinton had not totally written off the idea of a short-term stimulus plan.
 
 
'Bringing Jobs Back'
 "We'll be looking closely at every indicator between now and Inauguration Day which sheds light on whether jobs are really coming back," he said. "Bill Clinton is committed to bringing jobs back, and he'll do what's necessary to accomplish that."
Even if the economy continues to pick up, he said, Mr. Clinton would still probably embrace a plan to give tax credits to businesses when they buy new equipment -- a measure aimed at making American industry more competitive over the long term.
Mr. Reich voiced fears that many Americans would conclude that as the economy gathered steam, its long-term problems had gone away.
"If people say that the economy is recovering and thus there is no need for Clinton's economic plan, then they fail to understand what we're getting at when we talk about improving the quality of American jobs and earnings," he said.
Mr. Reich said that if any national leader was capable "of using the bully pulpit to maintain that focus on the long term, even when the economy is recovering, it's Bill Clinton."

HEADLINE: New Rules For Rating Insurers

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Insurance regulators from all 50 states approved a new standard yesterday for measuring the financial strength of life and health insurance companies.
The new yardstick, similar to the one used for commercial banks, is intended to make it easier for policyholders and investors to evaluate insurers. Regulators also hope it will help reduce the number of failures, which has been rising in recent years. Among those that have collapsed were the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark and the insurance units of the First Executive Corporation in Los Angeles. 
 "It means that insurance regulators will have another arrow in their quiver to use in protecting the solvency of the life and health insurance industry," William H. McCartney, Nebraska's Director of Insurance and president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, said after the vote at the group's annual winter meeting in Atlanta.
The model law, which sets thresholds for regulatory action, must be adopted by each state. Mr. McCartney said that the association had moved slowly so as not to make any grave mistake in drawing up regulatory mandates and that he expected all states to adopt the model.
The uniform formula contrasts sharply with the current system, in which each state has its own criteria for rating insurers and taking action against troubled ones.
Companies like A. M. Best & Company grade insurance companies, but the new system is the first tied to state enforcement.
Under the plan, called the life risk-based capital model law, insurance companies will be rated on how much capital they have to buttress the risk inherent in their investments and operations. A score of 100 percent or more will suggest an insurer is healthy because it has met or surpassed its risk-based capital requirement. Those that score below 100 will be subject automatically to action by regulators.
Companies scoring above 35 percent but under 50 percent could be seized by regulators, for example. Those scoring at least 50 percent but below 75 percent would be ordered to take specific action. Those with a rating of at least 75 percent but less than 100 would have to file a plan with state regulators to bolster their risk-based capital.
 
Many Executives Critical
 Many industry executives have criticized the new rule as potentially misleading to consumers. Others believe the standard may hamstring companies' competitiveness if they must sell high-risk assets, such as real estate, common stock or junk bonds, and shift increasingly to safer government bonds.
Insurance companies will have to post their ratings in their 1993 annual reports, which will be published in the spring of 1994, and in each annual report after that.
Life insurance companies have contended that the scores should be kept secret because some insurance agents may use them to criticize competitors, thereby misleading consumers.
 
Use in Ads Prohibited
 Regulators have added a provision banning the use of scores in sales or promotional materials.
The lines of argument against the grading system have been played out often in recent months. Richard H. Jenrette, chairman and chief executive of the Equitable Companies, said in October that insurance commissioners should have delayed their vote by six months "or pending some further sign of rejuvenation of the economy."
He argued that it was a mistake to enforce new capital adequacy requirements "in the face of what has become a worldwide recession and worldwide asset deflation." Mr. Jenrette was not available for comment yesterday.
Insurance industry regulators are researching a similar measure for the more complex property and casualty insurance industry. That is expected to take at least another year.

HEADLINE: Economic Growth Seen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: LONNDON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Economic growth in the world's seven leading industrial economies will accelerate to 2.8 percent in 1994, from 2.2 percent next year and 1.3 percent in 1992, the London Business School said in its latest International Economic Outlook. Growth last year was five-tenths of a percent. The school's Center for Economic Forecasting said the recovery in the Group of Seven nations is "slow by comparison with previous recoveries from recession." The forecasters see growth of 2.7 percent in the United States next year.

HEADLINE: If Only Barry Bonds Were Too Expensive

 BODY:
IF only a snag in the Barry Bonds deal with the as yet unapproved new owners of the Giants had developed earlier.
If only the Giants' new owners had done what the Yankees and the Red Sox did: spurned the sixth year in the contract sought by Bonds and Dennis Gilbert, the 28-year-old outfielder's agent. 
 If only none of the 28 teams wanted Bonds at what turned out to be the Giants new owners' price: $43.75 million for six years.
If only no team wanted him, sooner or later Gilbert would've said, "We've decided we'll take a five-year contract."
If only all 28 major league teams then decided that even for five years, Bonds was too expensive.
If only all 28 major league teams decided that for even four, three or two seasons, or for even one season, Bonds was too expensive.
If only that had happened, Bonds and Gilbert would have hollered "collusion."
If only that had happened, the 28 teams would have hollered: "It's not collusion. It's collateral. We can't afford to pay the money Bonds wants. He's just too expensive." So expensive he had priced himself out of the major league market. Priced himself out of baseball.
If only.
But there's always been one team that thinks it can afford the most expensive baseball player. In the beginning of the free-agent era, with George Steinbrenner offering millions, the Yankees were that team. Through the years, the Angels, the Dodgers, the Mets and the Padres paid the big bucks. Now the as yet unapproved new owners of the Giants are paying top dollar.
Yes, the same Giants who appeared on their way to St. Petersburg, Fla., until a San Francisco group was allowed to purchase the franchise from Bob Lurie for $100 million, $15 million less than the St. Petersburg buyers had offered.
By agreeing to Bonds's price, the new owners of the Giants obviously wanted to make a statement: that money will be no object in trying to create a pennant contender and trying to attract more than last season's attendance of 1,561,987 to Candlestick Park despite the usual chill and the wild winds that swirl on the backside of San Francisco Bay.
But the new owners not only jumped the gun in negotiating the Bonds deal but may have shot themselves in the foot with it.
If the other club owners don't think any player is worth $43.75 million for six seasons, they may disapprove the Giants' sale.
Suddenly in the middle of all this is the head of the Giants' new owners: Peter Magowan, the president of Safeway Inc.
If a loaf of bread suddenly costs more at a Safeway supermarket, inflation won't be blamed. Barry Bonds, the new Giants owners and Peter Magowan will be blamed. That's the flip side of their collaboration in negotiating to break baseball's contract record: an average of $7,291,667 a season for six seasons.
"I want to do the best job I can for my client," Gilbert has been saying recently. "The best should be paid the best."
Over the last few seasons, Barry Bonds has been baseball's best player. No argument. But he never shone in any of the last three National League championship series, each of which the Pirates lost. If his deal is eventually signed, his burden will be to lift the Giants not only to the N.L. West title, but to the pennant and to a tray of World Series rings.
If Bonds does that for the Giants, he'll be a bargain at $43.75 million. If he doesn't, he'll be hooted in his hometown.
Bonds grew up in San Carlos, Calif., not far from Candlestick Park, where his father, Bobby, was an All-Star Giants outfielder two decades ago. His father now would be the Giants' batting coach, as Barry had demanded. Maybe that's one reason Barry accepted the Giants' offer even though he knew that the Candlestick Park chill might reduce the numbers he put up in Three Rivers Stadium.
Going home, or staying home, has been the trend so far in this year's free-agent auction.
Doug Drabek, who has a home in Houston, and Greg Swindell, who grew up in Houston, signed four-year contracts with the Astros for $19.5 million and $17 million, respectively.
Kirby Puckett decided to remain in Minnesota even though it cost him a total of $5 million.
"Who's to say that you will be much happier elsewhere?" the Twins' center fielder said. "The grass isn't always greener on the other side. I'm happy to be a Minnesota Twin for the rest of my career."
Not that Puckett sold himself cheap. He got $30 million for five years. But the Red Sox and the Phillies reportedly offered him more.
"Breaking contract records," his agent, Ron Shapiro, said, "is not a goal in and of itself."
Puckett realized that he's happy with the life style he and his family have in Minneapolis, that he's happy playing for the Twins, that it wasn't worth another $1 million a year to risk being unhappy somewhere else. That's why he is who he is: one of the most likable and loyal players in baseball. One of the wisest, too.
If only there were more like Kirby Puckett. If only.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Thud! Economic Report Lands on Baseball's Desk

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 6

 BODY:
A long-awaited study committee report on baseball's economics recommends that players be eligible for free agency after three years instead of six, a move that would eliminate salary arbitration. The committee also recommends that clubs increase the amount of revenue they would share among themselves in order to protect financially weaker teams and that clubs and players enter into a partnership for the future financial benefit of the industry.
The report, which was supposed to have been completed by Sept. 1, 1991, was distributed to the clubs last week. A copy of it was obtained today by The New York Times from a member of management. 
 Donald Fehr, head of the Players Association, and Bud Selig, chairman of the Player Relations Committee's board of directors, declined to comment on the report.
 
Fehr Isn't Happy
 Fehr was angry when he learned that the report had become public. Selig agreed that "it wasn't supposed to be out for a while," adding he wanted the clubs and players to digest it before he says anything.
The report surfaced on the eve of a critical meeting Monday at which the owners will decide whether or not to reopen the collective bargaining agreement. They have until Friday to notify the Players Association whether they want to to reopen a year ahead of the contract's expiration.
The owners will enter the meeting sharply divided on the issue. Even owners who favor reopening acknowledge that the group is evenly divided.
Some owners oppose reopening because they don't want to put themselves in a position where, barring a new agreement, they would lock out the players next spring. Some of those owners also are among the opponents to reopening who don't want to adopt the increased revenue sharing that Richard Ravitch, their chief labor executive, has proposed.
 
A Compromise Plan
 A compromise plan was floated recently under which the labor contract would be reopened, but the owners would pledge not to lock out the players and the players would pledge not to strike. The plan, however, was rejected by the hard-line element of the owners who want to reopen, and the players never were formally asked to agree to it.
The proponents of reopening believe they have added ammunition in the flurry of free-agent signings the past week, especially the series of four-year contracts given to pitchers. Those owners argue that the contracts show how important it is to negotiate a new system now.
"We're not getting it done," one owner said.
But a reopener opponent countered, "They're saying we should save them from themselves."
 
Report Contains Audit
 The economic study report suggests ways of saving baseball from the potentially catastrophic events that owners generally predict but that players view with skepticism. The report was compiled by the four independent members of the committee: Henry Aaron (not the former Braves star) and David Feller, who were appointed by the players, and Peter Goldmark and Paul Volcker, who were named by the clubs.
The report includes an accounting audit of club financial figures for the 1991 season, the latest report that has been compiled. The audit shows that industrywide profits from baseball operations fell 31 percent, from $142,867,000 to $98,953,000. Since earning record profits in 1989 of $214,509,000, the 26 clubs have seen their profits drop 54 percent.
The report shows that from 1990 to 1991, operating revenues rose from $1,336,530,000 to $1,537,395,000 and operating expenses from $1,193,663,000 to $1,438,442,000. It says club projections indicate that the industry will suffer substantial losses in 1993 and 1994.
 
The Free-Agent Issue
 In probably the report's most interesting recommendation, the committee suggested that reducing the eligibility for free agency from six years to three could benefit both sides.
The change would eliminate salary arbitration, a procedure basically for players with three to six years of major league service. The clubs hate arbitration more than free agency because they cannot control the players' salaries when an aribtrator is involved. The change also could lead, the committee said, to an increased number of long-term guaranteed contracts by which clubs would retain promising players.
"We have not agreed," the report stated, "to recommend any changes in the rules governing player compensation other than the reduction in the service requirement for free agency from six to three years."
On the subject of revenue sharing among clubs, the report noted that such arrangements have not been updated "to reflect enormous recent changes in revenue sources."
As an example, the committee said, "The fixed nominal payment to visiting clubs in the National League represents a steadily declining share of steadily rising ticket prices. Such practices may have made sense a century ago. They are now inadequate to bridge current disparities in revenue among the clubs."
It is vital, the report said, to "fashion a mechanism that will support the financially weaker teams."
"A number of existing and potential revenue sources could be dedicated in whole or in part to an extended revenue sharing arrangement," the study added.

HEADLINE: The Senate's Ethical House of Cards

 BODY:
Acting expeditiously, the Senate Ethics Committee has started a preliminary inquiry into allegations of sexual harassment lodged against Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon. But the committee still owes a better response on another unpleasant matter: the strange case of Senator Phil Gramm's vacation home.
The home-building bargain afforded Mr. Gramm, a Texas Republican who is a leading member of the Senate Banking Committee, was disclosed last week by The Times's Jeff Gerth and Dean Baquet. Under a highly unusual arrangement -- there was no written estimate or contract -- Mr. Gramm paid a builder who also operated three troubled savings and loans only $63,433 of the $117,000 it cost to complete a two-story waterfront house in rural Maryland. 
 Mr. Gramm then gave the builder, Jerry Stiles, help -- "routine" according to the Senator -- as the builder defended himself against complaints by savings and loan regulators. The Senator advised Mr. Stiles privately and repeatedly passed his letters to regulators with cover notes urging that they listen to his requests.
Mr. Gramm says he received no special favors from the builder. But it's hard to imagine any ordinary citizen getting such a nifty deal. Why did Mr. Gramm hire a Texan who specialized in large subdivisions to put up a house in Maryland? Mr. Gramm's explanation -- that he wanted to stimulate the Texas economy -- seems odd at best.
So do other aspects of his account. He says, for example, he did not learn that Mr. Stiles had picked up nearly half the cost of his house until two years later, in late 1989, when he called a carpenter who worked on the house about another job.
Mr. Gramm says he immediately sent a check for the difference and asked for the Ethics Committee's advice. It's conceivable he was motivated to do so by the news, conveyed by the carpenter, that the F.B.I. was investigating.
In any case, Mr. Gramm didn't end up paying. Chairman Howell Heflin and vice chairman Warren Rudman of the Ethics Committee gave Mr. Gramm a letter declaring that Mr. Stiles's $53,567 contribution to the Senator's home was merely a contractual cost overrun, and not a "gift" under Senate rules. They relied only on affidavits from Mr. Gramm and Mr. Stiles, and skirted the committee's own public disclosure rules. Their letter may have discouraged further investigation by both the F.B.I. and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
The haste to give this suspicious-looking transaction a clean bill of health comes as no surprise, not after the committee's weak-kneed disposition of the contemporaneous Keating Five case. The committee has also responded lamely to ethics charges against Republican Senators Alfonse D'Amato of New York and Mark Hatfield of Oregon.
Indeed, the Ethics Committee has only itself to blame if the public smells a cover-up. The committee owes immediately a full accounting of its handling of the Gramm case. If that fails to clear the air, it needs to open an investigation into Mr. Gramm's peculiar home financing, or explain publicly why the scrutiny isn't warranted.

HEADLINE: Lloyd Bentsen: Insider at Treasury

 BODY:
By choosing Senator Lloyd Bentsen to be his Treasury Secretary, President-elect Bill Clinton would gain instant clout in Congress for his legislative package. Mr. Bentsen, who has run the Finance Committee with an iron first, won't need any road maps to guide him through the corridors of Capitol Hill.
Mr. Bentsen will also be well received on Wall Street and Main Street. The Texan has been a pragmatic legislator whose generally conservative views on tax and budget policies won't threaten business investors or foreign leaders. 
 He's shrewd. He's tenacious. He's statesmanlike. He's effective. That's a lot of positives.
But there's another, troubling side to Mr. Bentsen's record. Rather than the "new kind of Democrat" Mr. Clinton vowed to bring to power, he's the polished insider who has too easily sacrificed fiscal prudence for undeserving special interests. He's fought for loopholes for real estate investors, the oil and gas industry and other corporate interests. Worse, he's resorted to budget trickery to get his way.
Mr. Bentsen single-handedly got Congress to reinstate tax subsidies for retirement savings of wealthy families in the 1992 urban aid bill. The provision was carefully rigged to pay for itself for five years, as technically required by the budget law. But after five years, the provision would have opened up a gaping deficit.
Rather than serving the sublime purpose of raising savings, as Mr. Bentsen advertised, his provision would be little more than a windfall for the rich. It would have become law had President Bush not vetoed the bill for unrelated reasons. But what, taxpayers will want to ask, if there had been a Democrat in the White House?
That said, Mr. Bentsen's views do square with most of Bill Clinton's program. He would probably be comfortable raising investment in infrastructure, education and training, even if that meant only gradually reducing the deficit. And his yeoman efforts to beef up health programs for poor children fit nicely with Mr. Clinton's promise to bring affordable health care to every American.
More than most Presidential candidates, Mr. Clinton staked out firm positions on many economic issues. The role of his Cabinet, especially Treasury Secretary, will be to translate those positions into law. On that score, Mr. Bentsen should be a gem.

HEADLINE: Vacated Corporate Headquarters Scatter the Suburban Landscape

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 3

 BODY:
After more than 20 years as a magnet for large corporations, the lush suburban landscape of Fairfield County, Conn., has become home to hundreds of vacant executive offices that analysts say are among the worst white elephants of American business.
It was places like Stamford, Greenwich, Westport, Fairfield and Danbury that provided new and spacious homes for the first large wave of corporations that moved from Manhattan in the late 1960's and the 1970's, beginning a trend that permanently decentralized big business in the New York region. 
 But the takeovers, leveraged buyouts and reorganizations of the 1980's -- compounded by the recession -- have wiped out or drastically shrunk many of those companies, which can no longer use all the suburban space they created for themselves. And experts say that because of bad judgments in the design and location of the offices, many have been unable to attract new tenants.
The situation is hurting the companies themselves, the real-estate industry and the banks that have foreclosed on some of the properties. And the problem also weighs heavily on some Fairfield County towns, which were reluctant to accept large corporate complexes in the first place. Many exacted promises from the corporations not to subdivide the office space for new tenants, but now have been forced to negotiate new terms.
 
Not 'Jobs Machines'
 "It is bad luck for Fairfield that there was a lot of myopic decision making," said James Hughes, an urban planner at Rutgers University in New Jersey. "These companies were to be the great American jobs machines. We know differently now."
To be sure, Fairfield remains a vibrant center of business. The county is home to more than 25 major multinational corporations, giving it the nation's third-largest concentration of corporate offices, behind New York City and Chicago.
Nor have all the headquarters and large corporate divisions that left New York City for the suburbs proven disappointments. In this county, the Xerox Corporation, the GTE Corporation, the General Electric Company and others have flourished.
In Westchester County, Pepsico, Texaco and other major corporations settled into suburban settings, while New Jersey has attracted others from New York, including the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Merrill Lynch.
But the experts say Fairfield County's vacant and near-vacant headquarters buildings stand as monuments to corporate planning gone awry, and may provide object lessons for the region, where the competition for business remains fierce between states, counties and cities.
"One lesson we've learned is that if you create a unique suburban setting for one company, there is a great risk, at some point, that it will no longer want the space," said Al Remsen, executive vice president of William Pitt Commercial Real Estate, a brokerage in Stamford trying to find tenants for several corporate buildings.
Some analysts have criticized the relocations to Fairfield for more than a decade, saying they were prompted largely by a desire among senior executives to seek a more comfortable business setting than they had in Manhattan. Now, the most severe critics say, that the shortsighted desire for pleasant surroundings has proved emblematic of the companies' inability to cope with far larger problems in their global markets.
"They deserved what they got," said William H. Whyte, a New York City urban analyst who studied the relocations to Fairfield County extensively for his 1988 book, "City: Rediscovering the Center."
 
Closer to Home, Literally
 He looked at 31 relocations to Greenwich and Stamford from the late 1960's to 1976 and found that, in almost every case, the new suburban office was closer to the chairman's home. The average commuting distance for the chairmen was eight miles, Mr. Whyte said.
Other experts say the relocations were not the problem.
"There is no convincing evidence that these companies would have done any better if they had kept their headquarters in Manhattan," said Karen Gerard, a former New York City deputy mayor for finance under Edward I. Koch, and now executive vice president of Moran, Stahl & Boyer, a firm that advises corporations on relocation.
"But they didn't need crystal balls to know the world was becoming a more competitive place," Ms. Gerard added. "They should have planned for more flexibility."
The office vacancy rate in Fairfield County is 24.5 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial real-estate company; before the recession set in in 1988, the rate was below 15 percent.
 
A Corporate Orphan
 Cushman & Wakefield said only three other urban or suburban areas have higher office vacancies: West Palm Beach, Fla., Hartford, and northern New Jersey. But real-estate analysts said most vacancies in the other areas -- particularly in New Jersey -- were in multipurpose buildings suitable for many tenants, which are likely to have an easier time attracting new tenants than the specialized headquarters of Fairfield.
One of the orphans of corporate life in Fairfield is the former headquarters of the Singer Corporation. A maker of sewing machines and advanced aerospace products, Singer moved from Rockefeller Center in Manhattan to a new glass-and-steel building in Stamford in 1978.
But by the mid-1980's, Singer faced huge debts, had sold off its flagship sewing-machine business, and was shedding other operations. In 1988, it was acquired by Paul A. Bilzerian, a New York City investor, who sold most of its remaining assets and moved its headquarters to Tampa, Fla. In 1989 Mr. Bilzerian was convicted of violating Federal securities law and is in prison.
Now, the former Singer headquarters remains in downtown Stamford along with the home bases of GTE, Champion International Corporation and the General Reinsurance Company. Other tenants have taken 60 percent of the space formerly occupied by Singer, but the rest remains vacant. "At least it is in a downtown setting," Mr. Remsen said. "Other buildings are going to be harder to dispose of."
 
What Could Have Been
 Some of the most troubling prospects for Fairfield's towns and real-estate industry, as well as banks that have foreclosed on corporate buildings, are those that were carved into long-established residential enclaves, or on remote wooded acreage.
Several were built only after lengthy negotiations with town officials, and with firm assurances that they would never be subdivided or altered for other tenants.
One is the former headquarters of the American Can Company, built in the late 1960's on 150 acres of wooded acreage here. American Can moved from Manhattan in 1970. "It could have been a golf course, and what a magnificent thing that would have been," said James Sandy, Greenwich's director of planning.
 
Renegotiating Terms
 Less than five years after the move, the company began disposing of its manufacturing operations, shedding management employees and transforming itself into a financial services company with far stronger roots in Manhattan than Greenwich. In the early 1980's, American Can renamed itself the Primerica Corporation and left Greenwich.
In a five-year legal battle, Primerica tried to alter the original commitment by American Can to never subdivide its Greenwich building for other tenants. In 1990, Mr. Sandy said, Greenwich officials agreed to allow Primerica to seek several tenants, but not to exceed 1,700 workers in the building, the most employed by American Can in the 1970's.
Despite aggressive marketing efforts, the Greenwich complex remains without a single tenant.
In other cases, tenants have been found for Fairfield County's vacant corporate buildings, but not without heated negotiations between town and business officials. Perhaps the most innovative approach came in Stamford, where GTE abandoned a 10-story building before construction was complete in 1986.
The building was to have housed GTE's regional telephone company subsidiaries, but GTE decided to move the subsidiaries to Dallas instead.
The building was purchased for $45 million by the City of Stamford, which has made it its new City Hall and Government Center, consolidating dozens of city agencies that had been housed in several older buildings. Many citizens protested that the purchase was extravagant, but nearly all the space is now filled by city agencies and the Board of Education.
Real-estate executives in Fairfield say one of the county's most difficult blocks of corporate space to fill may be in the headquarters complex of the Union Carbide Corporation in Danbury, where the company developed 100 wooded acres in 1980.
Union Carbide's headquarters, a circular complex, was derided by architecture critics from the time of its completion. But Union Carbide soon had far more serious problems.
In 1984, the company was embroiled in the chemical disaster at its plant in Bhopal, India. It also faced financial problems in the United States and elsewhere, and it sold off several large divisions, including its automotive-products and household-goods businesses, by the end of the 1980's.
Union Carbide's building is now 30 percent vacant.
 
A Bitter Battle
 Another corporate void is in Westport, where the Stauffer Chemical Corporation developed 53 acres -- formerly a diary farm -- in 1970. It built an impeccably landscaped "corporate campus," with five buildings surrounding a broad lawn, but only after assuring Westport officials that the complex would never be used by more than one tenant.
The commitment proved a problem by the mid-1980's, when Stauffer was dismantled in a series of hostile takeovers and leveraged buyouts. By 1988, its Westport complex was vacant.
Like Greenwich and Primerica, Westport and Stauffer engaged in a bitter fight over the fate of the complex. In 1989, in an out-of-court settlement, the town agreed to allow as many as 20 tenants in the complex.
 
Looking Backward
 Although corporate tenants have now rented half the space in the complex, its layout and design are a handicap, and new entrances and lobbies are under construction to allow easier access by several tenants.
Westport officials now say they are ambivalent about the town's decision 20 years ago to accept any corporate headquarters.
"It seemed to fit at the time, it brought office space closer to a lot of commuters, and it preserved open space," said Kathy Barnard, the town's director of planning and zoning, adding that the Stauffer site might have been developed for a factory if not a corporate campus.
"But we know now that if they had built something suitable for multiple tenants, it would be a lot easier to manage," she said.

PUB-DATE: December 7, 1992

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 765 words

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
For the Real Potholes, See Moynihan

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
"ISN'T it about time we had a Senator" rivals George Wallace's "send them a message" as a campaign slogan that resoundingly struck a responsive chord. The time was 1970. The would-be Senator was James L. Buckley. The "we" were New Yorkers who for one reason or another felt disenfranchised.
Mr. Buckley, the Conservative Party candidate, won a three-way race. But a political power shortage that left New York State less franchised for nearly half a century has finally been rectified by Mr. Buckley's successor. This fall, after the death of Senator Quentin N. Burdick of North Dakota, Daniel Patrick Moynihan took over the Environment and Public Works Committee, becoming the first full-fledged Senate committee chairman from New York since Robert F. Wagner Sr. The father of the former Mayor of New York City and the grandfather of the former Board of Education president headed the Banking and Currency Committee until the Democrats lost control of the Senate in 1946. 
 If Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas joins the Clinton Administration as Treasury Secretary -- the announcement is expected this week -- Mr. Moynihan will automatically ascend to the chairmanship of the Finance Committee. Only three New Yorkers have headed the committee, the last, Daniel Dickinson, in 1849. By Senate standards, Mr. Moynihan's rise has been meteoric since he was first elected in 1976. When he got a seat on the Finance Committee after lobbying vigorously, he became the first New Yorker to serve on that panel, possibly the Senate's most powerful, since 1927.
In the House, where disparate New Yorkers have not been known as team players, Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, has risen to fourth rank on the Ways and Means Committee. Two other New Yorkers, the investment bankers Roger C. Altman and Robert E. Rubin, appear likely to be offered top economic posts by Mr. Clinton.
As the committee's second-ranking Democrat in seniority, Mr. Moynihan automatically inherited the chairmanship of Environment and Public Works in September when Mr. Burdick died. The committee's traditional credo has been "give a dam," the sort of government handout that may not ordinarily rank high on the agenda of urban coalitions.
But Mr. Moynihan has already derived more benefits for his home state from log rolling than from the pork barrel. He is credited with legislation to increase job-related mass transit subsidies and projects ranging from the belated repainting of the Hell Gate railroad bridge to the planned revival of the 42d Street trolley. Now, watch the groundswell develop for Mr. Moynihan's proposed magnetic-levitation express train from the Bronx to Buffalo.
"We have currency," Mr. Moynihan said. "Everybody needs something from Environment and Public Works. Either something they don't want in their state or something they have to have. Every senator who wants a dam has a committee from which we may want something." And everybody wants something from Finance.
Senator Jacob K. Javits headed the Republican Committee on Commitees. His successor, Alfonse M. D'Amato, has risen to ranking minority member on the banking committee. He headed a securities subcommittee, and, even as a member of the minority, has won a reputation for helping his constituents and contributors.
But in comparing the priorities of New York's two Senators, potholes versus policy is an oversimplification. Mr. Moynihan is known as the more cerebral Senator. He does not dispute that characterization. But he challenges two other perceptions: that he rarely delivers and that Mr. D'Amato always does.
Still, while Mr. Moynihan dutifully campaigned for the Democratic challenger, Attorney General Robert Abrams, he avoided dumping on Mr. D'Amato publicly. "It's the culture of the place," he said.
Mr. Moynihan's appreciation of the Senate's culture, coupled with its strict seniority system, his own sense of history and the inauguration of a Democrat as President, endows him with vast influence. But getting local officials to translate legislation into reality is another matter, even when money is appropriated.
"We can't even build a trolley across 42d Street," the Senator said. "We got money to scoop up PCB's from the Hudson, but 14 years went by because New York State can't find one-quarter acre to put them on. So we can't eat the bass that stopped the state from building Westway. We have not had the executive capacity to do something we decided was worth doing."
Few people doubt his capacity, or his potential, whether or not he always realizes it.

SECTION: Section D; Page 8; Column 4; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Diamandis Resurges in Cable Effort

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
In a long-expected comeback, Peter G. Diamandis, a dominant figure in the magazine industry until he was abruptly dismissed from Hachette Magazines in 1990, will resurface as a publisher of cable television guides.
TVSM Inc., publisher of The Cable Guide and Total TV, said that on Jan. 15 it would split into two companies. One of them, called TVSM, will continue to publish the monthly Cable Guide, which has a circulation of six million. A new company, Total TV Inc., will publish the weekly Total TV. Mr. Diamandis, 61 years old, will be chairman of both companies. 
 "If there is any industry that boomed during the recession, it's been the cable industry," said Mr. Diamandis, who spent 21 months negotiating the restructuring of TVSM. "Our goal is infinite. We expect to be a major force in the magazine business."
 
A Tricky Business
 Publishing cable guides is a tricky business. The average home now has 36 cable channels. But new technology involving fiber optics and digital compression raises the possibility that some systems may be able to provide 500 or more channels to cable subscribers by the end of the decade. Cable guide publishers have to figure out how -- and in what form -- a magazine will be able to print this much information.
To make matters worse, channel lineups vary from system to system. For instance, WLIW can be seen on Channel 21 on Cablevision on Long Island, on Channel 10 on Paragon Cable in parts of Manhattan, and on Channel 34 on Manhattan Cable in other parts of the borough. A cable publisher needs three different "system-specific" editions for cable subscribers to know what channel to turn to even though all live in the same area.
Cable television guides have encountered increasing competition from television supplements in Sunday newspapers, but the ever larger number of cable channels will make it more and more difficult for these supplements to remain viable. On the other hand, electronic on-screen television guides, which are now being developed, will eventually allow viewers to call up television schedules on their computers or television screens to find out what is on.
 
Precarious Finances
 TVSM was started in 1980 by a group of investors and the Chase Manhattan Bank, which originally lent the company some $60 million. The Cable Guide is sold to cable operators, which in turn distribute it to their subscribers, and the magazine makes a profit. But decisions to take it from digest size to a larger size three years ago and the introduction of a weekly magazine cost the company about $10 million and put it in a precarious financial position.
In February 1991, Chase Manhattan called in Mr. Diamandis as a consultant on how to solve the cable company's problems. He said he suggested bringing in cable system operators as minority partners.
TVSM, publisher of the monthly Cable Guide, decided to enter into distribution agreements with some cable systems operators: Time Warner Cable in Stamford, Conn.; Continental in Boston; Comcast in Philadelphia and Cox in Atlanta. Subsidiaries of these companies have been given equity in the company.
Chase has refinanced about $40 million at lower interest rates and remains a minority stockholder, a person close to the negotiations said.
Mr. Diamandis said TVSM had to split into two companies because some cable operators were interested only in the monthly magazine and others in the weekly.
Total TV Inc. will take over publishing of the weekly Total TV, which has a circulation of 225,000. It will merge with Total, a weekly cable guide published by the Atlantic Cable Television Publishing Corporation for the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, L.I. The merged magazine will have a total circulation of 425,000.
"Both properties will be in the black as of Jan. 15," Mr. Diamandis said. "We expect the weekly to grow to well over a million by 1994."
The dominant weekly in the industry is the mammoth TV Guide with its circulation of 15 million. It is the third largest magazine in the country after Modern Maturity and Reader's Digest, and it has many of the same advertisers as The Cable Guide.
"I just don't see this as having any real bearing on our business," said Joseph W. Cece, TV Guide's president and publisher, referring to the revamping of TVSM. "The Cable Guide has been out for years, and it has gone from 10 million to under 6 million. It doesn't really seem to affect my business.
"As for the weekly, the fact that a couple of competing cable guides are combining two money-losing magazines with a combined circulation of 400,000 just means that Cablevision gets out from under the burden of publishing a magazine on its own.
"And all I can tell you is that the publishing economics of publishing weekly system-specific versions of TV Guide is a very expensive proposition," Mr. Cece said. "Time Warner lost $50 million trying to publish TV Cable Week."
Richard Sperry, vice president for marketing of Comcast Corporation, a cable operator in the Philadelphia area that will obtain equity in TVSM, hailed the completion of the deal. "It frees TVSM to move ahead and to start marketing and promoting a weekly guide and competing on a more aggressive basis," he said.
Frank Smith, vice president and group director of the print services group of the ad agency Young & Rubicam, said that Mr. Diamandis "is certainly a man who has credibility in the print marketplace."
The magazine industry has been buzzing for a long time about what Mr. Diamandis might do next. In the 1970's he was the founding publisher of Conde Nast's highly successful Self. In the early 80's, he reversed the tide for Women's Day, then owned by CBS Inc. In 1983 he became president of the CBS magazine group and led a management group that paid CBS $650 million for 21 magazines. He sold off nine for $250 million and the rest to Hachette for another $712 million, reportedly making a profit of $312 million, which he shared with publishers, editors and even secretaries.
